









A
MALAY-ENGLISH
DICTIONARY.
(ROMANISED)
BY
R. J. WILKINSON, C.M.G.,
lately Governor of Sierra Leone; previously
of the Malayan Civil Service.
PART II-
(L-Z)
PRINTED BY
SALAYOPOULOS and KINDERLIS
ART - PRINTERS
MYTILENE
GREECE
1932




L
la. I. [Ar. la] Not; no. Only in Arabic
phrases. Exx.: la - bud (inevitable); la-haul
(•.there is no strength* save in Allah); la -
ilaha ila Allah (there is no God save Allah);
wa la - sliaiya baada -hu (and after Him
there is naught).
11. (Pen.) Now; Hu. La ni: id.; = (Kel.)
loh ini.
laal. Pers. Ruby.
laanat. Ar. Anathema; accursed, kutok, Perch.
Mai. 33. Of Satan; e. g. Iblis alaihi 1.
(Satan, may God’s curse rest upon him); Md.
Hanaf. 13, cf. Bost. Sal. i 65. Also as a
common term of abuse; si - 1. (that accursed
wretch), Ch. Jen. 102; kafir laanatan (God -
forsaken infidels), Sh. Rej. 3; etc.
laba. I. Laba - laba: spider; also labah -
labah, (Java) lawa - lawa, and (Ked.) lelaba.
Gen. for all spiders; varieties arc 1. - 1. bSrok
(•bird - spider®, gen. for Cytigradae);
J. - 1. lotong (large long - legged spider often
seen on ground - floor walls,La ter i grad ae);
cf. also harimau lalat (S all igra d a e).
Sarang 1. -1.: spider’s web. Bfisar 1. -1.:
«great at spider’s tricks®, ~ an artful rogue.
11. Much gain; good returns. Beroleh 1. -
1.: to do well out of anything; to prosper;
Sh. Rej. 4, 17, Tab. Mimpi 6. L. tertinggal,
Imrta lingknp: to get no gain and lose one’s
all; to lose both interest and capital.
labah. I. Melabah: to He upset; to worry.
11. See laba I (spider).
111. See lebali (bee).
labai. See lebai (levite),
labak. Ikan labak: a small fish (sp. unid.) that
is much pickled; HI.
labang. I. Melabang: (Ked.) to wander about
aimlessly; cf. melabang-lah puteri itu masok
hutan, keluar hntan; masok padang, kfiluar
padang (the princess wandered about, one
moment in the forest and the next in the
open); J. M. A. S. iv 111.
11. (Min.) To hammer out (metal); to beat
oat; Tn.
lIF. (T’k.) Hard of bearing; = p£kak.
IV. A berb, Curanga a mar a; W.
labat. See lebat (heavy, of rain).
labe. Buat pdlabean: (Batav.) making a show;
«eye - wash®; HI.
labenda. Eng. Ayer labenda: lavender - water.
labSrak, (Batav., from Hutch radbraken) To
thrash severely. Etym.: to break on the
wheel.
labSrang. [Lask. lab ran] Shrouds. Gawe 1.:
topmast shrouds. Sabur 1.: top - gallant
shrouds.
labi. Labi - labi; soft - shelled river - turtle,
Trionyx spp.; Ht. Pdk. 45, Pet. Ayam
90. Also (Ked.) lelabi. Siput 1. -1.: a large
shellfish, sp. unid., with bright markings on
a dark body.
labir. To chat; Sh. Cf. labim.
lablab. Ar. The lablab, Holichos lablab; =
kaehang kara.
Labnun. Ar. Jabal Labnun: the Lebanon.
laboh. I. Lowering by means of a cord. Of
dropping a curtain; letting down a net or
deep - sea fishing - line; casting anchor; also
(mblabohkan di-laut) to execute by drowning.
Labohan: roadstead. Bcrlaboh: to anchoi; to
lie at anchor; Mai. Annals G 2, Ht. Abd. 7.
MMabohkan baju Melayu: to «let down®
the Malay coat, i. e. to set the fashion of
wearing it long; Mai. Annals 171.
11. See leboh (road).
labok. See lebok (friable).
labu. L [Skr. ala bn] Gourd; gourd - shaped
watervessel. L. includes:
(i) the pumpkin, Cucurbita pepo(labu,
1. inanis, 1. peringgi);
(ii) the musk - melon, C. moschata (1.
inerah);
(iii) the bottle - gourd, Lagenaria


vulgaris (I. bfirlohcr, 1. jantong, 1. ko-
chong, 1. pandak: according to shape);
(iv) a wild gourd, Trichosanthes
cor data (1. aver hutan); and
(v) «calabash» water - vessels (1. ayer, 1. -
labu, lelabu). These last may be made of
coconut - shell (Min. 1. kerambil) or earthen-
ware (1. tnnah, 1. batu, kelalang, Sum.
bagan). Hid. Veth Ixxi 5,8, 9 and (1. keram-
bil) 4. But (he Peninsular 1. is often a far
handsomer vessel.
Mu’ 1.: nickname for pregnant woman.
Tampok 1.: the short stalk left on a gourd
to lift it; fig., clitoris, whence main tampok
1. = amor losbicus, = main abau.
11. Come up! A cry used by sorcerers to
get a crocodile to the surface. \V hence
buaya I. (a species of crocodile; sorcerer's
crocodile).
111. Siput labu: a shell, Mur ex haus-
te 11 um.
IV. Melabu; to blow oneself out.
labuchi. Spangles; = bintang temabur, kclip -
kblip, mutu, chemeki, jemeki, ch§rmin,
bedia.
labud. [Ar. 1 a - bud d a] Positive proof; certain.
L. pada akal: to be quite sure about; Ch.
Jen. 95, Ht. Pdk. 34.
See also labut.
labum. Ikan labum: a fish, sp. unid.
labun. Belabun: (Pk.) to chat; to gossip; to flirt;
to engage in amorous converse. Cf. labir.
labur. I. PMabur: working capital; supplies of
money and stores for an undertaking; see
also alat, bSkal. Tauke 1.: a Chinese who
finances an enterprise worked by others, e.
g. a mine, a gambier - plantation or a large
marine fish trap, Pelabur habis, Pelembang
la’ - alnh; <Palembang was still holding out
when the besiegers’ rations were exhausted*;
a proverb quoted against miscalculators. Cf.
also Hg. Tuah 58, Mai. Annals 59.
11. Besmearing. Of whitewashing (melabur
puteh = sup a puteh, sapu kapur); spread-
ing gum on card - board (Tan. Mangga 16);
daubing ink on an inscription to make the
lettering plainer (Ht. Abd. 168); colour -
washing; etc. Also (less correctly) labut.
HI. See 16bur.
labut. I. Ar. TV - bfirlabut or (Pk.) jais ta’ -
borlabut: making no impression; heard without
attention. Better labud, q. v.
If. = labor (to daub).
lachah. See Idchah (muddy).
lachak. I. Belaeliak, belaeliak yak, or melachak
yak: to be a drug in the market. Of a thing
obtainable in any quantity likely to be wanted.
Of. lochak, lewah.
11. (Pah.) To drag slightly (of an anchor).
Cf. larat, larut.
111. (Min.) Hard (of areca - nut); cf. ka-
chat.
IV. Bolt; door - fastening.
V. See iSchak, belaeliak.
lachar. Melachar: (Pen.) to be scratched or abra-
ded; = (Joh.) bergarut.
lacheil. (Min.) Slave; Tn.
lachi. [Dutch laadje] Drawer (in table or
chest of drawers); Si Jamin 12, 48, = (Baba)
toak. Also (Java) laji.
lachit. See lechit (to squeeze out).
lachuan. Silk crepe; Pant. Mai. 63, = lokehuan.
lachur. (Batav. from Bal.) Miscarried; gone
wrong; unlucky in one’s undertakings.
lachut. (Min.) To strike with a rattan; to switch;
Tn.
lada. I. Pepper; (sometimes) capsicum; «pepper-
corn» (i. e. candareen) as a measure of weight,
see saga Cf. chabai and pedas; Sund. pedes
= Mai. lada. L. covers:
(i) black pepper, Piper nigrum, =
Ked. lada, Joh. 1. hitam, Min. 1. padi;
(ii) P. lonchites (wild, climbing), = 1.
an tan;
(iii) P. cubeba, 1. bftrekur, (Batav.)
tomukus, kemukus, kemungkus, (Java)
kumukus, merieha buntut.
(iv) P. chaba, 1. China;
(v) P. caninum (wild)=l. bantu, 1. hu-
tan;
(vi) P. ribesioides (wild) = 1. rimba;
(vii) P. retrofractum = (Mai.) 1. pau-
jang, 1. sulah; (Java) chabe alas, chabe
sulali; (Min.) 1. sulah;
(viii) Guinea pepper, Capsicum annuum,


= Joh. 1. inerah, 1. chabai; Ked. chabai,
(Min.) 1. gfidang, (Java) chabe, lombok,
chabe gede;
(ix) chili or small capsicum, C. frutes-
cens; = chabai achong (Cl.), (Joh ) 1. bn-
rong, (Ked.) chabai rawit, (S. S.) 1. chili,
(Min.) 1. kctek, (Java) chabo setan, chabe
rawit, lombok rawit, lombok setan, godong
efiberang.
Unidentified: 1. changgai (long and smooth);
1. kapal (big non - peppery capsicum). Lada -
lada: a plant, Alsodeiaechinocarpa.
Kebun 1., ladang 1.: pepper plantation.
Solar 1.; to torture by inserting capsicum
into the vagina, a Pah. punishment. Sennit
1.: an ant, sp. unid.; see sennit. Buah I.
China: (Sp.) an edible sour fruit resembling
Piper chaba. Kuoh 1. mutia: small rolls
of flour and sugar suggesting pepper grains.
Bnrong t6rbang di - pipis 1.: «to pound
down peppers for (currying) a bird still on
the wing*; to count your chickens before
they are hatched; Prov., Mai. Annals 117.
Sunggoh kochil timbangan I. Pidir: «sraall
but precious as Sumatran pepper» = (Min.)
kctok - ketek 1. padi, cf. kfichil - kechil
anak harimau; Mai. Annals 14G.
Cf. sahang.
11. Tumbok lada: a small dagger; Perch.
Mai. 18, known also as tombak lada and
tombak lading, golok Eombau, (Min.) sewar,
(Ach.) renchong.
111. Bisul lada: crop of small bolls; =
bisul sabut, bisul solinap.
ladah. (Min.) Nervous mimicry, esp. by women;
cf. latah.
ladai. Ladaian: (N. S.) basket - trap for fish;=
(Ked., Pk.) bubu jantong, (Joh.) lukah.
ladak. A climbing shrub, Uvaria ridleyi;
W.
ladakong. Ikan ladakong: a fish, sp. unid.
ladam. I. (Pen. from Tam.) Horse - shoe; = b6si
kuda, (N. I.) s?patu kuda. Puknl 1.: to
shoe a horse, = pukul b6si.
11. = ladan.
ladan. [Hind, from Gk.] Minyak ladan: ladan on,
a resinous substance exuding from the bark
of certain trees. Used for caulking. Sctanggi
1.: a name for joss - sticks.
ladang. I. Unenclosed plantation on dry "round;
planted clearing. In contr. to an enclosed
plantation (kebun) or to a ricefield in a swamp
(sawah). Of gambier - estates (small = 1.
gambir; large = kSbun 1. gambir), pepper -
clearings (1. lada), etc.; but esp. of «dry
rice* (1. padi, = (Java) tanah tSgalan =
hnma). Cf. borladang ( bSrhuma), Mai.
Armais 18; peladang (peasant), Gul Bak.
132. Bakar 1.: to clear land by burning.
Padi 1.; (Ked., Pk.) hill rice, Oryza mon-
tan a, =padL huina. Tikav 1.: mat of coarse
matwork.
11. Black and tan (of a dog); see aujing.
lade’. (Min., slang) To eat; = makan.
ladeh. Curd; coagulated milk. Also dadch. Nyiur
1.: coconut of which the liquid has coagula-
ted into a viscous mass.
ladek. (Batav.) Still hard inside (of a tuber insuf-
ficiently cooked or a fruit not fully ripe);
Dl.
ladenin. (Batav.) To take notice; Dl.
lading. I. A long sharp single - edged cleaver of
the parang type; := parang 1.; see parang.
Hid. Veth xxvi 11, 12; xxviii 2; ci 0, 13.
Used for jungle - work.
11. Perahu lading; long narrow canoe of
a type used by the Orang Laut; Hg. Tuah
21, 21. Tombak 1.: see sewar.
111. Ikan lading - lading: a shad, Pellona
sp.
ladong. I. Stagnant; standing in drops. Of water
on a leaf or on the petals of a flower. Cf.
(on the failure of an enterprise through the
sudden death of its leader), Mai. Annals 81,
Clmupandan anak Bubanya
Pergi menyerang Melaka;
Ada chineliin borisi bunga,
Bunga beladong si - aver - niata;
Chaupandan the Prince of the Siamese
j Powers
Set out to assail our Malacca; and then,
When his hopes were as bright as a circlet
[of flowers,
Those flowers were bedewed with the
[tears of his men.


11. Batu ladong: plummet; sinker (on
fishing - line). Also 1. kail, batu ranggong,
batu tuntun. Kail berladong: weighted
deep - sea line, in contr, to drift - line (kail
ambur).
ladll. I. [Hind, laddu] Dumpling; ball of
food. Kueh 1.: dumpling of riceflour made
tasty with rasped coconut and cream.
11. (Java) Detritus left by an inundation;
lava after an eruption; B.
laduni. Ar. Inspired.
ladza, ladzi. Ar. Flaming Fire; Hellfire.
lafadz. Ar. Spoken word. Esp. of the knowledge
of the correct pronunciation of the Koran
passages (Eaj. Muda 3), in contr. to the
knowledge of their meaning (maana). L.
jalalah: the repetition of God’s Attributes
(in His Names) as a religious exercise. Satu
1. dua maana: «one word uttered and two
meant*; a double entente.
Also (coll.) lapal, lafal.
lafal. See lafadz.
laga. I. The fighting of animals that strike
each other violently after a charge. Of bulls,
buffaloes, rams, chevrotins, and even of
quails and fighting - fish. Cf. adu, juang,
pupoh and sabong. Naut., of a ship ram-
ming another ship; = langgar. Lagakan: to
strike two things together or set two animals
to fight in the way described; Ht. Sh., =
berlagakan (Sh. Mard.) or melagakan (Ht.
Koris). Ikan pelaga: lighting - fish»; Betta
sp, = loinpilai, seinpilai. Kambing berlaga:
«butting goats*; see kambing. Kerbau ber-
laga: fighting - buffalo. Puyoh berlaga: «the
fighting quails*, as the name for a double
star (in the tail of Scorpio).
11. (Batav.) To dupe; to cheat; to take
in; to play a practical joke.
111. A tree, Melanochyla tomentosa;
W.
lagah. See legoh (thud).
lagak. (Min.) Melagak: to talk big; to boast;
Tn.
lagam. I. (Sum.) Kayu lagam: a tree, Canarium
eupteron, yielding Copaiba balsam (minyak
1.). Cf. ladan.
Also (Min.) kayu kapur.
11. See lagliam
111. See 15gam I and 11.
lagan. A tree, Pimelandra wa 11 ich i i; W.
lagang. Molagang: (In matwork) to begin to plait.
The initial processes are lagangan; the bulk
of the work is anyain; the final weaving of
the selvage or border is legu.
lagham. [Pers. lagham; Hind. 1 agam] Bit (for
horse). L. bSrsainbong; snaffle. L. - nva
seperti orang Barbari: he used a bit of the
Moorish type; Abd. Mk. 87. Other types are
the Indian (1. lundi) and the Egyptian '(1.
masir). «Curb-chain» is properly rantai dagu.
lagi. I. More; yet more; still; = (Min.) I at.
Apa -1.; what else; what more than. Belum
1.: not yet. Berapa 1.: how many more.
Dan -1.: furthermore; «and what’s more».
Dua 1.: two mere. Sa -1.: so long as; while;
o. g. sa - 1. ada umur hamba (as long as I
live), Gul Bak. 15. Suatu 1.: there is one
point more. Tatkala 1. kechil: while still
young. L. teraug 1. bersuloh: «still light,
yet with a torch*; making assurance doubly
(or needlessly) sure; Prov.
11. From. A (coll.) variant of dari; q. v.,
Hn.
lagikan, = lagi - akan.
lagoll. See legoh (rumble).
lagonder. (N. 1., from Dutch d ra g o n d er) Dra-
goon; cavalryman.
lagu. Tune; (Pen., sometimes) style, way, =
macham, Hn. Bawa 1.: to sing a tune.
MSnurut 1.; keeping time (or step) with the
music. Fatah 1.: trill; modulation of the
voice in singing, Ht. Koris. Kitab pnji -
pujian dengan berlagu: hymn - book with
runes; Ht. Abd. 32G.
L. ni: (Pen.) in this way; so. L. tu: in
that manner. L. pemanggil: invocation song
to the spirits at a Shaman’s seance.
lagundi. See lenggundi (Vitex trifolia).
Lall. A proper name; short for Abdullah or
Dolnh, q. v.
lah. I- A suffix emphasizing the word after
it sometimes giving it the force of a
preterite (cf. Min. alah - Mai. telah), some-
times an imperative, sometimes a quasi -


demonstrative. In Min. it may begin a
sentence, e. g. lah lindang pills awak (my
money is all gone). It may be used also as
a sort of interjection, <-there you are»! Apa -
1.: to some extent; somewhat. Mari - lah:
hither = come here. Datang - lah ia: come
he did; he came. Dia-lah yang datang; he
it was who came. Sahaya - pun terlampau -
lah sayang kerosang itu: very greatly
indeed did I love those brooches.
11. Burong lah: ground - thrush; gen, for
Pittidae, = (Pk.) burong kubur, (Pat.)
burong pachat.
lahad. [Ar lahd; Hind. lah ad] Niche or cut-
ting in a Moslem grave for the reception of
the body itself. Also Rang 1. (Raj. Muda
58, Reich. Mai. 17), and (vulg.) lobarg ti-
kus. Poj ularly lahat; Pant. Mai. 103.
[Moslem custom ordains that the body
shall rest on the earth but not the earth on
the body. This object can be secured by the
use of a three sided bottomless coffin; or by
a narrow tiench along the bottom of the
grave, a plank being laid to cover the trench;
or by a niche along the side of the grave,
the niche being closed at (he side by a plank.
The niche is the Hang lahad].
lahak. (Min.) Stinking. Basok lahak: (Sel.) smell
that is foul.
lahan. I. Ar. Melody. Lidah - nya 1.; he had a
melodious voice; Bost. Sal. ii 88,
11. See perlahan (quietly).
lahang. (Java) Palm - sap; nira; q. v.
lahap. Pelahap; glutton; voracious eater. Cf. labor.
lahar. I. Ravening. Of extreme hunger; also
(fig.) of auger or lust. Api Nanirud yang
berlahar: the devouring flames of (the
fiery furnace at) Nineveh; Kamp. Boy.
1. Also (Sel.) lahau; melahau (to be ravenous).
11. (Ked., Kel.) Pool; mere; Perb. Java,
Kal. Dam. 72, = (literary) wilahar, cf. ben-
chab, (Ked.) redang, (Pk.) rawang, Cf. also
place - names such as Lahar Ikan Mati.
lahat. See lahad (grave - niche).
lahau. See lahar I.
lahia. (Min.) Ginger; = halia, (Java) jaho.
lahing. Melahing: (Min.) to slice into very thin
slices; cf. daong.
lahip. Weak; = (Ar.) dzaff.
lahir. Ar. Appearance; esoteric or visible; (coll.)
to be born. Hari 1.: birthday; Sid. Rama
101, 103, 181. L. di - Fnparua: born at
Saparua; Si Jamin 14. Dari 1. sampaikan
niati: from birth till death; Bur. Glat. 14.
Cf. also lit. Angg. 17, 75. For the other
meanings, see dzuhir.
lahu. I. Ikan lalm: a jewfith, Polynemus
sextarius. Also lau.
lai. I. Ikan lai - lai: (Pk.) a freshwater fish,
Cryptop terns spp., = lais - lais.
11. Ch. Guah lai: a pear.
111. = helai (leaf, sheet).
IV. (Min.) To be; -- (Mai.) ada. Esp. in
questions,
la’i. See lagi (still, more).
laichi. [Cantonese lai -chi] <.Lychoe», Nep h e-
-liuinli t c h i; Taw. Mai. 50. Also buah leng-
kong, kblangkeng, (Sum.) lingking.
laif. Weak; = (Ar.) dza'if.
laih. Laih atap: lath or spike worked into the
side of a piece of thatch rooting (see atap).
latk. See layak (proper, fitting).
lailah or lailat. Ar. Night. L. al - kadar: see ka-
dar. Alfa 1. wa 1.: the Thousand and One
Nights.
lain. Other; different. Lain - lainkan: to sort
(type), Ht. Abd. 110. Berlainan: differing
from; apart from. Melainkan: but; except.
L. daripada itu; other than that. Auak
orang 1., sahaya ini 1.: others are treated
in one way, I in another; Ht. Abd. 28.
lajang. I. (W. Sum.) To spring, e. g. of a tiger
or cat springing on its prey. Cf. Ibjang,
ktVang and rejang. Also of a hirse leaping
or springing.
11. Orang lajang: unmarried person
(bujang atau gadis), Kep. Mai. 43.
lajawardi. See lajuardi (lapis lazuli).
laji. See lachi (drawer).
laju. Swiftness; speed. Kapal terlalu 1.: a very
fast ship. L. lari - nya kijang itu: the deer
ran swiftly; Ind. Nata.
lajuardi. [Hind, lajwardi from Pers.] Lapis


lazuli; azure; blue enamel. Also lajawardi,
lazuardi, lazawardi, rajawardi and even
vajawali.
lajur. (Kel.) Strip; band; = jalur. Sa -1. tanah:
a strip of land; a «lot», such as a building -
lot.
lak. I. [Ch. lak: six] A suit of three Chinese
chicky - cards. These are differentiated by
various names, those in lak being; 1. pia or
(Cl.) 1. kSroh; 1. tiau or (Cl.) 1. tali; 1. ban
or (Cl.) 1. chantek.
Also gapet and kapit.
11. See laklak.
111. Batu lak: (Pk.) sealing wax; see
malau.
laka. Kayu laka: the Malay henna - plant,
Laws o n i a inermis; Raj. Haj i 183. L. -
1. jantan: Walsura mu 1 1 ij uga. Akar 1.:
a climber, Dalbergia parviflora, D.
stercoracea; W.
lakab. Ar. Descriptive name complimentary or
the reverse. Lakabkan: to give such a name
to any one, e. g. to a deposed ruler (Bost.
Sal. ii 120) or to a Sultan after his death;
see mangkat and niarhum.
lakak. Melakak: (Min.) to hit with anything
hard, e. g. with a stick. MMakak kuching
di - dapur: «to cudgel the kitchen - cat»; to
be a tyrant in one’s own household; Prov.,
Must. Adat 36.
lakan. [Dutch laken] Woollen cloth; Min.
Serai 15, Sid. Rama 8, 163.
lakang. See lokang (split).
lakap. See 16kap (cuddle up).
lakar. I. Unfinished boat (with outer planking
only).
11. See lekar (saucepan - stand).
lakas. (Min.) Quick; Must. Adat 11, lekas.
lakat. (Min.) To stick; to adhere; = lekat.
taken. (Java, from Dutch) Cloth; piece-goods.
See lakan.
laki. Husband. Less respectful than suarai. L,
bini: husband and wife; male and female;
married pair. Berlaki: to take a husband.
Berlakikan: to be married to (of a woman);
e. g. mSngapn maka tuanhamba berlakikan
tua bongkok ini: my lady, how comes it
that you are wedded to this crook - banked
old man; Ht. Mash. 12. Bakal 1.: future
husband; Simb. Ch. 13. Beli 1.: see beli.
L. ch&rmin muka, 1. perisai, 1. tangkal
inusaug; nicknames for a man married to
avoid scandal or to keep the wolf from the
door.
Laki - laki: male (usually more polite
than jautan); manly; masculine; = lelaki,
(Ked.) delaki, (.lava) lanang, jalu. Bukan
I. -1.; unmanly, cowardly (of stabbing a man
behind his back), Hg. Tuah 364. Monunjok-
kan 1. -1.: to show off one’s courage; Sri

Laksamana. Skr. Name of Rama’s half - brother
in the Ramayana. He drew the pentacle or
magic figure (baris L.) to protect Sita
against the assaults of Havana.
laksamana. [Skr.; , see previous word] A Malay
honorific title associated with the position of
Warden of the Coast and «King of the Sea*
(raja laut, Mai. Annals); cf. dato’ bendahara
memcrentah n6g6ri, 1. m6merontah laut
(the bendahara rules the land, the laksamana
rules the sea), J. I. A. i 150. The full title
(Pk.) is orang kaya - kaya laksamana raja
mahkota raja di-laut; he ruled the Perak
Estuary.
L. mengamok; name given to a fruit-salad;
membachang fruit cooked, chopped up,
and sweetened with sugar; cf. k6char.
[According to the Malay Annals (he asso-
ciation of the name with the office was
fortuitous. The young Hang Tuah was always
comparing himself to the hero Laksamana;
was nicknamed L.; and then was given the
name as a title. The title then went to his
successors with his office of Warden of the
Coast.]

lakuni. Wild vine, esp. V i t i s t r i f o 1 i a. Also
V. c i n n a in o m e a (1. laut); V. diffusa

The leaf of these vines (daun kepialu) is

lakun. «Drama®, = lakuan; see laku. Also lakon
and 161akon. L. is properly the acting or
illustrative narration (on stage, screen or
dancing floor) of any story, The Javanese
lelakon is usually shown as a shadow - play;
the <lakawn» of Southern Siam is acted,
wayang bun. It may also be danced; cf.
Mai. Dewa 25 (1. tari - nya) and Panj. Sg.
(gamboh lelakon). The stories so depicted
are all taken from old Indian mythology:
the Mahabharata (1. Pandawa Jaya); the
temptation of Arjuna (1. Rajuna fapa); the
marriage feast of Arjuna (1. Arjuna sasra-
bau, Tk. iv. 703); the Sang Samba (1. Samba
lalana, 1. Sang Samba, Tk. iv 703); etc.
Used loosely (Perch Mai. 37) ot any tales, e.
g. 1. jin (stories about genii, ghost-stories),
Perch. Mai. 37.

kup I.
11. (Min.) A wild mango; = lekup 11.
lakur. Fusing metals into an alloy. Esp. of an
alloy made up of various kinds of iron in the
superstitious belief that steel so derived is of
superlative merit. Cf. Hang Tuah’s kris of
«twenty makes of steel commingled* (dua
puloh pbrkara besi di - lakurkan), Hg. Tuah
40; now shown as the kbris Bali - Istambul
of the Perak regalia, which is reputed to
have belonged to Hang Tuah and to contain
iron from places as far apart as Bali and
Stamboul.

lam. I. Ar. A Malayo - Arabic letter translite-
rated as 1 and pronounced as 1 (with the tip
of the tongue and the lip). It has the value
30 in the abjad.
L. - alif: a combination (I a) regarded
sometimes as a distinct letter but not so
treated in the abjad. It is associated with
the la - ilaha ila Allah which has to be
repeated by a dying Moslem; and the vision
of it by a sick man is thought a portent of
death. So also a fortuitous marking suggesting
it (pamnr lam - alif) on a kris is thought
to cow an opponent. Ayer lam - alif (water
in which a copy of the la - ilaha has been
washed) is a prized charm.
L. jalalah: «the exalted letter lam», so
called because of its frequent occurrence in
the Creed.

(minyak 1.) that is a specific for wounds.

Seven years on the billows
Storm - tossed by the sea,
Dear heart, I shall never
Be faithless to thee.

lamina. Baju lamina: coat of scale - mail; Ht.

in front and behind. Differing also in the
fact that the scale - mail coat opens down
the back or front and is buckled; while the
usual chain - mail coat (baju rantai) is put
on over the head like a jersey.

lang. I. Bird of prey. Gen. for eagles, hawks,
ospreys, kites, falcons, kestrels, and even
for owls and some hawk-like cuckoos; but
esp. for the larger birds of prey (Aquilinae
and Pandionidae), the smaller being
sewah or sikap. Also hClang, Clang, (Min.)
alang; cf. (Jav.) ulong-ulong, (Sakai)
klak, k 1a n g, (Sund.) heulang. Varieties
are:
(i) sea - eagles and ospreys, (1. laut. 1.
siput, hamba siput); esp. Haliaetus
leucogaster. Specifically: H. leuco-
gaster (1. puteh; Java bahak); Polio-
aetus ichtyaetus (1. kepala puteh);
P. humi 1 i s (1. pekan); Pandion hal i -
a e t u s (1. .jala);
(ii) forest - eagles (1. rimba); including:
Ictinaetus malayensis (1. hitam);
Spilornis cheela (l.jambul); Spizaetus
limnaetus (1. bubun, 1. bumbun, I.kangar,
1. liindek); Haliastur intermedins
(1. merah, 1. reng, 1. tembikar); Elan us
hypoleucus (1. bueh); Pernistweed-
da I i i (1. borek, 1. burit).
The above are true lang (A quil i n a e
and Pandionidae). But 1. often covers:
(i) hawks (Accipitrinae) and falcons
(F alco n i n a e), properly (Mai.) sewah,
(Sum.) sikap, but often known as 1. sewah
or 1. sikap; these include: (a) the sparrow-
hawk (A cc i p i t e r virgatus) =l. sewah
pipit; (b) the goshawk (Astur trivir-
gatus) = 1. sewah burong; (c) the short-
toed hawk (Astur soloensi »)=l. sewah
tCkukur; (d) the falcons (Falco spp.) =l.
sewah vajawali; (e) the falconet (Micro-
hierax frin g i 11 ariu s) = 1. sewah bC-
lalang, (Java) alap-alap; and (f) the black-
winged kite, Elan us coeruleus, =l.
sewah tikus (Hn.); also (unid.) 1. sewah
padi;
(ii) owls, properly burong hantn and
having specific names of their own, but
described often as «night-hawks* (1. malam),
or «short - tailed hawks* (1. punggok);
(iii) smaller pied hornbills (1. ling), see
langling;
(iv) vampires (I. suir, 1. suyar), see
langsuyar;
(v) the black Indian cuckoo (Eudynamis
honorata), sometimes known as 1. t -
kukur.

langgai, I. [Ach. langay: plough] Plough-net.

Sum.) langai. Hid. Veth viii, xiii 3. A
small - meshed purse - net held open by two
rods and driven like a plough through mud;
the fine mud passes through and small
shrimps (My sis spp.) remain in the net.
Belat I.: purse-net attached to stakes in
a swiftly - flowing river. The bunt of the net
trails away with the current; small fish pass
between the converging lines of stakes into
the net where they are caught. Also arabai.

langit. Sky. Of the airy interspace between earth
and the Moslem heavens (shnrga, jannah).
Divided into seven strata (tujoh pfitala L)
made of various precious materials and
sevei'ally occupied by the seven heavenly
bodies (raja bintang); inhabited by celestial
beings (Bost. Sal. i 36); not to be confused
with the seven heavens or abodes of the
Blessed. Pintu 1., lawang 1. (gate of
heaven).
Langit - langit or Itdangit: «sky that is
no sky», i.e.:
(i) ceiling - cloth put up at weddings and
other great festivities;
(ii) c’oth canopy on posts over a grave
in honour of the dead (illd. Veth Ixxxvi 7);
(iii) palate or roof of the mouth (Peng.
Kuda 13), cf. tulang 1. -1, (palatal bone),
Pen. Premp 13;
(iv) a large four - sided net held open by
crosspieces and lowered or thrown on shallow
water to cover whatever fish may be there;
(v) a tree, Albizzia sp.; W.
Sangga -1; t-sky - support*, name for
Quainoclit pinnata; see sangga. Tun-
jok I.: king-post. Sa-b6rat 1. dfingan
burai: «as heavy as heaven and earth*, =
incalculably heavy; Ht. Angg. 129.
langkah. Step; first step; stepping over. Of
(i) actual steps or paces, e.g.; a man
dancing for two or three steps (nienari dua
tiga 1., Hg. Tuah 72); of a fencer stepping
briskly this way and that to test the
suppleness of his limbs (Hg. Tuah 356); of
a salute being fired when a General steps on
shore (Ht. Abd. 76);
(ii) the way one steps or w r alks, e.g. the
billowy «twelve-wave walk* (1. g6lonibang
dua bSlas, Raj. Muda 11), the «lonely-
orphan walk-> (1. anak yatim borjalan sa -
orang, Mai. Dem. 88), etc.;
(ii) the first step taken, e.g. 1. kanan (to
start off with the right foot—regarded as
lucky) or with the unlucky left foot (1. kiri);
(iv) the initial step with special reference
to its being taken at a propitious time; cf.:
balk 1. («bon voyages); salah 1., salah
nifdangkah (bad start, bad beginning);
inenanti 1. or mdnantikan 1. (to await the
propitious moment for starting), Ht. Angg.
53, Mus. Berj. 166; pahain di -1. (deeply
versed in divining lucky starts), Sh. Ul. 4;
di - langkahkan - nya sakalian pfirnhu - p£-

langkap. I. Division for betel - leaf in the tray of
a tepak or sireh - box. This tray has a row
of little compartments down one side to hold
the vessels (chembul) containing areca-nut,
gambier, lime, etc., chewed with the betel-
leaf. The rest of the tray is the langkap
and holds the leaf.
Also (Sel.) langkak.
11. A palm, Arenga obtnsifolia,
yielding a dark heavy wood from which
sheaths are made for weapons. Akarl.: Ti-
nomiscium petiolare.
111. A large fly, sp. unid.

langkara, = lengkara (possessed of magical power).

Also Rngkas.
11. Fiery (of a steed); spirited. Better
tangkas.
Langkasuka. A very ancient kingdom mentioned
in Chinese records of the Sixth Century as
being four centuries old; and existing till the
thirteenth Century. For some time it was a
vassal - State of Palembang. Probably in North
Malaya [where there is a River Langkasuka,
where the Kedah records speak of L. still
as an old Kedah capital, and where there
are traditions of a fairyland (alang-kah
suka) or kingdom of a Golden Age].
Langkat. A Sultanate on the Sumatran East Coast.
Best known for its oil - wells.
langkat. I. Three days hence, = tulat. The day
after the day after tomorrow.
11. Tikar langkat: mat of more than one
thickness. Also tikar b6rlangkat.
111. Chiak langkat: (Ked.) a finch, sp.
unid.
langkau. Omitting and then resuming. Of alternation
(N.S. = selang or lat); also of leaving a
blank when writing or skipping a paragraph
when reading. L. sa-bola: taking alternate
balls.

langsat. The «langsat*, a variety of Lansium
domesticnm; Mai. Pant 699, Ht. Koris,
Jay. Pati, Ht. Bngis 123, Ht. Abd. 170.
The langsat fruit is globular; the duku
(another variety of Lansium domesti-
cum) is more elliptical. Malaya recognize
sub - varieties: I. Ambon, 1. Minangkabau;
and of their own 1. they give the p'alm for
tastiness to that grown at Paleml ang (1. P -
lenrbang), Pel. Akal iii 23. Also (Java) lang-
sep. L. hutan: Erycibe aenea; Bkl., a
fruit suggesting a 1.
The colour of the 1. is a fawn or very
pale yellow and is a simile (Java) for an
admired complexion = puteh kuning (Ht.
Panj. 112), also kuning 1. (Sid. Rama 135).
But in the Peninsula it describes the pariah-
dog colour.

langsong. Forthwith; moving further on to; e. g.

langsuir. See langsnyar (vampire).
langsuyar. Yampire. An evil spirit: (i) of the
female sex; (ii) wdth long tapering claw - like
nails and (iii) long black tresses concealing a
hole in her back through which the viscera
may be seen; (iv) she has a shrill whinnying
cry and (v) preys on mother and child at
childbirth. Also langsuir; (Ach.) burong;
(Java) sundal belong.
L. is the identification of the ghost of a
woman who has died in childbirth (and is
therefore hostile to child - bearing) with the
fish-owl, Ketupa javanensis, a bird
of ill - omen.
[Cf. Mai. Magic 824 («the langsuyar
whose embodiment is supposed to be a kind
of night-owl»); Mai. Magic 32G («these
woman - vampires are fond of fish*). For the
whinnying (ngilai, tnongilai) see Mai. Magic.
824, 32G; «the Achehnese* i 380 (m eu- i -i);
and cf. the Encyclopedia of Netherlands
India s. v. nil, on the cry of Ketupa
javanensis (kStupok) «stem-geluid
dap op het gehinnik van een paard
gelijkt..]

lantai. Flooring. Etym., the thin strips of nibong

lantak. Bamming down; (N.S.) large piles in dam-
construction = balan. In polite language: of
ramrods (pelantak, 1. senapaug); and in the

to atoms) of the fate of villains who opposed
heroes of romance; Ind. Nata, Sh. Kub.

lantas. Proceeding forthwith to. Cf. langsong,

lantek. I. Installation; investiture. Of the ceremony
that confers a high office or dignity
(pangkat); cf. labal (coronation) and golar
(conferring an honorary title). Bidak di-1.:
crowned pawn. Bagai raja baharu di-1.:
«like some princeling newly invested*, i.e.
bursting with self- importance; Prov., Abd.
Mk. 37. Of the installation of a raja, raja
nmda, bSndahara and ffimenggong only
(Daik).
[lnvestitures are held in public with
considerable formality, the new Chief having
to make his way along the seri balai between
the lines of spectators with many bows and
prostrations till he reaches and does homage
to the Sultan. Offices are often confused
with the titles that usually accompany them;
but the two are distinct, and it is the office
that calls for the investiture (lantek). For
this reason (Pk.) comparatively minor digni-
taries — such as hereditary drum-beaters
are often installed with elaborate ceremonial.]

lantut (Batav.) Dawdling over work; cf. (Mai.)

Lanun. «Ilanun*. In its most limited sense, of the
Ilanun pirates; rather more generally, of all
Moro, Sulu and N. Borneo pirates. More
loosely still, L. describes all pirates who
worked on Ilanun lines, i.e. in large ships
(perahu L.) with heavy guns and crews of
100 to 150 men; in contr. to the Bugis who
did their raiding in fast small ships of light
armament (penjajap) and to the Orang
Laut who worked with boats. Cf. Sh. Peng.
13, lit. Abd. 325, and the description of the
Lanun pirate ship (Pel. Abd. 44, 46).
lanyah. I. Wearing (a thing) away by friction;
rubbing down.
11. (Min.) Mud; dirt; begrimed; Tn. Cf.
lanyau.
lanyak. Trampling down. Of buffaloes or elephants
turning up the soil with their tread; lit.
Abd. 50, Gem. Ht. 61.
Cf. penjan.
lanyap. See Ibnyap (to vanish).
lanyau. Mud of some consistency. Of mud that
can support a man even though he may sink


some way into it; cf. nmpatna lanyan di-
ayer, sa-barang tortadong mfinjadikan
daki: «like a muddy bottom, tread on it
and you’re defiled®; i.e. like pitch that you
cannot touch and remain c'ean; Prov. The
term covers: (i) caked soft mud above high -
water mark; (ii) mud much mixed with
vegetable tefuse; and (iii) any mud where a
boat can be careened or a man land. It does
not cover selut, the very fluid mud to
seaward of mangrove swamps; nor hard mud
into which the foot does not sink.

lapong. See lapun (net - snare).
lapor. (N. 1., from Dutch) Report; B.
lapun. Net - snare (for birds and small mammals;
ilid., Tijds. Aards. Gen., 1898, p. 657). On
the principle of a butterfly-net that comes
down suddenly on its victim. Var.: 1. dudok
(automatic, on a catch being released by the
prey passing the spot), or 1. tarek (worked
through a string pulled by a watcher at a
distance).
Also (Pulau Tujoh) lapong.
lapur. Belapur: (Min.) to strike a blow with the

larang. I. To forbid. Of prohibitions affecting a

turnt hati: Though the multitude forbid it,
Heart of Mine I follow' thee; Mai. Pant.
[Applied esp. to rules such as that which
prohibits the wearing of military uniform by
civilians; laws of universal application are
rather pantang. In many cases therefore
larangan is translatable as «resetved» or
• private* (forbidden to the public), e. g.;
balai larangan (pavilion reserved for ladies);
hutan larangan (forest game - reserve), Mas
Ed.; jambatan larangan (private landing-
stage), Ht. Angg. 8; kopiah larangan (a
style of cap that only privileged persons
may wear). Exemption from these elaborate
rules (moraakai tiada berlarang) was a
great mark of royal favour.]

larong. Coffin. Also bfdarong. Burong tumbok 1.;
«coffin - thumper*; a night-bird of ill-omen,
possibly a Scops- owl, whose note is likened
to blows on a coffin.
[A modern Malay larong is a three-sided
bottomless coffin built on the accepted prin-
ciple that the body itself must rest on the
ground but the earth must not rest on the
body. But the word itself goes back to a
time when the body was put into a sort of
ark and committed to the sea; cf. 1. itu tfir-
lalu bosar di - taroh - nya atap dan dinding
tgrlalu baik sepgrti sa-buah rumah (the
coffin was of great size with walls and roof
like a house), this «coffin» being borne by
the river and floated to the deep sea (di-
bawa-nya ka-tdngah laut makin jauh -
jauh); Tk. iii 672. Another passage speaks of
a body being placed on a raft (rakit) with
hangings and flowers and the dead man’s
kris, and then launched upon the sea (di -
hanyutkan - nya rakit itu ka - laut), Tk.
iii 673.]
laru. [Jav. laru, Sund. raru] Ingredient to

ruan (or laron): toddy so treated.

latah. I. Paroxysmal neurosis. A peculiar local
disease of which the symptoms are:
(i) the paroxysms are provoked by some
unexpected incident, startling but often quite
trivial;
(ii) the paroxysms are often mimetic and
seem due to suggestion;
(iii) the disease seems of sexual origin, is
found only among adults, and is accompanied
usually by obscene conduct or language
while the paroxysms last.
Exx.: 1. mulut (paroxysms limited to bad
language), Raj. Don. 4; pura - pnra 1. (sham-
ming latah), Bur. Nuri 23; 1. - lah s6p6rti
orang gila tiada khabarkan diri-nya
(she had a fit of 1. and behaved like a lunatic
not knowing what she was doing), Ht. Koris;
bonda Morah didalam 1. - nya, barang kata
orang semua di-turut-nya (Mother Morah
was having one of her fits of 1., all that
others said she was mimicking), Ht. Koris.
Used (fig.) for love - madness; e.g.: 1. wilan-
gan (unbalanced by love), Mas. Ed., Perb.
Jaya; hanya-lah tuan haraba latahkan
(with love I madden for thee alone), Lail.
Mejn. 33; 1. menyebut mas ttimpawan
(madly repeating, «Thou art my fair one*),
Panj. Sg.

A tale told against Min. Malays is that when
they see a fish, instead of trying to catch it
as best they can, they look at it and say,
Kalau ada kail ada 1. (had I a hook 1
should have fish for dinner). L. is used (fig.)
for a blockhead.]

Sebab pun tidak mahu bfirniaga,

Bahtera mas layar - nya sutera,
Hondak belayar, angin tiada:


Our poor attempt at trading fails;
He lacks the cash to pay;
His golden ship sets silken sails
To winds that die away.

ISbai I. [Telugu labbi] «Levite». Name of a
class of persons of Southern Indian ■ descent
and connected by family association with
religion, labbi being sometimes explained as
arabi. They are expected to be pillars of
the mosque and are invited to charitable and


religious' feasts; cf. Raj. Muda 2. Lag! 1.
lagi b6rjanggut: «he is a l§bai and he wears
a Ifibai’s beard», i. e. he looks the part of
a very holy man; Prov., cf. Ch. Jen. 24. But
in proverbs and folk - tales these levites [day
rather a sorry part.

11. Swivel - gun. L. majnun: name of a
swivel-gun in the Johor regalia; cf. bedil
kerajaan 1. majnun, Ht. Bugis 3G. This
gun was cast by a local coppersmith using
the model of one supplied by a Capt. Lucas
(seri lukus), it was named after the hero
and heroine of the Laila-Majnun romance:
and it gave its name to swivel-guns generally.
L. rambang: a hell - mouthed swivel-gun
scattering buckshot in all directions.
Kalau ta’ berlola
Baik bbrela - rela:
If grod guns you don’t possess,
Be profuse in saying, Yes;
i.e. the weak had better be subservient; Prov.
111. An honorific of rather indefinite
meaning both as a title (Maharaja Lela) and
as a term of endearment: 1. bangsawan
(fair and noble), Sg. Samb.; muda 1. (young
and charming), Gul Bak. 3G, 150. Ber-
maharaja 1. or meraja 1.: «to play the despot*.
Angkara maharaja 1.: gross contempt of
court.
[The Dato’ Maharaja Lela was master of
ceremonies at a Malay court and stood
with a drawn sword at his king’s side to
slay at once any one who was disrespectful
to the sovereign. He was thus the only man
in the State who could «slay without waiting
to ask permission*].

movements to avoid trees in the jungle (Ht.
Abd. 247); a ceremonial rocking of the
abdomen in pregnancy (1. pbrnt); a vagrant
«rolling up and down* (1. hulu 1. hilir);
walking with a marked roll (berjalan b6r-
ayun 1., Ind. Meng.) or with only a gentle
swagger (1. yang lemah lembut, Ind, Nata).
A mild swagger was cultivated even by
heroes of romance, the various «rolls» having
special names such as the •'spinach - sower*
(1. si-tabur bayam, Ht. Angg. 26), etc.
Tali 1.: mast-stay. See also lenggok, ch -
ledang.

Igngg a r3. I. Looking aftei; helping; protecting.


Mengapa demikian kelSnggara: why these
attentions? Tiada hamba kelenggarakan
pbkerjaan manusia lagi: «I won’t go helping
other people again*; i.e. in future I sha'l
mind my own business; Kal. Dam. 305. Cf.
also Mai. Annals 2GO, 2GI, 2G4.
[Politically mblonggarakau is «to protect*,
in the sense that Great Britain protects the
P.M.S. and attends to their affairs; it is
used also of the sway of the Judges (e.g.
Joshua and Samuel) who did not «rule» but
«looked after* the affairs of Israel; Bost.
Sal. i 101].

lenggoh. Melenggoh: to lie with one’s elbow

lenggok. Swaying the body; posturing. Of lateral
movements only; cf. liok, lemang, layah.
Such swaying movements had significance in
a dance, e.g. di-elakkan W. dfingan 1-
nya (she swayed her body out of W.’s way),
Panj. Sg. They formed part of the dancer’s
art along with arm - movements (tari) and
steps (tandak). But 1. is used also of body-
movements when speaking (bfirkata seraya
bfirlenggok), Ungg. Bers. 4; and of mere
wobbling or rocking, cf. lenggok - lenggang
bagai chupak lianyut (rocking about like
a floating coconut - cup), Prov.

L. niata: eye-socket; Peng. Kuda 9. Leng-
kongan bulan: crescent of moon. Belat 1.:
a moveable fish-screen a few feet high and
some 200 yards long with pointed stakes at
intervals for fixing it in the sea-bottom. The
screen is so disposed at high tide along
sandbanks and across the mouths of creeks
as to cut off all fish between it and the shore
so that they are left high and dry when the
tide recedes. Also bSlat telok, lorek. Pukat
1.: pocketless seine-net.

likas. Winder for new-made thread;=(Jav.)l ikas-

likeh, = lekeh (dirty).
likir. A herb, Amorphophallus prainii;
W., = lekok. Also other similar plants
(including Arisaema sp.) eaten by the

liku. I. Jav. Paduka liku: a title borne (in
the days of the Panji epos) by a junior
queen of a great Javanese ruler; etym., by
a wife of lower caste than the ruler. The
title occurs: Mas. Ed., Ht. Sh., Panj. Sg.,
Ht. Panj. 1. Higher titles are permaisuri,
paduka mahadewi, and (more modern)
paduka ratu; junior are niatur and mulangi.

Of. Also merlimau, lelimau and the unid.
1. chalong. A blood-orange is I. kesumba;
an orange-slice is I. sa-ulas. Limes are used
in washing, whence:
(i) berliniau, mandi bSrlimau (to rub
oneself down with split limes in ceremonial

Angg. 44.
Idiomatic: 1. karam (a bad lot); 1. nipis


(catamite); biji 1. (hard rice-grains; citrus-
pip as an art-motif); pntus 1. (to pay a
sorcerer by results); 1.-1. buaya or 1. purnt
buaya (round and rough knobs over a
crocodile’s eyes).
[The derivation of liman is doubtful.
Yule gives it as from the Arabic (1 irn a)
and Persian (1 im u, limuu) through
Portuguese. But the pomelo at least is in-
digenous to Indonesia and is known in Bengal
as Batavi nirabu (= liman Betawi);
it was taken from the East to the West
Indies by a Capt. Shaddock, whence one of
its names, Skeat suggests that the Persians,
Arabs and Indians owe the word to the
Malay limau. The objection is that the
Indonesian word for the pomelo is rather
jerok than limau; in Malaya it is an
imported fruit (1. Bali, 1. Bbtawi)].

Hmbai. Swaying the arm gracefully outwards,
esp. in dancing. A motion suggesting «go
away» or rejection; in contr. to lambai,
(beckoning). Melimbai or membuang I.; (of
a dancer) to hold aloof by gesture; to mimic
coyness or disdain. Membawa 1.: to sway
the arms (of a dancer); to carry oneself
gracefully but proudly, as a princess of
romance; Raj. Muda 105.
Also (Min.) lembai.

mati: «make no hole in the soil, break not
the stick you strike with, but kill the snake»,
= when you have a job to do, do it without
effort, damage or loss; Prov. Cf. lambang
and 16mbang.
The name Palembang is explained (Mai.
Annals 18) as Perlimbang or Paralimbang
(lowlands), Mahameru being the Highlands.

Varieties of leeches:
(i) the olive-green Hirudinariajava-
nica that attacks buffaloes (1. paya, I. por-
cha);
(ii) Chthonobdella sumatran a,
that swells out into the shape of a pear (1.
melong);
(iii) Hirudo vittata (1. padi);
(iv) a large leech described as hairy,
unid., = 1. gajah, 1. roman;
(v) varieties that live out of water (1.
gunong, 1. rlmba) = Scaptodella spp.?
(vi) the common springing - leech, Hae-
madipsa javanica (pachat, achat,
acheh).
Also halintah.
lintang. I. Position athwart or across; measure-
ment across, i.e. breadth or width. In contr.
to bujiir; cf.: bujur lalu, 1. patah (length-
ways you get through, crosswise you get
broken); fig., of a stick in a narrow stream
and implying that one should swim «with
the stream# and not athwart the current of
public opinion.
L. batang or 1. batangan: to lay a barrier
across a river to hold up traffic and make
it pay toll. L. bujur: diagonals; this way
and that, e.g. 1. bujur semut b6rlari (right
and left scattered the ants), Sri Ben. 4. L.
kodak: out of proper order; higgledy-
piggledy. L. payar: to lay a vessel across
stream to hold up boats for payment of tolls.
L. pukang: sprawling with the legs wide
apart (Ht. Pdk. 100); fig., topsy-turvy; «all
over the place# (Ht. Abd. 280); see also
pukang. Balai 1.: audience - hall at right
angles to the main palace - building (as used
by the Klana of Sungei Ujong). Palas 1.:
gangway or bridge across deck of Malay
ship. Sanggul 1.: hair dressed so as to
stand out on either side of the head; (Pk.)
bridal coiffure. Terambil 1.: .picked up
cross - ways*, of a child); snatched up anyhow
(Mai. Dem. 25, Ht. Angg. 43). Kasau
inelintang: crossbeams. Sumbang balai m -
lintaug: incest between near relatives, Ma-

luck; prevented by misfortune; Bur. Glat. 8.

«a hound that has crossed the trail of a
wild beast*, as a symbol of intense excite-
ment. Jadi melintang-lah pfirahu - p6rahu
Siak dengan kubu: the Siak ships lay
broadside on to the fort (and suffered heavily
from its fire), Ht. Bugis 100. Ada-lah
Kaabat Allah itu (panjang-nya) dua puloh

tiga hasta: God’s Caaba is 24 cubits in

The rapid movements of the cockroach make

Raffles was associated, Ht. Abd. 66); while
the flying cockroach (I. tbrbang) suggests
something almost impossible to capture; cf.
the pantun lines (Mai. Pant. 732),
Tuan laksana lipas tgrbang,
Sahaya di-bumi bila tdrchapai:
My love is like a Blatta
That whirls about on high;
How can I hope to win her?

lompang. Sea lumpang (cannon - muzzle).
lompat. Leaping; springing; e.g. of fish jumping
out of the water (Mai. Annals 67, 68) or

51). Also of jumping for joy (terlompat-
lompat, Gul Bak. 3G); and, more idiomatic-
ally, of undesirable people being so encouraged
as to «jump», i.e. get out of hand. Of. again:
1. sa-hari («jumping a day», i.e. every

longlang. Main longlang bnrong Jawa: a game
for children. Played by about a dozen, one
of whom is styled nenek and another ibu.
After some singing (beginning 1. burong
Jawa) the ibu gives permission to the nenek
to pull any child out of the chain that forms
up behind the ibu. Any child so pulled out
becomes nenek for the next round.

luchu, lucbun. Making fun of; to ridicule. Used
(Ht. Bugis 145) of an army taunted in a
very gross way to provoke it into attacking
a strong position (berperang seperti di-
luvium orang sahaja, di - beri orang burit
dan pantat - lah). The army in question was
too prudent to attack and did not enjoy this
type of facetiousness; so it returned home.
Also of superstition being luchu, a thing
to be laughed at; Kep. Mai. IG.

lugat, = lughat (word-book).
11l ghat. Ar. Exact text or literal translation;
precise meaning. Of a word - for - word
translation of the Koran, in contr. to: (i) a
free translation (maana) that makes the
meaning clearer at the expense of the exact
wording; or (ii) a translation and exposition
(niurad) which goes beyond the wording.
Cf. ini - lah 1. - nya (these are the precise
words; Kit. Muj. 53) of a formula, talisman
or charm. Ilmu 1.: philology, Kitab I.:
vocabulary; used of Marsden’s dictionary
(Ht. Abd. 6), but an explanatory dictionary
is more than lughat implies. Karans, the
usual word, is rather an «encyclopaedic
dictionary*.
lugu, I. Content; well - satisfied; having a good
conceit of oneself. Cf. the curious description
of what a soldier should be; lari ta’ - main,
berhambat ta’-l. (never too ashamed to run
away, never too self-satisfied to pursue), i.e.
getting the utmost advantage out of every
situation irrespective of what others may
say.

lulus. Slipping through,=(Pen.) chelus; coming
off. Of a thread getting through the eye of
a needle; a finger slipping into or out of a
ring (moluluskan chinchin, Ht. Panj. 122);
taking off a pair of trousers (luluskan chel-
ana, Ht. Panj. 104); cf. also: 1. benang 1.
kelindan (if cotton can go through so can
thread), Prov., and jalan-nya sa-1.-l. orang
sahaja (the path was just wide enough for
one person to pass at a time), Pel. Abd.
Whence secondary meanings:
(i) lulus = lain (to pass through); (Pen.)
sa-lulus=sa-lalu, sMaln (always);
(ii) to get a thing to go through, i.e. to
succeed; exx.: meluluskan perkara (to put
that business through), Ht. Abd. 314; luluskan
kehgndak (to carry out a person’s wishes,
cf. Pant. Mai. 43); 1. sepdrti sombah patek
ini (may it eventuate as I desire), Pg. Ptg.;
(iii) to slip through, i.e. to escape; cf.
Ifinyap dan 1. dari-dalam negeri (escaping
unobserved from the country); Ht. Panj. 38.
See also lolos, lorongkan.

ma’. I. Mother. Also mak and emak. More
familiar than ibu or bonda; used also to
aunts and old ladies treated as mothers by
informal adoption.
The terra includes:
(i) mother: (Mai.) ma’, ibu, bonda; (Java)
ma’, 6mbok; (Sum.) indu, indong, ma’
kaudong, ande, andeh, andai, inande,
mandeli, mandai, usai, amai, biai, dai, de;
(Batav.) nia’, mai;
(ii) step-mother (mu’ tiri);
(iii) adopting mother (mu’ angkat);
(iv) foster-mother (mu’ totok, ina’ kopek);
(v) mother-in - law (ina’ mcnUia, mfintua,
mertua; Pk. wan; Min. mfintua);
(vi) parents (mu’ bapa, ibu bapa’; Min.
ibu bapak);
(vii) aunt of any sort (mu’; Min. ande,
inande, de);
(viii) paternal aunt (ma’; Min. ande,
inande, de);
(ix) maternal aunt (ma’ muda, nia’ k -
chil, ma’ chi’; Sp. ma’ sudara; Pen. ma’
penakan; N.S. dansanak ibn; Min. inande
kete’);
(x) aunt by marriage (Pen. nianii);
(xi) eldest maternal aunt (ma’ tua, esp of
rajas; nia’ snlong, ma’ along, ma’ long;
N.S. kakak sanak ibn; Min. do tna);


(xii) youngest maternal aunt (ma’ su, ina’
chu, ma’ busu, ma’ bongsn; N. S. adek
sanak ibu; Min. nesn);
(xiii) intermediate maternal aunt (ma’
ngah, ma’ utoh; Min. do ngah);
(xiv) only maternal aunt (ma’ unggal,
ma’ tuuggal);
(xv) ladies in a quasi - maternal position,
e.g. duennas (ma’ inang);
(xvi) ladies described after their children,
e. g. ma’ Awang (A wang’s mother), see
awang;
(xvii) old ladies, «mammies»; e. g. ma’
mtindul (childless old thing); ma’ pek
(procuress); ma’ kopek (nickname for an old
hag); ma’ bnyong, ma’ labu (of pregnancy);
ma’ meleter (garrulous old crone); ma’ serbeh
(untidy old thing);
(xviii) a mode of address to «aunties» by
adoption;
(xix) «mother» in the abusive expression
puki ma’; (Batav.) puki mai.
Mil’ tua, ma' bongsu, etc. bear other
meanings in Minangkabau; ma’ or mak is
there a short form of mamak (uncle).

Ixxxiii.
maakul. Ar. Excogitated; deduced by the intellect.

who have a claim on the zakat.
ntaalim, =malim (learned, expert, ship’s mate).
maalum. Ar. Known; grasped; understood; Ht.
Pdk. 74, Hg. Tnah 101, Tuan-lah yang
16beh ni.: «j r ou, sir, will quite understand®,

saliabat beta: «I have to inform my friend®,
the conventional first words of a Malay

maalumat. Ar. Knowledge.
maainum. Ar. The people who stand behind the
Imam in’the mosque, i.e. the congregation;
Bay. Bud. It is the khatib who faces the
congregation.
maamur. Ar. Populous; prosperous. Of money being
plentiful (Ht. Abd. 151); of a town being
populous or frequented (Mai. Annals, Ht.
Abd. 31); etc. Bait al-in.: the Heavenly
Caaba to which the Heavenly Host address
their prayers; Bost. Sal. i 45, 46.
maana. Ar. Real meaning; sense. In various
interpretations:
(i) the real meaning behind a word or
parable or proverb or dark saying, in contr.
to the literal or superficial meaning (brti,
lughat), Kumb. Chumb. 3;
(ii) the intelligible translation of the Koran
(Ht. Bugis 123) in contr. to the literal word-
for-word translation (lughat) which owing to
differences in idiom does not explain properly
the meaning of the text;
(iii) the esoteric or mystical meaning of
religious doctrine in contr. to its exoteric or
superficial meaning (sifat), Mai. Annals 127;
(iv) the four key-meanings (m. empat)
of religious life or the path of the mystic
from formal religion (islam) to faith (inian),
self-devotion to God alone (tauhid) and the
divine enlightenment (marifat) that comes of
such devotion (Ungg. Bers. 8).
Cf. also, Tujoli shurga didalam badan,
itu-lah in. kaseh sayang: alive, yet in the
Seven Heavens; —so do I construe Love; Mai.


Pant. 187.
tnaanawi. Ar, Adj. of maana, q.v. Esoteric.
ntaanawiah. Ar. Spiritual or esoteric meaning
behind the illusive universe (Man. Pari 13),
i.e. the divine element in all things. To
realize it is to realize God.
maani. Ar Meaning; spiritual or esoteric signific-
ance; = maana, q.v.
maaruf, = maruf (known).
maashuk. Ar. Beloved. The loved one, in contr.
to the lover (ashik); Gul Bak. 105. Used
also as a mystic term with ref. to the divine
passion (ishk) that drives its votaries (ashik)
to seek union with God the Beloved (maa-
shuk).
maasiat, = ma’siat (enormity).

zulkan; to depose. Of dethroning a king

diri-nya), Mai. Annals 55. Cf. pechat.

mabau. Hantu si-mabau bunga: (Min.) an evil

mabok. Intoxication. Properly of anything that
«turns one’s head®: (i) of a person dazed by
talk or nagging (m. fahi tolinga); (ii) a girl
excited over her wedding - finery (m. bias);
of at the prospect of getting married (in.
andam); (iii) a man or woman madly in love
or mad with sexual passion (m. bfirahi, in.
chendawan, in. kosmaran); (iv) getting
sick at the sight or loss of blood (in. darah);
(v) sea-sickness (m. ombak); (vi) the effect
of unwholesome foods (makauan yang 1116-
mabokkan, Sh. Ibl. 1) such as datura,
Dioscorea spp., toadstools, etc.; and
(vii) the use of drugs such as opium (m.
mongisap chandu, Si Jamin 28). But if no
other cause is mentioned in. means «drunk»;
cf. bapa’ pcmabok emak pomadat (the
father a drunkard, the mother addicted to
opium), Si Jamin 13. Stages of drunkeness
are: in. khayal (excited or merry with
drink); m. fimpat tiang (gloriously drunk);
111. bunga raya (drunk and red in the face);
in. bunga selaseh (drunk and unable to
walk straight).

11. Fellow-wife; rival in a husband’s
affections. Also (Java) maru. Etym,, the
relationship between women married to the


same man. Of a woman sharing her husband
with three other wives (berinadu tiga orang),

madukara. A cloth-fabric of silk and gold woven

madzbah, Ar. Altar; place of sacrifice.
tnadzbuh. Ar. Offered up; sacrificed; slaughtered;
Lail. Mejn. 34 (of a man as an offering on
love's altar).
madzhab. Ar. School of jurisprudence; sect.
Usually of the rival doctrines of the four
great Jurists (Malik, Shafei, Hanifa and Ibn
Hanbal); cf. Shafei niadzhab-nya (he was
of the Shafeite persuasion), Bost. Sal. ii 121
But, etym., ni. means «way, course, manner
of acting, body of tenets*; it is used of a
Magian sect (Bost. Sal. i 13), of a schismatic
Moslem sect (Bost. Sal. i 31). and even of
the community of poets (Lail. Mejn. 6).
Balek in,: «to go back on one’s school of
law*, i.e. to accept the teaching of a rival
school on some particular point. The
Shafeite doctrine that Malays accept creates
difficulties on certain points and local jurists
evade those difficulties by accepting the
Hanifite interpretation of the law
in such cases only.
Also (coll.) niadahap, mejehap and (Batav.)
majohab.
madzi. Ar. Involuntary seminal flow (humor
tenuis qui propter lusum amato-
rium e pene virili effluit); considered
essential for fertility; Kit. Muj. 74, Man.
Pari 16. It is one of the three vitalizing
elements in the tnanikam, q.v.
Also (coll.) madi.
madzkur. See mazkur (written, recorded).
madzlutn. Ar. Wronged; = (Mal.) tfiraniaya. Enam
puloh laksa nianiisia di-bunoh-nya dengan
termadzlum: he slew 600,000 people wrong-
fully; i.e. he took 600,000 innocent lives;
Best. Sal. ii 97.
tnaedah. [Ar.; through Hind.] Table spread with
food; table in the sense that a man keeps a
good «table*. Cf. meja.
maentl. Mouse; Z.
maesan. Ar. Tombstone; see mesan, nesan.

25. Of evening prayer as a service (sembah-

(i) in the expresssions «Ruler of the East
and of the West* (raja mashrik dan in.),
i.e. Lord of the World; and «from the Bast


even unto the West* (dari mashrik datang
kapada m.), i.e. from one end of the world
to the other; and
(ii) of countries#, i.e. Europe,
cf. m. sakalian-nya ada kafir:
all Westerners (Europeans) are infidels; Bost.
Sal. i 79.
magil, = magel (half-ripe, hard).
Magindanau. Mindanao in the Philippines. Asso-
ciated in Malay history with the worst types
of pirates (orang M., orang Mangindanu,
orang malim danau, orang maling danu).
magon. See magun (fixed).
magrip. See maghrib (West).
magun. I Fixed; permanent. From Jav. pagon
:=pengukoh (Mai., kukoh, firm). Of fixed
awnings (kajang m.) in a Malay vessel; also
of built skylights (m. angin) or ventilating
windows (tingkap m.), in contr. to mere
apertures that are closed in bad weather.
Esp. of the steersman’s shelter or deckhouse;
Pel. Abd. 107. Also magon.
11, Magun - magun: herb, Coleus
earn osus; = bangun-bangun, see bangun.
M. jantan: herb, Adenosma caeruleum;
W.
Mah. A fern, proper name; short for Halimah,
Salmah, or Fatimah, Mai. Annals 168.
mah. (Ba tav. coll.) «Yes»; «certainly»; —as an
interjection, esp. at the end of a sentence-
Dulu mah lain: «formerly, I grant you, it
was otherwise®; Si Jamin 14.
maha. Skr. Very; most;—as a prefix, e.g.; maha-
mulia (most illustrious); maha-tinggi (all-
exalted). A courtly or literary intensive met with
in many expressions: (i) m.-baik (excellent), cf.
m.- chfilaka (terrible evil), Si Jamin 3; (ii)
m.- bosar (supreme, as a title given to God
or to a king or viceroy), Ht. Abd. 337, Cr.
Gr. 64, Bost Sal. i 37; (iii) m.-elok (most
lovely), Ht. Hamz.; (iv) m. - gempita (most
august); (v) m. - knasa (Almighty); (vi) m.-
lempah (ever - flowing, inexhaustible), Sg.
Kanch. 24; (vii) m.-luas (most spacious), Ind.
Jaya, Mai. Annals 39; (viii) m.-mulia (most
illustrious), applied only to royalty in Malaya,
see mulia; (ix) m.-murah (all-liberal), of God
or of a prince, Ht, Hamz.; (x) m-nyaring
(most piercing, of a sound), Isk. Dz.; (xi)
m.-paham (most knowing, most intelligent),
Ch. Jen. 3; (vii) m.-suchi (All-sinless, all-
pure), of God alone, Raj. Sul. 4; (xiii) m. -
tajam (of extreme sharpness), Ind. Jaya, Mai.
Dewa 31; (xiv) m.-tangkas (very quick in
its movements, as a lion); (xv) m. - tinggi
(exalted), esp, of the Holy Koran, Cr. Gr.
64, Host. Sal. i 5.
See also Mahabiru, Mahadewa, Maha-
dewi, niahajana, mahakota, mahamentfiri,
Mahameru, maharaja, maltarana, maharani,
maharishi, maharupa, Maheswara.
Mahabiru. See Mahameru (Mount Meru).
Mahadewa. [Skr. maha-dewa: Supreme God]
Siva as the Restorer of Life; the beneficent
Siva in contr. to Siva the Destroyer (Kala);
cf. also Siva as the Supreme Teacher (Guru).
As Mahadewa (or Maheswara) Siva
presides over one of the «five ominous
periods of times (kotika lima) making it a
lucky time; he figures also in temple-carvings
in Java as a God with either one or five
heads. If with five, one head is placed above
the other <four. Other attributes by W'hich
his image can be identified are: a skull, a
rosary, a yak- tail or whisk (chemara) and
a water-cruse (kendi).
Mahadewi. Skr. The «Great Goddess*, as a distinc-
tive epithet of Durga or Parbati, wife or
creative principle of Siva (Mahadewa). But
the name occurs usually in the form of an
honorific (paduka mahadewi) borne by queens
of the Panji period. This special title was
borne by the second queen, the senior being
pfirmaisuri, q.v. For lesser «queens» see
liku, matnr and langi.
mahajana. [Skr. maha -ja n a] Great man;
personage. Used only and rarely of distin-
gu’shed merchants when untitled men. Also
mahjana, majana.
mahakaitl. (Borneo) Main river, in contr. to
tributaries.
mahakota. A variant (by erroneous etymology) of
makota or mahkota (crown); see mahkota.
mahal. Hard to obtain, i.e. scarce or costly; cf.
m. di-beli sukar di-chari («dear to buy and
hard to win»), said of very precious things.
In Bazaar Malay m. = high - priced, dear,
costly. Etym., associated rather with scarcity:
m. orang yang tahu mtfnulis (men who


could write were few), Ht. Abd. 31; m.-nya
mendapat orang-orang Mblaka itu belayar
(rarely did you find a Malacca man willing
to travel), Ht. Abd. 4G.
mahaligai. Tam. Palace; princess’s bower. Also
maligai or malige; etym., maligai is more
correct, but the form mahaligai is almost
universal. In Java: the throne or cupola
of the throne; (N. S.) the single chamber
above the istana used by the tengku puan.
The name m. was given also to one of the
palaces occupied by the Sultan of Malacca
(Mai. Annals 114). Used loosely as a
synonym of istana (palace); but in many
passages and places specifically of the home
or chamber of a royal lady: m. puri (Mai.
Dewa 83); in. tnan putbri (Ht. Bangs. 3G);
cf. also a passage (Ht. Panj. 103) on the
setting up of a mahaligai as a residence for
two royal ladies; and (Bost. Sal. i 43) the
bowers of the houris of paradise.
maham. (Min.) To stuff food into the mouth; cf.
baham.
maham£nt£ri. Skr, Chief minister; Hg. Tuah
605. Literally a prime minister, but ranking
after the bendahara, temenggong, and (Pk.)
orang kaya besar. In Perak the «Mantri
of Larut» was tengku maliam6ntori.
Mahameru. Skr. The «great Meru* or Indian
Olympus; the Himalayan range generally and
(more specifically) the supremely beautiful
mountain - mass of Kailas at the source of
the Indus and Brahmaputra and near the
source of the Ganges. Regarded as the home
of the Gods; identified in Indonesia with
some of the loftier peaks such as Merapi
and Dempo in Sumatra and Sumeru in
Java (of which a summit still bears the
name Mahameru). Associated in Malay
history with the coming of the first kings
(Mai. Annals 18 to 20, 20). In literature and
modern speech M. is a symbol of gigantic
size; a man turning himself into a giant
(besar - nya sSperti gunong ind£ra M.,
Tk. iv 638); also of extreme elation (sepbrti
gunong M. besar hati - nya); a huge
quantity of gold (6mas sa-gunong M.), Tk.
iv 111. The forms Mahamiru (Ht. Angg.
43) and Mahabiru (Pg. Ptg.) also occur.
Mahamiru. See Mahameru.
maham. Ikan maham: (Sp.) a fish, sp. unid.
mahang, A plant-name; gen. for Macaranga
spp. Varieties: m. api or m. bayau (M.
javanica); in. bulan or m. serindit (M.
bnlletti i); m. puteh (M. hypo I e « c a);
in. tfikukur (M. triloba). Di - mana - kali
bertfiras kayn m.: <can a Macaranga
yield hard timber»? can you get figs from a
thistle; Prov. These trees contain tannin
which is used medicinally; Bkl.
mahap. See maaf (pardon).
mahar. [Ar. mah rj Settlement (by bridegroom)
on a Moslem bride; cf. (Mai.) mas kawin.
The amount of this settlement is stated
explicitly at the marriage - ceremony and is
paid or forfeited to the bride if she is after-
wards divorced without good cause. Cf. the
N. S. saying; orang nikah dengan m.-nya
(marriage implies a settlement); Mai. Say.
40.
Pulangkan in.: «to return the settle-
ments*; to restore payments and release a
bridegroom from obligations on his divorcing
his wife. This is done sometimes to avoid
scandal and secure an amicable divorce in
cases where a newly married man has good
reason to consider that he has been deceived
about his wife.
maharaja. Skr. «Very royal*, as an honorific in
titles, e.g.: bSndahara s6ri m., dato’ s6ri
in., tfmienggong sSri m., etc. Not now
properly in the Indian sense of a «maharajah»
or «great rajah»; this title was nevertheless
taken by the Maharajah (Abubakar) of
Johore before he became Sultan, and occurs
occasionally in literature, e. g.: m. Daha
(ruling prince of Daha), Ht. Panj. 58; m.
(title given to the queen of the
Mogul Akbar), Sid. Rama 182. Shortened
to maraja (Pant. Mai 435); meraja. The
old Shailendra kings of Sri Vijaya also bore
this title.
For in. lela see lela.
[Sultan Abubakar succeeded to the title
of Tbni6nggong with the honorifics S6ri
Maharaja. He changed or shortened this to
• Maharajah* probably because the latter
title was better understood by Europeans.
But an Indian «Maharajah» is always a
Hindoo].
maharam. (Min.) To squat; = meng6ram. See
also gajah maharam.


maharana. I. Skr. Great war, i.e. the Maha-
bharata War.
11. A variant (Cr. Or. 80) of maharaja,
q.v.
maharani. Skr. A title given in British India to
the wife of a Maharajah or Maharana.
Not really Malay; but the word occurs
occasionally in literature translated from
Indian romance, e.g. in the Isma Yatim;
also as a description of Queen Victoria (Jub.
Mai. 5); and as the title borne by the consort
of the Maharajah Abubakar of Johore, cf.
Bandar Maharani in Muar. Malay <queens»
are raja p6rdiiipuan, tengku puan, engku
puan, permaisuri; for Javanese «queens»
see ratu and permaisuri.
maharSsi or maharishi. Skr. Great Sage; supreme
«rishi»; Sri Rama, Bint. Timor 16.1.95. A
«rishi» was an inspired sage or prophet of
the old Hindu world, not a mere ascetic
but a writer or law-giver.
maharupa. Skr. Of supreme loveliness. A descript-
ion of Indra (Bur. Pungg. 207); but applied
sometimes to earthly beauty (Lail. Mejn. 50).
tnahatur. See matur (a queenly title).
tnahau. (Brun.) Tree, Nephelium malayense;
= (Mai.) mata kuching; M.
Mahbub. [Ar. = beloved] A proper name.
Mahdi. Ar. A proper name. See mahdi.
mahdi, [Ar. = guide; leader] Al - mahdi; the
divinely - appointed Leader or Messiah who
(according to Moslem belief) is to appear
before the Last Day and overthrow Anti-
christ (Dajal). Occasionally a proper name
in use among Moslems.
mahdzi. Ar. Pure; genuine. Wujud m.: true life,
i.e. the life of the mystic who lives in God.
mahesa. See mahisa (buffalo).
mahesan. A variant of mesan or nesan (tomb-
stone).
Maheswara. Skr. «Supreme Lord* as a name for
Siva; = Mahadewa, q. v. The name under
which Mahadewa presides over a period of
time in the ketika lima. Also Maisura.
Cf. permaisura.
mahfudz. Ar. Learnt, by heart. Mahfudzkan: to
commit to memory. Loh in.: the Tablet of
Fate; see loh.
Mahidin. A proper name; = Muhindin, q.v.
mailing. (Min.) Very foul, —of smell; Tn. Esp.
of the smell of a dead body.
mahir. I. Ar. Adept; expert; skilled. Of a man
who is a trained writer (in. menyurat), Ik.
Trub. 1; cf. also Anak-anak Minangkabau
torlalu in. dalam serba pSkfirjaan: the
natives of Minangkabau show great skill in
a number of industries; Al. Mai. 70.
11. Pers. The moon; KI.
mahisa. [Skr. mahisha] «Buffalo», but as a term
of honour and even as a title; the common
buffalo is korbau, (Min.) kabau, (Java)
kebo. Etym.: the pink or albino buffalo
which is much honoured in Bali and
whose flesh may not be eaten by high-
caste Balinese, a taboo surviving among the
Negri Sembilan Biduanda and the To’
Sandang tribe of Acheen. See also s. v.
Durga.
As a title the word (usually in the shorten-
ed form niisa) is prefixed to the names of
various heroes of Panji romance.
Also mahesa, mesa, niisa.
mahjana See mahajana (personage).
mahkamah. [Ar. and Hind.] Court of Law;
tribunal; Gul Bak. 157, Sh. Peng. 8, Gem.
Ht. 15. M. jenayat: (Trengg.) criminal
court. M. khas: (Trengg.) special court. M.
nial: (Trengg.) civil court.
mallkota. Skr. Crown; (fig.) royal. Also makota,
inahakota and (Min.) inangkota. In four
senses:
(i) the crown: m. enam pangkat (six-
tiered tiara), Mai. Dem. 106; m. s§gala
raja-raja: «diadem of kings* as a translation
of taj al-salatiu; merchu m., tajok m. (apex
of crown);
11. the ruler or crowned head: m. alam
(lord of the world), Bost. Sal. i 126; ampun
tuanku m. nfigeri (forgive me, Sire, thou
Ruler of the Land), Pr. Ach. B;
(iii) «crown» in the sense of «crown» -
prince: putera m., Sid. Rama 4; (Sel.) raja
m.; (Johore) tengku in., but these are
translations of the European term;
(iv) «royal», as an honorific, e.g. in the


title of the laksamana’s heir (dato’ raja m.)
in Perak. Also fig., in the language of
lovers: Tuan sa - orang m. hati, Hidup
mati kita bersama (thou art the crown
upon my heart; we live and die together),
Mai. Pant. 4GI.
B6latok m.: the «crowned» or crested
woodpecker; Thriponax javensis.
[Strictly speaking, Malay Sultans had no
crowns. The Malay idea of a crown was a
tiered headdress like the Papal tiara; one is
illustrated on the old Perak official buttons.
It is probably of Persian origin though it
bears some resemblance to Indo - Chinese
headdresses. The absence of a diadem is
explained by tradition in a legend that the
crown of Alexander which was brought by
Sang Sapurba to Sumatra was afterwards
lost in the sea. The Peninsular account
makes Telok Blanga the scene of the loss
(Mai. Annals 82); the Sumatran account
says that divers found the crown but could
not drive away a serpent (ular bidai) that
had coiled round it. They therefore had a
copy made, the maugkota sanggohani,
reputed to be in the Minangkabau regalia;
after which they slew the luckless jeweller
who copied it so as to prevent his making
other duplicates (Must. Adat 30, 31).]
mahlabi. A kind of cake; Dl.
mahmah, Ikan mahmah: (Pk.) a fish, sp. unid.;
cf. memak.
Mahmud. [Ar. ma h m ud; = belauded] A well-
known proper name. Often pronounced Mah-
mut and shortened to Mod or Mut.
Mahmut. See Mahmud.
mahong, = mahung or maung (mawkish, mouldy).
mahshar. Ar. Padang mahshar: «Plain of As-
sembly#; the place where all the Dead shall
come together to be judged on the Last
Day (yaum al-kiamat) or «Day of As-
sembly# (yaum al-m.).
mahsul. Ar. Produce. Hasil mahsul: the products
or exports of a country; Al. Mai. 4G.
mahtab. [Pers. mah-tab] «Radiance of the
Moon#. In the name Mahtab al - bahri
(Moonbeam on the Waters) of the sea -
princess whom Raja Suran married; Mai.
Annals 15, Properly «Roxana of the Sea»,
Roxana meaning «dight, splendour# (Zend
raohshna) and Alexander being the person
really credited with the descent to the king-
doms under the Sea.
mahtl. I. Wish; will; intention; (in Bazaar Malay)
a word used as an auxiliary to form the
future tense, e.g. sahaya mahu pergi (saya
man pegi)=l shall go. For the future in
literary Malay cf. hendak, akan, (Min.) ka.
Mahu ta’-mahu: willy nilly. Membunoh
kfunahuan hati; to kill the craving (for
opium); Dar. Chandu G. Hidup Regan mati
ta’-m.: «making no effort to live yet unwilling
to die#; said of a man lingering on very ill;
Must. Adat 30. See also emboli; (Min.) amoh;
(Batav.) amboh; (Sum.) bau.
11. Tahu-mahu: (Kel.) knowledge of any
sort; see tahu.
mahubi. A tree, Trigoniastrum hypo-
leu e u m; W.
mahung, niaung (mawkish in taste).
Mai. A proper name; Mai. Annals 204, 205.
Short for Maidin (M u h i - a 1- d i n).
mai. I. Corner or angle in a fish-trident; the
point where the outer prongs begin to curve
inward. Cf. inal I.
11. A title given (Pk.) to the direct
descendants of a marriage between a raja and
a sharifah; Wt.
111. Batang mai; State - treasury. A

maidah, = maedah (table).

Maidin. A proper name;=(Ar.) Muhiudin.
Mail. A proper name. Short for Ismail, q.v.
mail. I. Peti mail: powder-box with mirror in
lid for use when touching up the eyes.
Properly mail (Pers. and Hind.) is the little
steel bodkin with which the touching up is
done; in Malaya it is understood as the powder
itself.
11. Eng. Mile (as a measure of length);


Ht. A lid. 144, Abd. Jud. 11. Cf. batu
(milestone); pal.
111. A (closed and soldered) case in which
charms are kept to be worn on the body; K).,
Dl.
maimun. Ar. Lucky; fortunate. In the expression
Hikayat Khoja Maimun (tale of the lucky
merchant), a name given sometimes to Malay
versions of Indian parrot tales (Hind, tota
ka h a n i, Pers. t u t i n a m e h); also known
as Hikayat Bayan Bndiman.
Maimunah. [Ar.; fem. of maimun] A fern, proper
name. Usually shortened to Mnnah, Nah.
main. Play; pastime; diversion. In a wide sense
covering all forms of amusement from outdoor
games to illicit pleasures; also of sword-play
or finger-play or playing with anything even
when not done for sport. Cf. bcrraain daya
(to trick); in. panchalima (jugglery); bermain
tangan (gesticulation to illustrate or em-
phasize one’s meaning or for speech with a
deaf and dumb man), Ht. Abd. 2G,=m6m-
pormain-mainkan tangan, Sid. Rama 69.
The term covers:
(i) children mud-larking (m. tanah); or
playing in the sun (m. panas); or playing
with tops (m. gasing); or kites (m. wan, in.
layang-layang); or marbles (in. gulf, m. jaka,
m. buah keras, m. buah gandu, m. ukek);
or shuttlecocks (m. bulu ayam); or rounders
(in. awai); or quoits (in. gayau, in. porok);
or coins (m. tuju lobang); or shells (m.
seremban); or knuckle-bones (m. sMehinan);
or turning somersaults (m. senonggang
balek);
(ii) children playing specific games such
as leap-frog (m. lompat katak), or blind-man’s
buff (m. to’chan, m. china buta, in. los, in.
babi buta), or the many forms of hide-and-
seek (m. chekup-chfikup puyoh, in. hantu
rnsa, m. ibu anak, m. sembnnyi, m. sorok-
sorok, m. tutup ibu), or any peculiarly
Malay game (berapi, bdrbidas, beronyeh,
champak bunga, gap-gap udang, kfitip
semut, hantu musang, kachau kueh, kam-
bing, kul, kuching, longlang burong Jawa,
patpat siku rembat, pong-pong along,
rangkai periok, sapu ringin, s£n6bang-
s6nobu, tikam s6ladang, totoi, tul, tunggul,
ukas, ukck);
(iii) sports such as: football (m. futbol);
regattas (m. jinawari); boxing (m. kuntau,
in. mclela); medieval tournaments (m. tombak
di-atas kuda, Hg. Tuah 117); Malay football
(in. sepak raga); etc.;
(iv) indoor games such as: cat’s cradle
(m. tali); billiards (m. biliad); chess (m.
chatur, in. gajah-gajahan); draughts (in. dam);
fox-and - geese (in. riniau kambing), back-
gammon (m. dabal, in. tabal), dominoes
(in. datnnali), go-bang (in. chuki), cowries
on a boat - shaped board (in. chongkak,
dakon);
(v) games of chance (in. judi) such as:
heads or tails (m. chbmpelek, ni. kechek,
in. lerap, in. lambong, ni. sainpak, m. telaga
tari); games of the fan - tan type (m. poll);
card-games whether with Chinese cards (ni.
cheki, in. tan, m. yu, in. chuchut, ni.
chochot), or with European cards (in. chabnt,
ni. pakau, in. sekopong, ni. temp, ni. tiga
lai, in. turut;
(vi) dances and plays (see bandan, bddaya,
dabus, dzikir, gamboh, hadzrali, holi, joget,
jogi, lakun, ma’yong, niekmulong, men-
dora, mendu, pblandok, penchak, ronggeng,
sedati, serimpi, silat, topeng, wayang);
(vii) sexual pleasures, whether: flirtation
(in. niata); love-making (in. innda); intrigues
(in. burok, in. gila); unnatural offences (in.
adek angkat, in. berjantan, in. burit, m.
liman nipis, in. pautat, in. inaugkok, in.
semburit, in. punggong); amor lesbicus
(in. abau, in. tampok labn); and
(viii) playing on musical instruments;
conjuring (in. snlap, in. smiglap, in. silap
niata); etc.
main!. (Pen.) Wife of elder brother; = kakak

malt. See mayat (corpse).

(i) in. keling; the imported (dried and
pipless) fruit of T. arbore a; used medicin-

kSling;

of T. bal erica; used for dyeing and

lawe, majalawe;
(iii) in. sukun: the fresh fruit of T.
ba 1 er i c a; = (Ked.) inanja sukun.
Cf. According to Bkl. m.-kfiling
is the half-ripe fruit of T. cheb u 1 a; T.
arborea is a local substitute for T. che-

11. Buah maja: gallnuts or candle - nuts
imported from British India; cf. majakani,
bnah kemiri, buah koras. Used in medicine;
also (in burnt form) for making a black
pigment for tooth - staining or as a colly-
rium.

tanica), used medicinally. Rich in tannin.
