majamujtl. A variant (through erroneous etymo-
logy) of joinuju (caraway seed). See maja.
majana. Skr. «Personage»; = mahajana, q. v.
Used to translate shaikh on a tomb of 1467
A. D.
majapada. See manjapada (the earth).
Majapahit. Name (see majapabit) of the most
famous and powerful of the Hindu-Javanese
states. Founded. A. D. 1294; overthrown
after A. D. 1400. Ruled by a betara
through a prime minister known as pateh
gajah mada; the most famous rulers are
remembered as Hayam Wuruk and Bera-
wijaya. Its fall is associated with the story
of the lost Pleiad,
Bintang tujoh (inggal enam,
Jatoh sa-biji di - Majapahit:
«of the Seven Stars but six remain; a Star
is fallen in Majapahit*.
Kbris M.: name given to prehistoric and
sacrosanct krisses of which the (anthropo-
morphic) handle and blade are hammered out
of the same piece of iron. The blade may
be either straight or sinuous. Unserviceable
as weapons and probably associated originally
with some superstitious belief they are still
regarded as talismanic. One is said to have
been found buried under the foundations of
Borobodur. Also (Java) keris Pajajaran.
majapahit. (Java) The small tree Aegle mar-
m e 1 os, (Mai.) bilak, (Pen.) bel. Yielding
a good wood of which hilts for weapons are
made; the fruit is used as a remedy for
dysentery.
majar. See majal (blunt).
majasukun. See ninja I.
majEhab. See madzhab (school of law).
majSmok. [Ar. maj mu’: gathered together]
Minyak majeniok: a scented oil, the maj mu’
i-itr of India, so called because it is a
compound of various perfumes.
majEr. See majir (barren, sterile).
Majid. A proper name; see majid.
tnajid. Ar. Al-majid: the Great in Dignity;
God. Abdul m.: «servant of the Great in
Dignity*; a Moslem proper name often
shortened to Dumajit, Majid, Majit and
It.
majikan. (Batav.) Master; administrator; Z. From
Sund. pamajikan; Tk.
majir. (Batav., from Jav.) Sterile; unable to
produce offspring; = mandul. Of human


beings and anima's. Also maj6r; B.
majistret. Eng. Magistrate (Ht. Abd. 225, 214).
Also tuan m., tuan polls, in contr. to tuan
hakim (judge).
Majit. Ar. A proper name; short for Abdul -
majid. See majid.
ma’jizat. See mo’jizat (miracle).
majlis. Ar. Meeting; gathering. Di - tbngah m.;
before others. Ka - hadapan m., or ka -
hadapan medan m.: «to the presence of*;
a polite way of addressing a person whom
it would be presumptuous to address directly.
Also (Min.) majalis.
11. See mftjelis (pretty).
majmaat. Ar. Assembly; place of meeting; congre-
gation.
majmu’. Ar. Gathering or collection or compendium,
e.g. of perfumes (see majemok) or of Laws,
cf. majmu’ al - ahkam (a Johore Code).
tnajnun, Ar. ((Possessed by a jin», i.e. mad; cf.
sepSrti laku oraug ra. (behaving as one
possessed), Kal. Dam. 243. Used specially of:
(i) children who mimic frenzy in Minangka-
bau Hasan - husain processions;
(ii) the frenzied lover of Laila (often
mejnun) in the Eastern romance of Laila
and Majnun; and
(iii) the first swivel-gun (named Laila
Majnun) cast locally for a Malay Sultan;
from which all swivel-guns have come to be
known as lela.
majoh. To eat voraciously; to guzzle; cf. (Sund.)
maju, (Kawi) majuh (id.),
majong. See majun (oakum).
maju. (Batav., from Jav. and Sund.) Advance.
Majukan: to push forward; to encourage.
Kemajuan: headway; prosperity; progress
(Üb. Kayu 6). Of an army advancing (Si
Jamin 18); of progress and set - backs
(mundnr - m. - nya), Sid. Rama 75; of cattle-
breeding as a thing that sought to be
encouraged* (harus di- majukan), Sul. Hid.
31; of advancing the prosperity of the State
of Geglang (momajukan nfigfiri G.), Ht.
Panj. 104; of advanced civilisation (Kep.
Mai, 3); etc.
Majuj. Ar. Magog; see Yajnj (Gog).
majum. See majun (oakum).
majun, I. (Ch. moa-jiong] Oakum, as used for
caulking boats. Also majong; (Ked., Batav.)
majum; (Min.) majun.
11. Ar. Electuary, = maajun, q.v.
Majusi. Ar. Magian; Zoroastrian; the Fire-wor-
shippers. It is said (Bost. Sal. ii 6) that
this cult originated in the adoration of the
fire lit by Kaiomorz near the tomb of his
son who was slain by the Afrit; also that
on the night of the Prophet’s birth the
palace of Nushirwan fell in ruins and the
sacred fire of the Magians was extinguished
(padam api yang di-sembah Majusi di-
nogtsri Farsi), Bost. Sal. ii 38. Old Persians,
Turks and Kurds are all put down as
Majusi (Bost. Sal. i 80); and the Fifth
Circle of Hell is provided for their reception.
tnak. I. (Min.) Short and familiar for maniak
(maternal uncle), esp. in expressions like
mak tua, m, tengah, mail bongsu, m.
anchn (uncles in order of age). Not to be
confused with ma’ = aunt.
11. Mak pauh: a tree, Mangifera
longi p e s; W.
111. See ma’ (mother, aunt).
maka. And; then; after a short space of time.
The original meaning is «a moment of time»,
cf.
Bulan dan hari, jam maka - nya,
Aku hendak tabu semua-nya:
«the month, the day, the hour, the very
minute, —all these are things that I desire
to know*; Sh. Peng. 21. The word has
however been utilized (Mai.) as a copular
to bridge the interval between two state-
ments in sentences; cf. isteri - nya hamil-
lah, maka genap - lah bulan, maka per-
maisuri pun beranak-lah; his wife became
pregnant; maka = there was an interval; the
usual months passed; (a further interval);
she bore a child; Wt. In English it is
translatable by «and», «then», «next>, «fur-
ther*. It is a link between sentences, not
between nouns. Sa - bermula m. ada - lah;
once upon a time there was. Apa sebab-
nya m. tuan ka-mari: for what reason then
did you come hither; Mai. Annals 20.
Also mangka; (Kel.) moka; (Min.)
mungka, barauari.


Makadunia. Macedon; the country of Alexander
the Great; Mai. Annals 4, 8.

makan. To eat; to consume; to wear away; (in

hati (to be resentful); in. jenoh (to eat one’s
fill); m. kntip-katap (to live from hand to

whole as a python does); m. nasi (to dine);
m. nasi kawah: to be a coolie, see nasi; m.
penchen (to live on a pension); m. sa-daun
(to eat off the same plate as another); in.
scrap (to sponge for meals); m. serengam
(guzzling, gorging); m. serok (to eat moder-
ately); m. snap (to take bribes); m. ta’-siau
(Baba=dyspepsia); di-ni. karat (eaten into
by rust); di-m. rahn (eaten by the dragon
Rahu, i. e. eclipsed —of the moon); ber-
kilat sahaja haratn ta’ - in. (shiny but quite
unable to cut said of a showy but useless
weapon and of bluffers generally); seporti
orang pemakan chandu, dongan chandu
sampai ka-mati (like an opium smoker; he
won’t give up opium till he dies), Prov.
See also pakan iii. Cf. santap, kumi.

makin. More; the more. M. lama in. baik: the

Makkah. [Ar. makkat; Hind, makkah] Mecca.
The form Makkat is met with in writings
of men acquainted with Arabic, esp. in the


honorific Makkat al-musharafat (Mecca the
Exalted City), Post. Sal. i 59; but Makkah
is by far the commoner form.
[Mecca, «the Noble* (mulia, musharafah,
Bost. Sal. i 68, 69), or *the Mother of Cities*
(unirn al-kura, Bost. Sal. i 68) is venerated
by all Moslems. Death at Mecca when on the
pilgrimage is regarded as the surest pass-
port to Heaven. Tradition has it that when
the foundations of the Caaba were being dug
a tablet was found with the words, «Iu
Mecca is the palace that I have chosen for
Mine Own; to Me, God, Mecca belongeth;
those who dwell in it dwell with Me; and
all who come to visit it or to cultivate it
visit Me and ate My guests and under My
special care» (dalam M. itu istaua-ku yang
aku pileh akaudaku; aku-lah TLilian yang
eiupunya M.; dan isi segala yang meng-
ediami dia sa-kampong dengan aku sa-
kampong dengan istana - ku; dan segala
yang meramaikan dia dan segala yang
berhuma itu mengunjong-ku dan jaiuu-ku
dan didalam pblihara-ku), Bost. Sal. i 62.]

maksud. Ar. Intention; desire; will; aim. Layani
m.: to meet a person’s wishes, = layani

tnaktab. Ar. Place of writing; school.
maktub. Ar. Written down. Al.-m.: the Scriptures.
Jika sudah termaktub di-mana-kah dapat
di-munkiri lagi: when a thing is down in
writing there is no denying it afterwards;
Gul Bak. 61.
Termaktub (and tPrmazkur) are formal
terms used in letter-writing when dating and
addressing a letter, e.g. «written at Taipeng
on the 22nd Muharram* (termaktub di -
Taipeng pada 22 hari-bulan Muharram).
m'a’kul. See maakul (deduced).

mal. I. Base; root-portion; capital; collar-piece.
Of the base of a spear-head; the part of a
trident from which the three prongs project;
the ganja of a kris; etc. See mai; and of.
the expression mal datang or in. mbnumpang
for a kris in the making of which the ganja
and blade are made separately at first and
welded together afterwards.

mala. I. [Skr.; = wreath, chaplet of flowers]
«Flower®, as part of a composite flower -

mala (Sri Rama); seroja-mala mas (Sh.

(Sg. Samb., Jay. Asm. 57) and to which
Malay lovers liken the reviving influence of
a girl’s smile upon a despondent suitor.
11. (Ked., Kel.) Sere; fading; = (Joh.)
layu. Of flowers withering (m. kuntum,
Lail. Mejn. 8, termala kuntum, Sh. Kub.);
but usually, fig., of drooping health or waning
beauty, cf. the lines Janji tuan tidak bagitu,
kuntum mala sama di-pakai (not such was
the promise you made me; though faded the
flower would be worn); Mal. Pant. 631.
111. Skr. Baleful; having a curse resting
on all one does. Sometimes as the result of
a definite malediction; more commonly (in
the expression m. pestaka, Sh. Kub., Gem.
Ht. 12.; also malang pestaka, Gul Bak.
89; niala-pataka, Tk, iv. 607) through
being born under an evil star.

malai. I. [Skr. malya, through Tam?] Pendent
flower ornament for the human head; pendant
from the head of a standard (Hg. Tuah B 02).
Bubu m.; long strip-like fissures on the
sole (due to yaws). Smiting in., tajok in.,
or tajok bunga in.: a spikelet stuck in the
hair or headdress, with pendent ornaments
of thin metal or filigree work; illd. Mai.
Magic 378 (where the pendent malai and
the surmounting tajok can be seen clearly),
cf. tSngkolok hitain bertajok m. ber-
suntingkan bunga chempaka daripada mas
(a black headdress with aigrettes supporting
pendent flowers and surmounted by champak-
flowers of gold), Ht. An<rg. 23. These orna-
ments are worn on special occasions, e.g. by
a sovereign at his coronation and commonly
by a bridegroom at his wedding, whence (in
the sense of «bridal crown*) t. malai is used
as a term of endearment; Ind. Nata, Ht.
Koris.
Also mali; Dl.
11. Malai - malai: a tree, Litsea
(Cylico-daphne) sebifera, the seeds
of which yield an oil used by Malays. Not
to be confused with mali - mail or raeraali

malaikat. [Ar.: angels, pi. of malak] Angels;
but often used as a singular. Penghulu ra.:
leader of Angels; Archangel; Bost. Sal. i
21. M. yang iu6m6gang tidur: the Angel
of Sleep. Tiada ra6ngetahui bilangan banyak
ra. itu hanya Allah taala juga: there is
none that knoweth the number ol the Angels
save God alone; Bost. Sal. i 26.
In some passages (Raj. Muda SB, Ch..
Jen. 94) m. is used in our sense of «soul»
(e.g. tuanku patek-lah m. Si-Lunchai yang
mati itu: Your Highness, I am the soul of
the late Si-Lunchai); but this use is rather
irregular; see nyawa.
[The Malay idea of the angels is not the
conventional European idea. To begin with,
they are mortal; it is stated definitely (Bost.
Sal. i 25, 26) that Death shall slay them.
Nor are they of human shape (tiada sa-rupa
ia d6ngan laki-laki dan psr6nipuan); they
have filmy bodies (tuboh yang latif) and
can assume any form they please; Bost. Sal.
i 20],
malak. I. Ar. Angel, e.g.: malak al - maut
(Angel of Death), Bost. Sal i 25; m. al-
raad (the Angel of the Thunders; Bost. Sal.
i 52); in. zabaniah (angel - tormentor of the
damned), Bost. Sal. i 56. But the popular
word for «angel» is malaikat, q. v. and
malak is confused with malik (king, lord);
e.g. malik al - maut (death - angel). See
also maut.

malakat. [Ar.: possession] Mart; emporium (raala-
kat herti-nya perhimpunan segala dagang)
as a name applied by Arabs to Malacca;
Mai. Annals 2, 68, 184.
[The «mart» was originally on Water
Island. Owing to attacks by the Siamese
fleet it was transferred to the mouth of the
Bertam River on the mainland. This place
then became known as the «mart» (Malacca)
and the Sungei Bertam as the «River of
the Mart*, i. e. the Malacca River. See
Routfaer.
inalakut. [Ar. malak -u t] The Heavenly Court;

id.
malam. Night. Also (Java) uialfim. Properly the
sunless portion of the twenty-four-hour day
(in. hari); cf. m. buta (pitch-dark night);
m. - raalani (late at night); puknl dua
tengah ra. (2 a.m.); dunia di-pinjara sa-


hari sa - m. (life is but lent for a night and
a day). But Orientals reckon the twenty-
four-hour day as beginning at sunset and
often calculate by nights instead of days;
whence: m. ahad (their Sunday night; our
Saturday night); m. ini, sat ni (Pen.), m.
sSkarang (Sp.) = tonight; sa-m. (last night,
yesterday), = (Pen.) kelmarin, q.v.
Hari sudah jauh malain,
Mana-lah sahaya nak tmnpaiig tidur:
the night indeed is far advanced; where can
I hope to rest; Mai. Pant. 353.
Kembaug in., sfidap in., sandar ra., sun-
dal m.: the tuberose.
malan. (Min.) Bewdldered; perplexed.
rnalang. I. Adversity; mischance; piece of ill luck.
Etym., of something lying across one’s path:
pada tiap-tiap sawali terlihat - lah beber-
apa tali in. - melintang (in every rice - field
he saw scarecrow cords drawn across from side
to side), Bur. Glat. 3; also (Panj. Sg.) of
cannon blocking the way. But commoner in
the figurative sense: nasib -ku yang in.
(my unlucky lot), Ht. Abd. 2G3; shbab in.-
nya juga an gin tiada turun (by pure bad
luck no wdnd came), Ht. Best. Persistent
ill - luck is sial; m. refers rather to the
conditions of the moment. Cf. di-rundong
in. (dogged by mischances); sial bercham-
pur in. (unlucky and with conditions against
him), = nasib di - rundong in. (a lot ever
dogged by mishap). M. Pa’-Kadok: «Pa’
Kadok’s bad luck»; losing by whatever turn
events may take; Prov,, see kadok.

malar. Continually; more and more; to keep on.
Also mala; (Min.) malah; (Pk.) nalar. Of
a depth of water being constant at two
fathoms (ayer m. dua depa); of a person
being always pale and thin (m. puchat
kurus, Mas. Ed.; in. kurus dongan diri -
nya, Sg. Samb., Ind. Meng.); of a mourner’s
scarf being unceasingly wet with tears
(indnangis m. basah puucha sabok - nya),
Ht. Sh., Mas. Ed.
Malar-malar: on and on; however much;
the more. M. - in. habis - lah charek - charek
tiada juga malm puteh: she kept on
(scrubbing) till the cloth was worn to rags
but she could not scrub it white; Ind. Meng.
malas. Unwilling; idle. Etym., of unwillingness
generally, cf. Began; exx.: m. di - kenal
orang (unwilling to be known); m. rasa-
nya keluar (not wishing to go out); m.
patek menyeiubah orang yang demikian
(I don’t w r ant to acknowledge a man like
that as my superior); jikalau ram a aji
hendak porgi ka-Daha itu pSrgi-lah, yang
kita ini in. - lah rasa - nya pergi (if you,
Sire, wish to go to Daha you can go; as
for me 1 won’t go), Tk. iv 689. Put in
modern Malay specifically of people unwilliug
to work, i.e. lazy; cf. m. kelesa (idle and
slovenly); awak in. (lazybones); kursi in.
(easy - chair); in. pada pekhrjaan (lazy over
his duties), Ht. Abd. 181; senjata itu men-
datangkan m. (the wearing of weapons
encourages indolence), Ht. Abd. 184; tnana
yang in. di - salahkan, mana yang rajiu
di-kasehi (the idle he found fault with, the
diligent he commended), Must. Adat 20. And
a further distinction is drawn sometimes
between malas (sluggard) and chulas (clever
shirker).
Also as a tree-name, Parastemon
urophy 11 um;W. M. berdahan: Arthro-
phyllum ovali folium.
malati, =m6lati (jasmine).

Var: m. bbrduri (L. horrid a); m. - m. (L.

inalik. I. Ar. King; owner; lord. Al-m.: King
of Kings; God, —whence Abdul -m. as a
proper name; cf. Malek.
M. al-adil: «the just king*; an inscription
found sometimes on coins (to testify to their

Maliki. Ar. Malekite, i.e. follower of the Malekite

malim. I. Ar. Learned; expert; well versed in
some art. A «learned man* is usually orang
all in, orang ulama, esp. with reference to
religious knowledge. Malim occurs specifically
in three senses:
(i) mate or navigating officer (Ht. Abd.
260): m. bflsar (chief mate); m. kfichil
(second mate); in. angin (sailing master); m.
kapal (mate of foreign ship), Ind. Nata; in.
peraliu (mate on Indonesian ship), Ht. Best.;
in. yang tua didalam bahtera-nya itu (an
old ship’s officer upon the royal vessel), Mar.
Mah.;
(ii) among the Orang Kubn: a shaman,
= (Mai.) pawang, (Min.) poyang (see bblian);
(iii) in the form tnalin, as a (Min.) title
given to mosque elders (the imam, khatib
and bilal), and also as a hereditary distinct-
ion borne by members of one of the three
jonis or classes of the gentry (malim,
dubalang and mentbri) that may possibly
represent the old Hindu castes.
11. See Magindanau.
tnalin. See malim (iii).

mala. Feelings of shame, modesty or shyness.
Both in a good and bad sense; cf.: mon-
dapat m. (to be disgraced); tiada tabu m.
(to be shameless); monarch m. (to be modest).
So also kemaluan has three meanings: (i)
modesty or shyness; (ii) a cause ot shame, a
dishonour; and (iii) the pudenda, e.g.
bibir- bibir kemaluan (labia maj ora
et minora), Pen. Kudis 15.
In mysticism m. =«humility before God*,
which comes between the mere acceptance
of God’s Will (tawakal) and finding God
all - sufficient (ghina).

assertion. Malu-malu, puteri m,, si-m.,

mam. To suck at the breast; to eat (in baby-

mama. Hind. Maternal uncle; «uncle*, as a
description of Jawipekans of a certain age and
avuncular associations. Cf. nianiak and mamu.
mamah. Maceration in the closed mouth. Of the
way animals chew; cf.: pemamah biak
(ruminants), Sul. Ment. 2G; aku in. dongan
tulang- mu (1 shall gobble you up, bones and
all), Sg. Sarab.; mpa kain-nya seporti dl -

if a dog had chewed them up), Si Misk. 4.
mamai. A bemused look in an unconscious man.
Of a man s eep - walking or in a nightmare;
of a very sick man looking fixedly at one
point; etc. Sa - uinpania mabok dan m.: like
a person drunk or sleep - walking; Ht. Bugis
120. In a conscious person a bemused look is
mamang,q v. Also (Min.) of things being in
disorder.
Mamak. Orang Maraak: a Protomalayan commun-
ity in Sumatra. Its culture is high compared
with that of the Kubu or Akit.
mamak. I. Maternal uncle; (loosely) any uncle;
(Java) pa man. For the precise meaning,
cf. Post. Sal. i 96 and the Sri Rama passage:
m. juga kapada senda, ia-lah saudara
bonda patek (he is my mamak, i.e. my
mother’s brother). This is the common (coll.)
meaning in Minangkabau where the different
paternal uncles are mak tua, mak tengah,
mak bongsu, mak dm; paternal uncles
are bapa’ or bapa’ kechil. In the collo-
quial of Malaya pa’ saudara (Sp.) or (Pen.)
pa’ ponakan or (N.S.) diri bapa’ is in common
use for any uncle, but the word mamak is
known and is the conventional term for a
prince to use to his aged ministers; cf.:
mamak bendahara (Hg. Tuah, Kal. Dam. 202);
m. temenggong (Mai. Dewa 63); m. meu-
tbri-ku yang keempat (Mar. Mah). See also
mama, mak, mamanda, manda and mamu,
11, An occasional variant of mak (aunt).

mamat. Ramat- mamat: (Min.) a miscellany of

mambatlg. I. A spirit of the Indonesian pantheon.
The m. were minor divinities classified in
literature with the Arabian jin, the Persian
p6ri and the Indian dewa. They are
popularly identified with the tints of the
sunset - glow [awan - awan petang yang
bdrwarna raerah (te.ja); Perch. Mai. 45],
some which are thought maleficent (m. kuning,
m. liijau etc.). The former is believed to be
the cause of jaundice. The name m. is
given also to the four great spirits of the
sea. In some localities the ni. are regarded
as birth - spiiits.

headmen.

mampu. (Batav., from Sund.) Having means or

Orang in.: man of means. Tiada m. berubat

mampus. To die (expressed vulgarly); to be wiped
out, cf. hapus, apus. Of animals dying
(Tab. Mimpi 15); of an evil spirit turning
up its eyes and «croaking» (Ind. Meng.); in
imprecations (biar hamba m. = may I die
an ignominious death), Ht. Best.; in insult-
ing threats (hendak m. ■ kali engkau
do you wish to die like a dog), Pg. Ptg.

matnun. Ar. Safe; secure. Cf. aman.
ma’ mur, = maamur (abundant).
Man. A proper name. Short for Osman (TJthman),
Abdulrahman, Sulaimau, etc.
man. I. [Hind, man; Pers. man; Ar. mann;
Skr. man a] «Maund»; an Indo - Persian
measure of weight of about 80 lb. Delapan-
belas m. berat-nya: weighing 80 maunds;
Ht. Haraz. 26. Not much known in Malaya;
but one of the oldest weights in the world.
It, was the Babylonian name for an eightieth
of a talent (Yule); cf. also the Hebrew
man e h, Roman mi n a and Greek mn a.
But the amount it represented varied greatly.
The old maund* was lb. 82.2; the
Calcutta maund nearly 75; the Madras over
24; the Bombay maund 28.
11. Ar. Who; he who. Only in Arabic
quotations and expressions.
111. A short stave of music played
(repeatedly) at a Perak coronation by the
State Band (nobat).

whence. Di-m., tang-m.: where. Ka-m.:
whither. Orang m.: what man; who. Di-
manakan: how shall. Tekok in., masa m.:
when?

manawi, =maanawi (esoteric).
manazil. [Ar.; plur. of manzil] «Mansions, i.e.
stopping-places of the Moon* (manazil herti-
nya tempat perhbntian bulan), Host. Sal. i
49. A lunar mansion is a section of the
ecliptic—one for each day of the lunar
month—representing the path of the moon
for one day among the stars of the Zodiac.
The cmansions* are named after the fixed
stars that show the position of the moon in
the heavens on the night in question.

mandattl. Dizzy; intoxicated; overcome by some

Mandar. A territory in Celebes. Associated with
the Bugis raids on Malaya.
mandar. Burong mandar; (Batav.) a bird, sp.

mandarsah. Ar. Private religious foundation; Kal.

niar.de and mandeh. (Sum.) Mother; see ma’. M.
ketek: (Min.) aunt on mother’s side.
mandek. (Batav.) To hold up a work; Z.
mandi. Bathing. Etym., of bathing in water, e.g.
in a river like a poor person, in contr. to
having water poured over oneself (siram) as
a person in a bath-house. In this way
mandi is the popular word while siram is
confined to the ablutions of princes; but the
difference in meaning in the form the bath
takes has been ratber lost sight of. M. is used
of all ceremonial lustrations: m. bakai, m. gu-
bah (washing of the dead body); m. balai (for


exorcising evil spirits); m. basoh lantai (40
days after childbirth); in. bunting, in, lenggang
perut, in. wilada (in seventh month of
pregnancy); m. dauiai, in. snatn meuipolai
(after consummation of marriage); m. hadas,
in. janabat, in. junub (after ritual impurity);
in. haidz (after menstruation); m.-manda, m.-
m. (ceremonial lustrations generally); ra.
Safar (the Safar purification festival); ni.
sanipat, m. sapet (Pk., on third day after
marriage).
M. berlimau: washing with limes, the
limes being cut in two and rubbed against
the body. M. bersintok; washing with sintok,
q.v. M. darah: a blood-bath; fig. or other-
wise. M. minyak: oil-bath; common among
Tamils. M. pancha-persada, m. pancha-
pfirmandian, m. taman bfirtangkap, m.
tamun mayang: baths named after the type
of ceremonial bath-house in which they are
taken. Tempat in.: bathing place; bath-house
in general; also tempat permandian.
In sea- terms m.=spray-washed or sea-
washed; cf.: m. ombak (washed by a heavy
sea); m. angin (spray-washed); batu m. (rock
just awash); angin tonggara m. (strong S.
W. breeze causing spray). M. peloh: bathed
in perspiration. M. biar basah; «when you
bathe wet yourself properly»; no half-
measures. M. ta’-basah: «bathing without
getting web ,=skating on thin ice or offend-
ing without being found out; Prov., Mai.
Lem. 78.
Burong m. anak: a bird, sp. unid.,=(Pk.)
burong kuai.
mandika. Kayu mandika: stout post at the

Mandudari. Skr. Name of a great beauty of
Indian romance; Tk. iv 510. Variously (i)

Guru coveted by Rawana; (iii) a wife of
Dasarata coveted by Raw an a. In one

off by Rawana under the impression that
he was carrying off Mandudari herself.

m.; a barren wife; Gul Bak. 132. Bagai nia’
uiandul baharu beranak: «like a barren

mandzum. Ar. In the term dur al -

Varieties of mangoes are: (Mai.) m. dahi,

[The word inarhum is used in the official
posthumous titles of Sultans, e. g. marlinm
kahar; but popular variants have mangkat:
in. di - tubing, m. di-jnlaug, m. mahkota

mangkubuana. (Jav.) «Nurse (or custodian) of
the world*; a royal honorific or jojolok
borne by the Sultan of Jogja.
Also amangku-buana.
mangknbumi. «Nurse of the realm*; a description
of the position of a prime-minister. Common
in literature (Sg. Samb., Jay. Lengg., Ht.
Bangs. 1, Mai. Annals 42, 49, 54, 119). In
a Malay Sultanate the word for <prime
minister* is technically bondahara, but this
is regarded as a local term; and Malacca
envoys when speaking to the Siamese king
described their bendahara as the «Raja of
Malacca’s nrangkubumi* (in. raja Melaka),
Mai. Annals 89. Also used as a mere
honorific in titles (dato’ mangkubumi), such
an honorific carrying no duties or powers of
a prime - minister.
mangkudu. See mengkudu (plant-name).
mangkunggara. (Java) «Nurse (or custodian) of
the State*, a royal honorific or jojolok borne
by the pbngeran adipati aria (yamtuan
inuda) of Surakarta. He is known popularly
as «the Prince Mangku-negara*.
mangkurat. (Java) «Nurse (or custodian) of the
Kingdom*. A name or title met with occasion-
ally in Java; see mangku.
mangkus. (Min.) Efficacious; potent; in working
order.
mangkuta. See mangkota (crown).

11. Hind. Bead,=manek. Only in com-

Mantaka. Sang Maniaka: the traditional name of
one of the three princes who appeared on
Mount Si-guntang-gnntang.
manian. (Min.) Pregnant; Tn., cf. tian.
tnaniaya. Skr, To be guilty of injustice; Must.
Adat 45,=m6nganiaya. See aniaya.
manik. I. Manik-manik; (Brun.) the temples; M.
ll.=manek or mani (bead).
manikam. [Tara, from Skr. manikya] Precious
stone; quintessence; germ; embryo. Common
and indefinite in the sense of gem; cf.: ratna
mutn m. (gems of all sorts), Lang. Buana
64, Mai. Annals 7, Bost. Sal. i 40; jaulmri
juga yang mfingenal in. (it takes a jeweller
to tell a gem), Prov., Ht. Abd. 2. Technical
and definite in the sense of «germ of life*,
the essence of things in the smallest possible
compass,=jauhar, Pers. gohar or gauhar,
[The Islamic idea of the generation of
life is this. There exist separately in man
three elements; wadi, madzi, mani. These
elements, emitted at different times, first
meet one another and commingle in the
uterus. Their fusion creates the manikam or
germ of life. Cf. (Man. Pari 7);
Perfama wadi, kedua madzi,
Ketiga mani, manikam tfirjali,
(first the wadi, then the madzi, then the
niani, and the germ is complete). The germ
becomes a clot of blood, then coagulates into
flesh, then forms the embryo. The three
elements are often referred to in sorcerers’
incantations.]

mouths of Javanese speakers, cf. Hg. Tuah
198, Mai. Annals 174. M. sakalian ini
orang gimong; we, all of us, are men of
the mountains;Ht. Sh. Also manera, menera
and mfindera.

a charm to render the person

manjang. I. Hantu manjang, bantu manjangan,
or hantu manyangan: (N. S., Min.) fami-
liar spirit sent out by a wizard to suck the
blood of his enemies. It is embodied on its
errands in the wizard’s own head and entrails.
Cf. (Mai. Magic 627):
Kur ayam puteh, Kur ayam hitam,
Chatok-lali p6rut manjang yang terjela-
jela itu;
Chatok-lali hati jantong limpa manjang
itu:
«hither white fowls, hither black fowls, peck
at the manjang’s trailing viscera, peck at
the heart and liver of the manjang».
With the word manjang, cf. bajang,
anjong; with the shape, cf. penanggalan
or tenggelong; for the bloodsucking, see
pelfisit.

mantgra I. [Skr. mantra] Etym., a sacred text

dongau m.-ku itu: I have only to recite my

mantik. I. Ar. Hum mantik: logic; discussion by

term ilmu m. or iltnu in. maana is applied
usually to the logical exposition of the meaning
of the Koran; Bost. Sal. ii 123, cf. also Raj.
Muda 3.

mara. I. Kota mara: coping; breastwork; parapet

marghub. Ar. Enjoyable; pleasant; delectable; Ism.

marhum. Ar. Having known God’s mercy (as the
dead know it). A 1 -m,: «the late» (of
Sultans). Ayahanda-nya yang m. itu: his
late father; Ht. Panj. 131. Cf. lakab,
mangkat.
[When a Chief or Sultan dies he has to
be given a special name to distinguish him
from others who bore his title. In some cases
he is known by some peculiarity, e.g. b6n-
dahara garang (the «fiery b6ndahara» of


Perak) or orang kaya besar lambat makan
(the 0. K. B. who took a long time over his
dinner). But in most cases he is known by
the name of the locality where he died.
In the case of Sultans it is usual to give a
formal official title of this sort (which may
or may not be popularly accepted). Popular
descriptions of Sultans prefix mangkat, q.
v ; official names have the more courtly
marhum. Exx. of these latter are: m. kahar
(he who has known the mercy of the All-
Dominant), a name for the domineering
Sultans Iskandar dzu’l-karnain of Perak
and Alaedin Riayat Shah of Acheen; and
m. ghafur (he who has known the mercy of
God’s forgiveness), a name for Sultan Yusuf
of Perak who, it is hinted, badly needed
such forgiveness; cf. also m. bosar (the
Great), i.e. Sultan Mansur I of Trengganu;
and mangkat raahkota alam (who died lord
of the world), i.e. Iskandar Muda of Acheen].
mart. Hither; cf. kian ka-mari: hither and
thither; Si Jamin 16. Often translated «come»
because Malay conciseness, says «hither»
where we should say «come here». The com-
mon Bazaar expression marl sini is really
tautological.
Bawa m.: to bring.
Mariam, = Mfiriam (Mary).
maricha, =mericha (pepper).
marifat. Ar. Perfection of knowledge. Used in two
senses:
(i) skill or wisdom generally; e.g.: m.
tajwid (a thorough knowledge of the art of
writing Arabic), Ism. Yat.; muda m. (my
wise young friend), Sg. Kanch. 14; sudah
ku banding dalam m., sa-orang pun tidak
banding-nya tuan (when all are contrasted
in wisdom there is no one as wise as ray
love), Ht. Koris;
(ii) in mystic language: the «wisdom of
holiness*, i.e. the intuitive perception of
truth and falsehood possessed by adepts in
mysticism. This intuitive knowledge repre-
sents the goal of the mystic, cf. Sh. Mard.
31.
Coll.: maripat.
Marijah, Ar. Name assigned by tradition to the
wife of Iblis (Bost. Sal. i 29). Also um
kaldam. She is associated with the Ar.
marijun min (Kur. LV 14), «mixture of
fire*, from which all evil spirits were created.
This text is quoted: Bost. Sal. i 29.

origin of the word in Malabari is unknown.]
If. American. Also Merikan.
Marikar. See Marikan I.

chota, (Pk.) tongkat waren,

11. See madu (rival; fellow - wife).


maruas. Ar. A small hand-drum accompanying a
gambus; Wt.

inarut. Charut- marut: varied abuse; see charut.
Maryam. See Meriam (Marj 7 ).
mas. I. [Hind, mas ha; Skr. mash aka.]
«Mace», — an Indian term that bears various
meanings in Indonesia. Also «gold», because
measured by the mace.
(i) Etym., the weight of a bean, the Skr.
masha (Phaseolus radiatus or Ph.
mu n g o), used as an equivalent of the
weight of eight seeds of Abrus precatori-
us (Mai. saga). This bean-weight is the
«mace* of ancient India, only traceable in
Malaya in attempts to represent the later mas
as equal to 8 saga, q.v.
(ii) The medieval Indian masha, in-
troduced into Malaya by purchasers of gold
dust, weighed about 17 grains troy or about
10 Abrus seeds. In India the t u 1 or to 1 a
(Mai. tahil) was variously reckoned at 12 or
16 mace; the latter was the value introduced
into Malaya. It survives in the proportion
between the mas and the tahil.
(iii) This «mace*, as a weight of gold dust,
was a convenient standard of value, which
gave its name: (a) to a gold coin weighing
one mas, and (b) to gold generally. The coin
is now obsolete; but the meaning «gold» is
the commonest attaching to the word mas at
the present time, cf. rupiah m. (Indian gold
coin); tarekan in. (tool to make gold wire).
(iv) In the early days of the Spanish
dollar it was found that the weight of a
dollar gave greater fixity than the weight
of any seed or bean. Jewellers took the
weight of two dollars as that of a tahil for
measuring gold, and one-sixteenth of it as
the weight of the gold mas. But this caused
confusion with other «taels» and «maces»;
and this «gold» tahil of Java is commonly
distinguished (Mai.) as a bongkaland its mas
as a mayam.
(v) Gold in Malaya as elsewhere is synony-
mous with wealth and with things that are
precious, e.g. it is a term of endearment, esp.
as «pale gold* is the colour of an admired
complexion.
List of terms in use.
(i) Gold getting. M. berbuku, m. berkfitnl:
gold in nugget-form. M. sa - jongkong, m.
sa-kfitul, ni, sa-pukal: a nugget. M. urai:
alluvial gold. Galian in., kelian m.: gold
mine. Molanda in., meriau in.: to wash for
gold. TMerang m.: gold reef. Tintingan m.:
winnowing pan for gold.
(ii) Treatment of gold. M. bertitek, m.
tenipawan: hammered or beaten gold. M.
bertuang: gold cast in a mould. M. gera-
chang, m. kerachang, in. keranchang:
tinsel. M. kertas: gold leaf. M. lantak, m.
lantakan: bar-gold. M. nierah; gold reddened
by chemicals. M. pergul, sepoh in,: gilding.
M. terupani: burnished gold. Ayer in.,
dawat in., jatujam in.: gold paint. Benang
in.: gold thread. Pandai in., tukang in.:
goldsmith.
(iii) Purity of gold. Twenty - four carat
gold: in. chia, m. tulin, m. sa-puloh mutu.
Twelve-carat gold: in. lima mutu. Pure
gold: in. tua. Alloyed gold: m. muda.
Debased gold: in. tongkang. Gold alloyed to
improve its appearance; suasa. Counterfeit
gold: in. lanchongan.
(iv) Gold as a symbol of value. M. juita:
a term of endearment. M. kawin: settlement
on a bride. Bunga m ; golden flowers as
tribute or as propitiation. Tikar in.: «golden
sleeping - mat*; (fig.) a wealthy marriage.
Sahaya tidak momandang mas, budi bahasa
yang sahaya chari: gold is a thing that is
naught in my eyes; what I seek is breeding
and worth; Alai. Pant. 1032.
(v) Miscellaneous. M. nianah: contribution
by N.S. villagers to the Yamtuan’s expenses
on certain occasions. M. puteh: platinum.
M. tempawan: the colour of beaten gold as
an admired complexion; «my fair one*. Anak
in.: child born to slavery as the child of a
slave-debtor. Burong m.: the fiery ininivet,
Pericrotus igneus. Ikan in., tbmbera
in.: goldfish of ponds; Carassius ornatus.
Kain benang 111.: cloth shot with gold. Kain
bertekat m.; cloth embroidered with gold.
If. A Javanese title (the golden?) borne
by those of the hereditary aristocracy who
are not entitled to be styled princes (rad en).
M. ayn, in. ngauten: titles borne by the
wife of a mas. See also (Banka) penuas.
111. Ikan kembal mas, ikan tombol m.:


dried tunnyfish. From the Maidive word
kalu-bili-mas («black-bonito-fish»), the
kulb-al - mas of Ibn Batuta and keum a-
in ai h of Acheen. See kembal.
IV. Mas nrong: iron pyrites; = Sund.
masurun g,=Jav. mas wurung (worth-
less iron).
masa. I. Skr. Time; season; epoch; (etym.)
month. M. inana: when; at what time; =
(Ked.) tekoh inana. Pada in. itn; then.
Pada snafu ni.: once upon a time. Pada in.
yang telah lain: in the past. Pada tiap-
tiap ni. dan ketika: at all times and seasons.
See also masakan.
11. See tonnasa (show; festival).
tnasaalah or masaelah. [Hind., from Ar.] Question
on some knotty point; poser; e.g.: 6inpat in.
yang mushkil (four questions that are hard
to answer), Kal. Dam. 390; in. yang per-
tania, Baik berkata-kata daripada berdiain
(my first enquiry is, «Is speech better than
silence*), Raj. Sul. 2. Exx. of «posers» are
given also: Mai. Annals 128, 206, and in
the «Book of the Thousand Questions* (in.
sa-ribu), i.e. posers put to Mohammed by
Satan to discredit his teaching.
masai. Kusut masai: very dishevelled; Perch.
Mai. 71 , see knsut.
masail. Ar. Question; the (Arab.) singular of
masaalah.
masak. Ripe (of fruit or grain); cooked (of food);
(leas correctly) to melt metal (Ht. Abd. 189)
or boil sugar (Pert. Tebu 4, Pant. Shi. 10).
Memasak: to be engaged in cooking. Me-
masakkan: to cook. Mftniasak tiinah: to
smelt tin. Bangsal peinasak; cooking-shed;
temjiorary kitchen; Sh. Ul. 15. Juru in. or
tukang ni.: cook. Kapur ni.: quicklime.
Masak is not used of boiling the rice to
be eaten with the dinner proper; m. nasi
means to cook the dinner, tanak nasi is to
boil the rice for it, M. is used rather of
preparing the «curry»; cf. ni. asam (stewing
with acid fruits); in. bulat, in. golek, in.
opor (cooking without sauce or fat); in.
kari (currying in the Indian way); in. leinak
(cooking in a rich sauce of coconut - milk);
in. lodeh (cooking vegetables till they are
pulpy); in. manis (cooking in sweet sauce);
etc. M. implies the use of a belanga, q. v.
Masak-niasakan are cooked dishes served up
with rice; m. - mbntah are offerings of food,
both cooked and uncooked, to Evil Spirits so
as to suit all tastes, some ghosts being
supposed to prefer raw food.
Of fruit in. means ordinary ripeness; just
ripe is sedang m.; over-ripeness is m. lum;
luscious ripeness is m. rannm; unripeness is
b6luni m. The various stages of unripeness
have often special names. M. is used (also
sa - in.) of the interval between one crop and
another, cf. sa - in. buah piama (a full «rice»
year), Raj. Muda 40; sa-m. buah rumbia
(a «sago» year), Mai. Dem. 60.
Also (Batav.) mateng.
masakan. An expression of doubt or interrogation
at the beginning of a sentence; cf. (Cr. Or.
62),
Jika tidak karna bnlan
Manakan bintang tiinur tinggi;
Jika tidak karna tuan
Masakan abang datang kamari:
Were there no glowing moon above
Why climb, 0 Evening Star?
And were it not for thee, my love,
Should [ have come thus far?
[The word is explained as from inasa - akan
(when should); but Rigg derives it from Port,
mas.]
masakat. See mashakat (troublesome).
niasaktnanall. (Kel.) Officious; intrusive; = (Mai.)
e in ul.
masala or masalla. I. Ar. Prayer-mat; Kal. Dam.
228.
11. = nrasaalah (question).
masam. Acid; sour; darkened as by acid. Of sour

tartness; worst side of a man’s character;
chocolate - coloured. See also asam.
masebok. To «butt in»; to join unasked in a

Maseh. Ar. Messiah. Isa al-niasch; Jesus the
Messiah; a missionary-name for Christ, in
contr. to the usual Malay nabi Isa. But
the Bostan (i 106) speaks of Christ as the
Messiah, i.e. jadi Maseh ia-Pn nabi Isa
ibni Miriam.


maseh. Yet; still; continuously so; Raj. Muda,
Ht. Bugis 74, 188, = (Batav.) masi; also
(Java) tangi, maksih, miseh. M. ragu kami:
we are still in doubt; Sid. Rama 252. M.
hidup m. ada harapan: while there is life
there is hope; Si Jamin 78.
masehi. Ar. Etym., «messianic», i. e. Christian;
specifically Protestant in contr. to nasrani
or serani (Catholic). Tahun m.: A.D. Tarikh
m.: the Christian calendar; Ht. Abd. 1.
masek. (Min.) Clear - sounding; Tn.
maska. Ar. Masha Allah (or mashallah): as
God wills; D.V.; Ht. Bangs. 1, Bost. Sal.
ii 93.
mas’haf. Ar. Written page or portion (of the
Koran). The Koran was not produced as a
continuous work; some time after the Prophet’s
death the Caliph Omar collected the various
records (mas’haf) of the Prophet’s addresses
and edited them as one text, destroying all
variants. There is a reference to this in the
Bostan (ii 65). Omar’s own text was in his
hands when he w r as assassinated; and this
Koran, stained with the Caliph’s own blood,
was kept at Medinah till recently when it
w'as looted by the Turks.
mashaikh. Ar. Elders; patriarchs; plur. of shaikh,
Kit. Muj. 14. Often pronounced mushaikh
and used as a singular in the sense of a
saintly old man; Kal. Dam. 215.
mashakat Ar. Troublesome; J.M.A.S. i 299. Also
(coll.) masakat.
mashallah. Ar. As God wills; = masha-Allah.
mashawarat. See mgshuarat (council, conference).
mashghul. Ar. Sad; sorrowful; grieved. Mash-
ghulan: sadness; Gul Bak. 115.
Often pronounced masrul, mesrul; (coll.)
sugul.
Mashhur. Ar. A proper name. Often pronounced
Masohor and shortened to Shohor or Sohor.
See mashhur.
mashhur. Ar. Widespread (of rumours or reports);
widely known; famous. Of a scandal spread-
ing (m.-lah khabar yang jahat), Ht. Abd.
293; of a religion gaining ground (m. - lah
igaina), Bost. Sal. ii 45; of a temple being
the best-known in a town (yang tormash-
liur didalam nPgcri), Gul J3ak. 119. M.
kdnaniaau: of world - wide fame. Also used
as a proper name; see Mashhur.
mashrek or mashrik. Ar. East; the East. Esp.

(from E. to W.; from one end of the world
to the other), Mai. Annals 6; raja m. dan
maghrib (king of the East and of the
West; lord of the whole world); Mai. Annals
9.

mastuli. Kain maetuli: a cloth fabric of heavy j

Mat. A proper name; short for Muhammad or

mat. I. [Pers. and Hind.] «Mate», at chess.

mata. I. Eye; focus; centre; orifice; eye-like
feature; the evil eye; num. coeff. for things
numbered by orifices such as the rungs of
a ladder (m. tangga) or the meshes of a net
(m. pukat). Also of the cutting edge of a
knife or saw; point of a lance; source of a
river; needle of a compass; = the point on
which everything turns.
M. alamat or m. lamat (hull’s eye of
target); m. angin («eye» of wind, point of
compass); m. ayam (fowl’s eye; very red
eyes in a horse; old copper coin with a cock
on it; plant, Ardisia crenata, Ixora sp.,
Baccaurea brevipes); m. ayer (rill,
spring, source of stream); m. bajak (plough-
share); m. balut (eyes swollen with weeping);
m. bantal (pillow - end of thin silver - plate
or stiff embroidery), illd. Veth xiii 4; m.
bawat (heavy-eyed, sleep}'); m. bedil (muzzle
of fire-arm); mata belalang, m. bulalang,
m. belalak, m. bolblang (wide staring eyes);


m. bblanak («mullet-eye» = centre of whorl);
m. bfiling (pale-blue eyes in a horse); m.
bbliong (hatchet-blade); in. belodok, in.
terjegil, m. terjojol (projecting eyeballs);
in. bfinda (property focussed or concentrated
in small compass, i. e. valuables); in. biji saga
(blood - shot eyes); in. bilas, ni. belesan
(watery-eyed); m. bisul (head of boil; the plant
Aglaonema commutata); in. buku
(knot in wood; centre of such knot); m. bulan
gathering on cushion of finger); in. changkul
(blade of hoe); in. chbmperling («starling» -
eyes; very red eyes); m. dabus (dervish’s
stabbing knife); in. duelling (marks showing
the weights on a spring-balance); in. dagangan
(valuables); in. dua (name for the fifth suit
in chicky cards, = go and babi); in. duli
(ankle, politer than in. kaki); in. gobek
(cutting end of areca-nut pounder); in. hari
(sun; see matahari); ni. hati (mental percept-
ion, instinct); in. ikan («fish-eye»; pockmark;
corn; wart); in. itek (*duck’s eye», A rd i sia
oxyphyl la); in. jalan (scout; outpost); in.
jarmn (eye of needle); m. juling (squint); in.
kabur (dim-sighted); in. kail (fish-hook); in.
kakap (plug-hole); in. kaki (ankle, ankle-bone,

111. See matakau.
matab. (S.S.) Blue light; roman candle; = Lask.

matah. (Ked., N.S., Min.) Raw; = mentah.
matahari. Sun; «eye of day», = mata-hari. Also

M. hidup, m. naik, m. terbit: sunrise; the
East. M. berayun, ra. ayun temaynn: «the
sun hovering for its descent*, i.e. afternoon
about 3.30 p. m. M. lengser, m. miring,
m. gelinchir: the sun slipping down; about
4.30 p.m. M. turun, m. tenggfilam, tn. ma-
sok, m. mati: the setting sun; sunset.
SSperti bulan dfingan in.: «like the moon
and the sun*; a glorious sight; cf. bulan.
SCperti m. tengah gerhana: Hike the sun
in eclipse*; a darkened royal countenance;
Ht. Angg. 54.
[ln the Bostan (i 46, 47) the size of the
sun is given variously as the size of the
earth and 300 times the size of the earth.
As one of the seven great heavenly bodies
it is given a firmament (pfffala langit) to
itself and its apparent movement is explained
by its position on a car (pedati) drawn daily
by angels from East to West. The varying
length of the day is attributed to the car
being drawn from different springs or ■wells
in the East. These wells pass under the
earth and are full of boiling mud; the sun
travels through them from West to East at
night. The sun is said to have been made
from a minute portion of the glory of God’s
empyrean throne (arash) and like the moon
is destined to perish in flames on the
Last Day].
matai. See mata (net - repairing).
matakau. (Batav.; from Male, m a taka wo, Tk.)
Gonorrhoea. Also mata kau, and taken to
mean chancre (Hn,|.
matamata. I. Constable; a gen. term applied
specifically to police - constables (Ht. Abd,
174), but extended also to cover firemen (m.
bomba) and process - servers (in. saman).
M. chbrah: uniformed police - constable. M.
gelap: detective p.c. M. sik: Sikh policeman.
Etym., the matamata in an old Malay
State were the myrmidons of the Shah -
bandar, i.e. customs and port officers.
Bandar m.: the port authorities; the Harbour
Master and his satellites; Ht. Bugis 44.

matan. (Min.) The real; the true; Tn.

dry sandy soil, in contr. to tanah pamah
(low swampy land).

Mataram. Mataram in Java, the seat of successive

founded in (he middle of the Sixteenth
Century and lasted till 1755 A.D. when it
was divided into the modern States ot Solo
and Jogja. It was governed by a Susu-
hunan.

mati. I. Death; extinction; to perish. In various
senses.
(i) Literally. M. andar, m. modar: to
die idly or unavenged. M. beragan: to die


without visible cause of death. M. dengan
sSnjata, m. didalam seujata: to die in battle.
M. di-bunoh: to die a violent death. M.
di - salang: to die at the hands of the
executioner. M. kuinlah: to die a natural
death. M. lemas: to perish by drowning.
M. shahid: to die in God’s cause; to perish
in a Holy War. M. tiada kelindan lagi:
to die without regrets.
(ii) Figuratively. Billanja ra.: fixed
allowance. Geran in.: freehold title. Harga
m.; fixed price. Also of dead low water
(ayer m., m. kekat); the dying day (mata-
hari in.); wind dying way (keraatian angin);
loss of virility (m. puchok); a knot that
cannot be unloosed (sinipnl m.); etc.
(iii) Miscellaneous. M. di-bunoh:
to come to a bad end» (as a term of abuse).
M. hidup: herb, Aneilema lineola-
t u ra; W. Beraui m.: (Baba) foolhardy.

diacritical mark jazm. Burong m. anak: a

hornbill, Anorrhinus galeritus. Bn-
rong in. sa-tahun: (Pk.) plaited - casqued

Dudok in., berdiri in., sfirba m.: «if I sit
I die, if I stand I die; I die in any case»
(said of a hopeless situation); Mai. Annals
31.
[ln one passage (Bost. Sal. i 101) a
distinction is drawn between bunoh (to kill
by violence) and momatikan (to cause to
die). Tradition has it that Aaron’s dead
body was taken to heaven; with the result
that Moses was suspected of having murder-
ed him. God then restored the body tempo-
rarily to earth to show that Aaron had died
a natural death (di - matikan Allah taala).]

11. Tawar mawar; harmless; nullified;
see tawar.
mawas. Mias; orang outang; Simia satyrus.
Found in Borneo (mayas, kelabat) and
Sumatra (mawas); known by repute in
Malaya as a semi-human monster (mawas)
with arms of iron and a pot - shaped head
in which it cooks its food. Believed to kill
and eat men. Iron tools left in the forest by
forgotten miners are explained as besi ra. or
broken bits of the elbow-knife of the mawas.
Abdullah mentions a pair of captive mias
(dua ekur mawas yang di-namaf oleh orang
pnteh orang hutan=two mawas that the
English call orang-outangs), Ht. Abd. 61;
in Patani the male mawas is called budak
kelubi and the female kudai; the Malacca
sengsnt may also be a tradition of the mias.
Akar mawas: climber, Dioscorea
pyri folia, D. glabra; W.
mawin. KaAvin mawin; marriage-festivities of all
sorts; J.M.A.S. iv 144, see kawin.

of roses and other precious substances. It

11. A creeping herb, Commeliua ben-
gal e n s i s; W.
mayang. I. Palm - blossom: = (Min., N.S.) arai.
Properly the youngspikelet of the blossom that
the sheath or wrapper (seludang) pushes
out; this unfolding blossom (Mai. m. men
gurai, Java m. mfikar) is a symbol tor
curly hair (Sg. Samb., Jay. Lengg., Gul
Bak.); the wrapper pushing it slowly out is
likened to the revelation of beauties and to
the discarding of a fair mistress;the blossom’s
ultimate fall from its sheath is compared
with the fall of beauty’s tears (Sh. Kub.).
Bintang m.: the constellation Virgo and
specifically the star Spica Virginis.

11. Dayong - mayong: oars (or rowing) of
all sorts, = a collective of dayong, q.v.
111. See ma’ yong (operatic play).
ma’yong. A theatrical performance of a type
originating in Northern Malaya. Played by
two actors (the prince-hero or pa’yong, and
the clown or peran) and two actresses, the
princess (ma’yong, put6ri) and her duenna
(mek s6ni, ma’ inang). Performed usually
under a shed (bangsal m.), the audience
being in the open air. The orchestra includes
Northern instruments such as the anak
ayam, gSdombak, mongmong, g6du - g6du
and b6reng-bsreng.
Tradition has it that the ma’ yong was
introduced into Northern Malaya by two
white batak, i. e. aborigines.
mayun. I. A tree, Dipterocarpus lowii;
W.

Chinese and of the Batavia Bugis (Ht. Bugis
10, 115). Used of a military Major, Sid.
Rama 184.

11. Bafu ni6dang sila: gypsum. Malays

mßduwangsa. See medu I.
meeraj or meerat. [Ar.;=ascent] Ladder of ascent
to Heaven; the prophet’s journey to Heaven in
his lifetime (whence bulan in. is a descript-
ive name for the month Rajab). M. as «the
way to Heaven* is a euphemism for death;
cf.: biar-lah abang meftrat serta (may we
lovers die together); Sh. Kub., and redza-lah
jiwa meerat asalkan dapat anak-nya orang
(only to have won that maiden would I
gladly give my life), Pant. Shi. 7. Also (in
this sense) mengerat; mbngerat, Bur. Pungg.
H)8; (Batav). merad.

megan. A sweetmeat of the kueh dodol class.
Made of rice-meal, suet and egg; eaten with

tnSgapa. (Kel.) What; what is it;=moga apa.
mSgar. Jav. To open (of a blossom) ;=m6kar.
m6gari. (Kel.) To see;=nampak. Cf. p6gari.
mggat. [Skr. maga d h a: son of a Vaisya father
and a Kshatriya mother] A hereditary title
fairly common in Malaya but not conferred
by present-day Malay governments. Common-
est in the North. Said to be borne (Ked.)
by the descendants of commoners married to
princesses; possibly an echo of the time when
it was given to the children of women of
the royal kshatriya caste by lower caste
husbands. Associated (Pk.) with the descend-
ants of Megat Tbrawis who was probably
a soldier of fortune from Kedah. The title
occurs in the Malay Annals (121, 122, 228),
in some cases as an honorific. A Megat Seri
Rama was the assassin of Mahmud II at
Kota Tinggi; a M. Burong rose to he Sultan
(All Riayat Shah) of Acheen, A.H. 993,
cf. Host. Sal. ii 123.

MElayu. Malayan; Malay; (occasionally) Moslem,
e.g. masok M. (to turn Mohammedan). In
early times the word did not cover the whole
Malay world; and even Abdullah draws a
distinction between anak Melaka and Orang
Melayu (Ht. Abd. 183). It would seem
from one passage (Hg. Tuah 200) that the
word, limited geographically to one area,
became associated with a standard of language
and was extended to all who spoke « Malay*.
The Malay Annals speak of a sungai Melayu;
I-tsing speaks of Sri Vijaya conquering the
«Moloyu» country; Minangkabau has a
»Malayu» clan (suku); Rajendracola’s con-
quests (A.D. 1012 to 1042) covered M. and
Sri Vijaya as separate countries; the Siamese
records claim Malacca and M. as separate


entities. Rouffaer identifies M. with Jambi.

in the cockfight, winner in the crowing*,
said of a man who tries to persuade others
that his failures are victories; Prov. Raja
yang di-m6nangkan Allah daripada segala
sfitfiru - nya: a prince to whom God has

A tree, sp. unid. Its fruit is edible;
its root is used medicinally; Dl.
m£nt£H. [Skr. mantri] «Mandarin», i.e. official,
civil servant. Etym., a minister of State;
and still so used in some Peninsular titles,
literature and speech; cf.: the tbngku m. or
maha-mentSri of Perak; the prime-ministers
(in. besar) of Joh., Trengg., Ked.; the title
perdana m. (Mai. Annals 85, 48, 77); and
the prov., Bagai raja dengan in. (as a king
and his minister) =in perfect harmony.
Formerly (Malacca) a senior civil servant; cf.
the old title of the Klana of Sungai Ujong
(pgnghulu ni., Mai. Annals 60) and the
expression sa-tara in. (with the precedence
ot a m.), Mai. Annals 173. Occasionally an
honorific in titles, e. g. in that of the Dato’
of Jelebu. In Sumatra: one of the three
divisions of the (Min.) gentry, i.e. malini,
dubalang, m.; also an honorific. In Java,
gen. for any functionary however humble;

mgstika, Bezoar, esp. when endowed with talismanic
properties. Also mustika and (Min.) niantika,
nientika, muntika. Etym., any bezoar, =
(Mai.) guliga; used (Min.) in this sense and
illd. Veth xxxi 3, 4. But in Malaya a m. is
something supernatural or miraculous like
the in. gainat that «enables matter to fly»


and the m. gmbun or «petrified dew» that
can bring the dead to life. Cf. the expression:
in. nogeri (wonder-gem of the land); jauhar
m. ratu p6r6nipuan (pearl of bezoars, queen
of her sex), Panj. Sg.; m. yang tiada tfir-
nilaikan harga-nya (a talisman of inesti-
mable value), Gul Bak. 64.
Cf. also the pantun - lines:
Tuan laksana inestika embun,
Kalau niati hidup kembali:
my love is like the dew divine that brings
the dead to life.
[There is a in. embun in the Perak
regalia. It is a sphere of crystal-glass rather
smaller than a billiard ball but dates back
to a time when such an object would have
seemed of miraculous origin.]

min. Ar. From; of.
mina. I. Skr. Gajah mina: «fish-elephant»; raa-
k-ara; whale; walrus. The «makara» on old
monuments has the head of an elephant and
the body of a fish, whence (probably) the
term gajah m. Modern Malays who know
nothing of the makara interpret gajah m.
either as a gigantic «fish» (whale) or as a
tusked sea-monster (walrus). The walrus is
known through its ivory and through books.


11. Burong mina: (Batav.) mynah; =
tiong or beo.
Minah. Ar. A feminine proper name; short for
Aminah, q. v.
Minangkabau. An important Malay territory in
the highlands of Sumatra associated specially:
(i) with a group of dialects peculiar to
itself; (ii) with a «matriarchal» system of
law under which tribal descent is traced in
the female line; (iii) with a system of con-
stitutional government unique in Asia; and
(iv) in the Peninsula with the colonisation
of the Negri Sembilan. The standard of arts
and crafts is very high in Minangkabau;
but the Malays of that territory have an
unmetited reputation for homely wits: bodoh
orang M. yang tiada mOnnmpu laut (dull-
witted are the men of Minangkabau who
have no footing on the sea), Prov.
minantu. See menantu (son-in-law, daughter-in -
law).
minarah. See menarah (minaret).
minat. To have a liking for; to want. Of a
Chief having a fancy for a particular elephant
(Mai. Annals 191); cf. also the saying, Hang
ta’-m, aku-pun ta'bisat (you don’t want
me and I have no desire for you).
Cf. bisat, gamat, chanda, bn tang, indah,
doyan, solak, sualak, sir.
minatu. (Batav., from Sund.) Dhoby; laundryman.
Also menatu (Pant. Mai. 973).
minbar. See mimbar (lectern).

Akar m.: climber, L i m a c i a v e 1 u t in a,
Hypserpa cuspidata; W. Bakal in.:
crude oil. BSrchelur m.: ordeal by boiling
oil; Bost. Sal. ii 27. Belalang in.: a winged
insect, sp. unid., which when crushed gives

orientalis, Agathis alba. Hantu in.:
spirit of petroleum wells; this spirit, if left

the oil; Perch. Mai. 24, 25. Kelang m.: oil-
press; oil - mill. Mandi in.: oil-bath (as taken
by Tamils). Melumur in.: rubbing ointment
on the body. Pari m.: electric ray, T e m er a
hard wick ii. Rmnput m.: herb, Isachne
australis. Semut in. an ant, sp. unid. Tahi
in.: refuse oil; (fig.) a rotter. Yum.: dogfish,
Chiloscylliura spp.
limn kebal m. magic art of making one’s
body so slippery as to be invulnerable. Tahi
m. tanah; petroleum residue. BSrminyak
biar lichin: «when you oil yourself, oil
yourself slippery#, i.e. no half - measures.
Borminyak ta’ - lichin: «oi!ed yet not
slippery*; work that is ineffectively done;
Prov.
mior. See mir.
mipir, (Ked.) To edge away; = memipir. See
peper.
mipis, = nipis (thin, tenuous).
mir. [Ar. amir; Hind, mir] Ameer; Emir;
(Pk.) a title accorded to the descendants in
the direct male line of the marriage of a
commoner with a sharifah. A mir’s sister
is styled po’tun. Owing to Perak pronuncia-
tion mir is often transcribed in documents
as mior or meor.
In India mir and said are practically
interchangeable. See also mirza.
tnirah, Batu mirah: (Java) ruby; carbuncle;
jacinth (Kara. Kech. 7.)
mirat. Ar. Mirror; speculum. M. al-muminin:
«Mirror of True Believers*; the name of a


religious treatise.
rni’rat. A variant (Pant. Mai. 209) of meerat, q.v.
miring. I. A (Java) variant of mereng (to incline
to one side), Üb. Kayu 42.
11. Gambian miring: Javan orchestra as
used at puppet-shows; see gamelan.
mirip. (Batav.) Almost alike; similar; Z.
miris. (Brun.) Leaky; M. Cf. tiris.
mirut. Karut-mirnt: hopelessly involved; see
karut.
mirza. A Persian title prefixed to the names of
Indian people who claim Iranian descent. As
a suffix it is a princely title in Persia.
Short for amir-zadah.
misa. Skr. War-buffalo; champion of the arena;
as a title for warriors of medieval romance.
Also mesa and mahesa. Cf. Misa Gunawan
(Pant. Mai. 445).
misai. Moustache; Mai. Annals IGB, Ht. Panji
54, Sid. Rama 110. Varieties: m. bbramus
(bushy and hanging down); m. bbrtaring
(with fiercely turned-up points); m. chonet
(with waxed tips); m. kaku (stiff and large);
m. lalat hinggap (visible at the tips only); m.
Ibbat (walrus-type, with hanging ends). M.
Adam: grass, Themeda arguens; W.
M. kuching: Orthosiphon stamin-
e u s; Bkl.
[Moustaches were worn by warriors just
as beards were worn by the religious. But
ideal beauty—in the dwellers in paradise
had neither beard nor moustache; Host. Sal,
i. 45.]
rntsal. See mithal (example).
misail. I. (Ked.) Honey in the comb. Cf. manisan.
11. (Batav.; from Jav. or Bal.) Cousin;
first cousin. Cf. mindon and mintelu.
111. (Brun.) Tombstone; see mesan.
misani. Kbris kala - misani: a Javan variety of
kris; see kala and kbris.
misbah. Ar. Light; lantern; lamp; Raj. Sul. 20.
miseh. See maseh (yet, still).
misek. A tree, sp. unid.; Dl.
misiki. A (Min.) variant of meski (although),
Must. Adat 2.
misikin. See iniskin (poverty).
mising, (Ked.) Vomiting and diarrhoea as the
result of eating unwholesome shellfish or
prawns.
Misir. [\r. Mis r] Egypt; Mizraim. Nbgeri M.:
id. Orang M.: an Egyptian. Aziz al-M.:
• the darling of Egypt*; a name for Zulaikha
or Potiphar’s wife.
Also Masir, Mbsir.
miskal. Ar. Shekel; see niithkal.
miskin. Ar. Poverty. Jikalau bngkau iniskin
pinta-lah pada yang kaya: if thou art poor
ask of Him who owneth All; Ht, Abd. Also
(Min.) misikin.
[A distinction is drawn between the «poor»
(miskin) and the «needy» (fakir). The «needy»
are men (like cripples or the blind) who are
unable to earn a living. The «poor» are
able-bodied but poor. In mystic language the
• needy* (fakir) are those who feel the need
of God; they rank higher than those who «walk
humbly in God’s sight* (miskin).]
misoa. (Raba from Ch.) Vermicelli; = (Mai.)
laksa.
itlisoh. [Jav., from piso h] To abuse; to revile;
to use bad language.
Misri. Ar. Egyptian; Sh. Bid. 80, Ht. Bugis 57.
In India specifically of «sugar of Egypt*
or candy.
tnisru. Kain misru: silk or satin with a cotton
back. An old trade fabric; Ht. Koris, Jur.
Bud. 43. Also misrun.
misrun. See misru.
niissi. Eng. Miss, —in contr. to mem (Mrs.).
mistar. I Ar, Ruling-board for impressing lines
on blank paper; ruled line; line, = (Java)
mestar. M. mbnyurat and papnn m.: ruling-
board. Segala pantun-pantun Mblayu itu
bmpat m. ada-nya: all Malay pantuns run
to four lines; Pel. Abd. See also shatar.
[A ruling-board is a flat board over which
strings are stretched at regular intervals.
When paper is pressed on it long lines are
indented.]
11. Eng. Mr.


mistSri. See mestCri (master-workman).
misti. See mesti (must,inevitably).

for Abdul-hamid; see harnid.
mitai, [Hind.] Indian sweetmeats. M i t’h a i is the

varieties some of which have been introduced

Also misal.
mithkal. Ar. The ancient «shekel». Yule gives it
as the weight of the Roman aureus or
gold dinar, i.e. about 73 grains.
miting. Eng. Meeting; public meeting.
mitis. Tree-name; Bassia motleyana, or
Payena utilis; W.
miur. See mir (a title).
mizatl. Ar. The sign Libra in the Zodiac; Bost.
Sal. i 49. For purposes of divination it is
regarded as the «star» of Abraham and is
associated with the griffin (geroda), the cat,
the pigeon and the olive.
mo, mo’. (Red.) True; that is so; well yes.

Also Mut.
modal. Tam. Working capital. M. bglajar: cost
of an education (regarded as investment).
Makan ra.: to draw on one’s capital.
Menaroh m.: to have or invest capital;
Ind. Meng. Mgndapat m.: to acquire capital;
Ht. Abd. 810.
modar. Mali modar: to die an unholy or useless
death. Etym., of a beast slaughtered otherwise
than in the ritual way (see seraboleh); to die
uselessly; to die unavenged; but used also to
imprecate a bad death or a beast’s death on
a person. Auak si-Anu yang akan modar;
«may So-and-so’s daughter die miserably*;
Kep. Mai. 51.
model. (N. 1., from Dutch) Model; design. M. yang
baharu: of the latest design; B.
modin. 1. Ar. «Muezzin»; (in Malaya) circumcizer.
Malays do not employ muezzins. But how
the muezzin came to be associated with
circumcision is uncertain. See also muadzin.

tnodu. A tree, Aglaia argentea; W,

mohon, Bermohon: «to ask permission*, i.e. to
beg to be excused or to be allowed to
depart; = (Java) parnit. Idiomatic; e.g.
Mohonkan bersuaini akan raja Melaka itu
is not the literal «I ask permission to marry
the Sultan of Malaccas, but «I beg to be
excused marrying the Sultan»; llg. Tuah
101. It is usually a polite refusal; cf. mohon -
lali patek (please excuse me), i.e. I do not
want to do it; Hg. Tuah 74. Also of saying
goodbye; cf. Mai. Annals 90, and the passage
Tiada member! tabek atau bermohon lagi
(he left without a word of courtesy or
farewell) =he left rudely and abruptly; Ht.
Abd. 243. See also menampun (to ask a
raja’s leave to depart).
mohor. [Pens, muhr; Hind, muhur or mohar]
Seal; impression; mint-mark;=tAra. Chap m.:
the royal imprint, be it a seal or a guinea -
stamp; Ht. Best., Ht.Angg. 10, Raj. Muda
98. Chinchin m.: royal signet-ring. Yang
bfmnohor: «seal-possessing», i.e. royal; Ht.
Bugis 17.
mo’jizat. [Ar. through Hind.] Miracle; power to
work miracles. Limited by the orthodox to
the Prophet’s power, a Saint’s power being
kSramat, cf. Man. Pari 17; extended through
Shiite influence to the miraculous power of
the Prophet’s son-in-law Ali (Ht. Pdk. 03);
and used loosely even of the powers of
saints and holy men (Sid. Rama 10). Also
ma’jizat.
moka. See maka (and; then; next).

11. Cheeky; pert. Of spoilt children.
111. A variant (pronounced nasally) of

IV. (Batav.) An eel, sp. unid.; Baus. Also
moa, B.
muadzam. Ar. «August», as a term applied to
Sultans (sultan al-m., Mai. Annals 129);
especially in former years to the Sultan of
Turkey as premier Sultan.
muadzitl. Ar. Muezzin; caller to prayer; Bost. Sal.
ii 54. Nowadays pronounced tnodin and used
in a different sense; see raodin.
muafakat. Ar. «Agreement», i.e.;
(i) concord; bermuafakatkan (to reconcile),
Mai. Annals 78; in. itu berkat («harmony
has God’s blessings, motto of the Johore
family order);
(ii) a convention, treaty, or compromise to
end any dispute;
(iii) a resolution arrived at by a body of
persons in pursuance of a common object (Ht.
Bugis 91); and
(iv) a conspiracy.
Also (Min.) rules of law based upon agree-
ment between all concerned. As «agreements»
may he used to alter or override the common
law (adat) they are disliked by jurists; in.
lain didalam gelap, adat lain di - tengah
terang (pacts are put through in darkness,
custom lives in the light of day), Prov.
M. is used also of a married couple
making an arrangement between themselves
(Ht. Abd. 293); and of a Secret Society (Ht.
Abd. 220).
Also pakat, and (Min.) mupakat.
muai. To swell; to expand; = mual, q.v. Used
(fig.) of the growth of the British Empire;
Jub. Mai. 4.


muajar. See faragh (star-name).
muak. Disgust; nausea; to be sick and tired of
something. Also mua and mual; loya; luak,
luat, jCluat; (Kel.) dugal.
mual. I. To swell; to expand, esp. of rice when

when boiled*, —of anything quite worthless;
Prov.
11. Disgust (Sid. Rama 159); = muak,

Bangs 2,

muang. Muang bolakang: (W. Sum.) to flee; =

Muar. Name of a river and river - state (now
included in the Sultanate of Johore); Mai.
Annals 59. Its hinterland (Ulu Muar) is in
Negri Sembilan.
muara. Estuary; river mouth; a Borneo, Sumatran

Ht. 24, Al. Mai. 46, Mai. Annals 18, 29,
207, Pant. Mai. 571, 601.
muat. Ijoading. Muatan: cargo. Muatkan: to

to burst out; B.
mubarak. Ar. Blessed; bringing good fortune; Kit.
Muj. 71.
mubazir. Harga mubazir: fancy price; Sh.
mubeng. (Java) To circle; to revolve; B.
inubiar. (Java) To strike the eye; to «scream» (of
colouring); B.
mubtadi. Ar. Beginner; neophyte (in mysticism).
Technically a mystic who is still learning
that the world is illusion. When he «steps
outside illusion* he becomes a mutawasit.
muche. See niache (a W. Sum. title).
muda. I. Youth; to be young or immature; to
lack depth (of colouring). Pemuda: dealer
in love-philtres and charms; Kep. Mai. 18.
Mudakan: to rejuvenate; Bost. Sal. i 45.
M. belaka; quite young. M. belia: in the
bloom of youth. Ma’ ni.: mother’s younger
sister. Main m.: running after women—-a
stronger expression than main mata (eye -
play, flirtation) but not connoting illicit
relations; Ch. Jen. 72, Hg. Tuah 212, Mus.
Berj. 161. Ilmu in.: magic ars amoris;
Kep. Mai. 17. Mas in.: pale (alloyed) gold;
see mas. Morah m.: light red. Pa’ m.:
uncle younger than one’s parents. Tulang
m.: (i) gristle; cartilage; (ii) rib. Anak m. -
m.: the younger generation.
M. is common in titles in the sense of
c junior* or «future*; e.g.: raja m. (heir to
the throne); dato’ m. (heir to a title);
vamtuan in. (joint but junior ruler). In some
cases the title has acquired a special meaning
for historical reasons: thus the dato’ muda
of Linggi is the Chief of Linggi, the higher
title having ceased to exist; the Sultan
Muda of Perak is the Sorcerer - King of
Perak and the raja kgchil muda is his heir;
and tengku besar (not tengku muda) is
used preferably of an heir - apparent. Che’
muda: (N.S.) junior and non - royal wife of
the Yamtuan.
See also anom, inn, uda, da.
11. Muda - wangsa: «young and noble*;
better meduwangsa, q.v.
mudah. Easy; light; trivial. DiMigan m. - nya:
easily. Di-m. Allah akan mati - nya: God
will grant him an easy (painless) death; Kit.
Muj. 12. Hati-ku jangan kamu pSrmudah:
do not treat my heart as a thing of no
account; Sh. Bid. 112. Bukan - nya m. hati
yang kaseh, nyawa - ku pergi berbalok
datang: a loving heart enjoys no peace;
with my whole soul I wander to and fro;
Ht. Koris.

e.g. mudah-mudahan di-b£ri Allah akandia
shurga tempat kediaman - nya (may God

muddat. See mudat (prolonged).
mudek. Progress upstream; going back against
the current (cf. udi, uri), in contr. to
drifting down with the current (hilir). Mu-
dek mbnyongsong: id.; Mai. Annals 234.
Berbalek m.: (water) back to flow
upstream*; a proverbial impossibility or
miracle. Kanan m.: right bank (as you
journey upriver), i.e. the left bank as usually
calculated by ns.
Cf. udek, udi, kudian, uri, burl, burit.
mudgli, = madali (musical instrument).

8, Sh. Ul. 26. Cases are heard by the

up he refers it to the mufti.

Coll.; Morol; Dl.

rnuhalil, muhallil. [Ar muh a 11 iI ; = legalizer| The
«legalizer» of the remarriage of a fully di-
vorced woman to her former husband. Also
china buta and antara. Such a remarriage
is only permitted if the woman has been
married to some other man in the interval;
and if there has been no such marriage a
muhallil or temporary husband (who marries
her one day and divorces her the next) is
employed to meet the requirements of the
law.
Muhamat. See Muhammad.
Muhammad. [Ar. muhammad: worthy of praise]
Mohammed; a proper name. Colloquially often
pronounced Muhamat, and shortened to


Mamat or Mat. Nabi M.: the Prophet Mo-
hammed. Nur M.: the «light» of Mohammed;
the spirit of Mohammed regarded as an emana-
tion of the Divine Light (nur ahadiat).
Muhammadiah. [Ar. and Hind.] Mohammedanism;
Kit. Muj. 14. Yang M.: Mohammedan.
Muharam, Muharram. [Ar. muharram (sacred)]
Name of the first month of the Moslem
year; and more specifically of the first portion
of that month. Also (Mai.) bulan sura;
(Ach.) bulan api; (Min.) bulan tabut, bnlan
Hasan Husain, bulan pencheraian tahun.
[Ktym., the month of the Truce of God
when all warfare was forbidden among the
old Arabians.]

of the mystic.

Munkar, Ar. Name of an Angel-Questioner of the
dead. [Malays believe that soon after burial
the dead are interrogated by two angels,
i.e. Munkar and Nakir, who beat them
pitilessly if their answers are unsatisfactory.
The talkiu or exhortation is pronounced over
the grave to assist the dead in replying and
the dead are believed to rise slightly and
listen to it. See also wangkirun.]
munkir. See inungkir (retract, deny).
munsang. See niusang (civet- cat).
munshi. [Hind., from Ar.] Moonshee#; teacher of
an Oriental language; ct. munshi, hbrti-nya
guru atau pengajar dalam bahasa - bahasa
(«moonshec», i.e. a teacher or language-
instructor), Ht. Abd. 27.

mufa.

to bring up, e.g.: muntahkan bueh (to vomit
froth), Mai. Annals 21; muntahkan darah
(to bring up blood), Mai. Annals 81; rnun-
tahkan gbmala (to bring up a luminous
bezoar), Gul Bak. 84. Mabok in.: drunk and
vomiting. M. belut: a medicinal wood, sp.
unid.; lit., «eel’s vomit#. M. berak, m. cheret:
cholera,=taun. M. bumi: tree, Eurycoma
1 o n g i f o 1 i a; Bkl.
M lombu: name given to an old Malay
family claiming descent from Bat or Batala,
the herald who came out of the mouth of Sang
Sapurba’s bull, cf. Mai. Annals 21, 80. M.
monggek; glutted and sick with over-eating.
M. uangui: «wild-boar vomit#,—a name given
to white earthworms. M. pelandok betina:
name for an Ardisi a. For m. -m. darah
see kedadak.
[The members of the Muntah Lembu
family are still (Pk.) hereditary custodians
of the coronation-formula (chiri) and of the
Perak State Secret.]
muntaha. [Ar.: terminated, ended, final] Sidrat al-
muntaha: Lote-tree of Paradise beyond which
no living soul can pass (Bost. Sal. i 27); see
sidrat.
muntahi, Ar. Advanced student of mysticism. Cf.
mubtadi (neophyte) and mutawasit (continu-
ant); as a muntahi the student enters the
final stage and stands in the very presence
of Absolute Truth.

Abang di-laut Tanjong Jati;
Julita’s tresses may be long,—
They twine below her knee,
Yet ere the robin’s matin - song
I shall be far at sea.

rase;

ni. choreng; = (Java) linsang; also dSlun-

pulut; (Pat.) m. sbbarau; m. teberau; =
(Java) luak;

m. mongkuang; (Java) musang;
(vi) Cynogale spp.; ra. babi; = (Java)
bompfirang.
The bear-cat, Arcti c t i s, is also in.
turun, binturun, benturong, untarong,
tenturong, nienurong, raenturun, = (Java)

fimpis ra.: a bindweed, sp. unid.; known

Comes a pair of maidens gay,

Still unwarned that civets prey.

mustm. [Ar. mausin] Season. Also (Min.) musin.
Etym., anything that occurs once a year
such as the harvest (ni. padi); but used
much more loosely in modern Malay, cf.: m.
kesukaran (hard times); in. kelaparan
(famines); in. dainai (times of peace); in.
lechah (rainy weather); in. eimbang (un-
certain weather); in. singar (a time when
there are dangers about), Hn,; in. padi
binasa (periods when the rice-crop fails);
in. yang panting (critical times), etc.; Üb.
Kayu 1,2. More precisely of the seasons and
of events depending on the seasonal winds
or rains such as: the «kite-flying season® (ni.
orang bermain layang-layang), the «ta in poi
crop* (in. buah tompui niasakl, the «coming
of the Bugis ships* (in. Bugis datang), the
rice-planting season (in. piama), Ch. Jen.
69. The true «monsoons* are generally the
«dry» (in. koniarau, ni. tenggujoh, m. teng-
kujoh) and the «wet» (in. bah, in. liujan,
ni. ISchah, Java rendeng); or the N.E. (in.
utara) and the S.W. (in. selatan, in. teng-
gara); or in greater detail:
(i) February to April (m. kSmarau);
(ii) May (m. pancharoba);
(iii) June to September (m. selatan, in.
Jawa);
(iv) July (in, keniarau kfichil);
(v) August and September (m. p6nghujan,
in. piaina);
(vi) October (m. pancharoba);
(vii) November, December and January
(in. utara, in. gelora, in. tutnp kuala, m.
kelanibu menunggal.). Bergilir m.: the
circle or change of the seasons; Mai. Dem.
21. Enggang m.: horn bill (either Rhytido-
ceros undulatus or Cranorrhinus
c o r rug a t u s). M. sndah kasip: (Java) the
monsoon is nearing its close.

na. I. Ar. Our. A possessive pronominal
suffix (masc. and fern.) of the first person
plural; e.g. saidi-na Muhammad (our Lord
Mohammed).

= (Mal.) ya, itu - lah, bagitu - lah.

nabawiyat. = nabuyat.
nabi. Ar. Inspired preacher of God; « Prophet*.
Of Mohammed (n. Muhammad), Christ (n.
Isa), and great religious figures such as
Abraham (n. Ibrahim), Isaac (n. Isahak),
and even Jethro (n. Shuaib), Jonah (n.
Yunus), Khidzr (n. Khidzir) and St. George
(n. Jirjis). Cf. rasul.
Hijrat n.: A.H., see hijrat. Nabi - nabi;
a name for the seven - pointed starfish; also
for a large holothurian; Dl. Madinat al-n.:
the «Prophet’s City*; Medina.
[Moslems distinguish between major
prophets who had a definite new gospel of
their own. and minor prophets who confined
themselves to the true religion then existing
(Islam, q.v,). The former include Seth (the
special prophet of the Sabaeans), Moses (of
Judaism), and Christ (of Christianity); see
mursal. Mohammed brought the last or
completing revelation (khatam al-nabuat),
Bost Sal. ii 52; he is regarded therefore as
<?the prophet* (al-n.) or «head of all the
prophets* (ponghulu anbia).]
nabu. (Min.) Stone with flesh adhering to it. Of
fruits like the jack and durian; Tn.
nabuat. [Hind, nabuwat; Ar. nubuwat]
Prophecy; inspired Gospel (see note to nabi);
(also) inspiration, i.e. the gift or faculty of
prophecy, Host. Sal. i 107. See s.v. khatam.
nabuyat. Ar. Hijrat nabnyat; year of the Moslem

nafas. [Ar. nafs, nafas] Etym.,= «respiration;
breath*. With three meanings:
(i) breath, life, usually napas, q.v.; cf.
tiap-tiap yang bSrnafas itu (everything
that breathes, every living thing), Ht. Abd.
304;
(ii) the pride of life or lust of the flesh,
= nafsu, q.v.; and
(iii) conscious existence in contr. to mere
life (roll, ruh) that persists even when a
man is asleep or unconscious.
nafek, (Pk.) False; Wt. Cf. nafi.
nafi. Ar. Rejected, denied, Nafikan: to reject;
Sh. Mard.'
liaftri, [Pers. nafir; Hind, nafiri] A trumpet
treated as a special appurtenance of royalty
(Mai. Annals 7,6 G, 149, 157) and forming
part of the royal band. Also napiri, nem-
piri and lempiri. lIId. Mai. Magic 40. See
uobat.
[lt is thought sacrosanct and haunted by
a jinn.; at an installation it is sounded
when the whole assembly says daulat tuanku
(long live the King); it is blown also at a
boat’s bows when the Sultan of Perak
travels up or down the Perak River and so
serves to announce his presence].
nafkall. [Hind, and Ar.] Alimony; maintenance;
the supply of the necessaries of life. M6n-
chari n.: to seek a living (Ht. Abd. 84), =
monchari rozoki. Esp. of a wife’s alimony
after divorce. N. dzahir: wife’s maintenance.
N. batiu: conjugal rights.
nafsi. Ar. The adj. of nafas, q.v.; = (i) alive;
(ii) libidinous, carnal, see nafsu.
nafsial). Ar. Conscious and rational existence. See
nafas.
nafsu, |Ar. nafs] The animal in man; see
nafas. Of the passions generally (liawa n.)
and esp. of sexual lust. N. lawamah: (in
mysticism) ungodly passions. Menahan n.:
to exercise self - control; Kal. Dam. 135.
Pfinutup n.: charm - antidote to lust. N.
nafsi sultan di - hath «v\hen passion has
sway the mind must obey*; Prov. Terlbbeh
n. perSmpuan itu daripada laki - laki: a
woman’s passions are keener than a man’s;
Oul Bak. Gl.
naga. Skr. «Dragon». Etyrn., not a saurian
but a huge snake (ular n.) with a horn
(chula n.) and on its brow a luminous bezoar
(gemala n ) with which it lights its way at
night. But the saurian is known also through
Chinese influence.
Varieties: (i) n. antaboga (leviathan); (ii)
n. balun (a mountain dragon that kills with
its tail); (iii) n. borapi (tire - breathing); (iv)
n. bura (spitting venom); (v) n. gentala
(huge and motionless, sucking in its prey
with its breath); (vi) u. jadi-jadian (man or
spirit in dragon - form); (vii) n. unibang
(great sea-serpent).
Less definite dragons of old romance are
n. gaugga, n. mas, n. sampean, n. sokma.
«Dragon - patterns* include: (i) a straight
line broken by a gap, i. e. two dragons
charging one another (n. berjuang); (ii) lines
converging and then turning aside «to roar
before charging* (n. berseru, n. tarn); (iii)
lines converging «to seize one another* (n.
biirtangkap); (iv) parallel lines or the dragon
on wheels (n. gentala); (v) conventional
dragons depicted on batek sarongs (n. bulat,
n. puspa, n. sbtala); (vi) winged dragon on
batek cloth (n. seknik).
Other «dragon» terras are: n. balun
(griping pains); n. buana, n. jimat (shrub,
Phyl lan thus pul c h e r), Bkl.; n. ko-
pulir («s!eeping dragons, as the name of an
attitude in sleep, see kbpulir); n -n.
(keelson and figure-head of river-boat; planks
in an audience-hall forming a passage or
gangway for the official controlling the arrange-
ments); n. raja (Pat., a large and most
venomous hornet nesting in the ground, =
panah Bang, tembeliang); kakap n. (dragon-
boat, long state-barge used on rivers); londar
n. (dragon’s trail; tailings or pebbly deposits
in rivers); rabngarak n. (to carry a dragon
in procession); pontoh bernaga (dragon -
shaped armlets worn by Perak princes);
ular n. bura (a very venomous snake;
probably Ancistrodon rhodostoma,
but identified also as a dark variety of
Lachesis purpureornaculatus); ayer
di-mulutn. (water from the dragon-shaped
spout of a ceremonial lustration - building);
chachiug rnenjadi ular n. («worms becoming
dragons*, i.e. beggars on horseback); n. di-
telan ular lidi («a dragon swallowed by an
asp»; an improper victimisation of the great


by the mean).

natna. Skr. Personal name; (fig.) reputation.
Namakan: to name. Bernama: named; by
name. Ternama: of known name, i.e. famous.
Keburokan n. or (slang) n. busok; bad
name; ill-repute. N. yang bahari: fair fame;
good name. «Renowned» is mashhur kena-
niaan (Isk. Dz.), or besar lagi kenamaan
(Ht. Hamz,), or simply kenamaan; cf. Mai.
Annals 41.
[A Malay has usually many «names» of
which only two are nama, i.e. his baptismal
name (n. daging, n. tuboh, n. batang tuboh)
and the familiar name by which he is known
to his family (n. kechil). Pet-names are
timang-timangan; descriptive names of all
sorts from nicknames to titles are gelar,
q.v. But n. is used loosely of a title (Hg.
Tuah 389); and in Minangkabau (where titles
are abundant and in common use as appel-
lations) n. and gelar represent sometimes
the distinction between plebeian and patri-
cian, cf. the pantnn (Must. Adat 1)
Anak itek atas dolima,
Anak lang dalam bcMukar;
Kechil tidakkan terpuji nama,
Gedang tidakkan terpuji gelar.]
