nangka. I. A fruit; specifically the jack, Arto-
carpus integrifolia; but covering also:
the soursop (n. Bfdanda; also durian 86-
landa, Bolanda); another «jack»,
A. lan ceae folia (n. pipit); and two
other plants: M allot us macros tachyus
(n. kgrbau), Bkl., and Nauclea purpu-
rascens or Sideroxylon malaccense
(nangka - nangka), W.
The yellow colour of the nangka gives a
name (burong n.) to the Malayan oriole,
Oriolus m a c u 1 a t u a; = burong kuning,
(Ked.) burong kunyit - kunyit, (Job.) terok
chanai, (Java) kepudang, sfilftmpukau. The
fruit’s rind typifies a kind of invulnerability
(kebal n.) in which the skin is rough, hard
and impenetrable; see k£bal. The long seed
of the jack describes a lozenge - pattern
(biji n.); also the long snouts of two small
mammals, viz.: Hylomys suilla (tikus
biji n.) and the Rhinosciurus squirrel
(tupai biji n.) and the scales of the red
mullet (ikan biji n.); it is used also for a
certain kind of boring tool (biji n.) with a
«lozenge-like» point. The tight inner skin of


the fruit (sarong n.) gives its name to
• tights* (soluar sarong n.). A large jack
with a pulpy tasteless inside (n. bubur) is a
derisive name for women who are «all fat
and nothing else*. A «jackfruit abscess*
(barah n.) is a long abscess down the calf
of the leg. Last of all, the sticky sap of
the jackfruit (gotah n.), which is used for
bird-lime, typifies «getting caught* or being
let down; «one man eats, another is limed*.
Of. Mai. Pant. 1096,
Adat dunia telah sudah
Sa - orang makan nangka, sa - orang
[kona getah:
The way of the world turns always
On luck and on mishap;
One man feasts on the jackfruit,
Another dies limed on its sap.

11. Nara pusi: a medicinal plant, sp. unid;

111. Nara setu: see narastflu (spikenard),
naracha, = neracha (balance; scales).
naraga, See naraka (Hell).
naraka. [Skr. naraka] Hell. Of both the Moslem
Hell (n. jahanani) and the Hindu Hell (n. -
loka), in contr. to Heaven (shurga, shurga
loka). Api n.: Fires of Hell. Isi n.: the
dwellers in Hell.
Also neraka; (Ked.) nuraka; (Min.) naraga.
[According to Moslem belief Satan and his
legions dwell in the lower strata of the earth
(pbtala bumi) and not in a world apart. The
Hells are places of torment for the souls of
the wicked; and their custodians are special
angels known as umiak zabaniah. Naraka
is described (Bost. Sal. i 68) as booking
like a tiger with 30,000 heads»; and else-
where as made up of seven strata (tujoh
lapis) to wit: (i) jahanam (the bottomless
pit) for sinful Moslems; (ii) saYr (the flaming
fire) for Christians; (iii) sakar (scorching heat)
for Jews; (iv) jahim (huge hot fire) for infi-
dels and the arrogant; (v) hatarnali or huta-
niah (intense fire) for the wrathful and the
oppressors; (vi) lazza, naraka lajah (blazing
fire) for idolaters and self-worshippers; and
(vii) hawiah (pit of darkness) for heretics and
hypocrites. But experts differ; and some
authorities assign (iv) and (v) to the Sabaeans
and the Magians; cf. Herklots 98, 99.]

naranja. Ar. Orange. Also narinji. See liman.
narasStu and narawastu. See narwastu (spikenard).
nareh. See nyaris (all but).
nargis. [Pers. and Hind, nargis from Gk.J

Sami)., Boat. Sal. i 42. Made from Andro-
pogon nardus (serai wangi). A perfume
used at certain religious ceremonies such as
circumcision and burial. Also narasfitu and
narawastu.
nas. I. [Ar. nas s] Explicit or decisive dictum

texts or quotations that put an issue outside
the region of controversy.

nasi. I. Rice in two senses: (i) as cooked in
some particular way; and (ii) ad the staple
food of the Malays.


Varieties of «cooked rice* are:
(a) rice boiled in water: (i) in a Malay
cooking pot (nasi, n. jeniah, n. tanak); (ii)
in a bamboo vessel (n. I6mang); (iii) in a
leaf-wrapper (n. datang, lopat, ketupat); (iv)
with saffron (n. kuning, u. kunyit); cf.
kadang n. (see kadang);
(b) rice steamed: (i) in a bain-marie (n.
lengat, n. tini); (ii) in a dandang (n. kukus,
n. di - dang);
(c) rice boiled: (i) in broth (n. pulau); (ii)
in coconut - milk (n. Idinak); (iii) in oil or
fat (n. minyak); (iv) with chickpea (n.
Kabuli);(v) with vermicelli (n. berkuah laksa);
(d( rice cooked with other ingredients (n.
rawan), such as (i) egg (n. telur); or (ii)
vegetable broth, etc., for invalids (n. godak);
or (iii) mixed with prawns and vegetables
(n. ulam); or (iv) meat, vegetables and
spices (n. bfiriani, n. biani);
(e) boiled rice: (i) in small balls (n.
ntoroyan); (ii) beaten soft as a pap (n.
lechek);
(f) ceremonial rice-dishes; (i) any cere-
monial dish (n. bfisar); (ii) at state banquets
(n. angkatan); (iii) at weddings (n. damai,
n. hadap - hadapan); (iv) at funerals (n.
kuning); (v) n. tingkas (white rice with a
border of coloured - rice); (vi) n. udoh (rice
with coconut - milk); (vii) bunga n. (tiered
wedding-dish of rice);
(g) condition of boiled rice: (i) clotted (n.
kepall; (ii) insufficiently boiled (n. belantah,
n. jAlantah, n. mSntah); (iii) unsoftened (n.
biji limau); (iv) perfectly boiled and crisp
(n. pulan); (v) rice-gruel (bubur n,); (vi)
clot or lump (n. sa-buku);
(h) miscellaneous: (i) ration of rice (n.
pelabur, n. ramsutn); (ii) a second helping
(n. tambah); (iii) rice heaped up on a plate
(n. ru urn bong);
Exx. of «rice» with the meaning «food»
are:
(i) b6rsaji n. (to serve up the dinner);
(ii) makan n. (to dine); (iii) n. tersaji di -
lutut (food on your knees and ready for
eating) = good luck without the least exertion.
Other expressions are: n. bSrjiangau (a
filthy form of love-philtre, see jiangau); n.
di - tus (rice boiled and then dried by
letting the moisture drip away), Hn.; n. sa-
ketul (lump of adhesive rice-grains); kepala
n. (tray of offerings to evil spirits); makan
n. kawah (to eat cauldron - boiled food) =
to work as a coolie or one of a gang; lagi
lauk lagi n. (the more curry the more rice
eaten with it) = the more food the more
friends or followers; Prov.
11. N. ritnba; a plant, Vitex vestita.
N. sejok: (Ked.) a plant, Salacia sp.
Chaching n.: (Pk.) a worm, sp. unid. See
also nasek.
111. The white contents of a pimple when
squeezed; Hn. Cf. nasek-nasek.
nasib. Ar. Lot in life; destiny. Untong n.: id.
Bawa n.: to trust to one’s luck. Menchubaf
n.: to chance one’s luck. N. bSdebah, n.
chelaka, n. inalang, n. di-timpa nialang:
persistent bad luck. Apa boleh buat, sudah
untong n.: it is fated and what can oue do?
Often pronounced nasip.
nasihat. Ar. Advice; moral of story. Menasihat:
to counsel; Gul Bak. 82. Penasihat: mentor;
adviser. Banyak n. keluar daripada - nya:
there was much sound advice that he had to
give; Ht. Abd. 114.
nasik, = nasek (plant - name),
nasip. See nasib (destiny).
Nasir. A proper name; = Ar. nasir (helper).
nasir. Ar. Comrade. In its plural form (ansar,
ansari) this word is used of the Prophet’s
most loyal followers and helpers.
naskhah. [Ar. nuskhat] Exemplar; prototype;
original text. Of the ‘authorized version* of
the old Testament (n. taurit yang sail) as
given in the Septuagint (Bost. Sal. i 10G);
of the text and copyright of a work bought
for publication (Gul Bak. 156); etc.
Nasnas. Ar. Name of a legendary tribe of half -
men or cloven men, i.e. men with one eye,
one ear, one nostril, one cheek, one breast,
one arm, one leg, half a mouth, etc. (Bost.
Sal. i 78). Said to have spoken Arabic and
to have lived on the shores of the Indian Ocean.
nasratli. Ar. Etym.=:«Nazarene», i.e. any Christian,
and so used; Bost. Sal. i 68, 80, Pr. Acheh
8. But commonly of Malacca Portuguese
(Ht. Abd. 39) and Catholics generally; cf.
bahasa n. (Portuguese), Ht. Angg. 92.
Protestants are specifically masehi.
Also (coll.) serani.


Nasruan. A coll, variant of the name Nushirwan,
q.v.
Nasturiat. Ar. The Nestorian Christians, Bost.
Sal. i 81.
nasut. [Ar. nas (man) and the Aramaic final
u t] Humanity, Man. Alain n.: the world of
men; mankind.
nata. [Skr. nat’ha] Protector; lord. Only as a
royal honorific: sang-n. (His Sacred Majesty);
paduka n. (H.M.); indora n. (His Divine
Majesty); etc.
natal. I. (Batav., from Port.) A name for
Christmas. Hari n.; id.
11. A tree, Crudia curtisii; W.
natang. [Siam.?] French window opening down to
the ground but protected by a balustrade;
Pg. Ptg. Pintu n.: (Ked.) postern; back-
door; tradesman’s entrance; = pintu nialing,
natar. I. [Jav. la tar, Mad. natar] Basic
colour; background. Chindai n. kuning:
chindai-cloth of which yellow is the main
tint; Ht. Sh., Mai. Annals 218. See batok;
cf. latar, dasar.
11. Level; = datar.
nathrat. Ar. Th ree or four small stars in the
«nose» of Leo—constituting the eighth lunar
mansion; Bost. Sal. i 49.
nati. Fool. Hai n., aKu-lah raja di gunong:
thou fool, it is I who am king of the moun-
tains; Sh. Kub.
nail. (Java) Sugar-palm, Arenga saccha-
rifera; Sid. Rama 178. Also 6nau, aren,
(Min.) anau, and (Mai.) kabong.
nauli. Nauli-nauli: a shrub, Ardisia colo-
rata; W.
naung. Shadowing; shelter. Naungi: to give
shelter to. Bernaung: to take shelter under;
Ht. Abd. 338. KAringkan pada n.: dry it in
a shady place; Kit. Muj. 58. Di-bawah n.
kayu; under the shade of a tree; Ht. Best.
natiring. Vulture; Dl. See no’reng.
nauroz. [Pers. nan-roz] New Year’s Day.
naushadar or naushadir. See nnshadar (sal -
ammoniac).
nawab. [Ar.; through Hind.] «Nabob»; viceroy (of
the Great Mogul), a title retained by such
«Viceroys» even after becoming independent;
«Nawab» of Bengal; Ht. Abd. 74, 76.
[But Abdullah confuses him probably
with the great Mogul.]
naya. (Pen.) Injustice; wrong; = aniaya, q. v.
nayab. (Pal.) Theft by daylight; Tk. iii 311.
nayah. B6rnayah -nayah: (Ked.) in heaps; in
quantities.
nayaka, Jav. State-councillor; Tk. iv. 703.
nayam. Blade of a plough-share. Also (Malacca,
Batav.) lanjam.
Nayan. Ar. A proper name; short for S6nayan,
= ithnain (second day, Monday).
nayan. Lanyard.
nayub, nayuban. Sund. A feast accompanied by
a dance by professional dancing-girls; B.
naza. Ar. Moribund; in extremis.
nazam. Ar. Composing; see nadzam.
nazar. Ar. Vow; Ht. Angg. 116, = nadzam, q.v.
nebeng. (Kel., from Siam, nai-ban) Village headman;
= ketua kampong.
neeinat. [Hind, from Ar.] Anything pleasant; a
delicacy; a joy. Of sweetmeats (Mai. Dewa
85, Ht. Angg. Ill) and delicious food gene-
rally (Gul Bak. 33); also of the pleasures of
this world and the joys of the next (Ht.
Abd. IG3, 318).
Also nemat, Mai. Dewa 85.
nega. Skr. Kind; species; = neka and aneka.
nggara. I. Skr. City, esp. capital-city. A courtly
form of nSgeri, q.v. Common in poetry (Sh.
Rej. 4, Pr. Turki 3); in city-names such as
Amdan-n., Gangga-n., Bija-n. (Mai. Annals
10, 11, 33); and in titles, e.g. Mangku N.
(second prince at Solo); etc.
11. Skr. Negara bukit; level space on
hill-summit, cf. penara bukit. Etym., the
site of hermit-settlements on hilltops.
111. [Pers. and Hind, nagarati] Drum
(portable, sacrosanct and reserved for
royalty); Mai. Annals 66, 85, 149; illd, Mai.
Magic 40. See nobat. Also nfikara, lengkara
and (Ht. Bugis 52) nSuggara; (Brun.)
nakara, M.


[ln India the nagarah is a small drum
beaten by public criers; it corresponds to the
gong pengerah, chanang or mongmong. In
Malaya it is a royal larangan but ranks
naturally after the heavier gendang
nobat or big drum kept at the palace to
announce the prince’s doings. It is also part
of a nobat-band in India. In Brunai it is
covered with monitor-lizard skin].
ngggri. Skr. Settlement; city - state; = (Min.)
nagari. Used loosely (Mai.) of any settle-
ment, town or land, e. g.: n. China (China);
n. akhirat (the world to come); n. dan dusun
(towns and villages), Bost. Sal. i 69; metn-
buat u. or mumbuka n. (to found a colony);
di - tanali Kbling di-n. Nagur (at Nagore
in Southern India), Ht. Abd. 3. More
specifically (Min.) of an autonomous area or
group of villages under a penghulu andeka
(N.S., undang) or other territorial Chief, e.g.
Negeri Sombilan (the «Nine States*, each
autonomous though collectively under a
suzerain).
Anak n.: native of a place. Buah n.:
yassion-fruit, Passi flora edulis. Ekur
n.: down-river end of a river-side village.
Ibu n., kepalan.: metropolis; capital; mother-
city. Isi n.: citizens of a place. Kuching
n.: domestic cat. Pasak n. or turns u.:
linchpins or pillars of the state; magnates.
Sa -n. -n.: all over the town. Sidang u.:
general public. Hujan mas pei’ak n. orang,
hujan kerfs lembing n. kita: though it
rain gold and silver I am among aliens; though
it rain spears and daggers it is still my own
home; = there is no place like home; Prov.
Cf. balad, negara.
nggrah, = anugbraha (favour, gift).

neneh. Meneneh: (Ked.) to ooze out, as matter

ancestors, also dato’-n. N. saudara and n.
sanak dato’: grand-aunt. N. serta kakek:
grandparents.
Saudara sa-n.: first cousin; cousin-german;
Bost. Sal. ii 81.
See also nenenda, nenekda, and uenda.
Nenek is shortened sometimes (Ked., Pen.)
to nek, in which case nek = «grandmother»,
and to’ - nek = ancestors*.
N. kebayan: see kobayan.

nesan. I. [Pers. nishan: emblem] Gravestone;
—properly batu n. Also nishan, ningsan,
nian, inahesan and (N.S.) mejan. N. bulut:
rounded head-stone (for a man’s grave). N.
pipeh: flattened head-stone (for a woman’s
grave). Mari sa-kubnr bernesan dua: let
them inter us together, two stones to a single
grave; Pant. Mai. 837.
[Properly speaking there should be two
nesan: cf. dua biji n. di-beri tCntu, Sh.
May. G. The larger (at the head) is known
as rantau kfipala and may be elaborately
carved; illd. Winstedt’s «Malaya»; Colijn’s
«Nederlands Indie»; J.S.A.S. 85 and Vol,
iv pt. 3. The other (rantau pinggang) over
the middle of the body is smaller and simpler.
But poorer graves (kuburan) may have one
rough nesan with a line of stones (illd. Veth
Ixxxvi 2).J

topsail), n. tabur (lower royal). The upper is
upar. But these sails were rarely divided in
two, the ships being small.

nira. Skr. Fresh palm-sap (obtained by cutting

no. See nya (his, her, its).
nobat. [Persj. nau- b a t: nine items] Royal band
of «nine items»; (specifically) the principal
drum (gendang n.) of that band. Nobatkan:
to instal (a Sultan) by beat of the royal
drum (beaten only for Sultans); Mai. Annals
162, 170, = tabalkan. Bernobat: to be the
owner of the nobat, i.e. to be royal, to be
installed as a king; Ht. Bugis 21. Menobat;
(Orang Laut) to hold a seance of ghostly
powers; = (Mai.) berhantu. N. di-palu: the
royal drum was beaten (Mai. Annals
34),=bertitir n. (Ht. Best.).
[The full band consists of: (1) the big
drum or gfindang n.; (2) the royal trumpet
(nafiri); (3 and 4) the two royal kettle-
drums (negara); (5 and 6) two non - royal
pipes (serunai); and (7 and 8) two common
drums (gfindang). The conductor is the
ninth «item». The gfindang n. ( the most
sacrosanct item of all, is the Indo - Persian
tabl (see tabal) or drum beaten outside an
Eastern palace to announce to the people
the doings of their King; cf. Omar Khayyam’s
«Nor heed the rumbling of a distant drum»,
which refers to this palace-instrument. It is
a signal-drum like the mosque bfidok or
gendang ray a, and is once described (Mai.
Annals 71) as a gendang ray a. The nafiri
(with its single note) was blown when
homage was paid to the King; and the two
nfigara are of a type in common use under
the same name as crier’s drums in India.
In Malaya criers use gongs (chanang, mong-
niong); and the negara is associated with
royal announcements. It will be understood
that the palace - drum ranked highest and
was only beaten for royalty. But the Sultan
might send out the other instruments in
greater or less number' —to escort a mission
or honour a funeral; and the extent of the
honour varied with the instruments sent: the
negara with a white umbrella ranked highest;
the nafiri with a yellow umbrella ranked
after; and the non-royal instruments graced
minor occasions; cf. Mai. Annals 66. The
bandsmen were members of a particular family
(the orang Kalur) and their band-stand was
fenced in with cocks’ feathers; any tres-
passer in the charmed circle was punished
with a heavy fine].

nuni. A term of abuse applied to a Tamil; Mai.

nupin. Ikan nupin: a fish, sp. unid.
Nur. A masc. proper name; see nur, Noh.
nur. Ar. Light, —whether the solar light by
which men see, or the primal light that
illumined chaos at the Creation, or the light
of divine revelation that guides men to Truth.
God Himself is the Light (i.e. the Enlightener)
of heaven and earth; Kor. xxiv 35. N.
ahadiat: the Light that was in the beginning;
the Divine Light; (in mysticism) the True
Light. N. Muhammad: the light of divine
revelation in Muhammed; the soul of Moham-
med regarded as an emanation (panchar) of
the Divine Light; Bost. Sal. i 8. N. urfani:
spiritual light, the intuition that enables
God’s saints to distinguish unerringly truth
from falsehood.
Ya n. al - ain: «0 Light of my Eyes®, —
an invocation of God the Enlightener used
as a heading for love-letters; Wt.Mai.Grammar.
Ya n. al-ashikin: 0 Light of True Lovers,
a similar expression. Ya n. al-sliamsu
waT-kamar: «0 Light of the Sun and of
the Moon»; a similar heading to letters
addressed to persons who are illustrious but
not with the light of the True Faith.
Nur is used also as a proper name.
[From a ray of the nur ahadiat God
created the nur Muhammad, the world’s
guiding light. From certain aspects of this
light God made the soul of Mohammed
(nyawa M.) in the form of a peacock. From
an emanation of the nur Muhammad God made
the souls of His Prophets (anbia). From the
Light of the Prophets God made the souls
of His Saints (aulia). See Host. Sal, i Bj.
nuracha. See neraeha (scales, balance).
nuraka. See naraka (Hell).
nuratli. [Pers. nurani from Ar. nur] Lustrous;
illumined, whether by solar light or by the
light of religion or (in mysticism) by the
Light that knows no Illusion. Hati n.: the
heart of the true believer (Sh. May. 22) or
of the mystic. Tuan umpama bintang n.,
makin di - tentang bertambah torang: my
love is like a gleaming star whose lustre
waxes as I gaze; Mai. Pant. 90. Also Gul
Hak. 76, Sid. Rama 164.
nurap. (W. Sura.) Covering; plastering; = men-
urap from (Mai.) turap.
nurbisa. [Hind, nir-vish; Skr. nirvisah =
unvenomed)] Antidote to venom; countercharm
(to draw poison out of a wound).
Nurdin. Ar. A masc. proper name; = nur al-din,
nuru’d-din; commonly shortened to Din.
nuri. Parrot; lory. Burong n.: id. Specifically
of Lori us spp., but used of all parrots.
Ikan n. -n.: wrass, Cheilinus spp.,
ikan bayan.
nurmala. Skr. Faded; e.g. bunga sSri gading
sudah n. (scentless and dead are the flowers
of the srigading), Ism. Yat.
Nurudin. See Nurdin.
Nus. Ar. A masc. proper name; short for
Junus or Unus or Yunus (Jonah).
nus, (Ked.) A gen. name for Cephalopods: n.
chomek (small Loligo javanica), u.


karang (Sepia spp.), n. kereta (octopus),
n. torak (large Lol i g o java n i c a). Cf,
sotong, gnrita, pompong, mangsi.
nusa. I. Jav. Island (only in island-names, not
in speaking of an island); e. g.: Nusantara
(=Nusa Antara); N. Tamara (Flores), Mai.
Annals 36.
11. (Batav.) The day after tomorrow; =
(Mai.) lusa.
nushadar or nushadir. (Hind naushada r,=Pers.
n a v - s h a d u r; Skr. narasara] Sal-ammo-
niac; chloride of ammonium. Coll.; sadir.
Nushirwan. [Pees, nnshirwa n;=Pazend anosh-
rua n, Pehl. anoshak-ruwan (of immor-
tal soul)] Name by which Chosroes the
Great is known. Traditionally a very just
ruler (N. adil, the Just); a reputed ancestor
of the Malayan dynasty (Mai. Annals 9);
referred to briefly in the Bostan (ii 23); and
associated with the «Ninety-nine Laws» of
Perak. Not to be confused with another
Chosroes (Khusrau Parwiz) best known as
the lover of Shirin and for having torn up
contemptuously the Prophet’s letter to him
(Bost. Sal. ii 24) even as his own kingdom
was doomed «to be torn to pieces*.
nusta. See nista (abuse).
nusus. [Ar. nushuz] Recalcitrant. Of a wife who
refuses to cohabit with her husband and may
therefore be divorced with the loss of her
marriage-settlements (mahar).
nutfah or nutfat. Ar. Germ ot life; sperms
hominis. According to Moslem embryolo-
gists n. the combination of the three
seminal elements (mani, madzi, wadzi) that
create the «blood-clot» (darah yang beku)
from which the embryo is developed; Ht.
Bugis 1. Also jauhar, rnanikam.
nuwi. [Pers. shahr al-nuwi] A name for
Ayuthia; Mai. Annals 50, 75. Properly shahr-
i-nau (the new capital city). Used loosely for
Siam itself in the days when Ayuthia was
its capital.
nya. I. Name of the last letter of the Malay
alphabet. Not an Arabic letter. Pronounced
like the Ital. gn oi Port, ah, i.e. as the n
sound (like ny) in «new», «neuritis». Has
the cabalistic value 7000 in the abjad.
11. Its; his; hei; a pron. suffix of the
third person, =(Min.) no, na. Cf. Min, inya
(that, it, him, her); = (Mai.) ia. Kata-nya;
his saying was; he said. Di-dengar-nya: in
his hearing was, i.e. he heard. In Kel. nya
is used for ia, esp. respectfully.
nyadar. See nyedar (sound asleep).
nvadi. Nyadi bukit: a tree, Crypteronia
griffithii; W.
nyah, I. Be off; to disappear. Also finyah.
Nyah-lah Sngkau dari sini: clear out of
this place; Lang. Buana 79. Di-nyahkan-lah
daripada nbgori-nya: he was made to quit his
country; Ind. Meng. Also of a prince going
into hiding without quitting his country;
Mai, Annals 71. Of. Kal. Dam. 384, Ht.
Abd. 296.
11. See nah (there!).
nya'i I. (Bali and old literature) Younger sister;
beloved; = (Mal.) adinda; cf. nya'i pfingantin
(his bride), Ind. Nata; seri nyal radin galoh
adinda puteri, Ht. Sh.;— kakang dan ny;
sakalian (all you sisters of mine, = ladies
all), Ht. Koris. Also (N. 1.) a name given to
native mistresses of Europeans from the fact
that in early times they were usually Bali-
nese women. Etym., a low-caste term.
11. See niayi (lady, madam). Nya! Seri:
(Java) the Goddess Sri as the good genius
of the Rice-Crop, =dewi Seri.
nyak. I. Nyakkan: (Pk.) to push a man down
to the ground.
11. (Min.) Will; shall; = hSndak, nak.
Nyak ka-mana: where are you going.
nyala. Flaming; to Hare up. Menyala: to glow,
e.g. of tire «flaming up like the fiery furnace
ot Niueveh» (bernyala-nyala laksana api
raja Namrud), Gul Bak. 149.
nyalang. (Pen.) Run wild (of a cat); = jalang,
q.v.
nyali. (Batav., from Bal.) Gall; = hempedu,
kuaya.
nyarnan. I. Healthy feeling; the sense of well -
being. Also (loosely) = sedap (pleasant).
Makan ta’ - ny.: getting no enjoyment from

nicely; Sh. Ibl. 2. Demam kepialn ny.;
«benign» fever; mild enteric; in contr. to
high fever with delirium (deraatn kfipialu
radang).

(Stegomyia).

11. To babble; Sh. Old and doting; silly
and forgetful; Hn. Cf. nyanyok.
nyanyak. (Min.) Wet through; drenched.
nyanyi. Singing. M6nyanyi: to sing; Gul Bak.
11, 108, = menarokan ny. PCnyanyi;
minstrel, Ht. Panj. 43. ny. musical
box; gramophone. Shaer nyanyian: verses
intended for singing; song; Jub. Mai. 2.
BCrnyanyikan apa-lah budak kutok ini:
what is this young rascal warbling about;
Ht. Koris.
Apa-lah übat hati yang dendam,
Gesek biola tarekkan nyanyi:
For a heart that pines with longing
What solace is there yet?
The long-drawn note of a viol
That sweetens a song of regret.
nyanyok. In one’s dotage; Ht. Best. Orang tua
ny.; dotard. Cf. babok, nyanyah.
nyap. Nyap-nyap: (onom.) the «cheep» of young
chickens; twittering. Cf. chiap - chiap.
nyapang. Companion. Jangan di-16paskan takut
terkejut ny.: do not let it go lest your
fiiend be alarmed; Ht. Koris.
nyarak. (Min.) Burning up brightly (of a flame).
nyarang. (Batav.) A herb, Cyathula prostrata;
varieties: ny. merah, ny. puteh. Used
medicinally; Baus., Bkl. Also menjarang,
pen jarang, daun jarang-jarang.
nyarap, (doh.) To plug or cork; to close an orifice.
nyareh. See nyaris (nearly; all but).
nyaring. Clear (of utterance); shrill or high-pitched
(of the voice). Maha-ny.: very shrill or pier-
cing (of a sound); Isk. Dz. Of speaking
very distinctly (dengan ny. snara-nya, Sg.
Samb); of a dragon shrilling loud and
clear so that his words were unmistakable
(demikian kata naga itu - pun, ny. - ny.
juga suara-nya), Ind. Jaya.
nyaris. Well-nigh; all but. Nyariskan: id.; Sh.
Kub., = ny. akan. Ny. lepas dari tangan:
it was touch and go that he did not slip
through their fingers (i.e. die), Mai. Annals
154. Ny. ta’ - mat! karna rachun, matt
kerling sa-eknr mata: poisoned viands all
but slew me; now your smile has slain me
quite; Mai. Pant.
Also (Min.) nareh, nyareh.
nyaru. Nyaru bukit; a shrub, Pseud e r a n-
themum crenulatum; W.
nyaruan or nyarwan. (Batav.) A kind of bee or
hornet, sp. unid.; Tk. iv. 472, (Mai.)
nernan.
nyarum. Plant-name for many shrubs (R ub i-
aceae) that suggest a needle; see jarum.
nyata. [Skr. niyata.] Obvious; plain; manifest.


Nyatakan: to make known; to show plainly.
Kenyataan: explanation; announcement. Di -
pandang ny.: seen quite distinctly; Cr. Gr.
18. Khabar yang b6tul lagi ny.: news
that is reliable and definite. Also of facts
made plain by proof in a law-court; (Ht.
Abd. 173); and (Trengg.) of the manifest
of a ship (pdnyata muatan kapal), Mn.
nyatoh. Gen. name for certain trees of the genera
Pay e n a and Palaq u i u in that produce
a good class of timber (kayu ny.). Esp.
Payena costata and Palaq u i u m
j a v e n s e.
nyawa. Life; soul (in the Moslem sense); life or
soul as a term of endearment. The word is
highly specialized in meaning.
(i) Ny. = clife* (Gk. aveupa = Ar. ru h)
in its association with the breath (menyawa
=to breathe heavily, as in sleep), and in
the narrow sense of not being dead. Cf.
jikalau ny. kita tiada lagi: if we no longer
have ny., i.e. if we are dead; Ht. Bugis 39.
Ny. remains even though the body may be
asleep or unconscious or in extreme illness; cf.;
ny.-ny. ikan (at the last gasp), Ht. Abd.
44; berny, rapoh, or ny pergi ny. datang,
or ny. seperti telur di - hujong tandok
(frail tenure of life). It is distinct from
intelligent consciousness or the sense of
personality (Ar. nafs). Animals possess it
(binatang itu berny a wa, Bur. Glat. 14, SG);
and even plants (cf. ny, nabati). See also
semangat.
(ii) Ny. is «life» in common expressions
such as losing one’s life (putus ny.); having
a frail tenure of life (bfirnyawa rapoh);
offering up one’s life (bersembahkan ny., Hg.
Tuah 256); running for one’s life (bawa ny.);
throwing it away (inembuangkan ny.);
escaping with it (melepaskan ny.); or
begging for it (rainta ny.; Ht. Bangs 29,
Ht. Angg. 86), Also fig., whether of the
beloved being precious as one’s life or of
two or more people being as one; cf. lima
badan satu ny. (of a united family), Ht.
Bugis 47. But it is not «life» in the sense
that a biography is the history of a «life»;
this is kohidupan (Ht. Abd. 1).
(iii) Ny. is «soul» (Gk. in the sense
that it can exist apart from the body. The
Bostan says (i 86) that God created Adam’s
nyawa (translating Ar. a rw a b) 2000 years
before his body (jasad). This ny. entered
the earth of which Adam was made by way
of the fontanel and turned it into living
flesh and blood. So also the «souls» of the
unborn and even of the unconceived are
made to utter praise to God (Host. Sal. i
9). Death is the departure of this ny. (b6r-
cherai ny. daripada tuboh), Ht. Abd. 29;
and a pantun speaks of the nyawa weeping
by the side of the tomb wishing to return
once more to the earth (ny. menangis
di - pintu kubur hcndak balek kadalam
duuia). But it is not this ny. that lives
immortal in Heaven or Hell. The blows of
Munkar and Nakir fall on the actual human
body; and it is a new and incorruptible body
that enjoys the Moslem paradise (Host. Sal.
i 45).
(iv) The ny. is regarded by the orthodox
as an emanation (panchar) from the Primal
Light (see nur), either directly or through
the Light of God’s Saints. But mystics who
do not believe in individual souls use nyawa
of the All-Soul, the ny. rahmani, which is
composite. It is made up of the soul of all
plants (ny. nabati), animals (ny. haiwani),
human bodily lives (ny. jismani) and human
spiritual lives (ny. roliani).
(v) Ny. is used also of the Christian idea
of the Holy Ghost; Host. Sal. i 81.
nyaya. Skr. Injustice; wrong; Ht. Bugis 32, =
aniaya, q.v.
nyebeng, = ngebeng or mengebeng (to join in a
dance); see ebeng.
nygdar and nygdgra. Sound (of sleep). Also ng6-
dar and (Kel.) jendSra, chfindora, nidera.
Ny. laksana terkona pukau: dead to the
world as a man drugged; Lail. Mejn. 6.
nyeh, (Onom.) Blowing the nose; = ngeh.
nygligi. To prod; to dig with the finger; see
seligi.
nygnyai. Loosely made. Of a woven fabric such
as cloth or carpet.
nygnyak. (Borneo; Tk., also Batav.?) Deep, of
sleep (ny. tidur); Bur. Glat. 33, Ht. Panji
71, Ht. Bangs. 32, Si Jamin 10.
nygnyamok, = nyamok-nyamok (tree-name).
nygnyaring. Spokes (of an umbrella), = jaring -


jaring.
ny£nyaru. (Ked.) A plant, sp. unid. Cf.nyaru.
nyPnyarum. See nyarum, jarum (plant-name).
nyenye. (Batav.) To become molten or thin; to
flow; Dl. Cf. nyernyer.
nyenyeh. I. Mfiuyenyeh: to keep repeating impor-
tunately. Of a person pressing a gift on some
one who is unwilling to take it; of talking
on in a maudlin way; (Baba) of a dotard who
talks inconsequently. Cf. also nyenyen
(badgering) and nyonyeh (mumbling).
11. A pirate captain.
nyenyen. Teasing; worrying. Of children who will
not let another child have an}’peace but keep
mocking him.
nyenyet. Puffed or pulled out a little; Hn.
nySnyulong. (Ked., Pat.) Long-snouted ;=jenjnlong
and joloug-jolong. Of garfish, the gharial,

ny£pit. (Batav.) To compress; menybpit, see

nyernyer. (Batav.) Thin; loosely woven. Of basket-

nyenyai.
nyeyag. (Batav., from Sund.) To snap (as a dog).
nyiat. Nyiat-nyiat: a medicinal herb, sp. unid.,
used as a remedy for the itch.
nyigap. To stand at attention. Cf. sikap.
nyih, =nyeh (to blow the nose).

=menchinta.
nyingnying. (Batav., from Bal.) A sp. of mouse.
nyior, =nyiur (coconut).
nyireh. A sea-shore tree, Cara pa obovata;
its bark is used in tanning; Mai. Annals 80,
Pant. Mai. 317. Also (Sel. nyiris; and nireh,
niris.
nyiris. See nyireh (tree-name).
nyiru, A basket- tray, pointed and almost heart-
shaped, on which grain is tossed up and
shaken to rid it of dust and chaff after
pounding. Illd. Achehnese i 2.
Bingkai ny.: outer frame of winnowing
pan; (fig.) part of a buffalo’s intestine prized
as a titbit.
Also (Min.); = the Menado-Mal. sasiru,
Tk. A round winnower is badang.
nylur. Coconut, Cocos nuci f e r a;=Min. niur.
But esp, the fresh coconut, in contr. to copra
(Mai. kfilapa; Sum. kelambir, kfirambil).
Kelapa is sometimes in commoner use (Riau,
Joh., Sel.) than nylur (Ked., Pk., Sum ),
even for the fresh coconut.
Varieties (C. nucifera): (i) with edible
husk (ny. bawang, kfilapa luji, ny. manis);
(ii) husk edible near stem (ny. tampok
manis); (iii) ivory-white nut (ny. gading);
(iv) small pale-green (ny. puyoh); (v) green
(ny. hijau ): (vi) dark-coloured (ny. kdsumba);
(vii) with many nuts on one stem (ny.
belolok); (viii) short palm with nuts near
ground (ny. pagai, ny. nipah). From its
association with romance the ny. gading
(Min. kfilapa niur gading, niur balai and
niur gadai) is regarded as a variety not
found on earth.
Cocoa lodoicea (C. maldiva) is
pauh janggi, not nyiur.
Tree-growth: (i) trunk just forming (Pah.
ny. sauia alu; Ked. ny. dndok umbi); (ii)
formed but not in bearing (ny. dara); (iii) in
bearing (nyiur).
Nut-growth in general: (i) on its first
appearance (murabang); (ii) ripening (ny.
muda); (iii) ripe (ny. masak); (iv) destroyed by
squirrels (ny. di-tobok tupai, kelongkongau).
Nut-growth in detail: (i) on shedding the
bud (bungsil, munibang); (ii) shell quite soft
and edible (ny. kelongkong); (iii) when
interior softens (ny. ingusan); (iv)when the
nut takes the «goat-ear» shape (ny. tfdinga
kambing); (v) when the shell is just be-
ginning to harden (ny. chungkilan, ny. sung-
kuran); (vi) when shell is hardened (ny.
tahan kukur); (vii) when darkening on one side,
(ny.gigi belalang); (viii) when the liquid inside
can be heard on the nut being shaken (ny.
semantan,); (ix) when fully ripe (ny. masak,
ny. tubal; (x) sold as a fresh nut (ny. bulat);
(xi) with the husk chopped off to lighten it
for transport (ny. gubal); (xii) preserved as
a seed-nut (ny. kotai). Dried for copra it is
kfilapa or kgrambil. Abnormalities are: (i)


aboitive (ny. komeng); (ii) milkless (nV. di-
makan bulan); (iii) with coagulated milk
(ny. ladeh, ny. dadeh).
Miscellaneous: manggar ny. (dry spikelet
from the fallen blossom); minyak ny. (oil
of the ccco mt); panglal ny. (visible root of
coconut-palm); polepah ny. (frond); tombong
ny. (seed-bud in coconut); tupai ny. (common
squirrel, Sciurus notatus); ayer niada
ny. (sap collected for sugar-making from
the severed palm-blossom of the coconut);
chinchin bunga ny. (curb -shaped ring).

T. ov a t u s .

11. Ochok - ochok; (Pen.) a rattle or
sistrum for driving or attracting fish; =

rochok, ran-ran, orok - orok, q.v. It is a

Opsir. Eur. Officer (military or naval). Patut-nya
b6rpangkat o. sebab bbngis rupa tabiat -
nya: he was the right kind of man to be an

Also afsir and apsir.
OpU. District-headman (in Celebes). This Bugis
distinction like that of daeng has some
celebrity in Malaya because the founders of
the Riau and Selangor royal houses were
styled daeng and claimed descent from an
opu; cf. Ht. Bugis 3. In this way daeng
has come to be regarded by some as the
Bugis equivalent of raja or tengku; and opu
of a yamtuan. By others a distinction is
drawn (cf. Ht. Bugis 4) between the Bugis
pirate chiefs who are styled opu daeng to
raise them above their followers who are
merely daeng.
ora. Jav. No; not.
orak. Unwinding; uncoiling; stretching oneself
out of a huddled-up position. Of living things;
for ropes, etc., being uncoiled, see urai.
Segan m6ngorak lingkar: «slow to unwind
its coils® (of a snake), i.e. slow to bestir
itself, idle, lazy; Prov. Also (loosely) of
charms for opening locks and ridding oneself
of chain-fetters; Kep. Mai. 76.
Oran. Oran merah: a climbing shrub, Neuro-
peltis racemosa; W.
Orang. I. Person; human being; num. coeff. for
human beings. Adjectivally it means «other
people’s® e.g. anak o. (another man’s child),
negeri o. (foreign countries). In compounds
it is used of social ranks and professions or
the reverse, e.g.; o. kaya (nobleman); o. besar
(dignitary); o. hanyut (loafer); o. pokah
(wastrel); o. dawa (prosecutor); o. mampu
(man of means); o. pbriman (civilian, with
special reference to civilian dress); o. tani
(peasant); etc. It is also used in national,
descriptive or tribal names like «man» in
‘Englishman* (o. Inggbris); o. sabun (albino);
o. ternak (natives of the country); and even
of impalpable fairy folk (o. halns).
For local racial or tribal names see A-kit,
Bajau, barat, Bolandas, benna, B6sisi,
biduanda, bukit, darat, Dayak, Galang,
gergasi, Hudai, hulu, hutan, Jakun,
Kobok, laut, liar, Mamak, Mantang,
Mantfira, Mayak, Melayu, Pangan, puteh,
Rawa, rayat, sakai, Sekanak, s6lat, 86-
litar, Semang, Talang, Tambus, and
tanjong.

P
Pa. I. Name of a Malay letter transliterated
as P, and given the numerical value 5000
in the abjad. The sound P does not occur
in Arabic and is represented differently in
Turkish, Persian and Hindustani. On the
other hand the Arabic F is pronounced P
in colloquial Malay; and in most Malay
writings no distinction is made between the
symbols for P and P. Purists write P with
three dots and P with only one.
11. (Ked.) A suffix giving a plural meaning
to the pronoun preceding it: sahaya (I), sahaya
pa (we); hang (thou), hang pa (you); dia
pa (they). See also sepa (sahaya pa) and depa
(dia pa). Cf. ina, denia. Less commonly apa.
pa’. Father; daddy; papa. A short and familiar
form of bapa; q.v. Applied to a father and
also to uncles and «old daddies®, not alwa}'s
respectfully. For uncles:
(ii) pa’ long, pa’ hia, pa’ hr, pa’ wa,=
eldest uncle;
(ii) pa’ bongsu, pa’ busu, pa’ chu, pa’ su,
pa’ nnchu, pa’ muda, pa’ kfichil, pa’ chik,
patik, = youngest uncle;
(iii) pa’ ngab, pa’ alang, pa’ lang, =
uncle between eldest and youngest;
(iv) pa’ saudara, pa’ penakan, = uncle
generally.
Proverbial old «daddies» include:
(i) Pa’ Belalang: a specious old humbug
associated with the «devil’s own luck®
(mujur Pa’ Belalang);
(ii) Pa’ Kadok: a legendary old idiot
whose bad luck (malang Pa’ Kadok) is a
proverb;
(iii) pa’ niMeter; prosy old fool;
(iv) pa’ mnsang: «Father Civet-Cat®; a
legendary old fox who wriggles out of every
difficulty;
(v) Pa’ Pandir: the typical Juggins who
makes an amusing mess of all he under-
takes;
(vi) Pa’ PCchekok, Pa’ P6chokok, To’
BMiau: «old what’s his-name», any un-
pleasant old nuisance;
(vii) Pa’ Pulas: «old Squeezer»=any
Shylock;
(viii) pa’ randok: «the old billy goat®, =
(i) tiger; (ii) old profligate;
(ix) pa’ sambnt: plagiarist; parasite;
(x) Pa’ Sanggup: «Daddy who pleads
guilty*, i.e. a man who marries a woman
already pregnant;
(xi) Pa’ Sauk: «Daddy Scooper®, =
sneak-thief;
(xii) Pa’ Si-B6ndnl: «Daddy Sit-on-the
doorstep®, the rustic gossip or thick-
headed countryman.
For pa’ tiang and pa’ awang; see tiang,
awang.

[Each layer of these official mats being
smaller than the one below it, the number
of folds is visible at once.]

IF. Boundary; common portion. Usually

padang. I. Treeless waste land; (loosely) treeless
plain; cf. pada tiap - tiap segala yang di-
jijak nabi Allah Adam ilu dan
dusun, dan barang yang tiada di-jijak
Nabi Allah Adam itu jadi rimba dan p.:
at every spot where Adam set foot there
sprang up towns and villages; and every
spot he did not tread became jungle or
treeless waste; Bost. Sal. i 59. Varieties: p.
anak (desert); p. jarak, p. tokukur (abandon-
ed land); p. tandas or (Sul. Hid, 5) p.
tandus (bare uncultivated country); p. sau-
jana or (Min.) p. si-ranjana (plain extending
as far as the eye can see). More recently
perhaps, of definite plains or open spaces,
e.g. p. mahshar (the Plain of God’s Judgment
on the Last Day) and p. Till (the Wilderness
of Sin). In Bazaar Malay, of esplanades and
playing-fields. Also for a free sphere of
action (p. Fapang): p. pdrahu di-lautan, p.
hati di - pikiran (a ship’s playing-field is
the ocean, the heart’s field of action lies in
thought), Prov. But in old Malaya of waste
land only; cf.
Sayang di-kampong di-larang orang,
Sayang di-padang bertfimu juga:
the love men forbid in the homestead may
lead us to meet in the waste; Mai. Pant. 373.

padat. Crushed into the least possible space;

quantity into a small area. Also (Java)

padSri. [Port.] «Padre»; Father; priest. Applied to
Christian ministers of religion of any deno-
mination; Ht. Abd. 94, 121.
[Yule notices that the term was used in
Portugal of regular priests only. In Portu-
guese India it was applied to secular priests
as well and came in this sense to Malaya].
pad Pt. See padat (packed compactly),
padewakan, = pedowakan (Bugis trading ship).
padi. I. Rice: (i) as a plant; (ii) in the ear; and
(iii) as an unhusked grain. Cf. bfiras (husked)
and nasi (cooked rice). In Java: rice still
in the field; rice harvested but unhusked is
gabah.
As a plant p. = Oryza spp.; viz.;
(i) rice grown in swamps (0. sativa, =
p. sawah; Ked. Pk., p. Pah., p.
paja; Kel., p. baroh); and rice grown on dry-
soil (0, moutana —p. huma or Ked., Pk.,
p. ladang);
(ii) ordinary rice (0. sativa, 0. mon-
tana, = p. jawi) and glutinous rice (0.
g 1 u t i nosa = p. pulut, pulut); and
(iii) innumerable subvarieties, each with
its own name but classified generally as
p. dalatn or p. berat (that take long to
ripen) and p. radin, p. ringan (that ripen
quickly).
Rice in the ear goes through various stages:
(i) when plant tapers: p. mfinirus; Pen.,
p. bulu ayam; p. dudok buku;
(ii) when plant begins to swell; p. bunting
kechil; p. bunting sening; (Sel., Min.) p.
perut kfichil; (Min.) p. niengandong;
(iii) when swelling is marked: p. bunting
besar; p. perut besar; (Min.) p. perut
gedang;
(iv) when ear shoots out: p. buah - nya
memanah; p. tinjau - meninjau; (Min.) p.
tfirbit berbatang - batang;
(v) when whole field is covered with
blossom: (Pen.) p. mengapar; (N. S., Pah.)
p. mirnghampar; (Min.) p. lepas terbit, p.
mengapar;
(vi) when ears bend under weight of
grain: p. tundok kakak; (Min.) p. tundok;
(vii) when the green colour loses its
brightness: (Min.) p. layu-layuan;
(viii) when the leaves begin to yellow:
(Min.) p. kuning;
(ix) when the unripe grain is just edible
(as peringgi); p. panggang peringgi;
(x) when the unripe grain is edible (as
omping): p. p6r6u ping, p. pengfimping;
(xi) when the grain is ripe: p. inasak;
(xii) when it is overripe: (N.S.) p. kukok;
(Pen.) p. ranap; (Pah.) p. korukut.
Other padi expressions are: p. bangsai
(grain with some husk left on it); p. b6r-
dukong (freak double grain); p. bfirnas
(healthy - looking r ice); p. dol (Trengg., rice
sown on wet soil), Mn.; p. hanchur, p. luloh
(worthless grain); p. kgrnap (re-fill seedlings);


p. lumat (that has ripened well); p. mendara
(with white markings on ear; deemed auspi-
cious); padi mengurai (opening rice-grain as
a pattern in bracelets); p. muda, p. pCnfmgah,
p. tua (seedlings of different stages); p.
selimbu (rice from plants left untouched as
unripe at the first reaping); p. taburau
(Trengg., rice sown on dry ploughed land);
p. usang (old rice - grains; husk and little
else); chap p., tampang p., unting p. (hand-
fnlls of seedlings for planting out); chiak p.
(rice-bird, Munia oryzivora); jajar p.,
(Kel.) nirai p. (line of rice-plants in field);
musim p. (rice-planting season); bMalang
p. (locust); puji p. (ceremonies at harvest);
semangat p., arwah p. (life-spirit in the rice,
—which has to be propitiated); ibu semangat
p. (rice - mother; rice-sheaf left standing
after propitiation); cheding p , tunas p.
(aftergrowth); tahun p. (solar year from rice-
crop to ricecrop).
P. baharu: the gymnura or (Borneo)
the aquatic civet. P. -p.: tree, Deca-
spermum panic n latum; W. Burong
laki p.; rufous fantailed warbler, C i s t i c o I a
c i s t i c o 1 a, = chiak tingting. Burong laki
p. halus: a wren, Pnoepyga lepida.
Rumput p. burong; a common grass, P a n i-
cum colonum.
Pagar makan p.: «the fencing eats up
(the value of) the rice»; overdone precautions;
Prov. Taroh btsras dalam p.: hiding husked
in unhusked rice—keeping secrets properly.
Kalau tiada p. sa - bn rang kfirja fa’ - jadi:
without rice (resources) there is nothing
doing; Prov.

padtr. Tiada memadir: (Ked.) profitless.
padtni. (Java) Queen-consort. Etym., a Brahman’s
spouse; used ,in modern Java of a sovereign’s
principal wives who are regarded as «queens»,
in contr. to his secondary wives (gundek,
selir, ampean). The consorts have usually
distinctive queenly titles of their own.

V. (Java) Quarrel; dispute; lawsuit; B.
paduka. [Skr.; = footgear] A way of addressing
a Sultan by suggesting that a subject
may presume to speak to the shoe which,
like himself, is under the Sultan’s feet. To
address the Sultan personally would suggest
equality and be presumption. Whence p. has
become an honorific (meaning «royal») in
titles: Bendahara Paduka Raja, Menteri P.
Tuan, Imam P. Tuan, Dato’ Seri Raja P.,
P. Liku, P. Mahadewi. The word occurs
also in letter-writing: seri p. sahabat beta
(to a Sultan, Deputy Sultan or Governor);
p. sahabat beta (to a raja or Chief of high
rank).
Cf. pada, dull, kaus, chorpu, sampean.

puan.

pagut. Peck (of bird); bite (of snake); nibble (of
fish). Not of the bite of a mammal (gigit,
tokak). Also (Baba) pagok; patok, chagut.
Of tapping blows with a beak or fang,
e.g.: a bird pecking up food (Kal. Dam. 75);
a falcon pecking out a dragon’s eyes (Pg.
Ptg.); a griflfin pecking a dragon to pieces
(mati putus-putus di -p. oleh geroda),
Tk. iv. 672. Coll., of the bite of a snake:
di-p. tbdong (bitten by a cobra); for fish,
cf. the proverb: biar di-tSlan buaya, jangan-
lah di-p. ikan kbchil (better be swallowed
by a crocodile than be nibbled to pieces by
wretched little fish),= better die honourably
at the hands of the great than be the
victim of the mean.
pall, I. (Pk.) Grandmother (if of gentle birth);
cf. pan (a less respectful or more familiar
word).

Pahang. A river and Sultanate on the East Coast
of the Malay Peninsula; Mai. Annals 246.
Conquered by Sultan Mansur Shah of Ma-
lacca about A. D. 1460; made into a separate
Sultanate about A. D. 1470; united with
Johor A. D. 1677; made the feudal appanage
of the Bendaharas of Johor and Daik in the
Seventeenth Century; Bendahara made Sul-
tan, A.D. 1888.
pahang. A tree-name, Dysoxylum arbore-
scens, Weinmannia sp., Tk. iv 13.
pahar. I. Large pedestal - tray; Sh. Bid. 46, Ht.
Bugis 122, Raj. Muda. Usually of brass, occa-
sionally of silver; serves as a table on which
the curried dishes are arranged. Smaller pe-
destal-trays (sembdrip) carry the rice. In
Java the pahar (por) may be an ordinary
tray on three or more low feet. See also
dalong.

paja’, pajali. (W. Sum.) Progeny; children; Dl.
Pajajaran. An ancient kingdom in Java (about

also with the oldest krisses (keris P. = keris

and n?geri alang-kah suka,
which are similar fairylands.

pajak. I. [Dutch pacht] Monopoly; regie;
ga belle. Of former farmed monopolies:
p. arak (spirit-farm); p. chandu (opium farm);
p. gadai (pawnbroking farm); p. judi
(gambling-farm); hasil p. chandu (opium
revenue; monopoly rent). Of modern shops
licensed by Government as monopolists; p.
chandu (licensed opium - saloon); p. gadai
(pawnbroker’s shop). Of municipal markets
in Penang: p. ikan (fishmarket); p. (any
market); kutu p. («market - bugs*, vagrants
who hang about the markets); cf. pasar.
In Java: of land-revenue (because it was once
farmed), cf. Pert Tebu 2(5, 4G; and (by
association with the pawn - broking monopoly)
of shops where unredeemed pledges are sold,
= (Sp.) p. gantong, (Pen.) p. lelap. Also
pak; (Java) pajek, pajeg.

(wear forbidden by religion, e. g. hatbrims

pakat, I. Ar. Agreement; (S.S.) conspiracy; plot;

11. (Min.) Thick, of liquids; = pbkat.
pakau. I. Ch. Main pakau: a game of cards; Ht.
Bugis 105. Known also as main tiga lai
because the hand consists of three cards.
Like poker in that the players stake, draw
and discard, the strongest hand winning.
With slight local variations the highest hand
is three aces, then three threes, then three
tens, then three court cards, then hands
with «pips» adding to various amounts (9,
19, 29; 8, 18, 28; 7, 17, 27; etc.); cf.
Maxwell, J.S.A.S. xiv, Mai. Magic 292.
11. Trimming; lining; framework for
stiffening (anything).

ends of which the heddles are suspended; =
c liana ng.

palit. Smudging. Memalit: to soil; Sh. Ul. 13.
Of putting the finger on a blot or smut and

is chalit. Sudah chalit jangan p.: «when
muddied don’t go smudging the mud*—don’t
make a bad situation worse; Prov. Kerbau
sa-ekur mfimbawa lumpur, kerbau seraua-
nya terpalit: «if one buffalo is muddied the
whole herd gets dirty*, = referring to the
habit buffaloes have of rubbing up against
one another; Prov.

means love-mad ness*.

11. Pampang kbmudi; (Brun., Sar.) fork-
support for paddle-rudder.
pampas. Compensation; damages; amends. ChSn-


chang memampas: «for a wound a payment*,

pamunchak. (Min.) Apex; summit. See punchak.
patnur. (Etym.) «Alloyed» (iron); from Jav. wor
(mixed, i.e. mixed with nickel, = meteoric
iron); (Java) meteoric iron used in making
the damask on krisses; (Mai.) the damask
on a kris, meteoric iron being besi pamur.
Cf. sopah sireh itu sudah hilaug p. - nya
(the quid of betel had lost, its magic alloy),
i.e. the talismanic element in it had worn
off, Ht. Panj. 133. Iron seems to have been
known first in Java in meteoric form,
whence its rarity and supposed talismanic
value as shown in the cult of certain early
weapons (see keris and chura); at a later
date when purer iron (besi khftrsani)
was imported in ships from the Persian
Gulf a certain amount of meteoric iron (Mai.
besi p.) was still worked up into the kris
to give it magical properties, the magic co-
ming out in the lucky marks (Mai. pamur,
bunga p.) made by the nickel; last of all
(in Java) the makers of krisses had enough
command over their materials to control
pattern and make ornamental damasks.
Indeed damask can now be made by
the use of pure nickel, but this modern
developernent lacks the tuah or talismanic
virtue attaching to meteoric iron.
KSris berpainur: damasked kris. A long
list of lucky «damasks» is given by Wt.,
s.v. pamur; cf. also Raj. Muda 19, Ht.
Angg. 23.
Also (Min.) pangur, = markings on steel.
pan. I. (Pk.) Grandmother as a familiar form
of address. The more respectful form is
pah.

(Council of India).

panat. (Min.) Stiff joints; weariness. See pbnat.
panau. Light painless spots or marks on the
human skin, regarded as beauty spots or
otherwise. Varieties: p. bSsi (black, hair -
covered); p. bunga (light); p. mongkarong
(light, hair-covered; caused by Microsporum
mansoni, Giml.); p. tfikukur (small, light);
p. lekir (light, streaky). But romance-writers
speak of p. empat-puloh bin pat, i.e. 44 varie-
ties of beauty-spots, all with names of their
own; see Aw. Sul. 69. For beauty-spots, cf.
the passage in the romance of Awang Sulong,
Di-dagu knmbang bertedoh,
Di-dahi panau m«sninjau,
Sa-biji panau yang elok,
Tumbok di-16song 16song pi pi,
Imbau-imbauan di-bawa tSrtawa,
Naina panau Nabi Adam;
In his dimpled chin there nestled
Spot as black as bee in blossom,
Arched spots upon his forehead;
One spot, fairer than all others,
In the mortar of his cheeks,
Dimpling, as he smiled in laughter,
Called the antimony of Adam.
[Translation by Winstedt.]
Mfincholek p. yang kabut: to remove a
blackhead.
These panau-marks are due usually to
Pityriasis versicolor (or Tinea
fla v a, Giml.), skin-diseases not unknown in
Europe. Cf. kedal, sopak.

of strength in which one man’s hands rest

the other back; Sh. Kub., also main p.

Manchang gelanggang or memanchang
gblanggang: (N.S.) the right to drive in the

of revenue. The exercise of this right against
an undang once led to a war. Wang p.:
bribes to market-peons. Cf. pachak, pachok,
pachu.

words are restricted (Mai.) to hook-and-line
fishing while payang is any form of fishing.]

[The right to execute by the sword
involved the of blood* and was
a royal prerogative (pbdang pemanchong
raja yang empnnya); see salang. But the
Dato’ Maharaja Lela, who stood with a drawn
sword at the ruler’s side, had authority to
slay instantly any one who showed disrespect


to the Sultan (p. ta’ - bertanya = to slay
without asking leave). And a suicide who
slays himself asking leave* is
described variously as p. ta’ - bfirtanya,
panchongkan diri and salang ta’- bcrikat],

panchut. Spouting or gushing out under pressure.

squirt; syringe. Cf. panchur, panchit.

pandai. I. Artist-craftsman; expert; specialist.
Also (Java) pande. Properly an industrial
artist, in contr. to a mere skilled artizan
(tukang, ufas). P. b£si: kris-maker; artist
in iron; Hg. Tuah 20. P. chanai: knife-
grinder; man who preys on others. P. kayu:
wood - carver; Sh. Mard. P. lukis: painter
of pictures and designs; Gul Bak. 100. P.
mas: goldsmith; Sh. Mard., Isk. Dz., Kal.
Dam., = (S.S.) tukang mas. In the present
dearth of artist-craftsmen p. is used of book -
learning and any cleverness cf. mdmandai
sCndiri - nya or membuat p. -p. sendiri
== omaking themselves out to be learned
people*; Ht. Abd. 827, 30. For a link between
these two meanings cf: monnrutkan mana
sa-p.-p. ktiki - nya juga (taking the line
that his feet found best to follow), Ht.
Sh.

pandak. Short; pendek. Esp. as a familiar

pandattl. I. Fixing in rosin. Of smiths fixing a

11. (Min.) To transfix or stab; cf. pcndam.
pandatl. I. Smaller screwpine; Ht. Sh., Ind.
Nata, Pant. Shi. 1, 14. Gen. for all such
Pandanaceae as are used for fine mat-
work or plait work; the coarser varieties are
mengkuang. Malays have many local names
for these plants, notably:
(i) p. duri, p. laut, p. podak (a littoral
Pandanus with prickly leaves and a
fragrant flower);
(ii) p. darat, p. wangi (a Pandanus
with hairy leaves and a fragrant smell.
Ridley gives: P. ovatus (p. berduri,
p. tikus); P. fas cicu laris (p. duri); and
P.russow (p. rasau). A Riau list gives: p.
jakas, p. jeleta, p. laut, p. perak, p. podak,
p. siah. Watson gives: Pandanus or-
nat u s (p. berduri); P. fa scicu 1 a r i s
(p. duri, p. laut); P. hu 11 ell i i (p. hutan);
P. aurantiacns (p. ikan); P. odorus
(p. jeliugkeh, p. wangil; P. parvus (p.
kara); P. r i d 1e y i (p. tikus).
[The difference between a pandan and a
mengkuang is shown in the cross-section;
each is V-shaped but the latter has a flat
rim on either side. Pandan is an honorific
variant of pala; Tk.]

Panggil is used very loosely in town

t£riak; (ii) to call a person by a certain

panjSr, = panjar (advance), Pert. Tebu 32.
Panji. Sira Panji: name of the hero of the
« Panji* cycle of Hindu Java. Also (popularly)
Seri Panji. Properly Raden Inn Kartapati,
crown-prince of Kuripan, who took service
as a private soldier to win distinction apart
from his rank. His betrothed (Chandra
Kirana, princess of Daha) disguised herself
as a man and did the same under the name
of Panji Sumirang or Panji Sfinrerang.
The wars and adventures of the pair are the
subject of the «Panji» cycle.
panji. I. Panji-panji: streamer; pennon; pennant.
Used of long triangular flag-emblems (illd.
Veth xxxvi 8). Cf. also panji-panji bf'rnaga
ala rat raja Johan (pennons displaying a


dragon, the badge of Raja Johan), Lang.
Buana 29; also of the Prophet’s banner (Bost.
Sal. ii 54), and of the flag of Portugal hoisted
at a mast-head (Ht. Angg. 121). Loosely
also of pennons on lances; of the nondescript
strips of coloured cloth decorating a kramat;
and even of the «streamers» on a bursting
cotton-pod (kSkabu panji-panji).
11. Jav. An honorific in Javanese titles;
e.g. pfingeran p., raden p. It does not
carry precedence except over such princes
(pfingeran, raden) as have no honorific at
all.
111. Chblana panji-panji: short trousers
(of the chblana type, see chelana) as worn
by warriors.
patljing. (Pal.) To become a domestic slave of the

pans!. See pangsi (cuttlefish-ink),

pantai. I. Beach; sea-shore; (less usual) fringe of
a forest (p. suatu hutan, Gul Bak. 82).
Oraug p.: coast-people, in. contr. to orang
darat (dwellers in the hinterland). Lobok
jadi p.; «when the depths of the sea become
beaches®,=when all the seas run dry; Prov.
Lautan madu berpantaikan sagar: «a sea of
honey with a sugared beach», a symbol of
extreme sweetness; Ht. Koris.
Mouyusur p.: to hug the shore. Susur
p.: sea-edge of beach. Ikan pantai: (Sp.) a
fish, sp. unid.
11. (Min.) Oblique; at a slant.
pantak. I. Driving a long body into a narrow
cavity, e. g. a nail into wood, a cork into a
bottle, etc.
11. (N.S.) Small pile (in dam-construction).
Large piles are balan, kayu pgnunggul, or
(N.S.) lantak.
111. (Brun., Sar.) Witchcraft.
pantang. I. Taboo; thing not done; prohibition due
to custom or superstition. Chas p.: the
evil that follows on the violation of a taboo.
Etym., the courtly form of an old word pali
surviving in pemali (q.v.); whence the
collective pantang-pemali (taboos of all sorts),
Ht. Bugis 155. The word would cover such
superstitions as our objection to sitting down
thirteen at table or walking under a ladder;
with Malays it covers the «prohibitions» that
enter (for unknown reasons) into every
department of life. It does not cover the
ruler’s own prohibitions (larang). But it
includes offences prescribed by customary or
common law such as murder or adultery. It
lays down what a pregnant woman may not
eat or do and indeed what her husband must
abstain from doing (p. beranak), the pantang-
period lasting from the seventh month of
pregnancy to the 44th day after childbirth;
cf.: 16pas - lah p. pormaisuri (the queen’s
danger-time was over), Mai. Dem. 61; makan
pun tiada berlauk oleh ia-pun didalam p.
lagi (she could not eat fish as she was still
in her pantang-period), Ch. Jen. 16. P.
also enters into industry; cf.: p. tuai (things
one may not do at harvest-time), Mai. Magic
226; p, di-laut (tilings forbidden to sailors at
sea); p. di-hutan things forbidden to hunters
and collectors of jungle - produce); p. kapur
(secret language for use when camphor -
hunting, plain Malay being forbidden). It
enters even into sport: p. gftlanggang (things
one may not do at a cockfight), Mai. Dem.
88.
11. (N.S.) Momantang: to find fault with;
Wt.


pantas. Becoming; neat; graceful. Also pangus
(Mai. Annals 93); (Batav.) pantos. In Malaya
it connotes nimbleness or speed; cf. p. mulut
(ready of speech); p. tangan (deft); p. ber-
jalan (swift-footed), Mai. Annals 176. Sepbrti
kilat p. - nya: swift as lightning, Gul Bak.
45. In Java it connotes suitability, e.g. of a
person being fittingly dressed, or even of a
fair price, defined as = harga yang patut,
Sul. Hid. 49. Not a Min. word.
pantat. Lower portion of body; haunch or quarters
of animal. Variously the posterior, the
pudendum virile and the pudendum
muliebre. Used (Min.) in the last sense
only—see also pantek; (Pen.) of the buttocks
(buah p.)=(Sp.) punggong, pungkur, burit,
bantat, buntut; (Sp., Riau) of the pudenda,
cf. burit dan p, (Ht. Bugis 145). Usually
of the bottom or hindquarters; cf.: the passage
(Mai. Annals 183) of an elephant having
very sloping quarters (p. - nya tSrlalu
churaui); also of a boy being caned on his
behind (di-sesah p. - nya), Ht. Abd. 19;
and of a man having skin rubbed off by
much riding (p. lechet oleh sebab naik
kuda), Ht. Bangs. 12. Other examples are:
p. bhlanga, p. periok (saucepan - bottom =
something black, dirty and unsavoury); p.
siput (shell-bottom; core of whorl); p. bawa
sfingat (with a sting on its behind) = double-
faced, treacherous; Prov. Burong p. labu:
(Sel.) a bird, sp. unid. Main p.: sodomy; Hn.
pantau. I. MSmantau: to visit; to look up a
person.
11. (Ked.) Rack for sticks, etc.
111. (Min.) A small freshwater fish, sp.
unid.
pantek. I. Striking together two hard substances,
esp. flint and steel. Pfimantek api: spark -
maker (of flint and steel). Moniantek urat:
to open a vein; to bleed.
11. (Sp.) Pudendum muliebre.
Properly a (Sum.) variant of pantat. Occurs
in the expression p. ibu = puki ma’ (a gross
insult).
111. (Java) Nail; pin; spike; B.
pantSlun. Eng. Pantaloons; trousers.
pant Es. See pantas (deft).
panting. See pontang shelter - skelter),
panti. Jav. Dwelling; place of residence.
pantis, I. Touching up. Of laying things on in
small quantities; a lady using lip-stick or
kohl (Kuinb. Chumh. 25); a man putting
chalk on the tip of his billiard-cue; a Malay
chalking his kris-handle to improve his grip;
the use of face-powder; etc.
11. A tree, Lophopetalum sp.; W.
pantit. Memantit: (Min.) to circumcize. Cf.
pantok.
pantok. Coaming on a Malay boat; cf. leper.
pantong. Determined; peremptory; Kl.
pantul. Pantul balek: to bound back (as a ball);
cf. antul, ambul. Also (Min.) pantun.
pantun. 1. Verse of which the first portion
suggests the second; verse-making by met-
onymy. Pantunkan: to make some person
or thing the subject of such a verse. Buang
p.: to extemporize such a verse. P. bdrnaka-
naka; dialogue in this form of verse; sets
of verses. P. rampai: disconnected verses.
Etym., sa - pantun seems to be a courtly
form of seperti = «one in meanings, from
6rti (meaning). It has this meaning in
Sumatra, cf. Jub. Mai. 15, Must. Adat 10,
Pant. Mai. 663, 839.
Kaseh ka - tuan t6rs6nibunyi,
Sa-pantun duri dalam daging:
my love for you must be concealed; a thorn
embedded in my flesh; Pant. Mai. 116. In
old literature the word is used of any proverb
or simile; cf. Hg. Tuah 101, 102. But the
modern pantun is based more on metonymy
or sound-suggestion than on metaphor. It is
enigmatical, cf. Pant. Mai. 267,
Pantun sahaya sa - rnpa kata,
Tuan pikir didalam liati:
my verse is like a message; think out the
thing it means. It is made up of two parts:
the first part has a hidden meaning; the
second part (which rhymes with it) explains
the first. In very many cases there is no
clue save the rhyme. In Malaya the pantun
is a topical quatrain, either improvised for
the occasion or repeated appositely from
memory; in Sumatra it may run to six, eight
or even more lines, —in that case each line
in the first half rhymes with the corresponding
line in the second half.
[For fuller accounts of the pan tun see


P.M.S., Malay Literature, part I, and Dr.
Winstedt’s introduction to Pautmi Melayu
(Mission Press, Singapore, 1914). The loose
translation following will give a fair idea ol
what is meant by assonance or sound -
suggestion in a pantun,
Dari - ruana punai mblayang?
Dari paya turun ka - padi;
Dari-mana kaseh sayang?
Dari mata turun ka - hati:
The fate ot a dove is to fly,
He flies to his nest on the knoll;
The gate of true love is the eye,
The prize of his quest is the soul.
See also verses s. v. ruang, rumput.
Mr. Overbeck has shown that this type of
composition is not peculiar to Malay].

papa. Skr. Destitute. Also (Min.) papar. Etym.,
= «unfortunate»; e.g : p. kerrua (a man who

Sh.; tujoh kali pindah jadi p. (to move
house seven times means beggary), Prov.

para. I. Shelf; rack; partial ceiling. Of

crossbeams in a fishtrap; these serve to
hold the structure together; (iii) any shelf-
like upper apartment in a Malay house;
serving as an attic or home for a young
girl during her seclusion (pingit).
P. buang: a sort of chute for rubbish;
it is, made by thrusting out the upper part
of a wall so as to leave an opening through
which things can be dropped out of the
house. Arang p.: soot. Panjat p.: see panjat.

Paranchis. (Min.) French; = Peransis.
parang. I. Cleaver; machete; to chop. Also (Brun.)
pfimarang. The special feature of the p. is
that its cutting edge is concave and that the
blade gets broader and heavier as it leaves
the handle. Used (Mai., Min., Brun ) for
industrial purposes; but the parang Hang of
the Dyaks is a sword and differs from the
kelewang only in the slightly concave
character of its cutting edge. Momarang: to
use a cleaver or sword; Lang. Buana 12. Ht.
Bangs. 29. Kachangp.: a bean, Canavalia
ensifo r m i s.
Varieties: p. panjang or (Sum.) p. lading
(long and sword-like); p. bagong, p. bang-
kong, p. pandak, (Pk.) p. gondok (short,
heavy, not markedly concave); p. latok
(short, heavy, with hooked point); p. chakok
(E. Coast, with blade like a bill-hook), = p.
kokot; p. kekot, (Kel.) p. jengok, p.
bongkok, p. bcngkok, (Kel.) pajak (all
markedly concave); p. sabit (sickle); p. koteng,
p. chandong, peranggi (handle and blade in
one piece, illd. Veth ci 6); p. gabus, p.
pitting, p. terubok sa-kampoh (tempered
and much sharpened, used for forestry and
as weapons).
Kaparan p.: flat side of blade. Paparan
p.: blunt side or back of blade. Pisau dan
p. itu tumpul, niiika mnlut manusia
t&rlebeh fajam: knives and cleavers are blunt;
the human tongue is far sharper; Ht. Abd.

pari. I. Skate; ray. Gen. for sting-rays (Trygo-
ni d a e), electric (T orped i n a e) and
•eagle-rays (M yliob a t i d a e). Beaked rays
and sawfish are yu.
Varieties of the electric ray;
(i) Narcine timle i = p. kbbas, p.
kelobas, (Pk.) p. atnpai;
(ii) Astrape di pterygia =p,
mengkek, p. mingkai, p. bunga;
(iii) Tern era hardwickii = p. lichin,
(Pen.) p. Ibndir, (Sel.) p. minyak.
Of the sting-rays;
(i) Urogymnus spp. (or thornbacks):
(Ked.) p. dedap, (Sel.) p. kikir, (Sp.) p.
onak; also p. teritip, p. landak, p. kblikir;
(ii) sand - loving spp. of Trygon, e.g.T.
u a r n a k, T. b 1 ee k e r i; = (Sel.) p. bbting,
(Pat.) p. pasir, (Ked., Pk.) p. tanjong;
(iii) the mud-loving Trygon kuhi i i,
= (Pen.) p. lanyau, (Pk.) p. lumpur, (Sp.)
p. rbnyau;
(iv) Trygon sephen, = p. daun;
(v) the spotted Trygon walga, =p.
bintang, p. tahi lalat, (Ked., Pk., Joh.) p.
lalat.
Eagle-rays, batfishes and devil-fishes
(M y 1 i o b a t i d a e) are of five genera:
(i) the batfish proper, Mylio b a t i s
spp., = p. kblawar;
(ii) the eagle - ray proper, Aetobatis
n a r i n a r i, = p. lang;
(iii) the thin-winged Rhinoptera
aspersa, = p. bbndora;
(iv) the horned devil-fish, Ceratoptera
spp., = (Joh.) p. tandok, (Ked., Pk.) p.
knlok;
(v) the hornless devil- fish, Dicero batis
spp., = p. pauh, (Ked.) p. pans.
The name p. Ibkap is given (Pk.) to
those rays that have a habit of leaping out
of the water and then falling flat upon it (to
kill sucking-fish attached to their bodies).
TTnid. are: (Batav.) p. bills; (Sel.) p. dbpa;
(Batam.) p. jadong; (Ked.) p. lamuu;
(Batam.) p. mono; (Ked., Pk.) p. nyonyah;
(Sel.) p. paksa; (Ked., Sel.) p. rimau; (Joh.)
p. sumpit or p. sbnyumpit; (Ked.) p. seran;
(Ked.) p. sbtoka, (Joh.) p. toka-toka, p.
tfitoka (Sel.) p. sisir; (Ked., Sel.) p. sumbat;
(Pat.) p. tarutn; (Pat.) p. tasek, p. tohok;
(Batam) p. unat, =p. onak?
Other terms are: bintang p. (Southern
Cross constellation), Bur. Pungg. 213; kikir
p. (skate-skin grater); kulit p. (shagreen);
knsta p. (black swellings with knob - like
projections, regarded as leprous); lawi p.
(fin under ray’s tail); panggang p. (see
panggang); sengat p., sonak p. (venomous
spikes on ray’s tail); tikam p. (spearing
skate); buloh sbngat p. (bamboo with
successive down - turning ridges); Ibmbing
sfingat p. (spear with three barbs).

11. Tidal flow. In contr. to surut (ebb).
P. anak: neap-tide. P. bah: tide causing

P. kflling: exceptionally high springs. P.
tides at the full moon. Ayer p.:
rising tide. Bunga p.: first of the flood.
P6noh p.: the full rush of the tide.
[Tides are explained (Bost. Sal. i 66) as
due to the breathing of the great ox (I6mbu)
upon whose back the world is set. When
he breathes, the tide rises (apabila ia bfir-
napas inaka jadi p. - lah ayer laut); when
he draws in his breath the sea ebbs
(surut).]

pati. I. «Cream» or «pick» or finest portion of

kabar. The residue or refuse after that is
hampas. P. arak: pure alcohol. P. Melayu:
a Malay of the best; tout ce qu’il ya

IV. See pematong.
patpat. Main patpat siku renibat: a game
(rather complicated in minor details) in
which a boy is selected by chance to be the
mount of another. He goes on carrying the
other till he can guess correctly in which of
two hands a certain article is. The two boys
then change about. The game takes its name
from the first line of certain nonsense-verses
sung in it. Also chan-chan siku renibat.
See Mai. Amusements 10, Mai. Magic 497,
498.
pattern. KSris patrem: a small-bladed kris (illd.
May. ii 538) carried by women. According
to legend the first ruler of Java (Saputram)
was born with one of these krisses in his
hand.

pau. I. Ch. Nankeen; Chinese calico.
If. See paupau (stocking-purse).
pauh. I. A tree-name (Mangifera spp., Bid.;
Buchanania s e s s i 1 i fo 1 i a, W.).
Varieties: p. kijang (I r v i n g i a malayana);
p. kijang jantan (Evodia la ti folia);
p.-p. pasir (Croton caudatum). Putok
p.: descriptive name for a hook that curves
first outwards and then inwards.
P. janggi: a legendary tree growing on a
«sunken bank* (tebing runtoh) at the navel
or centre of the Ocean (pusat tasek). This
tree is believed to drop into the waters its
sap (ambergris) and its fruit (buah p.
janggi, i.e., the double nut of Cocos
maldiva or Lodoicea seychel-
larum). This double coconut, of which
specimens were occasionally washed up on
the shores of S. Asia, was highly valued,
even in Europe, as a sort of talisman; and
was used as a beggar’s bowl. Tasek p.
janggi: the Great Ocean; the Indian or
«Southern» Ocean; = (Java) segara kidul.

an honour to its distinguished writer), Ism.
Yat.; of the bearers with their insignia being
arranged in proper order (p. di-atur), Jay.
Pati; Ht. Bangs. 39, Lang. Buana 71. The
insignia themselves are alat p.
pawaka. Skr. Fire; Kl.
pawan. I. A title or appellation borne by many
Malay - speaking Indians, esp. in Penang; =
pa’ wan?
11. A plant, Clerodendron inerme.
pawana. Skr. Wind; Kl.
pawang. Expert in any art believed to need the
use of magic. Etym., = navigating officer,
shipmaster; used in this sense; Mai. Annals
27, 55; Isk. Dz. The term now covers many
other callings: managers of large marine
fishtraps (p. bblat, p. j&rmal, p. kelong);
collectors of certain jungle-produce (p. di -
hutan, p. gaharu, p. kapur); honey-gatherers
(p. lebah); elephant-trappers (p. gajah);
fishermen at sea (p. pukat, p. di-laut). All
these callings, tnough based on experience
and skill, are accompanied by much old-world
ritual. But at the present day and in
South Malaya only (Pk., Sel., Job., Pah.),
p. is used specifically of the village
medicineman or shaman, = bffiian, (Ked.,
Pat., Kel.) bomo, (Min.) poyang, (Kubu)
malim, (Java) dukim. This man is supposed
to be in touch with the w T orld of spirits and
plays a part in exorcising illnesses, driving
ill-luck out of a district by propitiating
unseen powers, choosing lucky times for
opening a new mine or planting a new crop,
and performing the customary rites that took
place on such occasions. For these services
(Pk.) the village medicine - man, like the
village midwife, was entitled to maintenance
and fees. Bunga p.: tree, Radermachera
a m o e n a; W.
pawas. (Min.) A freshwater fish (unid.) bred in
fishponds for consumption.
pavvat. Payong pawat (or payong bawat): a
small state - umbrella on a very high staff;
see bawat, payong.
pawirsian, (Java) Nursery; = Pert.
Tebu 17. See semai.
pawitra. Ayer pawitra: (Skr.) water of purification;
cf. di-ambil oleh Begawan Narada ayer
yang p. lain di-siramkan kapada kepala
Sang Bima dan Dewi Rimbi (the Holy
Narada took up the Water of Sinlessness
and sprinkled it upon the brows of Bhima
and Rimbi), Tk. iv 221.
pawotl. Jav. Kitchen; caboose; B.
paya. Swamp; morass;=(Kel.) benchah. Of grass-
land sodden with water in the wet - season;
not of mangrove swamp (hutan bakau) nor
yet of deep meres (danau, redang, lahar,
rawaug). P. yang dalam - dalam: deep
swamp; Lang. Buana 6. For its nature cf.
the lines,
Laksana ikan di-paya,


Datang kfimarau k6ring-lah ia:
like fish that live in a swamp, there comes
a drought and leaves them dry.
P. kumboh: a swamp that grows rushes;

= padi sawah, see padi.

payang. I. Fishing. Etym., of fishing in general
and line - fishing in particular; = punching
(etym., its honorific form). But identified
nowadays with deep-sea - fishing with nets
(pukat); in Java p. —(Mai.) pukat. PSrahu p.:
a large boat used on the East Coast for deep-
sea-fishing; illd. J.M.A.S. iv, and known
elsewhere as perahu pukat, pbrahu penia-
yang, (Java) perahu mayang. This boat
is about 40 feet long, has 13 or 14 oars, 4
or 5 paddles and a large steeling oar. It
sometimes has a dinghy (sampan p.) to help
in working the net (pukat petarang). Sa-
orang p.: a fisherman; Mai. Annals 200.

payar. Guarding or patrolling by means of a ship

narrow sea, etc.; Pel. Abd. 6, Ht. Abd. 160.

stream so as to enforce payment of tolls or

payong. I. Umbrella; (fig.) protective shelter.
In various senses.
(i) The ordinary umbrella, With its top-
knob (kfipala p., kSmonchak p.); frame
(jaring - jaring p.); catch (pachat p., p6n-
yangga p.); and stick (batang p.).
(ii) The umbrella as indicating rank;
also (Java) songsong. P. bawat, p. pawat:
Javan umbrella, small on a high staff and
coloured to indicate a man’s rank; illd. May.
ii 606, in over a hundred varieties of
colouring (pi. xx, xxi). P. ch6t6ra: canopy;
canopied umbrella; Bur. Nuri 30. P. bSrapit:
a pair of small umbrellas carried side fry
side before a high dignitary: cf. Mai. Annals
149. P. übur-übur; fringed umbrella; Ht.
Bakht. P. iram, p. irania, p. rama-rama:
the fringed umbrella used by royalty in
Malaya.
(iii) Umbrella-shaped; e.g. asap berpayong
(smoke rising umbrella-wise in still air), or
of the head of a nail.
(iv) The area «sheltered» under one of
these emblems of authority, esp. (Sum.) the
autonomous unit under a territorial head
(pSnghuln andeka, N.S. undang); cf luak.
(v) Trees suggesting umbrellas in some
way. Daun p.: (i) the palm, Teysrnannia
altifrons; (ii) herb, Biophytum spp.,
esp. B. adiantoides; specifically daun p.
Ali and used as an aphrodisiac. Rumput p.:
a grass, Mari s c u a cyperinus.

Ind. Nata. Sddiakan p. sa-belutn hujan:
to open one’s umbrella before the rain
begins; to overdo precautions; Prov.

Also of the diffusion of perfume, cf. Mai.

Padi di - bawa dari Balok,
Tiba di-kuala p6chah pbrahu - uya;
Bunga pun dapat kita nan jolok,
Sampai di-k6pala pechah ban - nya:
The rice was brought from Balok town,
But on the bar the ship was shattered;
I win and wear the rosy crown
And on my head the scent is scattered.

pgda. (Pk.) Fish pickled in brine; = (Min.) pada
or lank pada; (Job.) p6ndap, rusib; (Ked.,
Kel.) budu; (Java) peda, botok, bebotok.
The fish are anchovies (Stolephorus spp.,
Engraulis spp.) and sardines (tamban);
they are packed in large jars (tompayan) with
brine; and a cover is stretched over the jar
to prevent the air getting in or the smell
escaping. See also bubu, kenas, pekasam.

pgjgslt. I. A familiar spirit; a «sucker» or vampire.
i. (Sum.) A vampire; from lesit (sucking),
=the «sucker.» P. bnngkai: a ghoul; a
wizard who «sucks» the bodies of children
out of newly-made graves in order to feast
upon them; Perch. Mai. 63. P. kudong: a
wizard who sends his head to suck the blood
of his enemies, the body staying behind; cf.
pfinanggalan, manjang. P. kudong itu
boleh-lah b6rch£rai konon kepala - nya
dbngan badan - nya; kbpala-nya pergi


mbnchari niakanan dan badan-nya tinggal
di - rumah; niakanan - nya ia-lah daging
manusia, daging anak- anak
kbchil yang aniat di - g6mari - nya: the
• headless one» has the power of severing the
head from the body, the head going to seek
what it may devour while the body remains
at home; the food is human flesh, especially
that of young children; Perch. Mai. 62.
ii. (Mai.) A familiar spirit in the form of
a cricket. Prom lesit (rustle). Cf. pelfisit
yaani sa-jenis rohani yang mfinjelma atau
niengambil rupa menjadi sa-jenis bSlalang
(the p., i.e. a kind of spirit that becomes
incarnate in, or takes the form of, a kind of
cricket); Perch. Mai. 62. The «cricket» is a
Phasrna and is known as belalang peßsit,
belalang polong, b6lalang bantu, belalang
bajang.
Actually the two ideas are connected. The
cricket in question flies in a way that
suggests to Malays the backward flight of a
human head trying to reattach itself to its
body.

p&mali. Taboo; (Min.) pamali, = pantang, q. v.
Etym., from pal i, of which pantang was
the courtly and is now the commoner form.
But a distinction is drawn sometimes
between pantang (taboo at certain times, e.g.
the birth-taboos or pantang beranak) and
pgmali (taboo at all times, e. g. a boy may
never touch a rotten egg nor may any one
unmarried eat out of a cooking-pot or take
the first helping out of a jar of a fish-pickle,
nor may any one at sea upset a cooking-pot
and then wash it out; these things are
pemali and, if done bring a curse). P. is
also used as a term of abuse, e.g. Si Jebat
p. orang chglaka (this accursed Jgbat, this
man of ill omen), Hg. Tuah. But distinction
between pantang and pemali is not invariable:
war-taboos are described, for instance, both
as p. (Sh. Kub.) and as pantaug (Hg.
Tuah 224).

Mai. 40.

pgnajur. Line of fishing - stakes drawn across a

See tanak.
pEnanggah. Cook-house;=rumah dapur or (N.S.)
dapur bandong. Also pSnanggahan; Ht.
Bugis 50. Malay cooking is done usually in
a corner of the house (dapur), not in a
special kitchen. A p. is a special kitchen or
outhouse used for cooking; cf.: sfelang p.
(raised and covered way to kitchen), Raj.
Muda 2,3, and ia-pnu pergi ka-p. m6n-
chari pSriok (he went to the kitchen to
look for a cooking-pot), Mai. Dewa 103. A
royal kitchen is always referred to for
reasons of politeness as a penanggah even
if is a mere dapur.
pgnanggalan. «The severed head». A birth-spirit
preying on newborn children and women in
labour. It is usually credited with having
the shape of a human head with pendent
viscera. Also (Ked.) tenggelong. Cf. tanggal,
penggal.
The penanggalan myth is composite. It
is really identical with the familiar known
as (N.S.) bantu manjangan or (Sum.) pelesit,
the sucker of blood; cf. Mai. Magic 627
where one charm so identifies it. But it has
come to be associated with the vampire
(langsuyar) and has the vampire’s whinnying
cry and hatred of woman in labour. Cf.:
ada-lah p. itu porempuan asal-nya; maka
ia - itu mPmakai ilnin sbaitan yang di-
p6rchaya-nya s£rta di - araalkan akandia
pada siang malam, hingga sampai - lab
kapada waktu perjanjian - nya kapada
gnrn-nya yang boleb ia t6rbang itu, maka
tanggal - lab Idler - nya itu bSrgantong
dengan p£rut - nya kduar bfirjela - jela,
maka tuboh-nya itu tinggal-lah di-tSmpat-
nya; maka barang - dimana orang yang
bendak di - aniayakan - nya itu, terbang-
lab k£pala-nya itu s£rta pergi
mengisap darah orang itu (the pgnanggalan
was once a woman; she used the magic ai ts
of a demon whom she trusted by devoting
herself to his service day and night for an
agreed term, after which she was able to fly;
that is to say her head and neck could fly
when loosened from her body with the
viscera depending from them, while the body
remained behind; wherever the person whom
she wished to injure might live, thither flew
her head and bowels to suck his blood); Ht.
Abd. 108. This description corresponds
exactly with the (N. S.) manjangan and
(except for the hanging entrails) with the
(Sum.) p6lesit kudong; see pfilfisit. But in


Malaya it is often regarded as a birth-spirit
and confused with the langsuyar.

pgnchil. T6rp6nchil: detached from the main body;
separated; strayed away. Of stragglers being
taken by tigers (Kal. Dam. 382); a prince
becoming separated from his army (Ht. Gh.);
ships being unable to keep up with a fleet
and so falling into the hands of the enemy

Pgndawa. Skr. «Pandawa»; son of Pandu; hereof
the Mahabharata. Hikayat P. lima or

(Maharaja Dermawangsa), Bbima (Sang
Bima), Arjuna ((Sang Ranjuna), Nakula
and Sahadewa. Sikap bagai P.: bearing
himself like a hero of old romance; Ht.

pSndawa. K6ris pSndawa: a Javanese pattern of

pendek. Short; = pandak. Panjang p.; tall and

Bbkerja panjang p.; to work by fits and
starts. Jumpa yang rfndah tfirpendek
sangat: «if he met a short girl he found her
too short,» said of a person whom there
was no pleasing; Mai. Dewa 46.
In Singapore pendek, not pandak, is the
usual word for «short».
pgndekar. Leader of a charge; fighter; swash-

pSndSrah. Charm against hostile krisses. A p.
enables your own kris to parry attacks, or
paralyzes your enemy’s arm, or reduces his
blade to brittleness.
pgndiat. Enclosure into which wild elephants are
driven; corral.
pending. I. Embossed plate of metal covering a
clasp through which a girdle (tali p., tali
juita) passes; worn as an ornament in front
of the body. lIId. Veth xiv 2, xxiii 5. In
shape roughly elliptical, sometimes with the
ends of the major axis pointed rather than
rounded. Worn by bride and bridegroom at
weddings; also (Min.) by magnates in gala
dress. Rank may be indicated by tiers or
raised surfaces in the central rosette (tampok
p.) = p. bertingkat; if this rosette is of
raised filigree work the p. is p. berkfirawang.
The p. is sometimes called (Sum.) jadam
when made of niello; but jadam is really the
name of the material.
Also (Min.) panding.
11. Bunga pending: edging round a
basket.

pSngap. I. Preserving (fish) by shutting out the
air, e.g. as in «tinning» or «canning». It is
done by Malays in jars with tightly closed
covers; but as the method is imperfect the
fish are also salted. Cf. budu, p£da, pendap.
