pSngEmbar. Screen (worked like a large fan) used
by fishermen to hustle fish into a trap
(kelong). Cf. penghalau.
pSngeran. Jav. Prince. A title (Borneo, Java,
Pal.; not Mai., Min.) given:
(i) in Solo and Jogja to princes of the
highest rank other than the Susuhunan and
Sultan themselves;
(ii) in the rest of Java (by Dutch approval)
to the heads of great princely houses;
(iii) in Palembang to divisional Chiefs;
(iv) in Dutch Borneo to members of
reigning houses;
(v) in Brunei to nobles generally;
(vi) in the Pulau Tujoh to the Chief of
Terempa (p. pangku negara).
In Java holders of the title may be either
p. by birth (p. putSra, p. sentana) or by
creation (p. sEngkan). They are also of
various grades (usually according to the
nearness of their relationship to the sovereign):
p. adipati aria (yamtuan niuda, king
coadjutor); p. adipati anom (raja muda,
crown prince); p. aria (prince, son of the
sovereign by a royal wife); p. ngabehi
(prince, eldest son of the sovereign by a
secondary wife), etc. Outside Java these
grades do not exist. The title is met with
in literature: Ht. Sh., Ht. Koris, Mai.
Annals 173, Ht. Bugis 103.
pEngEras, Pee (for services rendered);=(Ked.)
pEngkgras.
pEngErawan. See mengorawan (tree, H o p e a sp.).

pSnggal. I. To be cut off short. Esp. of

pSnggawa. Skr. District officer; Commissioner.
Etym., an old Javanese military distinction, =
«bull-champion». In old literature; a title of
rather indefinite character; cf. niEntEri p.
(Sh. Bid.), mentEri para-p. (Mar. Mah.),
p. agong (Hg. Tuah 49). In Bantam: an
assistant District Officer, subordinate to a
D. 0. or tEmenggong. In Palembang: id.,
but subordinate to a pfisirah. Introduced
into Johore by Sultan Abubakar as an
equivalent of Met with as
a title in Selangor also.

pEnggllling. Pangolin; mania; = tEnggiling, q.v.
pßnghulu. Headman; superintendent. From hulu
(head); cf. kepala. Of headmen of all sorts,
e.g.: kitchen chef (p. dapur): head-slave
(p. dengan, Mai. Annals 118); palace
housekeeper (p. inang); palace-caretaker (p.
istana); mosque-caretaker (p. masjid); and
even of angel-leaders (p. malaikat) and
principal wives in heaven (Bost. Sal. i 44).
The Prophet is described also as p. of all


mankind, as in the paraphrase of the Creed,
Allah taala sa-benar-nya Tuhan, Nabi
Muhammad pbnghulu karai.
Specifically, p. is a title given;
(i) in the Colony: to mukira headmen; =
kepala kampong; (Pat.) kueng; (Java)
kebavan;
(ii) in Pk., Sel., Pah.: to headmen of
several mukim with some judicial authority;
= (Java) demang, w6dana;
(iii) in N.S.; to undang or provincial
Chiefs (but the description is sometimes
resented nowadays, dato’ being preferred);
(iv) in Min.: to tribal headmen (p. puchok
= N.S. lembaga), and to provincial Chiefs
(p. andeka = N.S. undang).
A lawyer is sometimes styled p, in
Kelantan; and a distinction is drawn occasion-
ally by purists between ponghulu (the
head of all mankind, i.e. the Prophet) and
pengulu (all lesser «headmen»).
pSngilar, pßngilau, pßngilir. Long cylindrical
fishtrap between two waterways. Any fish
passing into this trap find egress prevented
at both ends by in - turning spikes (injap,
unjap).
pSngit. I. Hangit- pengit:; all kinds of filthy
smells or tastes; Ht. Pdk. 12. See hangit.
11. (Pk.) Deafening. Of a loud noise next
the ear.
pgngkah, = pangkah (punkah).
pßngkalan. Landing-place; wharf; stopping - place
for diserabarcation. See bagan, pangkal.
pengkat. Misshapen in the legs, e.g. bandy-legged
(p. ka-dalam) or bow-legged (p. ka-luar).
pßngkglang, Pengkblang palm: groin; haunch;

pgngkßras. (Ked.) Fee for services rendered; =

pßngkilai. A shrub, Cler ode n drum panic il-

pßngkis. Memengkis: to shout out defiant words;
=m6m6kis, from pekis, q.v.
pßnglima. Executive officer. Also (Ked.) panglema.
Etyra., from lima (hand); ranking after
pSnghulu (from hulu = head) Properly a
title of secondary rank associated with action
rather than counsel; e.g.: military officer (p.
b§sar, p. perang, p. kanan, p. kiri); chief
scout (p. kakap); court - chamberlain (p.
dalam), Ht. Bugis 49; master of the elephants
(p. gajah), Mai. Annals 86. Common in
literature of military commanders, e.g.: of
the Achehnese generals who besieged Malacca
(Bost. Sal. ii 124); of the Persian leader
Rustam (Bost. Sal. ii 25); of the military
governors of provinces in early Moslem times
(Bost. Sal. ii 62); and of the T6m§nggong
Sbri Udana in his capacity as Commander-
in-Chief (Mai. Annals 231). So used also in
the (N.S.) title of tengku p. besar, and the
Achehnese p. kaum (bead of a clan) and p.
sag! (head of a province). Cf. hulubalang
in Perak. On the whole, however, the title
is not held in special honour and is often
given (N.S., Pk.) to aboriginal headmen of
negrito and Proto-Malayan communities.
pSngorak. A herb, Asy stasia intrusa; W.
pßngsan, pengsan. Fainting; loss of consciousness.

p.: nearly fainting. Terpeugsan sioman
pula: fainting and then coming to; Ht. Abd.
10. Sedan daripada p.: to come to after a
faint.

(Min.) pansan.

pgnjagur. (Ba tav.) Name of a sacred cannon at

pgnjajab, = pfnjajap (Bugis warship).
pStljajap. «Pinjajap»; Bugis warship. Illd. Ht.
Bugis 11. A light vessel used by the Bugis
raiders; in contr. to the heavier and heavily
armed lanun used by the pirates of
the high seas. The p. had a mainmast and
mizzen and was small enough to be propelled
by oars if necessary. Varieties (p. kepala
kakatua, p. pagan tbnggalong) according to
the type of quarterdeck.
Also penajap.
penjam, =pinjam (to borrow).
penjatl. Treading underfoot, e. g. as grapes are
trodden down in a winepress. Of the making
of a kind of sago by treading down pith in
this way (Taw. Mai. 50); also (Ked.) of
fields being trodden down by buffaloes instead
of being ploughed. Cf. lanyak, I6nyek.
pSnjara. Large cage. Of cage-prisons; cage-traps
for large animals such as tigers and leopards
(illd. Veth. cxxi 1, cxxii 1); (fig.) prisons
generally. Penjarakan: to imprison; Mai.
Annals 85, Ht. Abd. 46,==in6mp§njarakan,
Gul Bak. 73. Malay prisons were cages
(pfinjara or Kel. gob, gok) in which the
prisoner was left to be fed by his relatives.
Usually with thick wooden bars; but an iron -
barred prison-cage (p. b6si) is mentioned; Ht.
Angg. 91.

Pgranggi, = Peringgi (European).
pgranggi. Iron-handled chopper; = parang chan-
dong.
pgranggu. Set or suit; e.g. set of buttons or studs
(sa-perangguan butang, Sing. Terb.) or
suit of clothes (p. pakaian, Mar. Mah., Ind.
Meng., Ht. Sh., Perb. Jaya, Ht. Angg. 72).
A full perangguan of clothes consists of
trousers, coat, waistcloth, shouldercloth and
headcloth; but cf. a flying suit of two pieces
only (baju layang kain layang sa-perang-
guan), Raj. Muda 47.
Also (Batav.) perangkat.
pgrangkap. Cage-trap for birds or mice. Tarang
perangkap: artificial nesting-place with a

IV. Getah pgrcha: gutta percha;=getah
taban, getah meutaban.
[Etym. doubtful. The tree itself is taban;
its sap is getah taban. Ggtah percha was
a trade-name for the marketable article,
probably=«strip-gutta» from its appearance.
The great value attached to gutta is quite
modern and upsets any idea that the name
for Sumatra is linked with it.]

religious duties that are merely «com-
mendable® (sunat); cf. Ht. Bugis 148. See
also wajib.
[Thus there are five daily prayers that
are perlu, i.e. that it is a sin to omit; and
two extra daily prayers that are sunat, i.e.
that it is praiseworthy to make].
pßrlus. Stepping into a hole; putting the foot
into a catch of any sort. Esp. of animals
stumbling into pitfalls.
p&rmadani. [Old Jav. praraadani, prangwe-
dani] Floor-rug. Of imported floor - rugs
of any sort; and even (Pat.) of blankets or
bed-rugs. In contr. to small mats (tikar)
and rolls of matting or carpeting (hamparan).
Cf. p. buatnn Turki (Turkey rugs), Sid.
Rama 129; and (for its relatively small size)
its use as a sitting mat (Hg. Tuah 278,
Mai. Annals 171).
pgrmai. I. Pretty. Of a garment (Ht. Koris); road
(Mas Ed.); tank (Gul Bak. 87); hair or
tiesses (Ind. Meng.). Bbrtambah - tambah -
lah p. chantek mojSlis: he grew in beauty,
charm and daintiness (as he put on his
wondrous garments), Mai. Dem. 21.
11. Queen; Sh. Bid. 3. Short for pfir-
maisuri, q.v. Also pgrmai mbngindbra;
Raj. Jer. 29.
pgrmaisura. Skr. Lord of All. Applied formerly
to Siva (now Maisura, Maheswara, q.v.);
and to kings, e. g. to the first king of
Malacca (according to Albuquerque) and to
the first king of Siak at its conquest by
Mansur Shah (Mai. Annals 121, 122). Still
an honorific in Brunei; and often used in its
feminine form (pbrriiaisuri = queen).
See also 6swara.
pgrmaisuri. Skr. Queen; Queen Consort; wife of
a permaisura. Used of Queen Victoria (p.
Wiktoria, Ht. Abd. 304; also p. Kuin); of
the chief wives of kings of the Panji period
(junior wives being mahadewi, matur, liku
and mulangi); or principal commoner - wives
of Sultans of Perak (raja p., tbngku p.).
Otherwise raja porSmpuan, tbugku puan=
«queen» or «queen regnant* in Malaya: ratu,
ratu kenchana, ratu Sultan = «queen» in
Java. One passage (Mai. Dem. 101) speaks
of a junior queen as p. tfingah; in such
cases p. indera would be the first queen.
pgrrnan. Ar. Command (from Ood); = firman
Allah taala. See firman.

villages in Banka of which all the natives

I love a pearl; amid the grass
It keeps its hue though low it lies;
I love a girl; such love will pass;
A pearl of dew, it slowly dies.

pgrut. I. Belly; stomach; womb; (Min., N. S.)
uterine family.
(i) The organs of the stomach: p. b§sar
(visceral cavity, stomach proper); p. mnda
(enteron, intestine, = usns); ayer p. (gastric
juices, secretions of liver and pancreas);
selapnt p. (peritoneum); tali p. (viscera).
(ii) The stomach as part of the figure.
P. besar, p. bunchit, p. gSndut: big -
bellied; obese. P. kerapas: limp and flabby
about the stomach.
(iii) The stomach in connection with
digestive or intestinal feelings. P, kempong;
distention after a heavy meal. Alas p.:
appetizer. Bawa p.: to cadge for a meal.
Buta p.; indifference to what one eats.
Cherak p.: looseness of the bowels. KAnyang
p.: sated, of appetite. Memnlas p.: griping
pains. P. - nya lapar dan dahaga: he was
hungry and thirsty.
(iv) The uterus. P. b6sar, (Sum.) p.
gedang: pregnancy. P. padi=bunting padi;
see padi. Kirim p.: to bespeak a midwife.
Mandi lenggang p.: ceremonial «rocking» of
the body of a pregnant woman; = mandi
wilada. Didalam p. ibu - nya: in their
mother's wombs.
(v) In Min. and N. S.: uterine or matri-
lineal family, descent on the distaff side
alone being recognized. This is the family
unit in communities where the matriarchate
prevails, the tiead of it being (Min.) tung-
ganai, (N.S.) ibu-bapa’, buapa’.
(vi) Miscellaneous or figurative. Mfirut:
to swallow the bait —of a fish. P. bStis:
calf of leg. P. lemhu: tripe. Pftrntan kapal:
body or waist of ship. Pechah p.: to split
one’s sides with laughing. Chinchin p. lintah;
ring circular in section (but of uneven thick-
ness) suggesting a gorged leech.
(vii) Plant-names (from real or fancied
likenesses to stomachs: Byttneria main-
gayi (p. gagak, p. kechar); Erycibe
pr i n c e i (p. kerbau, p. kijang); Gnetum
campestre (p. 16nibu); Payer.a spp.
(p. pcdandok); S c i r p u s spp. (p. tikus); W.

pSsaka. I. Heirloom; family property; = (Min.)
pusaka, see also saka. In Malaya rather
an indefinite word for any «heirloom» (cf.
keris itu asal-nyap.: the kris was an old
heirloom in his family; Mar. Mah.) and even
of piracy as the national heritage of the
Malay (merompak itu sudah p. - nya), Ht.
Abd. In Min. and N.S. pusaka represents
property of which the family enjoys only the
usufruct. This covers all inherited property
in contr. to personal earnings (harta pen-
charian) which are the absolute property of
the persons earning them during their lifetime
and only become harta pusaka at death; cf.
the saying dari ulat bulu, kupu-kupu; dari
pencharian pusaka (the caterpillar becomes
the moth, property earned becomes property
entailed). Such property is inherited in tail
female: tSrbit p. kapada saka (inheritance
comes through the mother).
Kata p., kata saka: tradition as embodied
in old sayings. Gelar p.: a family title; see
gelar. Tanah p.: inherited land that one
cannot readily alienate.

saka. From Jav. saka=(Mal.) tiang.

11. Pesan - pesan: a venomous spider
(Poecilotheria sp.); lustrous black hard
body with yellow stripes. Si-p. (or sepSsan):
(Sum.) a centipede; = (Min.) si-pasan.
[Gimlette (Mai. Poisons, p. 144) gives
the pesan as a grasshopper, Gryllacris
sp.; and this has support from Kedah where
it is described as a keridek. The insect
described above (lustrous, black, hard, yellow-
striped) was actually collected by me in the
Bindings and was said bj< all to be very
venomous, but it was not identified and
cannot he asserted positively to have been a
spider].

his courtiers. See also wijil.

pSsolot. A short creek; J.S.A.S.
p2sona. [Pers. afsun] Spell; incantation; sorcery.
Of witchcraft (ilnui p.); assailing by sorcery
(membuat p.); being the victim of sorcery
(kena p.); sorcerer or sorceress (si -p., Gul
Bak. 80; orang p., Sh. Bid. 47); cf. siapa-

pesong. Terpesong: diverted in its course. Ot a

pSstaka. I. [Skr.; = book] Book of divination or
sorcery; black art generally. Has a wide
range of meaning, viz.:
(i) book of divination (Hg. Tuah 167, 177,
217);
(ii) fortune as read or worked out from a
book of divination; cf. p. kuda ini baik dan
jahat-nya (the horoscope of this horse and
the good or evil in it), Hg. Tuah 119;
(iii) the magic or fortune investing any-
thing; cf. p. pakaian itu (the magic in those
garments), Gem. Ht. 34; demikian - lah p.
keris itu (such was the magic of the kris);
Mar. Mah.;
(iv) a magical weapon, e.g. the magic
weapon (p. Kalimasada) of Yudisthira that
could take any form he chose, see Tk. ii
226, iv 212;
(v) sorcery or the black art: kbras p.-nya


daripada haraba (his magic is mightier
than I), Sh. Kub.;
(vi) a spell or curse or evil as the result
of sorcery (bala p.; mala p., Gem. Ht. 12;
malang p., Gul Bak. 89; also mala-pataka,
Tk. iv. 507).

newly drawn), Ind. Nata; didalam hati
sudah di - potakan (she is imaged in one’s
heart), Lail. Majn. 33. But in modern Malay
of a map, a working plan, or any basis for
working on; e.g. p. rumah (plan of a house),
also rimba rumah.
11. PSta-ratna: dais of honour; a variant
(Sh. Kub., Raj. Muda 131) of peterana, q.v.
Also peta-ra’na, peta-rana.
peta. Clearly; plainly. Pandang p.-p.: to make
out distinctly.
petah. See pitah (witty).
pßtai. A tree, Parkia speciosa. Also (Java)
pete; (Min.) patai; and patal (Cl.). It bears
a long pod with flat beans that smell
offensively but are thought good eating
whether cooked or raw.

petak. I. Compartment. Of a storage hold or
compartment in a Malay ship (p. jubong),
Ht. Angg. 49; cubicles or divisions of a house
with floors at different levels (p. rumah),
Gem. Ht. 81; a wardrobe divided into com-
partments (lomari yang bfirpetak - petak),

(Mai.) division of a rice-field,=(N.S.) 18pak,

pStaka. Skr. Curse; = pataka or pestaka, q.v.
pgtal. A variant (01.) of pfitai (Parkia
speciosa).
pgtala. Skr. Fold; layer; stratum. Esp. of the
seven strata (Skr. sapta-patala) of the
sky and the earth. These should not be
confused with the seven heavens or the
seven hells. Cf. falak, tank.
[The «seven firmaments* (tujoh pefala
langit) are the Ar. samawat; a heaven
is (Ar.) jannat = (Skr.) shurga. Each of
these is the residence of a nabi. The first
(Adam’s) is of virgin silver; the second
(Enoch’s) of gold; the third (Joseph’s) of
pearl; the fourth (Christ’s) of emerald; the
fifth (Aaron’s) of ruby; the sixth (Moses’)
of garnet; and the seventh (Abraham’s) of
crystal or light. But there is much difference
of opinion regarding these materials; Bost.
Sal. i 35, 36.
The seven strata of the earth (tujoh lapis
dunia, tujoh p. bumi) should also not be
confused with the seven hells (naraka);
They are made, like the heavens, of materials
that are the subject of controversy; but their
inhabitants are as follows: in the seventh,
Angels; in the sixth, Iblis and all his hosts;
in the fifth, evil spirits (shaitan); ' in the
fourth, snakes; in the third, scorpions; in
the second, genii; in the first, Man. Cf. Bost.
Sal. i 55.
The name p. bumi is given also to some
magical simples including leaves of Eur y-
coma longifolia and Rourea humilis;
Bid.]
pCtaling. A tree, Ochanostachys amentacea.
It gives a hard timber that is white-ant-proof.
Also (specifically) p. bukit.
Other trees known by this name are


Homalium frutescens (p. aver); H.
griffithianum (p. jantan); Strom-
bosiarotundifolia (p. gajah); Aporosa
prainiana (p. fandok); and Antidesma
cuspi datum (p. tugar); W.

pafamari. A light vessel built for speed
rather than for cargo-carrying capacity; cf.
petamari ia-itn perahu yang bertiang satu
chondong ka-haluan (a pattymar, i.e. a ship
having a single mast with a forward rake),
Abd. Jud. 6. It is still in use (commonly
with two masts) on the Malabar coast. Etym.,
(Konkani) path-mar (courier; t'dings-biinge;).

pStaram. I. Pukat petaram (or petarangi: (East

of fish is located the net is laid as far round
it as possible and the fish are then driven
by noise in the direction where the net lies.

pichit. I. Pinching; compression in the hand; a
form of massage, = (Java) pijit, pijet.
Memichit: to massage by taking the flesh
firmly in the hand and using the thumb


(without ointment or lotion); Ind. Nata, Ht.
Koris, Abd. Mk. 88. It represents massage
by kneading and light pounding in contr. to
massage by rubbing (burnt). Pichitkan: to
squeeze, e.g. to squeeze a girl’s hand or
finger (di - pichitkan jari pbrmaisuri); Ht.
Koris. P. pblipis: pinching the temples as a
cure for dizziness.
Keris pichit: kris «shaped by finger-
pressure*. Malays believe that certain
smiths of old time had the power to mould
iron with their fingers; cf. jikalau besi pun
di-p.-nya menjadi lilin (were it steel and
he pinched it, it became as wax in his hand),
Sh. Mard. But the alleged «finger - marks*
on a so-called keris p. may be the ordinary
marks known as pijbtan in Java.

restrict supplies.

pinang. I. Areca-palm; areca-nut; a gen. name
for many palms suggesting the areca - palm
and for many things associated with the
areca - nut.
(i) A plant - name for: Areca catechu
(pinang); the sealing-wax palm, Cyrtosta-
chys lakka (p. laka, p. raja); the «Penang
lawyer*, Licuala acutifida (p. liar);
the common Pinanga malayana (p.
boreng, p. kampong, p. linau, p. s 6 > bawa);
and the following (given by Watson):
Pinanga disticha (p. boreng padi); P.
polyraorpha (p. d£gong, p. legong); P.
scortechinii (p. lokal); Iguanura
co rn icu 1 ata (p. angin); I. geonoma e-
formis (p. burong, p. k6lasak„ p. pachat,
p. tikus); Areca furcata (p. kaki pSlan-
dok); Actinorhytis calapparia (p.
bantu, p. penawar, p. sftnawnr); Meliosma
nitida (p. pfdandok); Gonostylus
maingayi (p. muda); Pentace triptera
(p. baik); and a grass, Mariscus cype-
rin u s (rumput p.). Burkill adds: Aniso-
phylla disticha (p. kanchil); and
Agelaea wallichii (pokok p. kotai).
(ii| The areca - nut (buah p., jambi,
puchang) is prepared in various ways for
chewing with betel - leaf (sireh); p. awak
(with its ends sliced off and the rest cut
into four parts); p. jfirkat or (Pk., Ked.) p.
kachat or (Min.) p. lachak (unripe); p.
k£dat (at its best and tart in taste); p. kotai,
Kel. p. kusi (dry and hard); p. rampang,
p. tokek (juiceless); p. ukup (perfumed);
sabut p. (areca - nut fibre); tanipok p.
(corolla of nut).
(iii) Appliances connected with the chewing
of the areca-nut include: chawan p., pfibuah
(cup, holder); I6kas p. (box for all appli-
ances); lesong p. or gobek (pounder for
crushing the nut for consumption by people
with poor teeth).
(iv) Associated with the sending of areca-
nut and sireh along with a formal proposal
of marriage are: (to ask in
marriage); sireh peminang (the ornamental
leaves and nut sent with a proposal); cf.
also Mai. Pant. 73,
Anak orang di-pandang sahaja,
Hbndak pinang tidak berduit:
the maid is there; I can but look; I lack
the cash to seek her hand.
(v) Areca-nut grain (bfiras bunga p.) is
used also at royal obsequies.
Other pinang expressions are:
(i| p. bfirjijek; «palms in ordered rows*,
as evidence of long tenure of land;
(ii) p. kotai: dry nut (see above), cut in
two and attached to levers for pressure on
the temples in a cruel form of torture;
(iii) p. kotai bukit: a millipede, Chi 1 o-
gnatha sp.; known also as gonggok and
tSnggulong;
(iv) p. n asak: deep rich yellow, the hue
of the ripe nut;


(v) p. muda: young nut, of which the
two halves are symbols of a perfect match,
Adek chantek, abang chantek,
Bagai pinaug b6lah dna:
Fair the maid and fair the swain
As a pinang cut in twain;
whence p. muda has become a euphemism
for one who brings lovers together, i.e., a
go-between or procuress; Pel. Abd. 78, Kal.
Dam. 55;
(vi) belalang p.: a brown-bodied cricket
with green wings;
(vii) chink p., pipit p.: a finch, Muni a
acuticauda or M. punctulata.

pingit. Being shut up; confinement to the house.
Esp. of unmarried girls in seclusion (gadis-
gadis pingitan, Sid. Rama 120; anak dara
yang pingitan, Gem. Ht. 23; anak - anak
dara pingitan, Sid. Rama 184); cf. also
btirpingit seperti anak dara (shut up in
the house like a maiden daughter), Gem. Ht.
9. Malay girls are shut up in this way from
the time they become marriageable to the
time they are married. But the word is
applied also to a wife who is allowed no
liberty by a jealous husband, and is even
used (Al. Mai. 80) of the way the Yamtuan
Muda of Riau controlled the Yamtuan
Bflsar.

pirukang. Ikan pirukang; (Pen.) a fish-name;
gen. for many Ari ida e, = pedukang, q.v.

God pardon it, God forbid; -= astaghfir
Allah.

(Ism. Yat.) and permata pirus, Jay. Asm.
118.
11. = perus (pale).
piruzah. Pers. Turquoise; = firuzah.
pis. Interjection to frighten cats. Also pus
and pas.
pisah. I. (Batav., from Jav. and Sund.) To
sever; separation; = ch6rai. Pisahkan: to
divide; to segregate; Pet. Ayam 105. Berpi-
sah: to he separated, cf.
Bdrpisah jauh tiada mengapa,
Badan - nya jauh, hati - nya d£kat;
what care I if we be parted parted in
body when linked in heart!
pisak. I. (W. Sum.) A piece; a bit. Sa -p. roti:
a bit of bread; Dl.
11. = pesak (gusset).
pisang. I. «Banana». In various senses:
(i) gen. for Musa spp.; e.g., the banana
(M. paradisiaca); Manila hemp (M. te x-
til i s = p. menila); the wild plantain (M.
malaccensis = p. hutan); and the wax -
plantain (M. sp. =p. lilin);
(ii) a specific name for the banana in its
many forms (see below);
(iii) «banana - coloured*, i.e. pale yellow
in descriptive names of animals, e.g. chiak
pisang, beronok p.;
(iv) a number of plants suggesting the
banana in some way (pisang -
pfirpisang, pepisang, merpisang), see be-
low;
(v) the imported persimmon (p. kaki);
(vi) the banana as a plant and a food;
(vii) Min., the papaya (p. pela, p. P6tu-
kal), see betek; and
(viii) Min., the pineapple (p. anas).
The principal varieties of banana are;
(i) p. mas (small, gold-yellow, popular);


(ii) p. raja, buah punti (large, ruddy -
skinned, good eating);
(iii) p. Ambon or p. hijau (large and
green, good eating);
(iv) p. Almeida, p. rastali (Singapore
varieties);
(v) p. susu (veiy delicate in flavour);
(vi) p. tandok, p. kapas, p. rimpi (edible
only in cooked form).
Other varieties (of little importance) are:
p. abu; p. anak lebah; p, awak; p. ayam;
p. batu; p. bbraksa or p. raksa; p. bbrangan;
p. Boyan; p. gombur; p. gbrasau; p. buaya
or p. jari buaya; p. kajar; p. karok (a wild
variety of which the leaves are used as
torches); p. kelat; p. keling; p. lang; p.
Ibmah manis; p. lidi; p. moris; p. monyet;
p. muli; p. nangka; p. Padang; p. Pahang;
p. pinang; p. sbrendah; p. udang; p.
wangi.
The term pisang-pisang includes a number
of wild anonaceous plants (from the shape
of their fruits), Bkl. They include:
(i) Uvaria purpurea (p.-p. jantan,
p.-p. kuning, p.-p. tandok);
(ii) U. dulcis (p.-p. hitam);
(iii) Unona discolor (p.-p. buku);
(iv) U. dumosa (p.-p. padi, p.-p. pipit);
(v) Melodorum prismaticum(akar
p.-p. bukit);
(vi) Phyticrene palmata (akarp.-p.
buloh).
Other pisang expressions are: p. goreng
(banana toasted on a pan); p. memaudak
(see pandak); p. rendang (banana fritter);
p. sa-biji, p. sa-butir (a single banana);
p. sa-sikat, p. sa-sisir (a comb or single
row of bananas); p. sa-tandan (a whole bunch
of bananas; also, descriptively, a penthouse);
katak p. (tree - frog, 11 hacop h o r u s
leucomystaxor Rana erythraea);
kolak p. (bananas stuffed with palm-sugar
and coconut-milk), Ht. Panji 96; sa-pbr-
pisang (as long as it takes to eat a banana;
a primitive measure of time); tali p. (dried
strips of banana); aku bukan budak-budak
makan p. (I am no banana - eating boy, i.e.,
I was not born yesterday), Prov.
11. Pisang-pisang or (Red.) pgpisang;
rubbing - strake on a Mala} boat.
111. Ikan pisang-pisang: (N.S.) sea-
bream, Caesio spp,, = delah.
pisau. Knife. The term includes:
(i) table - knives (p. meja) and bread -
knives (p. paring);
(ii) clasp-knives (p. lipat, p. chaku), office
pen - knives (p. lidah ayam), and lancets
(p. daun padi);
(iii) razors (p. chukur, p. pfinchukur, p.
pPnyukur) and saw-edged knives for tooth-
filing (P- gfTgaji, p. geriujam);
(iv) knives for Malay wood - carving
(p. rant, p. pangot, for rough work, and
p. wali, p. bayong, for finer work);
(v) jungle - knives (p. chandong for all
purposes; p. chalok, p. chalong, with
curved point for felling undergrowth; p. pen-
jangat for splitting rattans; p. sadap for
tapping trees).
Other expressions are: ikan p. (a skeleton-
fish, Amphisile spp.; also Centriscus
sp.); umpan p. («knife - food*, i. e., fore-
doomed to an ignominious death); burong p.
rant (a heron, Ardea sp., = burong
ranggong).

examine witnesses one by one.
piskal. [Dutch] Procurator - fiscal; sheriff; Ht.
Abd. 22. In old Malacca it meant an officer
with powers of summary jurisdiction in small
cases and of prosecution in serious cases.

pitam. Bush of blood to the head causing

[Vertigo, described by Malays as «a
rush of blood to the head causing dimness
of vision and a sensation as if the earth was
being folded up to engulf us»; Giml.]

pitek. See petek (a sea-perch).
pltSra. See pitrah (charitable levy).
piling. Short for kgpiting (crab); Kl.
pitis. Ch. Coin of very low denomination; usually
of tin (p. tiniah) and with a hole in the
centre, suggesting an imitation of Chinese
cash. Hid. Veth xxxix 7. Also pichis,
pisis and pipis. In Marsden’s time COO
pitis went to a Spanish dollar; Abdullah
gives 3840 tin Trengganu p. to the dollar
(Pel. Abd. 35); lately in Kelantan 480 tin
p. represented a Straits dollar. P. of low
denomination are referred to in the Hang
Tuah (p. 122). On the other hand one old
passage (Mas Ed.) speaks of p. of gold and
silver; and the word p. is used sometimes
for cash or money generally; Must. Adat
20, 52. For etymology see pichis. P.-p.:
pennywort, Sarcolobus globosus; Bid.
Akar p.: a creeper, Dischydia collyris,
W. Tabong p.: money - box.
pitnah, = fitnah (slander).
pitrah. Ar. A charitable contribution of a gantang
of rice made by every member of a Malay
mosque - congregation at the end of the
fasting - month for the nominal purpose of
enabling their poor to celebrate properly the
great annual festival (hari raya bdsar).
[See «Achehnese», pp. 238 - 240 for
details as to its distribution. Also fitrah;
(Batav.) pitera].
Known also as zakat badan in contr. to
the tithe or true zakat levied on property.
pitu. Jav. Seven; = tujoh. Bulan kbpitu:
seventh month.
pitting. Paring pitung; (Java) bamboo, Dendro-
calamus spp.,=buloh b6tong, awi bitung.
piun. I. Port. Peon; office - messenger. Etym.
= «pawn» (at chess) = footman, foot - soldier
(Hind.piadah); whence «orderly, messenger*.
Practically confined to Government office -
messengers, those in mercantile offices being
known as tambi, q.v. The Hindustani word
piadah has also been used in the past in
the Sp. Secretariat.

pokok. Stem or trunk, i.e. beginning = pohon.
In various senses:
(i) the tree-trunk as suggesting the tree:
p. kayu (tree), p. kblapa (coconut - palm);
hasil p. (tree - revenue, i. e. assessment on
cultivation);
(ii) a tree - trunk as suggesting the
beginnings of anything: p. angin (storm -
cloud); p. hujan ((rain-cloud); pulang p. (to
get back one’s capital only, i.e. to be back
where one started); pokok - nya (it began as
follows);
(iii) «trunk» in the sense of source: p.
pencharian (main source of livelihood), Sul.
Hid. 9, = p. penghidupan (Sul. Hid. 6);
pokok = capital (Pet. Ayam 10);
(iv) «trunk» as principal part: p. hikayat
(leading characters in a tale), Sid. Rama 1;
p. pencharian (principal quest, i.e. the
pursuit of knowledge); Must. Adat 23;
(v) the butt or «■ trunk* of a counterfoil
receipt;
(vij the tree-trunk itself, e.g. pangkal p.
(lower part of trunk).

polong. I. A familiar spirit. Practically identical
with one form of the pelesit, q.v.; a bottle -
imp, blood-fed by its owner (jinjangan), Ht.
Abd. 108, 109; and sent out in the form ot
a cricket (bblalang pelesit, bblalang hantu,
bblalang bajang). Cf. also: daun p. (a
parasite destroying the tree to which it
attaches itself); seperti p. kena sembur
(like a familiar spirit spat at with holy
water), Prov.
Represented variously: as any small animal,
reptile or spirit (Malay Sketches pp. 197,
198); as a sort of penanggalan (Mai. Magic
582). Probably a confusion of several myths:
that of the vampire (langsuyar, sundal
belong); that of the manjangan or penang-
galan familiar; and that of ghost - crickets
(bblalang hantu).

45, Perch. Mai. 30.
Pontianak, A Borneo Sultanate founded in the
last part of the eighteenth Century by an
Arab of the Al-Kadri family with a fol-
lowing of Arabs, Bugis and Borneo Malays.
Malay is the language of the rulers; the
major officials are wazir, the district-heads
wakil raja and the village headmen
kobayan.
pontianak, = puntianak (birth-spirit).
ponting. I. (Slang) To cheat; to bilk. Also punting,
ponteng. Prom Ch.; Hn.
If. (Batav.) To run away; Z. Cf. pontang.
pontoh. Dragon - armlet. Worn in Java on the
upper arm; in Malaya as bracelets on the
wrist; referred to (Ht. Bakht.) as worn on
the ankles. Not in common use but mentioned
in literature: (p. bernaga), Ht. Koris, Ht.
Bakht.; (bfirpontoh) Perb. Jaya, Mai.
Annals 66. Two pair (p. bbrnaga, p. ular
lidi) are included in the Perak regalia.

poyot. Ancestor in the fifth or sixth generation.
Also moyot, buyut, boyot, monyet. Cf.
piut.
puadai. Tam. A cloth or mat used as a seat for
royalty. Described variously: in the Malacca
Code (Newbold ii 234, 335) as a cloth,
usually white, over which a funeral procession
passes; as a paclxar or sitting - mat (Tk. ii
216); as a curtained seat for a married pair
(Tk. ii 216); as something «>rolden<> (p. yang
kemasan) on which a prince sat at his
religious marriage (Mai. Annals 253); as a
seat (mat or dais) for bride and bridegroom
at their borsanding or sitting in state (Ht.
Bangs. 40, Ht. Panj. 76); and as a jrolden
processional litter in which a bridegroom
was borne round the town (Ht. Panj. 129).
puah. 1. Puah-puah or frizzly - haired;
Papuan; cf. kulit-mu hitani sa-bagai Puah-
puah (your skin is black as that of a Papuan),
Ind. Nata.
11. = puar (Amomum sp.) and afuah
(holy powers).
puak. I. Troupe; large group. In various senses:
(Pen., Ked., Pk.) troupe or company, =
pasok; (Pah.) family group, = sanak; cf. also:
berpuak (to be herded together, of animals',
Ht. Best.; kaum p. or (Baba) puak - puak
(folk, kindred); maka sogala p. masing-
masing naik ka - atas bahtera - nya (the
various ship’s - companies departed, each to
its own ship), Ht. Hamz.
11. Belalai puak: a plant (unid.) of which
the root is used medicinally. Cf. puar.
puaka. Genius loci; spirit of a locality.
Bbrpuaka: haunted. Identified sometimes
with the earth - spirits (jembalang, pelak,
hantu tanahl to which sacrifices are offered;
cf. jembalang p. mdnjadi nyawa kapada
tanah (the earth-spirits are the living forces
in the earth), Mai. Magic 583; see also the
sacrifices offered (a fowl if the puaka is
strong, a mere egg if the p. is little), Mai.
Magic GOO. But modern Malays discriminate
between the earth forces (which are every-
where) and the p. which is a special spirit
haunting some definite spot and whom the
reverence ol ages may turn into a dato’ ke-
ramat or tutelary and miracle-working saint.
The puaka is mentioned: Perch. Mai. 78;
cf. also Mai. Pant. 88G,
Ayer berputar jangan chebok,
Puaka besar dudok menunggu:
dip no bowl in eddying wmter, Some grim
ghost is lurking there.
Cf. angkar, dedemit in Java.

puan. I. Caddy - shaped large betel - bowl; cf.
puan yaani tempat sireh (a puan i.e. a
receptacle for betel leaf); Ht. Bugis 26, cf.
also Mai. Annals 159 where the Sultan takes
betel from his puan. Two golden p. are
included in the Perak regalia (p. naga tarn, p.
bujur). An attendant in the prince’s train bore
the p. on his lap or against his chest
(niembawa p., Mai. Annals 102; moriba p.,
lit. Angg. 34; memangku p.).

puar. I. A gen. name for wild gingers and esp.
for the local cardamom, in contr. to the


imported cardamom (kepulaga, buah pcdaga,
kerengga - munggu). Watson gives:
(i) Globba spp.: G. malaccensis (p.
udang, p. rimba); G. aurantiaca (p.
kumbar); G. panicoides (p. birah);
(ii) Amomum spp.: A. cardamomum
(puar); A. uliginosum (p. hijau, p.
gajah); A. squarrosum (p. tad ah embun);
(iii) Alpinia spp.; A. cannaefolia
(p. xninyak); A. javanica (p. puteh);
A. rafflesiana (p. mungkang);
(iv) Elletariopsis pubescens (p.
kanipong).

puas. To have had enough: (Kel.) to have had
more than enough, cl. jemu. P. hati:
satisfied. Minum ayer sa-p.-p.: to drink
one’s fill. P. - lah sudah di - chanangkan:
it had been sufficiently advertised. Sudah
p. tuan melihat taman itu: have you looked
at the garden long enough. Lihat-lah enchek
puas - puas: have a good look at everything;
Ht. Abd. 228.
puasa. Skr. Fast; abstinence from food or drink.
Puasakan: to make or observe a fast; Ht.
Abus. 32. Esp. of the Great Fast (p. Ra-
madzan) held during the month*
(bulan p.) of Ramadzan during which period
every Moslem must fast throughout the
daytime (p. pada slang hari, Kal. Dam. 380).
This is followed by the Great Feast known
as the hari raya p. to distinguish it from
the hari raya haji. Minor fasts (p. sunat,
Ht. Bugis) are observed by the religious at
other seasons but are neither general nor
obligatory, e.g. the p. shawal or p. enam
for six days in the month shawal.

puchat. I. Pallor; wan. P. kesi, p. 16si, p. 16su,
p. perang, perang-perus, puteh p.: blanched;
very wan. P. manai: anaemic. P. muka:

wan. P. pudar: see pudar.
If. Dirty (of the tongue); furred; Z.
puchek. Principal post or pile in the construction
of a large marine hshtrap. Placed at the
outer or seaward end of the trap; either as
a single pile (in the belat Kedah or belong)
or as a pair (p. tua, to the left, looking
seaward; p. muda to the right). These two
are joined by a sort of St. Andrew’s cross
in the bdlat Belawi hut not in the jermal.
Upon the puchek are hung the offerings to
the Spirits of the Sea.
Also puchik; and puchi (Mai. Magic 78).
puchi or puchik. See puchek.

pugar. Repair; restoration to health or to good

puin. (Batav., from Dutch) Rubbish; scrap.
pilja. Skr. The ritual of paganism or superstition.
Etym., the ritual of Hinduism; used at
present of the ritual and ceremonial of
sorcerers and (in literature) of worshipping
idols (mSmuja bfirata); cf. Sh.Kub., Ind Meng.,
Jay. Asm. 138, Ht. Angg. 150, Mai. Dem.
20. In India p. means ceremonial rather than
language (flag-puj a = trooping of colours); in
Malaya p. is rather the utterance of sorcerers’
texts over an object, e.g. the magic words
of Brahma and Vishnu over the nagasari -
flowers that they turned into Darmadewa and
Darmedewi (Sg. Samb.); or the mumbling
of texts by a Malay pawang, cf. kayu
gaharu kayu puaka, sukat di-puja baharu
di-pakai (agila wood is a wood that is
haunted, only by magical words to be won),
Mai. Pant. Cf. also puji 11.
puji. I. Praise; laudation. Angka pujian: marks
for merit, Puji-pujian: the • compliments®
that begin a Malay letter. Memuji diri:
self- praise. Kitab puji-pujian: hymnbook.
Shaer puji-pujian: complimentary addresses
in verse. P. dan chela; praise and blame.
Tiada ia malm memuji tulisan - ku; he
would not say anything nice about my
handwriting.
11. Skr. Superstitious or pagan ritual; =
puja. P. padi: the harvest ceremonies by
the sorcerer (pawang); Mai. Magic 230.
Memuji berhala; to do worship to an idol;
Lang. Buana 35, = memuja berhala, niemuja
berata.
plljok. Coaxing; blandishment; blarney. Pujokkan:
to coax (a person); to wheedle; Sh. Bid. 46.
Memujok: to say nice things; Gul Bak. 101.
P. empeuak: spoiling (a child); making too
much of any one. P. Melayu: «Malay blarneys
(which is proverbial). P. pangku belai:
wheedling, cuddling and caressing; Mai. Dem.
57.

pujut. To strangle; Kl., = kujut.
pukah, = pokah (twisted, spoilt).
pukal. Lump; clod; meaty. P. hati: to make up
one’s mind. Bayar p.: to pay in a lump
sum. Kgris sa-p.: a kris hammered out of
one piece of steel (not out of two, the blade
proper and the ganja, q.v.) = keris ganja
iras. In the Peninsula a kgris sa-p. is a
straight-bladed kris in contr. to a sinuous
(kgris bgrlok), but the source of the name
lies in the difference in making the two
kinds. Mas sa-p.: a nugget of gold. F. isi -
nya ikan ini: this fish has lots of flesh on
it; Hn.
pukang. Fork; thigh-joint (of animal); crosspiece
(of anchor). P. ayam: a pattern in lace -
making. Sela p.: perineum; Panj. Sg., =
chelali kangkang. Tulang p.: ilium (in
man); upper part ot hindleg (in horse); Peng.
Kuda 43. Kain terlengser terbuka p.: the
sarong slipped down exposing the privities;
Panj. Sg. Cf. pukas, puki.
Pukang-pukang; ghost of which only
the legs are visible. Lintang p., pokok p.;
lying across one another at right angles, like
the crosspiece (pukang) of a Malay anchor
in contr. to the shaft (batang sauh); or
like two wooden darts sharpened at both
ends (soligi tajam bertimbal) and then
fastened at their centres to form a pukang
or hook for crocodiles; see alir.
Cf. kukang, kongkang.
pukas. Nudity; improper or indecent exposure.
Berpukas ka-laut: to plunge naked into the
sea (deemed most improper); Maxw. Rama
5. Mandi berpukas-pukasan: to bathe
shamelessly with no clothes on; Ht. Koris,
cf. also Mai. Dewa 88. Berpukas-pukasan
tiada sgdarkan kain: quite naked, caring
nothing for their clothes: Ind. Meng. Cf.
pukang.
[Used esp. of latah-subjects who strip
themselves when under the influence of the
disease; see latah.]
pukat. I. Net; drift-net; seine;=(Brun.) rambat.
Specifically of nets that drag fish ashore or
into which fish are driven or over which
they are attracted. Barrier-nets and simple
drifting nets are jaring. P. is used also of
fowlers’ nets (p. tanah, bantau). Pemukatan:
a long narrow Brunai type of fishing boat.
Bentang p.; to put nets out to dry. Matap.:
mesh of net. Pawang p.: expert in charge
of net-fishing. P6rahu p.; boat for deep-sea
fishing. Sampan p.: cinghy used with nets.
The num. coeif. of pukat is rentang.
Nets are differentiated sometimes by the
fish that their size of mesh is meant to
catch; e.g.:p. kedgra, p. siakap, p. talang, p.
udang. Otherwise their main varieties are
as follows:
(i) p. bawal, p. tanggok: a purse-net
for catching mullet that follow a clump of
fronds;
(ii) p. chang: a small deep-sea net worked
hy a large boat and a swimmer for
encircling shoals of fish;
(iii) p. china; seine with pocket;
(iv) p. dalam; large gill-net about nine
dgpa deep and worked on the East Coast by
about a dozen men;
( v ) P- goggong: small Danish seine or
purse-net worked from a boat in shallow
water by one man;
(vi) p. hanyut: drift-net into which fish
are driven;
(vii) p. ikan: light seine worked hy
three or four men;
(viii) p. kesut: an East Coast light river -
seine;
(ix) p. kisa: see kisa;
(x) p. lengkong: pocketless seine;
(xi) p. payang, p. petaram, p. pgtarang:
large East Coast seine-net laid round a
shoal of fish by a big boat and a dinghy;
(xii) p. sudu: an East Coast purse-net
worked by three boats to catch pomfret;
(xiii) p. tangkul; ground-net over which
fish are attracted by bait;
(xiv) p. tarek: seine-nets generally.
Cf. also: p. berahi (nets of love); p. di -
darat («fishinir on shore* = looking for
trouble); p. kikis (a fleecer); p. subal (net
of coarse material); p. tgrbubul (patched
nets); laksana sampan p. (<dike a fisherman’s
dinghy»=that never goes far afield), Prov.
11. Buah pukat: the avocado-pear,
Persea gratissima; = buah apukat;
buah pokat (Kl.); buah teiupurong. From
Dutch advocaat.
pukau. I. Narcotic (commonly datura seed burnt


under a house) used by thieves to drug to
sleep people whose quarters they propose to
burgle. NySdar laksana terkSna p.: as
dead to the world as a man drugged to
sleep; Lail. Mejn, 6. Cf. Mai. Poisons 215,
216.
11. Burong pukau: a bird, sp. unid.; Dl.
See pikau.
puket. (Batav.) Crosspiece of a kris - sheath; =
sarapir or (Java) warangka.
puki. (Vulgar) Female genitals;=(Batav.) chuki;
(Min.) chakai, charut; (Orang Laut) bonek;
cf. pantek, pantat, pukang. P. anjing: a
plant, Cynometra cauliflora. P. ma’:
a grossly insulting expression; =p. ma’ di-
amput kuda. Also pantek ibu and (Batav.)
p. mai.
pukul. Strike; hit; knock; to take (at chess); to
multiply (=dzarab); to average. An idiomatic
word ot wide meaning, not confined to any
kind of blows and used loosely in many
other senses: p. bangkong (to draw a
lottery); p. bantai (to give a man a hammering);
p. bbsi (to shoe a horse); p. chanang (to
beat a gong); p. chap (to print); p. £mpat
(four o’clock); p. lobang (to work as a broker);
p. lotSrai (to raffle); p. ratakan (to strike an
average); p. talifun (to use the telephone);
p. tambur (to beat the drum). Ikan p.
gfindang: a fish; the star - gazer, Per c i s
pulc h e 11 a.
pul. Kachang pul: a bean, sp. unid.
pula. Anew; again; then. Dfimikian p.: so then.
Dan - lagi - pula: once again; moreover.
Mengapa p.; why then. Siapa p.: who then.
Pula never begins a phrase; it always follows
the word to which it relates.
Also pulak.
pulaga, = pSlaga (cardamom).
pulai. A lofty tree, Alstonia scholar is.
It gives a light cork-like wood (kayu gabus);
its latex makes a poor rubber; and its bitter
bark (cortex Ditae) is a medical drug
of some value.
P. pipit: Elaeocarpus stipularis.
P. bukit; Alstonia macrophylla; W.
pulak. I. Brun.) To pluck fruit or flowers. Alto
pupul.
11. See pula (anew).
pulam. See pualam (alabaster).
pulan. I. Inadhesive; crisp; nicely boiled. Of
well-cooked rice, the grains of which do not
stick to one another. Masak nasi p. -p.,
kasi niakan raja kita: cook the rice crisp
and nice; give it to our prince to eat; Ind.
Nata.
11. = polan (so - and - so).
pulang. Return to one’s home or first place of
departure; to revert. Pulangkan: to restore;
to give back.
P. pohon: anniversary; see pohon. P.
pokok: to get back one’s outlay. P. puleh:
to he restored (e.g. to health or prosperity).
P. ka-rahmat Allah: «to return to God’s
Mercy*, = to die. Tiada di-16pas p.: not
allowed to go home. P6nyakit-ku itu-pun
p. - lah sbperti sedia - kala: my illness came
back as badly as before, i.e. I had a
severe relapse.
Cf. kembali.
pulas. I. Wringing; twisting; (fig.) extorting or
cheating. Pulaskan leher; to wring the
neck. Memulas perut or mulas perut or
sakit memulas: gripes, colic. Pfimulas
sekerup: screw - driver. Pa’ Pulas: an old
Shylock; Gem. Ht. 3. Yang tolinga lembut
ia-itu-lah orang hendak p.: «a man with
soft ears is bound to get them twisted*, a
lamb is born to be fleeced; Prov.
11. Pulas hantu: a plant, Petu n g a
venul o s a.
111. See pulasan.
pulasan. I. The <-.pulasan» fruit-tree, Nephe-
lium mutabile. The fruit resembles
that of the ra nbutan but has short stumpy
excrescences instead of the long chairs* that
give the latter its name. Also rambutan
kapri, sangga lotong.
P. hutan: a tree, Anthocephalus
indicus. Akar p.: Flacourtia jango-
m a s; Bkl.
11. The Malay weasel, Putorius
n u d i p e s; j6lu masak pisang.
pulasari. A climber with yellow flowers, Alyxia
s tel lata. Also pelasari and merapblas
hari. Its bark (cortex Alyxiae) is a
remedy for dysentery and sprue.


pulau. I. Isolated patch; island. Also (Sp.,
Batav.) pulo. Of patches of land in the sea
(waterless rocks are tokong); islands in
rivers; dry land surrounded by swamp;
patches of forest (p. hutan) surrounded by
ricefields. Very large islands (such as Bali
or larger) are tanah. Pulaukan: to isolate; to
boycott. Kepulauan; (the Indian) Archipelago;
Indonesia, Sul. Ment. 83; but smaller
«archipelagoes» are tokong p. or gugusan p.
Hati ingin memandang pulau,
PSrahu ada kemudi tidak:
the sight of her isle sets me pining, my
shallop a rudderless craft; Mai. Pant. 359.
In a river-island the point upstream is
kepala p.; downstream, buntut p. or ekur
p. or burit p. Groups of islands are some-
times known by the number of their larger
units, e. g. the Pulau Sfimbilan (off the
mouth of the Perak River) and the Pulau
Tujoh in the China Sea. These last include
Jemaja, SCrasan, Siantan, Bunguran,
Tambfilan, Pulau Laut and P. Subi.
Sumatra is known variously as P. Mas,
P. Pfreha, P. Andelas. But the histoiy of
these names is very uncertain.
11. Hind. Nasi pulau: pillau rice; rice
boiled in bouillon.
pule. I. Pule pandak; (Batav.) a plant
(Ophyoxylon serpentinum; Dl.) from
which a purging medicine is obtained.
11. = pulai (tree - name).
puleh. I. Return; revival; renewal. Pulehkan;
to restore or bring back (Ht. Koris, Pg.
Ptg.); e.g. mfmulehkan rayat-nya undur
(to lead back to the fray the soldiers who
retreated), Ind. Meng. Also ot one’s normal
health coming back (puleh - lah pulang sa-
niula), Ht. Abd. 13. Simpul p.: slip-knot
(= simpul hidup, simpul sentak), specific
for a sheep - shank knot.

Bkl.,=sepuleh.

pulut. Sticky; a name (= padi p.) for glutinous
rice (Oryza glutinosa) and for cakes
made from glutinous rice. In. Min. and Java
the word is common for «sticky»; cf. terpulut
(adhering to, attached to); Panj. Sg. In
Malaya; only ol glutinous rice (==• Batav.
kbtau) and rice-cakes made of it, viz.:
(i) p. apit, p. tbtal, kuoh total: a
wafer-biscuit of pressed pulut;
(ii) p. udang: p. and coconut, mixed with
prawn, red pepper and saffron, and served
up in a leaf cover;


(iii) p. inti; p. in a syrup of coconut,
sugar and egg;
(iv) p. kachau: uncrushed p. cooked with
sugar and coconut-milk; = wajek, kueh
kachau;
(v) p. lemah: crushed p. in a syrup of
sugar and coconut-milk;
(vi) p. panggang: crushed p. and coconut
in a wrapper of banana-leaf;
(vii) p. sdrikaya: crushed p. and coconut
with a spiced syrup of coconut and egg.
Cf. kadut, piang.

pun. I. Even; yet; also; too. A particle suffixed
to a word that it is intended to emphasize.
Ada-pun: now (introducing a parenthesis).
Itu-pun: that also; even that. Sa-kali-pun;
yet; although; even. la-pun pergi; he too
went; well then, he went.

punggok. Stumpy; bobtailed; short and squat.
Of an island «squatting» on the horizon;

Burong p.: owl; esp. of the «moping»
owl that complains to the moon (p. merin-
dukan bulan) and is regarded by Malays as
a symbol of hopeless passion; sometimes
also of presumption (burong chabul) in
daring to hope to win the moon. Variously
identified with Ninox scutulata, Glochi-
diumbrodii or Syrnium seloputo;
probably gen. for any owl with a plaintive
note in contr. to screech - owls which are
birds of ill - omen (burong bantu) or vam-
pires (langsuyar). P. api: bay - owl,
Photodilus badius. Cf. Mai. Pant,
323,
Sahaja punggok fa’ - sodar diri,
Bulan yang tinggi hendak di-chapai:
The moping owl forgets his place Who
seeks to win the moon on high.

IV. Ikan punti - punti; a marine fish,

puntianak. Vampire; evil spirit preying on women
in labour and on babies. Etym. = pati-anak
(child-killer), cf. (Baba) mati-anak. Referable
to the Indonesian belief that an unnatural
death creates a malignant spirit. The «child-
killer* is usually either (i) the ghost of a
woman dead in childbirth or (ii) the ghost
of a child murdered to hide a mother’s shame.
For (i) cf.: puntianak itu sa-jenis bantu
perempuan; kata yang lain pula ia - lah
(burong bantu malam) penjelmaan dari-
pada perempuan yang mati bSranak (the
p. is an evil spirit of the female sex; others
say that it is a night - owl embodying a
woman dead in childbed); Perch. Mai. 87.
Better known in Malaya as langsuyar, q.v.
For (ii) cf. «the Pontianak (or Mati-
anak) is the still - born child of the
Langs u i r» (Mai. Magic 327); and «that
weird little animal the mati - anak that
makes beast - noises round the graves of
children* (Clifford, «In Court and Kampong*,
p. 231). But it has other names: the (Min.)
anak si - ngiang - ngiang, the ghost of a
child-victim of infanticide who whines for
help (rnengiang) from the jungle where the
child was thrown to perish; cf. also the p -
lesit bangkai that preys on the bodies of
babies, see pMosit; and the bajang that


cries like a cat (mSngeong) and troubles
women in labour, see ngiang.
Akar p.: a flowering shrub, Quisqualis
i n d i c a - = (Batav.) kembang udani.

(haft).

punya. Ownership; possession. Also Smpunya,
q. Sawah kepunyaan desa: rice-fields the

Mfinjadi p. dari negcri: becomes the pro-
perty of the State; Must. Adat 43. Anak -
ku ala p. bini di - Mompawah: my son has
a wife at Mempawah; Ht, Bugis 124.
In Bazaar Malay p. is used to make a
genitive and even (by a literal translation
from Chinese) to make an adjective; e.g-
saliaya p. bini (my wife), kaya p. orang
(a rich man). This way of making genitives
and adjectives should be avoided as alien to
Malay ideas.

pupus. I. Blighted; withered but not actually

pilput. I. Blowing upon; the work of windage.

City of Indra); Singa-p. (Lion-City); Istana-
p.-nSgara (Hastinapura of the Mahabharata).
Jikalau kita diam di-p. ini: if we stay in
this city; Sg. Samb.

purdi, p6rdi (backstay).
purl. Jav. Residential quarters reserved for the
Sultan and his ladies in a palace. In Java a
palace (dalam, keraton) is a walled enclosure
that may house as many as ten thousand
souls. Puri is the sovereign’s home in that
enclosure. Malay palaces are on a more
modest scale, but the ruler’s private
apartments are (politely): istana puri (Raj.
Muda 123); niahaligai p. (Mai. Dewa 83);
cf. bbradu ka-p. (to sleep in the private
apartments), Ht. Sh.; masok kadalam p.
(to withdraw to the puri), Pr. Ach. 3, Ht.
Panj. 17.
paring. Ikan paring: a fish, identified variously
as Pellona brachysoma and Clu p e a
variegata.
purir, = pulir (quarter- master).
puris. (Ked., Pk.) Vein-like midrib of palm-leaf;
- lidi.
purnama, = pernama (full, —of the moon).
purok, =porok (coconut-quoit).
puru. Sore; ulcer; (specifically) sores due to
yaws or Framboesia tropica, a tropical
disease caused by a spirochaete (Spiro nema
pertenue) and bearing certain likenesses
to syphilis which is caused also by a spi-
rochaete (Sp. pallidum). Also (Bene.)
nambi; (Java) patek, selokarang; (Min.)
nambi, puru; (Borneo) puru. Cf. bubul.
The disease has three stages (perhaps four,
Giml.).
(i) The primary stage is a sore (ibu p.)
due to the infection of a lesion on the skin,
usually on the lip and often made worse by
scratching. GAtekkan p. di-bibir: «to scratch


at the framboesoma on one’s lip*, Prov., =
to make matters worse instead of better,
J.S.A.S xi 32. [But any scratch is sufficient,
e.g. a fissure on the nipple, a kudis sore
or even a vaccination scratch; Giml.]
(ii) The secoidiry stage is complex, be-
ginning usually with an eruption in the form
of minute roundish papules (kbtut p., Giml.),
about the size of a pin’s head. From this
eruption comes, by mere increase in size,
the «eflflorescence* of secondary yaws
(bunga p., p. bunga). But this stage may
take many forms, see below.
(iii) The tertiary stage does not always
occur. [ft takes the form of serious lesions
of the integumentary or locomotive systems
or of the internal organs; Giml.] A common
form is found in very painful sores in the
hands or feet (p. bubok, bubul).
Borpuru; to suffer from puru; Tab.
Mimpi 10. P. ayal: cancer; Cr., Marsd. P.
baka: scrofula; Marsd. P. beka; secondary
yaws when the eruption takes the form of
large flat ulcers; G. P. jahat: gangrene;
cancer; Marsd. P. kochi: an ulceration
of the genitals, either venereal (Cr., Marsd.l
or the Cochin-China sore (Giml.), rare and
akin to sclerotising granuloma of the
pudenda (Daniels). P. lembek: soft chan-
cre. P. paka: Saccharomycosis ho-
rn inis (Blastomycosis). P. sfimbilek:
piles; Marsd., —but possibly fistula. Katak p :
the common toad. Bagai lalat chari p.: «as
a fly makes for a sore*, = with speed and
certainty and eagerness; Prov. Orang yang
p. gatal tuboh-nya neschaya mbnggaru
juga kerja-nya; a man itchy with yaws
•will always be (showing it by) scratching
himself; Prov., = a guilty conscience keeps
betraying itself, Kal. Dam. 297.
[Gimlette gives also the following varieties
of secondary yaws:
(i) p. dedak, p. sSkam: when the initial
papular eruption becomes scurfy;
(ii) p. kechar, p. siput: «shell - yaws*;
benign with rupial shaped sores;
(iii) p. kSnatu: slump-yaws*, with circular
red lumpy spots all over a child’s body;
(iv) p. kerbau, p. inata kerbau: sbuffalo
yaws*; large sores that heal readily;
(v) p. kertas: «paper yaws*; the worst
type; skin-deep, gyratory, very painful and
hard to cure;
(vi) p. pitis: «coin yaws*; with flat circular
sores;
(vii) p. ta’-jadi: suppressed yaws;
(viii) p. tapak anjing: «dog-print yaws*;
severe and very painful, leaving sores that
suggest a dog’s footprints.
Also for tertiary yaws,
(ix) p. dalam tulang: ulceration of the
bone, a late sequela of puru;
(x) p. parang: «chopper yaws*; deep
ulceration on the foot attacking old people;
cf. also bubul, nambi.
Bengal p., (Kel.) senggai p.: constitutional
symptoms of yaws such as malaise,
simple periostitis, etc., when the eruption is
delayed J.

tikus) and Lepironia mucronata (p.

ra. I. Name of a Malayo-Arabic letter transli-

raba. I. Feeling or groping with the hands. Of

rabak. Gashed; torn. Koyak r.: much torn; holed

40. Tibia pad a mulut-nya, r. sampai ka -

[Cf. rabek (a lesser gash or cut). Purists
distinguish between: rabak (a three-sided
rent); kobak kelam (two-sided rent); rabek,
rabit (tatter at edge); robek (worn through);
belah belong (vertical rent); koyak (diagonal
cut); soyak, soyat (torn from top to bottom).
But these distinctions are rarely observed;
and there are other words for rents or gashes:
chobak, chabek, chabir, etc.]

rabok. Tinder; touchwood. Usually soft dusty
material found in bamboo and inflammable;
but other such tinders are r. dudur (from
the wild dudur-palm), and r. tukas (from
Ventilago leiocarpa). Pig., of the
inflammable heart of youth (r. dengan api=
«fire and tinder*, as when young people meet);
and of the devastating, progress of love (api
inomakan r. <'tire burning up tinder*), Ik.
Trub. 22.
R. is used also to describe ash that does
not crumble readily, loose ash being habok;
also (Batav.) litter or rubbish in general; B.

gallon measure; see gantang. Ayer r., pasang
r., ayer naik merabong: spring tide or
very high tide. Chakapan r.: brag; boastful


talk.
Pfirabong: ridge - covering on a Malay
house to prevent leakage at the ridge - pole.
Made of a double row of pieces of thatching,
one being «astride the ridge-pole* (chblapak
r.). The hook pinning them together is
(Sum.) panjai pSrabong; illd. Yeth ci 14.
11. See rebong (edible bamboo - shoot).
rabu. I. Lungs; cf. jantong limpa r. hempbdu

bird’s foot to step into, e.g., when an argus-
pheasant dances. Tahan r.: to set a hanging-
noose - snare.

a thin slicing or very small piece. Daging
sa-r.: a minute bit of flesh regarded as the
germ of life contributed by the male, in
contr. to the «clot of blood* (darah yang
beku) from the mother.
rachit. I. (Min.) To knead; to squeeze.

rachun. Stomach - poison. In contr. to venom,

Merachun; to poison (Gul Bak. 50); also
a strong repudiation or negative, «may it
be poison to me». Ayer r.: liquid poison;
Ht. Panj. 12. Kepala r.: virulent poison.
Makan r.: to swallow poison, e.g., for suicide;
Mai. Annals 74. Mbmbfiri r.: to administer

radak. I. Stabbing upward. Esp., of assassination
by driving a spear through an interstice in
the lath-flooring of a Malay house so as to
stab a sleeper on that floor. Also of a man
on a lower level thrusting upwards at an
enemy on higher ground, cf. Hg. Tuah 365;
and of a bird’s-nest collector trying to prize
out (cholek) an edible marten’s - nest with a
long pole (pbradak). In vulgar slang, r. is
used of ramming down food and ol sexual
intercourse. Sakit raeradak-radak; shooting
pains.
Cf. also chadak, sadak, rodok, ranggah.
Stabbing downwards is tujah.

radang. I. [Sund.] Sakit radang: (Batav.) disease
in severe form, e.g.: r. kura (spleen - disease

sakit pinchaug (a disease attacking a horse’s

111. (Min.) Meradang: to wander about,
e.g. over a field; Tn. Cf. rodong.
raden. I. (Java, Palembang) Prince; princess.
Etym,, rahadhyan, from dyah; whence
rahaden, raden. A title given once to
all non - reigning princes in Java, reigning
princes being ratu; but nowadays the nearest
relatives of the Susuhunan and Sultan are
styled pengeran, q.v. Thus «Crown Prince*
is; (Old Java) raden inn; (Modern Java)
pengeran adipati anoni; (Malaya) raja muda.
Cf. also anah peradenan (Ht. Sh.) = anak
raja - raja (Mai. Annals), = non - reigning
princes generally. The title raden can also
be conferred, e.g., on a native regent; and
need not connote royal descent.
(i) Regents in Java, if of raden rank,
are known as r. adipati, r. temenggong, r.
ngabehi, according to their grade.
(ii) The consorts of non - reigning princes
of high birth and of regents, and the un-
married daughters of the Susuhunan are
known as r, ayu.
(iii) The consorts of non - reigning princes
of the second rank are r. nganten.
(iv) Unmarried princesses (other than the
Susuhunan’s daughters) are r. ajeng or r.
lara according to their rank. In ancient
Java and in old romances their title was r.
galoh.

like matted hair; Mai. Annals 38, Ht. Abd.
277.
[ln Malay football the players do not try
to get the ball through any goal hut to
keep it in the air and prevent it touching
the ground. This needs great skill if the
ball is to be kicked up fifty or sixty times
without a break.]

tagam. [Hind, and Skr. rag] Etym., a «raag»
or mode in Indian music; (whence) «air,

sition. Indian music distinguishes between
the air (rag), the key (sur) and the time
(tala); see tala.
Meragam: to sing; to give out a varying
sound as a voice broken by sobbing (Sh.
Kub.), or a bird singing (Raj. Jer. 4), el-
even as the creak of a rudder (Sri Ben.
22). R. manusia; human melodies (Gul Bak.
112), in contr. to celestial music. Banyak r.:
multifarious; e,g., of fashions in dress being
numerous (Must. Adat 38), but also of a
fickle or changeable disposition; cf. banyak
orang banyak r. - nya (so many men, so
many characters), Prov.

11. Morahang: to smell foully.
rahap. I. Kain rahap: a handsome outer cloth

11. Fallen in (of a house). Used where
the pillais have given way or the roof has

in the side only.
111. See rahat (fall of durians).
rahasia. See rahsia (secret).

rahim I. Ar. Al-rahim: «the Merciful*; God, as

him, Him and Im. Ghafur al-r.: the All-

11. Ar. Womb; uterus; Pen. Premp., cf.

bonda kaudong: since first my mother bore

rahin. (Min.) Lap (of mother); Tn. A variant of


rahim (womb) q.v.
rahip. Ar. To disappear; to vanish; = ghaib.
Rahman. Ar, A masc. proper name; see rahman.
rahman. Ar. Al- rahman: the All - Compassionate;
God as He who pitieth all mankind (not
True Believers only); cf. rahim. Abdul -r.:
a masc. proper name, commonly shortened
to Duraman, Doraman, Raman, Aman,
Man. Bismillah al-r. al-rahim: *in the
name of God the All-Merciful and the
Compassionate*; the usual heading to a
book or treatise.
rahmani. Ar. Associated with God the All-Merciful.
Nyawa r.: (in mysticism) the Divine Soul;
the Soul that permeates all Nature. See
nyawa.
rahmat. Ar. Mercy; pity. R. Allah an - hu: «May
God’s mercy rest upon him*, said of
saints who rest in God; Bost. Sal. i 7.
Kembali ka-r. Allah, pulang ka-r. Allah:
«to return to God’s Mercy*, = to die.
See also adil, insaf.
rahsia. Skr. A secret. Membuka r.: to reveal a
secret to a third party. MemSchah r.: to
become widely known, of a secret. Menaroh
r., mSnyimpan r.: to keep a secret.
SStia r.: (Job.) private secretary. Yang
bSrnama r. itu melainkan pada fimpat te-
linga dan dua kepala juga: what is really
a secret is a thing limited to four ears and
two heads only; Kal. Dam. 200.
Rahu. Skr. The snake Rah u, a monstrous dragon
that is believed to cause eclipses by his

makau R.: the moon in eclipse; (fig.) pallid
beauty, or a woman in her lover’s arms.
rahun. (Min.) Lost. Hilang rahun: lost utterly;
untraceable; Tn.

raih. I. Drawing towards oneself; scooping in;
annexing. In contr, to tolak (pushing away).
Tolak r.; give and take; bargaining; the
handling of an oar. Mata tolak r.: a keen
eye for a bargain; an eye on the main
chance. Malang ta’ - dapat di-tolak, mujur
ta’- dapat di-r.: «there is no fending off
had luck; there is no scooping in good

Prov., Si Jamin 28.
Cf. rais, kais, kait, kaih.
11. Straightening a mooring-post (pan-
chang) to which the current has given a

towards the operator.
111. Pbraih ikau: middleman who buys

raip. (Coll.) To disappear; to vanish; = (Ar.)

rairat. (Coll.) Rapture; Pant. Mai. 120, = (Ar.)

rais. To sweep off, as one sweeps crumbs off a
table. Cf. raih.
raja. I. Skr. «Rajah»; i. e. king, prince or
administrator; *king» (at chess or cards); an
honorific in titles. Rajakan, m6rajakan: to
raise to the throne; Mai. Annals 56, Sg.
Samb., Ht. Koris. Mdraja: (i) to be a prince,
e.g. sama nieraja putera (both were princes
by birth), Ht. Bugis 185; (ii) = maharaja,
q.v.
(i) Etym., = <rruler». So used in many
popular expressions: naik r. (to ascend the
throne); anak r. (scion of royalty, prince);
seri Sultan r. Perak (H.H. the Sultan, ruler
of Perak); —and even loosely up to quite
recent times of administrative * officers such
as the Resident or Resident Councillor at
Malacca and the Senior District Officer or
Superintendent of Province Wellesley.
(ii) Specifically a ruler is yangdipertuan;
raja is now used as a personal title for
non - reigning princes and princesses in Perak,
and also in Selangor. It was so used
in old Malacca and Pahang; and in
Johore up to 1700 A.D. After that date
the title raja was taken by members of the
family of the Yamtuan Mudaof Riau, while
those of the house of the Yamtuan Besar
took the title of tongkn, q. v. The later
branches of the Yamtuan Bosar’s family in


Singapore and Trengganu also took the title
tengku; and the princes of the more recent
Sultanates of Pahang and Johore have done
the same.
(iii) Raja still remains (in some places,
e.g. Perak) the title of the heir - apparent
(r. muda; and of the reigning queen (r.
pfirempuan, r. pfirmaisuri). But more modern
titles like tfingku bfisar and tengku mahkota
( «crown-pi ince*) and tengku puan (queen)
are tending to drive it out.
(iv) Raja figures also in many official
titles both royal and non - royal. In the
former case it may he translated «prince»,
e.g. Raja di - hilir (Prince of Lower Perak).
In the latter case it is an adjectival honorific
and may be compared to the former Imperial
German Consul - General, who w 7 as not
personally or to our own distinc-
tion between a British Vice - Consul and one
w'ho is styled H.M. Vice-Consul.
(v) Raja occurs also with the meaning
«king» or ruler in certain conventional titles,
such as r. laut or r. di - laut (king of the
sea) as a title for the laksamana or lord
high admiral, = (Ar.l amir al-bahar; and r.
sa - hari, r. sari (king for the day) as a
name for a bridegroom who is treated
as royalty on his wedding-day. But many
titles that suggest this use, e.g. R. Mahkota,
R. Negara etc., are mere honorifics and
should have dafo’ prefixed.
(vi) Other raja expressions are the
following.
R. badar: a white cotton fabric. R.
bergelar: prince wdth a personal princely
title such as «prince of Lower Perak* (raja
di - hilir). R, bfirjalan, angkatan r. -diraja,
pancha - raja - diraja: royal hearse. R. bin-
fang: ruling heavenly body. R. bunga: the
peony. R. di - muda.: (N.S.) dais at right
end of palace verandah. R. jfinang, r. je-
jenang: (Sum.) master of the ceremonies at
a cockfight. R. kayu: a tree; Cassia
fistula (Kl., W.); Terminalia citrina
(W.), Dracaena spp. (Bkl.), but see rajah.
R. Ida, meraja lela: see maharaja lela. R.
penomah: customary gifts sent with a royal
mission (Perb. Jaya). R. rimba: (N.I) higher
forest - official. R. udang: kingfisher (see
udang). R.-wali: hawk; eagle (see raja-
wali). Benang r.: rainbow, see pfilangi.
Budak r.: (Pah.) royal retainers, court-pages
(Hg. Tuah 34G); = (Pk.) budak kundang.
Burong r.: (Sel.) sparrow, = burong gfireja;
see chiak, pipit. Hamba r.: debt - slaves of
the ruler, see hamba. Kfirja r.: unrewarded
work. Pinang r.: red-stemmed palm; sealing-
wax palm, Cyrstostachys lacca. Pi-
fang r.: a large variety of banana. S6nyum
r.: hypocritical smile. Sang -r. Guru: a
name for Siva the Supreme Teacher; Hg.
Tuah 49.
11. A name for various diseases. R. puteh;
leucorrhoea. R. singa; syphilis. Barah r,;

raka. I. Fragile through damage. Of an injured

11. Ar. Echo; B.
rakaat. Ar. The series of ritual movements that
follows a Moslem prayer and can be used
as a way of counting how many prayers a
devotee has said; cf. sembahyang fimpat r.
(four prayers), Kit. Muj. 14. The Prophet’s
grandson Husain is said (Bost. Sal. ii 84) to
have uttered a thousand such prayers
(sembahyang sa - ribu r.) daily; but this
would be a miracle.
The prayer itself is uttered standing. It
is followed by a deep bow (rukok), then by
a prostration (sujud, sujut), then by a rise
to a kneeling posture, and then by a second
sujud. Rakaat is (etym.) the stand in
prayer; but it is used by Malays to cover
the whole series cf movements.

Rakip. Ar. A masc. proper name; see rakib.
rakit. I. Laying long objects side by side;
anything so arranged. Esp. of a raft of long
bamboos laid side by side; see below. But it
is applied also to crossbeams or floorplanking
in a house; to a man’s ribs sticking out in
parallel lines (tampak b6rakit-rakit), Kumb.
Chumb. 22; to things in layers such as a mat
in two thicknesses (tikar berakit) or two
sireh-leaves sandwiched one on the other
(sireh sa-r.); and even (Java) to a yoke of
oxen. Loosely, it may mean: <<arrangement,
planning*' cf. barang pekerjaan jangan di-
r. (don’t plan out any arrangements), Sh.
Rej. 8. The word occurs also in verses as a
rhyme or suggestion for sakit.
[Raft-building is illd. Veth. xcii 11. The
■w ord rakit is used of rafts generally; special
types have special names. The Peninsular
raft usually has the thinner ends of the
bamboos at its bows: (Pk.) lanting; (Pah.)
telatah, (Kel.) juriau. The Sumatran type
has the converse arrangement: (Sum.) anchu;
(Mai.) rakit R6mbau. In Java there is a
type (getck) of wood and bamboo. A raft
houseboat is: r. balai gambang (Mai. Dem.
49); rumah r., B.]
IF. (Min.) Cake of banana strips fried
in oil; Tn.
rakna. Skr. Gem; princess;=ratna.
rakong. See rengkong (larynx).
raksa. I. Skr. Mercury; quicksilver. Considered
by Malays to have medicinal and magical
value, cf. Kit. Muj. 02, 03, 66, 70 et passim;
associated in particular with a form of
invulnerability (apong ponimbul, k6bal
penimbul, ponimbul. r.). ‘Massaging quick-
silver into the pores* (kebab r., Ked. gosok
r.) is believed to put it under the skin and
cause it to flow quickly to any spot where
metal strikes the skin providing a sort of
subcutaneous armour.
11. See bSraksa.
raksaniala. Kayu raksamala: a fragrant wood
used for burning; Canariura microcar-
pum. Minyak r.; honeydew; the imported
balsam of Liquidambar orient a 1 i s.
Pokok r.; tree, Altingiana excels a.
Honey - dew and this fragrant wood were
used in pre - Mohammedan days at funeral
cei emonies.
raksasa. Skr. Ogre; goblin of Hindu mythology.
Often mentioned in literature (Sg. Samb.,
Ind. Nata, Sh. Maid., Ht. Abd., Sh. Nas.
9); and depicted on Javanese kris - handles
of the jawa s£jok type. Described as a


cannibal giant; Perch. Mai. 48. [Not an
evil spirit but a sort of half - human gorilla,
a tusked man - eating monster of hideous
appearance and repulsive habits. Probably
a personification of the early Dravidian whom
the Aryans conquered in India.)
raksi. I. Skr. A person’s «star», i. e. the
astrological force in the ascendant at the
time of his birth and affecting his fortunes
throughout his life. Balk r.: born under a
lucky star. Sa -r., serasi, asian:
born under similar stars and likely therefore
to live together in perfect harmony; affinities.
[Popularly the word is associated with a
kind of divination. The cabalistic values of
the letters in the names of an engaged
couple are taken, added up and then divided
by nine; the balance left over is the fateful
number. The expression di-raksi nama - nya
(Ht. Best.) refers to this calculation. If the
balance is inauspicious the pair are said to
be tiada sa-r. (not affinities), Ht. Abd. 11;
the engagement should then be broken off.
Raksi has thus two secondary meanings; (i)
«mixing» - from the «commingling» of the
numerical values of the letters; ct. lilin di-
r. dbngan susu (wax joined to milk), Gul
Bak. 80; and (ii) «ducky» (sa-r.) or <?unlucky»
(tiada sa-r.) in any sort of enterprise).
11. Moraksi: to perfume. Minyak di-r.:
liquid scent., Sh. Kub., Sh. Bid. 66, =
minyak wangi, minyak ukup. But specific-
ally of the practice of perfuming a bed, the
perfume (peraksi) used being fragrant leaves
or flowers chopped up small. And since faded
flowers are generally so used peraksi is
symbolical of the wife who has ceased to be
a mistress and is only of use as a household
drudge. But the metaphor may also be the
reverse ot this, e.g., of a prince taking some
flower-like girl «to perfume his royal couch»,
i.e.: akan meraksi peraduan (Sh. Kub.); buat
peraksi dalam peraduan (Ht. Koris); ambil-
kan patek buat r. (Ind. Meng.).

friendship, i.e. too casual about the friends
they make; B.

Ramadzan. Ar. The ninth or «summer» month
of the Moslem calendar; and, as being the
hot month, made by Mohammed the month
of the Great Fast (bulan puasa). But as
the calendar is a lunar calendar this considerate
choice of a hot month has been nullified.
R. (coll. Ramlan) is also used as a masc.
proper name for male children bom in that
month.

11. See rambutan, pSrambut.
rambutan. A tree, Nephelium lappa ceum,
yielding the well-known «rambutan» fruit, so
called from its hairy integument; see rambut.
The best r. fruit is grown at Batavia (r.
Betawi), Pel. Ak. iii 22. A variety (r.
lekang) is much prized because its flesh
does not adhere to the skin and is eaten
more easily. Also rambustan; Sh. Kub.
Other «rambutans» are: N. eriopetalum
(r. bulan lima), W.; N. mu t a bile
(pulasan, Pen. r. kapril; Erioglossum
edule (r. hutan, mertajam); and a number
of trees of all sorts known as r. pachat, e.g.
A g 1 a i a sp. and Xerospermum noron-
hianum, a wild tree with yellow edible
fruit.
rambuti. Hair-cloth; woollen cloth; see rambut.
fame. See ramai (festive; well-attended),
rameh. See rami (rhea-fibre, China-grass).
ramek. Ramok-ramok: (Min., N.S.) titbits of
buffalo - meat taken from the intestines and
presented to honoured guests at a feast or
the triLai Chief as his perquisite. Kitab r.-r.:
book of miscellanies. Membfili r. -r. to buy a
bit here and there; to sample. Mengbtahui
r.-r.; to have a smattering of knowledge.
Meramek - ramok cherdek: to be up to all
sorts of tricks.
ram Sling. (Batav.. from Dutch) Hammering (in
the sense of giving a man a good hammering);
drubbing; B.
rattiSs. (Batav.) To knead; to massage; = ramas.
rami. I. «Ramie»; specifically rhea or China -
grass, Boehmeria nivea, from which
excellent string (tali r.) is made. Also rami -
rami; (Min.) ramin; (Sum.) kolui; (Batav.)
rameh, rami.
In verse the word occurs frequently as a
rhyme suggesting kami (us). Kain r.: «ramie-
cloth» is properly cloth made of rhea fibre
but is used often with the meaning «sack -
cloth», which is usually cloth of jute-fibre.
Other «ramies» are:
(i) r. betina, ramin bfitina (Macaranga
1 o w i i);
(ii) r. bukit, r. hutan, ramin bukit (A 1-
chornea villosa);
(iii) r. buah, ramin buah (Phyllan thus
nir u r i), Bkl.;
(iv) r. bantu (Ficus char face a);
(v) r. sengat (A bro m a augusta).

rampagi. (Min.) Pocket - knife; = korampagi.
rampai. Miscellaneous; mixed; varied. Esp. in the
expression bunga r. ( = Batav. kembang
rampe; Java kembang ramping); pot-
pourri. This pot-pourri is made by
chopping up petals and leaves, esp. pandan
(mbrampai si - bunga pandan, Jub. Mai.
15), and adding scented water.
Rampaikan: to scatter flowers; to dis-
seminate news. Achar r.: mixed pickles.
Chakap mfirampai: talk on all sorts of
subjects; Hn. Hasil rampaian: (Trengg.)
miscellaneous revenue; Mn. Minyak r.: scent
from mixed flowers. Pantun r.: disconnected
pantun - verses. Penganan r.: cakes of all
sorts. Khabar di - rampaikan: the report
was spread; Sh. 18. 66. Pikir nan jangan
banyak di-r.: let not your thoughts be too
inconsequent; Put. Ak. 29.


rampak. I. Umbrageous. Of squat spreading shade-
trees like the rain - tree, Samanca saman;
and in contr. to the shadiness (rimbun) of
very tall trees like the ansenna. Terlalu
sangnt r. dahan - nya sanipai ka - tanah
seperti suatu bilek rupa - nya: its boughs
gave great shelter; they bent down earthwards
so as to form a bower; Ht. Koris.

Used of sequestration by Government; Ht.

rampat. L Merampat: to hit out all round. Of a
man swinging a long pole all round; turning

papan: to scatter abuse at everybody.
Also (Min.) rampak.

ratnpek. (Min.) Shrunken; emptied (of a sack);

ramping. I. Prettily slender; the converse of
dangkat, dengkok. Esp. of a slender waist
(pinggang r.), Sh. Bid. 21, Cr. Gr 20, Gul
Bak. 105; such a waist being lissom but
not a wasp-waist (pinggang gonting) which
is not admired. R. is used also of a horse’s
head curving inwards between the muzzle
and its upper portion; Peng. Kuda 7.
11. Meramping: to be frayed at the edge,
e.g. as old matting. Rompang -r.; very
frayed and tattered; riddled, as a wall after
a bombardment; Pel. Abd. 52. Cf. robak -
rabek, chompang - champing.

ramsum. Eur. Ration. Etym., of rations issued to

prostitute following troops.
Also ransum, ressum. Cf. gelas, roji.
ramu. Gathering up odds and ends that may

40); or gathering thatch, rattans and timber
for putting up a house; or collecting medicinal
simples (Si Jamin 48); or, like a robber, laying

bertfunu), Ht. Abd. 301.

ratlda. I. (Batav. and Min., from Skr.) A widow,
widower or divorcee; cf. janda. R. is (etym.)
a widower; in Java it is used of any person
of either sex who has been married before
but is wifeless or husbandless at the moment;
in Min. it is used more loosely of wifeless
men and husbandless women of a certain
age, including old bachelors and old maids;
in the Peninsula janda is used of ex-married-
women only, not of men. R. gadis; (Min.)
old maid. Meranda tua: (Min.) old bachelor.

ranggong. Holding the legs apart; (fig.) two sticks

rangkah. (Min.) split; cleft. Cf. rckah, rengkah.
rangkai. Rangkaikan, merangkaikan: to string
together; to combine. Of joining letters to
make up a word (merangkaikan huruf, Ht.
Abd. 38) or words to make up a sentence


(Ht. Abd. 310); of tying queues together
(rangkaikan tali tauchang, Sing. Terb. 29)
so as to march Chinese more easily to a
police-station; etc. Berangkai - rangkai: in
bunches or clusters. R. is used also as a
num. coeff. for heads of maize.
R. -r. periok: a mimetic game for very
young children. A «house» is built by the
children crossing arms; then a verse beguiling
r. -r. periok is sung; and at its last words
(rak - rak rum) the house is supposed to
come crashing down as the hands are let go.
Also (Batav.) rangke, rangkei.
rangkak. M6rangkak: to crawl on hands and
knees; to make slow progress. Si-r.: «the
crawler*; a name for the crocodile. Merang-
kak menjulur: to crawl up to a Sultan in the
curious wriggling way prescribed by Malay
etiquette; Mar. Mah., Ht. Best. Merangkak-
r. membacha: to stumble through a passage
in reading; Ht. Abd. R. is used also of the
way a wounded centipede covers the ground;
in contr. to merayap, his usual crawl.
Also m&rakak; (Min.) merangkak; (Batav.,
from Sund.) merangkang. Cf. sftrangkak.
rangkam. Merangkam: (Min.) to seize with

much as one can so seize. Cf. rangkuni,
chfikam, gonggain, raup.

rangkup. Laying two things one against the other

foim a conduit when drinking at a spout.
When the two hands form a cup, not a
conduit, raup is used. R. is used also of
the w'ay a shaman covers his face with
his hands at a seance.

to excite a man into fighting; Ht. Best.

(Pen. Premp. 1); or of a strong or exciting
scent (Hn.). The form ggrangsang also
occurs.

ranjau. I. Caltrop; bamboo spike or spikes arranged
to wound a hasty enemy and so to force him
to go slowly. Illd. Yeth cxx 4,5, 6. Loosely
of any such obstruction whether a true
caltrop or not. Varieties are as follows:
(i) r. babi: pointed stakes stuck point
upwards in a pitfall for wild pig;
(ii) r. b6si: chevau-de-fri.se of iron;
(iii) r. champak, tahak: the true caltrop
which is dropped to impede pursuit and
■which is of two kinds, one so made (r.
mata tiga, r. silang) that one point is
always turned upwards, and one one-pointed
(r. mata satu) on a flat base;
(iv) r. chachak, suda, jojol, ranchang:
fixed spiky obstruction stuck in the ground
in front of a tort to prevent a rush; and
(v) r. penunggul: caltrop of some height
intended to wound an assailant in the body
and not in the feet.
Meranjau: mulierem subire; =
(Batav.) ewe. Peranjau: day-prowler on
the look-out for what he can steal when
darkness comes. Kena r.: to come up against
a snag; (in cards) to be bluffed, = k6na das.

Ranjuna. Skr. Sang - Ranjuna: the hero Arjuna.
Famous (in the Mahabharata) for his archery
and for his manly beauty.
(i) Busar R.: Arjuna’s bow; a simile for
the curving line of the arm of a beautiful
girl. Panah B.: Arjuna’s arrow; a name
given to meteors and falling balls of flame,
regarded as evil spirits and much feared by
Malays.
(ii) SSperti R. rupa - nya: «handsome as
Arjuna*; Ind. Nata. R. fapa sudah Sang
R. di - goda oleh bidadari ketujoh: «Arjuna
the Ascetic, when the hero Arjuna was
tempted by the seven heavenly nymphs*,
an old Indian legend recalling the story of
St. Anthony; Perb. Jaya. This legend and
the tale of Arjuna’s marriage to the nymph
Sri Kandi (Sergandi, Mas. Ed., Raj.
Muda 70) are the subject of old plays and
poems, e.g. the famous Kawi poem Arjuno
Wiwoho.

rasul. [Ar.; = «one sent* (by God)] Apostle.
R. Allah: «God’s Apostle*, i. e. Mohammed.
Sunat al -r, sunat r., (N. S.) santa r,:
religious knowledge, with special reference
to the examination in religious knowledge
that precedes circumcision. Kesah segala r.:
(in Christian terminology) the Acts of the
Apostles.
Strictly speaking, rasul is a term that
may describe any of the major prophets
(anbia yang mursal); and it is actually so
used (Bost. Sal i 91) of nabi Idris. But in
common speech Mohammed alone is rasul;
the others are nabi or, at most, mursal.

ratau. I. Meratau; to rave in delirium; = me-
