11. (Kel.) Place; region; = rantau, q.v.
rati. MSratikan: to recall to mind; = mem-
perhatikan. Rati - rati: dreams coloured by
the day’s incidents.
ratib. [Ar.; = uninterrupted, continuous] A
mystic exercise based on the repetition
of a religious formula such as «He is
God* (Hua Allah) or «God is Great*
(Allah akbar). The formula is repeated
slowly at first so as to allow the mind to
think out what it means and suggests; then
the repetition becomes louder and more rapid
so as to divert the mystic’s attention from
the illusive world around him and enable
him to realize and enjoy the celestial truths
in the formula.
Also (coll.) ratip.
[Ratib - mystics are the so-called «howling
dervishes*. The •'howling* is not prayer in
the usual sense; though it is often taken for
piayer, even by Malays; ct.
Ratib - nya itu tiada berhenti,
Memuji kapada rabb al-izati:
their voices rose unceasingly in praise to
God All-honourable: Pr. Ach. 13. It can be
laughed at also; cf. the expression for a
ramshackle wooden house shaking in a strong
wind, runiah sudah r. (the house is doing
mystic exercises). But in reality it is a sort
of self-hypnotism for diverting the mind from
•allusion*.
Various formulae (ratib) are recommended
by different schools of mysticism as being
specially efficacious; cf. the ratib saman of
the Samaniah school. But some teachers of
mysticism prefer silent meditation; others
again the «dancing dervishes*—like sound
and motion; and those of one school (see
dabus) stab themselves when dancing.]
ratin. [Dutch ruiten], (Pen., Min.) The
cardsuit «Diamonds». Also (Java) ritin,
(Pk.) retin: cf. daiman, dobin, jubin,
batu Melaka.
ratip. See ratib (mystic shouting).
ratna. I. Skr. Jewel; gem. R.-keudi; precious
stone. R. chempaka: topaz. R. pekacha:
•gem of limpid purity*, as a term of en-
dearment; Sg. Samb., Kumb. Chumb. 13.
R. niutu manlkam: gems of all sorts; Lang.
Biiana 64, Bost. Sal. i 39.
Also rakna, ra’na; of. adiratna.
11. [Skr.; = «gem», but in the secondary
sense of a human gem, «princess»] Princess,
e.g., tnan putori Ratna-dewi, anak
raja Feringgi (the lady Ratna - Dewi,
daughter of the king of the Franks), Jay.
Lengg. Cf. galoh.
111. Peta - ratna: royal dais. Properly:
peterana.
ratong. See restong (phagedoena, esp. of the
nose).
ratu. Jav. Ruler; queen.
(i) Etym., and in old literature, = <'king».
Of.: sang-r. (king), Ht. Panj. 6; r. Mdlayu
(the Malay ruler), Hg. Tuah; r. Majapahit
(the king of Majapahit), Mai. Annals 27;
para -r. (assembly of princes), Ht. Sh. Also
in the titles of kings in the shadow - plays:
r. Jawa, r. seberang, r. Daha, etc. So too
in the name for a Javanese palace (keraton);
for the king-turtle (ratu, katong); and in
the title of Bantam princes (tu - bagus =
ratu-bagus). In the kindred form data it
figures as the title of the king of Sri Yijaya
on the Kota Kapur inscription of A. D. 686.
(ii| But in modern Malaya, Borneo and
Java ratu is specifically «queen*. Cf. r.
kenchana («Empress of Java*, the title
borne by the Susuhunan’s principal wife);
r. Sultan (title borne hy the principal wife
of the Sultan of Jogjakarta); ratu (as the
title of daughters of the Susuhunan and
wives of certain high dignitaries in Java);
r. penembahan, r. Sultan (as the title of the
principal wives of rulers in Borneo), Ht.
Bugis 111. In the Peninsula, ratu was the
title given to the wife of the Sultan of
Johore (Bint. Timor, 23. 1. 95); but raja
is technically more correct.
ratus. I. Hundred. Meratus: in hundreds; the
hundredth. Sa-r.: one hundred. Dua r.: two
hundred. Beratus-ratus: in hundreds; by the
hundred. Akar r., daun r.: the plant
Justicia bracteata, because of its many
bracts; Bkl. Rempah r.; «the hundred
ingredients*; name given to the mixture of
many drugs given to a woman after her
confinement. Meratus chSrmin di - kaki:
«with spangles by the hundred on his


trousers*, a description of an obsolete fashion.
Khanduri pada mcratus hari-nya: funeral-
feast held on the hundredth day altar death;
Ht. Bugis 128.
11. The winning stroke in the game of
porok.
IH. Meratus: to twitter (of bulbuls).
rail. I. (Onom.) Sound such as that of very
heavy rain or of a swollen mountain-torrent.
Rau-rau: clapper-rattle; sistrum;=orok-orok,
kerochok. Terbgrau: crushed (of fallen tree-
trunks).
Cf. derau.
11. A tree, Santiria lax a; W.
IH. See rawa (morass).
ratlb. = raup (cupping the hands).
rauf. Ar. Al-rauf; the All-Pitying; the Very
Merciful; God. Abdul-r.: a masc. proper
name; commonly shortened to Dfiraup.
Ranh, = Rahu (dragon causing eclipses).
raum. I. (Onom.) Murmur of voices. Meraum -
raum: to croon; to speak soothingly to; e.g.,
as a man trying to quiet a frightened girl.
Cf. runirum.
If. Meraum: to be rapacious; to want
all.
raun. Eng. Police or military «rounds». Pergi r.;
to go on patrol or beat duty. Cf. ronda,
sambang.
raung. (Onom.) Deep cry, e.g., of pain. Also
(Min.) rarong; cf. laung (deep cry) and
(Bal.) aung (howl of a dog). In Malaya of
lamentation by unmeaning cries in contr. to
mere weeping (tangis) or lamentations put
into words (ratap); cf.: r. dan ratap
(lamentations of all sorts), Ht. Abd. 299,
Mai. Dewa 93; r. sawab (groans and sighs),
Raj. Muda 5; meraung mSnyeru akan
suarni - nya (screaming and appealing to her
husband for help), Ht, Best. But the
Balinese meaning (howl of a dog) is given
it in the passage suara-nya mSraung
siiperti bunyi suara anjing (the sound of
his lamenting was like the deep cry of a
dog), Kal. Dam. 255; and the idea of an
animal cry occurs also in a passage (Ht.
Pdk. 15), where it is used of the cry of a
tiger. In another book a distinction is drawn
between the cry of the tiger (mfindfiram,
mfingaum) and the cry of a man taken by
a tiger (meraung); Sid. Rama 229.
Cf. also mengerang, mongaroug, ngarong.
raup. Putting the hands together cup - wise;
turning in the paws (as a cat, to prevent
its prey escaping); inturning (feet) as a
deformity. Of scooping up water to drink;
catching the bird-like spirit of life (sftmangat)
in one’s cupped hands (Raj. Don. 55); holding
the sovereign’s feet in one’s hands (as a
mark of respect), = meraup kaki baginda,
Mai. Dem. 68. Sa -r.; a double handful, as
a measure of quantity, e.g., of earth (sa -r.
tanah, Dost. Sal. ii 48) or of diamonds (Ht.
Abd. 295).
Cf. kaup, kaut.
raut. Whittling off asperities. Pisan r.: a small -
bladed knife used for this purpose and for
rough carving generally, fine carving being
done with a pisau wali or pisau bayong.
Burong pisau r.: (Pat.) a heron, Ardea
typhon, = burong ranggong. Tingkap
rautan: windows of carved lattice-work.
In Min. raut = shape; si -r. = shaping -
knife (pisau r.).
In Java too raut is used (Peng. Kuda 52)
of trimming a horse’s hoof for shoeing. Rotan
(rattan) is explained sometimes as rautan
because it is trimmed before use.
Rawa. Orang Rawa: a name given loosely
(Mah) to non - Minangkabau immigrants from
Central Sumatra. The true Orang Rawa of
Sumatra are Siak aborigines who do not
emigrate. The Peninsular term includes
inter alios Orang Rau from behind
Tapanuli and Orang Rawas from the Jambi-
Palembang area.
rawa. I. A round-topped tree; Mangifera
microphylla, M. pentandra, W.,
with thick - set glossy dark - green leaves; it
gives an edible fruit and a good timber;
J.S.A.S. iii 98, viii 131, Ht. Koris.
Also raw r a - rawa.
If. (Pen.) A triangular plough - net of
sacking used on mud banks for catching
prawns; = sungkur, sondong. So called
perhaps from the sackcloth of w'hich it is
made.
HI. Morass due to a river overflowing its

(Min.) ran.

b i c o 1 o r,

bulbul; = barau - barau, ch(*ngkerawak.
rawah. I. Financing labour. Of the common
Malay practice by which a capitalist buys a
boat, nets, etc. (or builds a large fishtrap)
and then lets the property out to a gang of
men who work it for a share or interest in
the proceeds.
11. (Min.) Storing-jar for water. Tblinga
r.: «storing-jar ears*; that hear not; also
telinga tSmpayan.
111. = rawa (morass).
rawal. I. Line of unbaited and unbaibed hooks
laid by Chinese fishermen across a tideway
to foul-hook any scaleless fish, esp. sharks and
rays, that may be passing by; (Brun.) long
line of baited hooks, = (elsewhere) r. umpan.
Merawai: to fish in these ways.
11. Merawai: (Pen.) to beg from door to
door; = mbradai. Cf. mendahana, nierapu
dana, bawa tempurong.
111. Papan rawai: (Brun.) ornamental
moulding or carved work on the walls of a

IV. A tree, Xanthophyllum griffi-
thii; W.
rawak. I. Gula di-rawak: syrup;=gula derawa.
See derawa.
11. See gawar.
rawan. I [Hind., from Pers.] A conveyance.
Etyra., the takht-i-ravan was a dais or
platform carried on men’s shoulders: but the
takht-i-ravan of modern Turkey or Persia
is a sort of bus or «diligence». The rawan
or rawana of Malay literature seems to
have been a sort of flying dais (r.
Sh. Kub.) comparable to the flying carpets
of the Arabian Nights.
11. Emotion; tender feeling. Merawan;
to be stirred. MembSri r.: to inspire sympathy
or tenderness. Jangan berhati r.; sigh no
more; be not melancholy; Abd. Mk. 20.
Tgrlalu r. hati - nya: he was much moved;
Sg. Samb.
111. Nasi rawan: rice boiled along with
other foods such as peas. In contr. to plain
rice or pillau to which such foods are added
after it has been boiled.
IV. Tubing rawan: (i) gristle, Sh.; (ii)
the breast-bone, = [ Ked.) tulang papan.

bfirkerawang.

high; = berawan.

string; e.g., nets.

Gunong r.: highest peak in a group of hills.
Hantu r.: the greatest of the evil spirits of

or hantu pfimburu and even with Siva

rayah. I. Jav. Menjarah - rayah: to go raiding

rayap. I. Merayap: to crawl; to spread or creep.

11. (Java) Termite; white ant; = anai -

rayat. [Ar.; = «herd at pasture*, i.e. the
subjects of a shepherd or king] Peasant;
private soldier; the humbler people in a
State. R. hina-dina: the masses; the plebs.
In a military sense r. means militia or
conscripted troops in contr. to professional
soldiers (hulubalang).
Orang r. are also specifically the Proto -
Malayan subjects of a Malay Chief or Sultan,
in contr. to his own civilised Malays. They
rank, however, higher than his orang Sakai
or non-Malayan «aborigines», except in the
Riau Archipelago where all are Proto -
Malayan and are styled sakai and rayat,
«Sakai» being the higher. Of. also Belandas,
biduanda, Mantera, Jakun.
rayau. Merayau; to prowl about; to wander.
Of primitive nomad-hunters who have no
settled home (Al. Mai. 18, Taw. Mai. 1);
animals in search of food, cf. Ht. Pdk. 25;
and men foraging in the jungle to see what
they can find (Ch. Jen. 37).
rayu. Plaintive; emotional. Merayu hati, mfirayu
jiwa; to inspire tenderness; to make a person
fee! pity; to soften the heart; Fnd. Meng.
Telah di - rinoh - rayu; when he had been
coaxed and appealed to.

rSban. I. Fowl-house; usually a pen under a

Fowls are allowed to forage for themselves

rgbat. Barring the way by means of a barrier
of any sort; =£ (Min.) rabat. Of cksi ig
a road for repair; nailing up a gate;
girdling a tree-trunk with thorns to keep
away climbers; putting a freshly-cut branch
across one path (where two paths meet) to
indicate that the other is the path to be
taken. Oleh si - chelaka itu di - ambil - nya
segala duri di -r. - nya pohon ara itu: the
rascal collected all the thorns he could get
and wound them round the ara-tree (on
which his wife was); Ht. Mash. 35.

rebeh. Malformed, injured, or deficient (on one

rgbong. Bamboo-shoot when young, soft and edible;
=(Min.) rabong. In contr. to the hard grown
bamboo (aur, buloh). Puchok r.: «line of
young bamboo shoots >, as a descriptive name
given to a well - known pattern (seen on all
batek sarongs) consisting of a succession of
very acute-angled triangles; and also to the
very serrated edging of basket-work. Pantang
akan r.: (in this illness) young bamboo - shoots
may not be eaten; Kit. Muj. CD.
rgbus. I. Boiling along with the water (as rice

egg is usually boiled), =chelur. Rice-boiling

etc. R. ta’-empok: «boiled yet unsoftened®,
to all appeals; Prov.

reja. Leavings; scraps; anything left over. Of

rgjal, = rijal (men).
rSjam. Ar. Doing a man to death, esp. by suffoca-
tion. Etyin., the old punishment of stoning,
which was carried out by burying a man up
to his v aLt in the earth and smashing his
skull with boulders or big stones. Hence
several derivative meanings:
(i| dashing down one heavy object on
another, = umban;
(ii) thrusting a man’s head into water or
mud and keeping him there till he suffocates


(r. di - ayor, r. di - selut), also of accidental
death in this way;
(iii) the Min. punishment (rajam) of
rolling a man in a nail-studded barrel till he
is pricked to death; whence r. = «pricked

Best.).

r.; whooping-cough.

rgndang. Cooking in nothing more than a little

p6das: dry-currying (Ht. Bugis 148); =
«devilling». Pisang r.: banana fritter.
Merendang implies the use of a cooking -
• pot (End. Meng., Kumb. Chumb 24) and does
not cover toasting (panggang) or baking in
ashes (bSinbara) or roasting on a spit(pachak).
It is used in contr. to gulai (cooking in a
rich sauce; wet-currying). Whatever oil is
used in merendang should be used up,
leaving a dry food.
Also (Min.) randang.

rengan, = ringan (light in weight).

rgngap. Berengap: to extinguish with a puff; to
blow out. Rengap is a word used by sorcerers
(Ked., Pat.) at the end of an incantation to
suggest that the evil influence has been
puffed out like the flame of a candle.
P6rengap: charm to destroy an enemy’s
power.
rgngas. Gen. name for a number of trees, mostly
Anacardiaceae, with an irritant sap
(getah r.) that sets up acute dermatitis and
when taken internally is a painful poison.
Some also yield a fine timber known os
<'Borneo rosewood*; and a varnish (minyak
kayu r.).
Watson gives the following varieties;


(i) Gluta spp.: r. ayer, r. kerbau jalang;
r. seluang (G. coarctata);

pasir;
(iii) Melanochyla spp.: r. api (M.
tomentosn); r. lanjut (M. auric u la t a);
r. raw a (M. n i t i d a);

(M. wallichii, Bkk); r. tandok (VI. woods-
iana): r. tSlentaug (M. aptera);
(v) Swintonia spicifera: r. kilat
senja.

rgsam. I. Forest fern; = (Min.) rasam, ransom.
Three varieties are commonly recognized:
(i) the rbsam proper, Gleic h e n i a
linearis; of which some parts are like
whalebone and make Malay pens (kalam r.),
Ht. Abd. 12;
(ii) the large r6sam (r. gajah) much used
in the construction ot fish traps; and
(iii) the worthless r&sam (r. piai) too
short for use.

padi); and Hypolepis punctata (r.
pay a).

rgtak. Crack-marking, e.g., on crackle porcelain.
In contr. to a real rift however narrow; cf.
r. m£nchari bclah (the crack trying to
sever, = the little rift within the lute that
by-and-by will make the music mute); Prov.
R. is used:
(i) of line-markings on the hand, important
in palmistry, =r. tangan, siput r. sa-ribu,
such as the lucky r. tangga mas or
cgolden stairway* made up of the lines of
different lengths at the finger-joints;
(ii) crack - markings on krisses; e.g.: r.
bandut (near the aring and deemed lucky);
r. dagu burok (at the broad end of the
ganja in a straight kris).
R. is used also (loosely) of an unhatched
chicken trying to crack and break out of
its shell (merotak kulit tolur), Pet. Ayam
81.

the modern milled dollar or ringgit, q.v.;
fig., of money or wealth. A distinction may
also be drawn between the ordinary old
Spanish unmilled dollar of 371 L grains of
pure silver (rial), the Venetian ducatoon (r.
kdtun, r. di - kotun) of 398 gr., and the
unminted stamped dollar or nugget-dollar (r.
batu) once imported direct from Mexico and
unminted but of the same weight and fine-
ness as the ordinary Spanish dollar.

Buloh porindu: Eolian bamboo. A name
given to:
(i) a musical instrument of the Jew’s harp
type, worked by the wind (Ht. Bangs. 3);
(ii) a semi # - legendary bamboo growing on
high mountains and believed to give out a
plaintive note when swayed by the wind;
Mai. Annals 176. Alleged cuttings of this
plant are prized as love - charms; and a
bamboo, said to be this bamboo, is known to
science as Bam bus a magic a. Cf.:
Suara-nya Sang Samba itu sep6rti buloh
porindu: Sang Samba’s voice was as tender
as the note of the buloh p6rindu; Sg.
Samb.

ringgit. I. Milled or serrated; milled coin; modern
dollar; dollar as a symbol of wealth. Efym.,
= «jagged» or ('toothed a; cf. gigi, rigi,
ggrigis and the pantun - line Gunong Beli-
tong beringgit - ringgit (Billiton Hill has
jagged peaks). Whence rial bSringgit =
milled or saw - edged Spanish dollar; and
the name ringgit for milled dollars in contr.
to the old unmilled rial. Nowadays the old
meaning has been lost sight of and the rial
is obsolete, so ringgit may be used of any
dollar.
Terms in use:
(i) the dollar-piece, =r. bulat;
(ii) the dollar-note, = r. not; r. kortas
(Ht. Abd. 304);
(iii) the modern Spanish dollar, = r. bgsar;
(iv) the Spanish pillar-dollar, = r. nieriam,
r. patong;
(v) the Spanish dollar generally, =r.
pansfimat, r. pasmat, r. porarasa, = (Dutch)
Spaansche mat;
(vi) the Mexican dollar, = r. gerdan; r.
janek;
(vii) the British or Hongkong dollar, =
r, tongkat;
(viii) the Dutch rix-dollar with the king’s
head,= r. kepala, r. tengkorak;
(ix) the rix-dollar with the queen’s head,
r. nona; and
(x) the rix-dollar generally, =r. bare.
Also, but less correctly:
(xi) the old Venetian ducatoon, = r. di -
k6tun, r. ketun, r. k6tong, rial di - kfitun;
and
(xii) the old minted dollar in contr. to
the unminted rial batu; Ht. Bugis 12.
For these last two see rial.

rintak, = rentak (to tug).
fintang. (Sum.) Worrying; continued interference.
E.g., of business men being harassed by

(sangat di-rintangi oleh bbberapa aturan),
Sul. Hid. 35; cf. also Pert. Tebu 6, 45. Pe-

the attacks of evil spiiits; Pant. Mai. 143.
But the word need not mean unpleasant
worrying only. R. berpikir - pikir: wrapped
up in one’s own thoughts; occupied in
thinking; Must. Adat 26. Mata - nya di -
r. oleh penglihatan yang indah-indah:
his eyes were kept busy by the wonderful

along, crossing from cape to cape», instead

finteh. Merinteh: (Java) to groan; to lament; B.
fintek. Spot; blotch; mottling. Of speckled fowls
(ayam bSrintek); dew dropping here and
there (erabun r.); and esp. of slight rain
that leaves spots behind it and does not wet
the ground everywhere (hujan r.-r.), Sg.
Sarah., Sh. Kub., Tab. Mimp. 4, Ht. Abd.
284. Bolang r.: speckled markings. Burong
r.-r.: the fantail flycatcher, Rhipidura
javanica. Umpama bunga - bungaan
k6ua r. hujan pada ketika dinihari: like
flowers refreshed by drops of rain at dawn;
Host. Sal. ii 127.
R. is also a descriptive name for the short
suit tiau in a chicky-pack; see cheki.
Cf. also borek, korek, chechak.

rioh. I. Clamour; hubbub. R. - rendah: riotous

riok" Chapek riok: lame as the result of a

11. (Onom.) A rustling sound.
fisa. Painless wen; (Ked.) hard leathery patch

risalat. Ar. Apostolate; mission. R. al-muhabbat:
message of love; letter of affectionate solicitude.
fisau. Disturbance.
(i) Passively, of disturbed feelings: Jangan-

(ii) Of disturbers of the peace: Di - kum -
pulkan - nya - tah orang yang r. beratus -


ratus hendak mengambil negeri Riau (he

risek. I. Confidential enquiries. Merisek: to sound
a person without committing oneself to
leading questions, e.g., trying to find out if
a marriage - proposal would be accepted so
as to avoid the humiliation of a direct
rejection. Dengan perlahan di - chari r.:
quietly did he seek for information.

robah. (Batav.) To change; obah, übah.
robak. Robak-rebek: very tattered and torn.

robat. See robak (torn).
robek. Worn through: perforated. Of matwork;

roboh. Heavy fall; crash. Of the fall of buildings
(Ht. Abd. 263, Mai. Annals 59); tiled roofs
(Kamp, Gl. 9); castle-gates (Mai. Annals 11);
great forest - trees (Sg. Sainb., Ind. Nata);
rock - avalanches or land-slides (batu r.).
This last expression is proverbial for uproarious

batu r. = laughing like a land - slide), Ht.
Best., Mas Ed.; cf. also batu r. sa - kali
semua - nya kita kawinkan (let us make
one huge splash by marrying them all at
the same time), Mas Ed.
The «fall of Malacca fort» (r. kota MSlaka)
was proverbial in the old days for an unlikely
or impossible event; Sh. Kub., Ind. Jaya.
See also rSbali.
robok. I. MSrobok: to eat inwardly or in
concealment, e. g., as an abscess without
external symptoms. Hati r.: suppressed
wrath; bottling up anger.
11. Merobok: (onom.) to bubble up —as
a bottle full of air when thrust into water.
Also niembobok, gelobok, gerobok, gogok.
rochah. Dirty and untidy.
Rochoh. Rochore. Now a suburb of Singapore.
rochoh. Prodding. Cf. rojok, rujah, rodok.
roda. Port. Wheel. R. kacha: glass wheel. R.
lambong: paddle-wheel. R. takal: sheave; =

r., gantang - gantang r. Gandar r.: axle; =

Also menggerodak.
rodan. Injury in a tender spot; very painful
injury.
rodi. Eur. Order; command; = ordi. Esp. of

5, 47, Waj. Hak. 4. R. kopi: (N. I.) the

11. Merodok: (Min.) to run wdth out-
stretched neck; to dash along in nervous
haste. Cf. rodong.
rodong. Running up against; coming into contact
with. In various senses;
(i) a chance or casual acquaintance, a
friend one has picked up on the road;
(ii) an intimate friend as one with whom
one is in constant association;
(iii) a husband (Pah.);
(iv) knocking about in, e. g. mSrodong
hutan duri (knocking about in thorny
jungle);
(v) colliding with; cf. terodong kaki
Raden A. J. pada batu itu lain luka
(Prince A.J.’s foot struck the boulder and
he was hurt), Perb. Jaya; and
(vi) wandering at haphazard (Min.).
Cf. randong, randok, serandong.
rogas, = rugas (broody, of hens),
rogoh. Mbrogoh: (Java) to insert a hand into an
aperture to draw something out; B.
rogol. Jav. Rape. Mfirogol: to ravish; Mai.
Annals 174. Di-r. oleh paduka anakanda:
she has been violated by the prince, your
son; Mas. Ed.
roh. [Ar. ruh] Quickening spirit of life. It
differs from nafas (breath of conscious life)
in that it persists even when a man is
asleep or in a swoon. In Moslem belief it
is a subtle vaporous substance, the principle
of vitality, sensation and voluntary movement.
This roh is breathed or blown (di - tiupkan
r.) into the blood - clot or embryo to create
a living entity, the toe t us; Ht. Bugis 1.
In theory and etymology it differs from the
sSmangat or bird - spirit of life (of old Indo-
nesian belief), but both mean «life - spirit*
and are often bracketed or regarded as
synonyms; cf.: r. - semangat (Raj. Don. 55,
Mai. Dem. 46); r. mMayang (Ht. Koris);
tSrbang r. (Jay. Asm. 26); tfirbang r. s -
mangat (Raj. Muda 27); cf. also panggil r.
(= panggil semangat) and tiada beroli
(faintness), Sg. Samb. See also rehan, a
rare word but nearer s6mangat in these
senses.
The definite departure of the roll from
the human body means death. Whence roll
can be used loosely for «soul» (better nyawa)
or for «breath of life* (better napas). Roh
is used for soul (Ht. Bugis 128); and (in the
same sense) r. malaikat (Raj. Muda 33).
Arwah, the plural of roh, is used also with
the meaning «soul*.
Mystics who believe in the unity of all
things and the illusive character of heaven
and earth reject the idea of individual souls
and use roh of aspects of the quickening
principle; e.g.:
(i) r. rahmani, nyawa rahmani: the All-
Soul; the spirit of God;
r. insam: the spirit of intelligent
self-consciousness in man;
(iii) r. haiwani: the less intelligent life -
principle in animals; etc.
These are further subdivided according to
their functions:
(i) r. jismani: the spirit by which the
body lives;
(ii) r. imani: the force that makes us
believe in religion;
(iii) r. idzafi: the power that leads us to
God. And so on.
R. al - kudus: (in missionary language)
the Holy Ghost. The early Arab Christians
used this term of the Second and Third
Persons of the Trinity so that it has some
authority; but Mohammed, who knew of
it, used it in a different sense (Koran
Ixxviii 38); so that the expression «Ho!y
Ghost* is better perhaps translated as r.
rohani or nyawa rohani.
rohani. Ar. Spiritual. Roh p.: the quickening
spirit of spiritual life; see roh. Nyawa r.;
the Soul underlying all spiritual (or real
life); in contr. to the nyawa jismani which
underlies physical or illusive life.
rojah, = rujah (downward thrust).
rojak. I. Jav. A sort of fruit - salad; Ht. Sh.,
Sid. Rama 176, = chenichah, ehecholek.
It is made of fruit (unripe and uncooked)
flavoured with red pepper, condiments
(sambal) and sugar; if the fruit is cooked


the salad is pinchok, q.v. See also kechar.
Rojak-varieties are: r. manis (of coconut);
r. parut (fruit in pungent sauce); r. pisang
(banana salad).
11. Merojak: (Ked., Pk.) to pound up
areca-nut. so as to prepare it for people who
cannot masticate properly; Ch. Jen. 67. P -
rojak sireh: areca - nut pounder; = gobek,
lesong pinang.
roji. [Pers. and Hind.: rozij Daily food;
ration, = ramsum.
rojok. I. Ar. Return (of a divorced wife) on the
annulment of a provisional divorce. After a
first or second talak (provisional divorce) a
husband has the right exercisable for 100
days only —of changing his mind and revoking
the divorce. In that case the wife has to
resume married life with him (rojok). After
the expiry of 100 days or after a third
talak has been pronounced the divorce is
final.
Also (Trengg.) of referring back, e.g., to
a section in an ordinance; Hn.
11. See rujah (thrust downwards).
rojol. Merojol: to jut out; Gem. Ht. 43. Of a
snake’s head emerging from a hole; a man’s
head thrust out of a window; a stick or
spear run through anything and projecting
on the further side; a swimmer’s head
emerging from the water in certain ways of
swimming; etc.
rok, I. (Oaom.) A dull cracking sound; the

Gem. Ht. 78.

rombok, (Min.) A kind of filigree-work; Tn.
rombong. I. ‘Malacca basket*; Al. Mai. 32. This
is a basket of line pandan matwork made
usually in a set to nest one within the other;
in shape round, triangular or polygonal; each
basket having a separate overlapping cover.
But the older rombong was of larger size
and used for storing rice; cf. tfirubong.
The small sizes (known also as kembal)
are used as work-baskets, sireh-baskets, etc.

rompak. Piracy; robbery on the waters. In confr.
to robbery on land (rampas). Pfirompak:
pirate; buccaneer. Perorapak darat di-gelar
orang: men called them land-pirates |Pr.
Turki 10), i.e., because they were bolder
and more pitiless than ordinary robbers.
Loosely, of all pirates: di-r. Lanun
(plundered by Ilanun pirates), Sh. Peng. 13:
ada laut ada-lah pfirompak (where you
have seas you have pirates), Prov. But a
distinction was made sometimes between
lanun (gen. for pirates on the high seas) and
pSrompak (pirates in their own territorial
waters); cf. Ht. Abd. 335.
Also (Kel. ropak) of gang-robbery by
night.
rompang. Rompang-ramping: tattered and torn

rongak. Broken by gaps; discontinuous. Pagar r.:

Anak tiong terdongak-dongak,
Terdongak-dongak dalam perahu;
Nak bbrchium gigi rongak,
Didalam gelap siapa tabu:
The mynah- bird uplifts his beak
And gazes skyward in my bark;
The kisses that the gap-toothed seek
Well, what’s the difference in the dark?
Cf. ronggang, rbnggang.
roilgga. I. Cavity; hollow. Of hollows in tree-trunks
(r. kayu) and river - banks; cavities in the

hollow. Luar kilat dalam - nya berongga:

rota. A tree, Canarium sp.; W.
rotan. «Rattan». Possibly = rautan, from raut
(to pare or trim for use). A gen. name for
many climbing palms of greater or less
economic value for fastenings, bindings, mat
or basket-making and (in some cases) export
to Europe. The best are Calamus spp.;
but other useful genera are Daemonorops,
Korthalsia and Plectocoinia.
Rattans exported to Europe (mostly for
making cane-furniture) include:
(i) Calamus caesius, the best, =
r. s6ga;
(ii) C. micranthus (r. sega ayer) and
C. o mat us (r. sega badak), slightly in-
terior;
(iii) C. 1i 11 oral i s (r. ayer), C. di d y mo-
phyllus (r. getah, r. udangl, and C.
javensis (r. lilin); second quality;
(iv) C. option us, the well - known rattan
used for caning children. = r. buyong; and
(v) C. s c i pi o n u m (r. somambu, s. raja,
r. chinchang), the well - known
cane».
• Unexported, but of economic value, are:
(i| C. manau (r. manau, r. manau t6lur),
very long and strong and used tor construct-
ing hammock - bridges;
(ii) C. aci d u s (r. asam) and Daemo-
norops hystrix (r. buah), which bear
fruit; and
(iii) D. draco or D. propinquus (r.
jornang) which yields the gum - dammar
known as dragon’s-blood.
Others are:

Di-mana kuang bertfilur?
Di-atas lata di-ruang batn.
Di-mana abang nak tidur?
Di-afas dada di-ruang susu;
Where does the plover make his nest?
In the cleft lip of some ravine.
Where does my lover take his rest?
In the soft dip my breasts between.

ruing. Revolving thread-winder used with a loom.
Also reweng. The skein is taken off the
long likas with both hands and is placed on
the square ruing so that the coil may be
unwound easdy, the slightest push making
the winder revolve.
These winders are of two types:
(i) horizontal, = Jav. undar, Sund.
hu wing an; this is the type used by Malays
in Java and illd. Jasp. ii 24, 26, 27; and
(ii) vertical, = (Mai.) ruing; this is the
Peninsular type and is illd. Jasp. ii 28, 40.
Both are square - framed and suggest the
winder of a fishing - line in England. The
frames are known as daun r.
ruit. Bent; hook-shaped; (Brun.) hook or barb.

rulus. A tree, Sapium baccatura; W.
Rum. [Ar.;=:Rome] «Rome», i.e., the Byzantine
or Eastern Roman Empire and its successor
the Ottoman Empire; (geographically) any
countries therein included. Thus Alexander
of Macedon was geographically a «Roman»;
cf. Mai. Annals 4. Laut bf'nua R.: the
Mediterranean (as one of the Seven Seas);
Boat. Sal i 70.
Also (Min.) Ruhum.
rum, = rom (rum).
ruma, = roma (down on body).
rumah. House; = (Min.) umah. Specifically a
dwelling-house in contr. to a mosque, or to a
balai or meeting-house open to all. Thus
bfirumah = entrer en menage, to set
up house, to get married; mSrumahi = to
break into a private house to compromise or
violate one of its inmates. Nowadays rumah
covers many types of house.
For the construction and types of a
Malay dwelling-house see Veth, p. 149.
Normally it consists of a large central room
(tfingah r., ruang tfingah, dalam; Min.
mSdalam) with or without a verandah (s -
rambi, Sum. s§lasar) and separate cook -
house (r. dapur. pSnanggah).
R. api: light-house; (also) case for housing
a lamp. R. bangSla, r. bangftlo: bungalow -
house. R. barak: barrack. R. batu: stone or
brick house. R. b6rhala: temple; church
(with images). R. b6rk6timpal: many houses
clustered together. R. gambar, r. p6nuntunan:
museum; exhibition - house. R. kampong,
(Min.) r. kota, (Java) pekarangan: farm -

rupiah. Hind. Rupee; guilder (as worth about a
rupee). Etym,, = «shaped» (i. e., minted)
money, cf. rupa; in contr. to the rough
block money ot stamped bullion once used
in India. Introduced by Sher Shah (A. D.
1542) to replace the block-coin of 96 ratti
weight, the ratti being the saga, q.v,
In Malay the word covers:
(i) the modern Indian rupee (r. Hindustan);
(ii) the Dutch guilder (Ht. Bugis 107),=
r. Jawa;
(iii) the old copper guilder of 100 doits
or five-sixths of the present guilder, = r.
tembaga;
(iv) a gold coin described as r. mas (Abd.
Jud. 6, Ht. Abd. 180); and
(v) the old Indian «sicca» rupee (r. sokah)
which was of higher value than the present-
day rupee.

rusa. Deer. Specifically the sambhur, Cervus

bSrangga (antlered); (iv) r. dandi (short-

(dark - coloured); (vi) r. saput (skin on horns);
(vii) r. übi (hairy - horned).
The word has also been extended in
meaning to cover foreign or imported «deer»,
e.g.: r. bintang (Cervus axis, imported
by Governor Phillips for his park); r. s£ng-
girek (the Oryx and the unicorn; known
through imported oryx - horns and the
British coat of arras); babi -r. (Babirusa
alfnrus, from Celebes).

supposed that they have been enticed away

ruyong, I. Outer and harder portion of a palm -
trunk; palm - trunk dried till only its harder
portions remain. Used as rough building

makes a good stockade.

ruyut. Much attached to one another; united,
B.
S
S 3. • I. A prefix implying unity: «one*; «one
in some feature*, i.e. alike; cmaking up
one*, i.e. all, the whole.
(i) As a numeral or as «a, an*, sa is
linked commonly to a «classifier»: sa-ekur
kfirbau (a buffalo); nyiur sa-batang (one
single coconut - palm); sa-orang manusia (a
human being). But this is not always the
case; cf.: sa-hari (a day*); aa-paroh (a half);
sa-tahun (a year). Cf. also: sa-orang-orang
(a man quite alone, i.e. lonely); sa - orang -
orangan (loneliness).
(ii) For «oneness in some feature* cf.:
sa-rupa (one in appearance): sa-elok ini (as
handsome as this). Hence sa can be used as
a comparative. Langit yang sa-bosar itu:
the sky which is so broad. Ada-kah sa -
banyak bulu ayam jantan itu: are they as
many as the feathers on that cock.
(iii) For sa as «making up one», i.e. the
whole, cf. sa-umur-ku (all my life); ku
jawab dengan sa-tahu-ku (I answered to
the best of ray knowledge). Emphasis can be
added by doubling the word: dengan sa -
suchi-suchi hati (with the purest of feelings);
sa-panjang - panjang hutan (from end to
end of the forest).
(iv) Sa -sa or sa - suatu = each, every.
Sa-sa-orang: each person.
Other expressions are: sa - bblah (see be-
lah); sa-b6lum (while as yet not; before);
sa-hingga (until); sa-kali (all at one
time; altogether; together); sa - kali-pun
(although); sakalian (all); sa-kian (this much,
so); sa - lagi (while still); sa - niata - niata
(obviously); sa - tolah (when it was over; =
after); sa-tuju (in harmony, harmonious);
sa-umpama (as for instance).
«Like» or «as» is often an idiom in sa; sa-
bagai, sa-macham, sa-laku, sa-rupa, sa-
umpama, etc.
If. [Ch.; = three] Name of the third suit
in chicky cards; see chbki, Also serong.
111. = sha (willed).
Saaban, = Shaaban (name of month).
Saad. [Ar.; fortunate] A masc. proper name;
usually pronounced Sahat or Saat and
shortened to Ad, At, Hat.
Saad. Ar. «Auspicious*, as a name for certain
stars or star - groups. Four ot these are
of the moon* (manazil), viz.;
(i) saad al-dzabeh; two stars in the horn
of Capricorn; the 22nd mansion;
(ii) saad al-bula’: three stars in the left
hand of Aquarius; the 23rd mansion;
(iii) saad al-saud: «b» in Aquarius and
?d» in the tail of Capricorn; the 24th
mansion; and
(iv) saad al-khiba or a. al-akhbiat: four
stars in Aquarius; the 25th mansion.
See Bost. Sal. i 49. Collectively these
«mansions* are-known as suud (Ar.; plur.
of saad).
saadah. See saadat.


Malaya,=Majesty: bagindas. (H.M. the King),
Lail. Mejn. 7; pangkat s. (royal rank); dar
al-s. (seat of royalty; Constantinople), Also
saadah; Ht. Bugis 129. In Turkey and
Persia saadat=<'Excellency»,
saadiah. Ar. Coal of mail from Sa’d in Arabia
(where the best were once made); Bost. Sal.
ii 54. The coat of mail refen'ed to in this
passage was in the Prophet’s possession at
his death and is described as the coat worn
by David when he slew Goliath.
Saat. See Saad (proper name).
saat. Ar. Period of time; hour; moment. Often
with special reference to auspicious and
inauspicious times: al -s. (the Fateful Hour;
the hour of judgment); s. yang nahas
(inauspicious time); s. yang sempurna (most
favourable hour), Ht. Angg. 6. Commonly
of the present time (Pen. coll.: sat ini; =
saat ini; literary, dengan sa-saat ini
juga); cf. also pukul sa-pulohs. yang
tentu (at ten o’clock exactly).
sab, = sap (fibrous stuff).
Saba. Ar. Sheba; Sabaea; Arabia Felix. See
also Sabi.
Saba. I. Skr. Frequenting; visiting. Bersaba:
to associate with. Yang tiada di-s. orang:
lonely; unfrequented (of a well); Kal. Dam.
31.

sabar. [Ar. sabr; Hind, sabar] Patience.
Sabarkan: to bear with. Tahan s.: to be
patient. S.-lah dahulu: have some patience.
S. is used also by mystics in the sense
of the stoical acceptance of pain, sickness
and other visitations.
sabarin. Ar. Al-sabarin: the patient; i.e., the
submissive. In a Koran text («God is with the
Patient in Spirit») that is much used as a
heading to letters of condolence.
sabas. See shabash (well done).
sabasani. Pohon sabasani; a legendary tree shaped
like a snake and slaying all who looked on
it; Ht. Pasai 42. Cf. Hind, sabsabani:
Ghat which creeps like a snake*.
sabat. I. Sabbath. Prom Hebrew through English;
a missionary term. Cf. sabtu.
11. Ar. Seven.
111. = sahabat (friend).
sabda. fSkr. shabda] Utterance; to say. In
ordinary use limited to the words of the
Prophet, or of a non - Moslem royalty or of
a Moslem major Chief, the words of a Mos-
lem king being titah. The adat - saying is
Raja berdaulat, pgnghulu bfirandeka;
Raja bertitah, penghulu bSrsabda:
The King hath Majesty, the Chief lordship;
the King commands, the Chief ordains. So
s. is used (Min.) of a pfinghuhi andeka or
territorial Chief; (N.S.) of an undang; (Mai.)
of a great Chief such as a bdnduhara (Mai.
Annals) or an orang kaya bgsar (Ht. Angg.
33, 36). The association of Utah with the
Moslem daulat makes sabda the proper
word for the utterances of a non - Moslem
ruler such as the b6tara of Majapahit or of
a prince of romance (Sg. Samb., Ind. Nata,


Jay. Lengg., Ism. Yat.). The injunctions of
the Prophet are s. nabi or s. rasul (Jay.
Lengg., Mai. Annals 46, 67). To reply to a
sabda is mSmbalas s. or menyahut s. To
carry out a Chiefs orders is s. di-pikul, to
carry out a King’s being titah di-junjong.
sabdu. [Ar. shaddu] A name for the vowel
point tashdid, q.v.
sabe’. (Min.) Hindrance; obstruction; Tn.
sabffda, = sabda (ordain).
sabSlah. See belah (side).
sab&las. Eleven; see b«Mas.

sabhan. Ar. Giving praise to God by using the
words subhana Allah (Exalted be Allah).
sabhat. Ar. Rosary-bead; see tasbeh.
Sabi. Ar. Sabaean; Sheban; see Saba. [Sabaeans
are classed with Christians and Jews as
kitabi, i.e. as having orthodox scriptures.
According to the Bostan (i 79, 80) they were
of the religion of Seth and Enoch and had as
their Bible (kitab) the writings (suhuf) of
Seth. These writings are said to have enjoined
good conduct, charitable gifts, the Holy War,
hospitality to strangers, hostility to evil,
seven daily prayers, proper funeral rites and
a yearly fast lasting for a month. Their
holy place was a tabernacle (kubah) in Egypt,
built by Enoch; and they traced their
ancestry to Sabi (son of Enoch) whose tomb
is in the sacred enclosure (haram) at Mecca.
Othlr authorities such as Lane explain sabi
as «one who changes his religion* and say
that the Sabaeans were star - worshippers].
Sabi. I. [Pers. shabi] Shirt; loose garment
worn either by day or night. Meninggal
akan jubah dan s.-nya: discarding his coat
and shirt; Ht. Koris.
11. Sabi - sabian: (Min.) partizanship; Tn.
Sabi’. Ar. Seven.
sabik. (Min.) Tatter; cf. chabek.
Sabil. Ar. Way; road; —but always associated
with the words (Ar.) fi sabil Allah (on
God’s path, i.e. in God’s cause), and rftmally
with the Holy War (perang s. Allah), its
warriors (bujang s. Allah, Hg. Tuah 531),
its warfare (bCrbuat s. Pr. Turki 7), and
death in the Holy War (shahid fi s. Allah,
Ht. Bugis 141). Others again speak of
parang s. kechil (Mohammed’s war against
the Koreish) and pSrang s. bfisar ya - itu
peperangan manusia dfingan hawa-nafsu-
nya (the major Holy War or man’s war
against his own passions), Kep. Mai. 72.
Technically the expression mati s. can be
applied to a man who dies in carrying out a
duty such as the pilgrimage to Mecca, but
this use is not conventional; cf. also its
application even to a Thug who dies for the
sake of his Goddess (mati s. s6bab mati
didalam monjalankan kewajiban), Sid.
Rama 282. Cf. shahid.

sabit. I. Reaping-hook; sickle; illd. Yeth xc G,
ci 5, = (Kel.) ch6rok, cherot; (Trengg.)
cherut; (Java) arit. In harvesting with the
sickle (mfinyabit) the rice-stalks are cut
about half-way up and built into small stacks
(bumbun) the ears being thereby kept well
off the ground and dry; Cl. Seed - rice is
harvested with the tuai, q.v.
Penyabit: reaper; (fig.) stealer of heads
for propitiating the earth-spirits when a great
public work is undertaken; there, being
periodical scares (known as musim ikan
sepat; «seasons of headless fish*) when it
is believed that heads are wanted for this
purpose; cf. J.S.A.S. Ixvii 117, Ht. Abd.
313-317.

sabok. I. Jav. Sash; broad band of rich cloth


(chindai or petola) worn by warriors of old
romance (Ht. Sh., Ind. Nata): by being wound
in many folds round the body, it gave some
protection against cuts. The s. is still met
with in Java and Patani; it is used also
with pendent ends that are swayed by
dancing girls (did. Raffles pi. xx); and for
special types of sash see sampur and sembong.

ikan s.), and cocks (s. ayam). In this last

cock); bagai ayam s. (like a pair

Safar. [Ar. sa fr, Hind, safar] Name of the
second Moslem month, «Safar», the «unlucky
month* (bulan nahas) because it contains
the anniversary of Hasan’s death. Mandi s.;
a day of purification (made by Malays into
a festival) during this month. Often pronoun-
ced Sapar.
Safar. Ar. Travel; journey. Dzu-s.: traveller.
safarja!, Ar. Quince, Pyrus cydonia.

safil, safiiin. See asfal (low, mean).
safir. Ar. Traveller; Kit. Muj. 8. Cf. safar,
musafir.
salrah. See sufrah (ground-sheet).
sag. Pers. Dog; Dl.
saga. I. Name given to two berries that are
used as measures of weight for gold and
therefore as standards of value (that berry’s
weight of gold):
(i) the «crab’s eye* or seed of Abrus
precatorius, = (Sum.) saga, (Mai.) s.
botina, s. kechil, akar s.;
(ii) the seed of Adenanthera pavo-
nina,=(Sum ) s. kayu, (Mai.) saga, s. besar,
kenderi batang.
Other plants called saga but not used as
measures of weight are; (iii) s. bukit (P i-
thecolobium angulatum); (iv) s. gajah
(Pi the oo lob iu m fasciculatnm); (v)
s. hutan (Ormosia parvifolia); (vi) s.
kayu (Micromelum pubescens); (vii)
s. paya (D al b e r g i a j u ng h u h n ii); (viii)
akar s. betina (a vetch, unid.); (ix) s. serong
(Pithecolobium clypeariu m); and
(x) akar s. raolek (Lettsomia rubi-
cunda). Also of watermelon - pips (s. sd-
mangka). The seed of Abrus preca-
torius is a round berry of a bright red
colour (with a black spot). It is a simile for
blood - shot angry eyes (mata biji s., Sh.
Kub.), and for a «pea on a platter* (s. atas
talam), i.e. a «wobbler». It represents also
the minimum measure of weight and value,
e.g. suatu s. mas tiada ku lihat (not one
tittle of money have I seen), Ht. Hamz.
These berries of Abrus precatorius
are remarkably uniform in size and weight
and are the basis of the oldest Indian table
of weights, i.e. 8 of them to the mas ha
(see mas), 16 mas ha to the weight now
standardized in the rupee. A single saga
represents about I—grain; and this is the
weight known in Malaya as buah berfiksa,
hitam tengkok, lada, k6n6ri or kenderi, s.


kechil, s. keneri and (Ked.) saga. But the
Sumatran mas was much more in weight
than the Indian mas h a (possibly owing
to the difference between the dollar and the
rupee); and as the saga was supposed to
represent an eighth of a mas the name saga
was given to the weight of the violet-red
bean-like beiry of Adenanthera pavo-
nina which weighed about an eighth of a
mas.

11. = sagur (dug - out).
sagran. A climber, Willughbeia flavescens;

sagu. I. Mealy pith. Associated usualljr with
«sago», i.e. the mealy pith of the • sago-
palm (sagu rurabia) which is of value as a
food - stuff and much consumed in the Ar-
chipelago in localities where rice is not
grown. In Malaya and Sumatra, where rice
is preferred, untong sagu (sago-luck) is the
lot of the second best or of a lady’s «second
string*. But sagu only means «mealy
pith» and is used of banana-pith (s. pisangl
and sugar - palm pith, besides being applied
to sago, arrow - root (a. Belanda) and tapioca-
flour (s. tepong).
For commercial purposes «sago-pith» is
brought from other parts of the Archipelago
to Singapore in conical wrappers of pandan-
leaf (sagu tampin) to be refined and roasted
by European methods into the granular sago
(s. rfindang) of our markets. This is the
pith of Metroxylon sagus (pohon s.
runibia).
Cf. also sagun and sesagun.
11. Sagu hath douceur; propitiatory
gift.

pirates).

sah. I. [Ar. sah h] Valid; in force; authoritative;
in order; proven. MSngesahkan: to verify;
Ht. Bugis 17. Khabar yang s.: definite and
reliable news (Hg. Tuah 37, 604); also
perkhabaran yang s. (Raj. Muda 35).
Keterangan yang s.: a full and proper
explanation; Sid. Rama 123. Itu-lah naskh-
ah taurit yang s.: that (the Septuagint) is


the authoritative text of the Old Testament;
Bost. Sal. i 106.
In legal diction sail means «fully proved*
according to the canons of evidence: sail
kata adat apabila tertanda terbeti. Ta’-
sail is non-proven, i.e., not fully proved
though probable. Sail ta’- sail or sah-batal
(guilty or not guilty, proven or non-proven)
refers to the verdict, not to the sentence.
If. See shah (king; check to the king).
sahab. See sahap (veil, cover).
sahabat. Ar. Friend; comrade; companion. Ber-
sahabat: to be on friendly terms. Bbrsahabat
karib: to lie on terms of intimacy; Sid. Rama
39, S. rasul Allah; the Prophet’s greater
disciples such as Abubakar, Omar and
Othman; Bost. Sal. ii 54. Daripada ba-
nyak s6teru balk berbanyak s.: better many
friends than many toes; Mai. Annals 87.
In letter - writing s. beta, (or Pah.,
Trengg., Kel.) s. kita, is used as a pronoun
of the second person; with s6ri paduka
prefixed when addressing a Sultan and
paduka when addressing a Chief or non -
reigning raja.
Also (Batav., Baba) sobat.
sahadat, = shahadat (attestation of faith).
sahaja. Intentionally; of set purpose and without
orders; on one’s own; only; simply. Also
(coll, and Min.) saja; s«smaja; sengaja; and
cf. (Sund.) haja (to do intentionally). In
Bazaar Malay s. means «only*; the older
meaning (intentionally) is lost sight of.
Bahajakan; to bring about of set purpose;
Pg. Ptg. Menyahaja igama: to devote
oneself exclusively to religion; Bost. Sal. ii
114. Anak tuan-tuan yang bersahaja-
sahaja: sons of gentlemen who were «on
their own®, i.e. had no regular employment;
Mai. Annals 64. Bukan di-sahaja, sfibab
akal budak: «there was no deep-laid plan, a
child’s suggestion did it», —said of the defeat
of the swordfish; Mai. Annals 58.

Sahat. A proper name; = Saad, q.v.
sahaya. Skr. Humble servant; follower; domestic;
your humble servant; I (in polite but not
obsequious language). Usually pronounced
sahya or saya. In regular use among Euro-
peans as the pronoun of the first person. Cf.
also s. tuan and s. dato’ (your lordship’s
servant; Hg. Tuah 894) as rather more de-
ferential pronouns of the first person; and s.
semua or sema or sepa as a plural (we).
As a slave a sahaya was a household
worker and ranked higher than a hamba
who worked in the fields. Hamba s. (serfs
and slaves) represented slaves of all sorts;
Gul Bak. 13, 46, Mai. Dem. 14. Other
terms are: s. pemerdehekaan (1 i b e r t i n u s,
freed slave), Bost. Sal. ii 95; s. pSrgmpuan
(female slave), Bost. Sal. ii 40. and s.
tobusan (bought slave', I'o t. Sal. ii 40.
sahayan. A fabulous bird of romance; Dl. Also
sahian, Pant. Mai. 668.
saheh. Ar. Valid; proved; certain; cf. salt. Sa-
telah s. - lah pada Pa’ PSnjerat akan ke-
matian Sang Kanchil itu: when the old
Squeezer thought that the mousedeer’s
death was a positive fact; Ht. Pdk. 26. Also
of a tradition (hadis) being ; see
hadis.
sahi. I. Careless; slovenly; thoughtless.
11. = sai (a skate).
sahian. See sahayan (fabulous bird).
sahib. Ar. Owner; possessor; = yang gmpunya.
S. al - hikayat: the author of the tale; the
writer; «we». S. al - kapi; «one of those of
the cave*; one of the Seven Sleepers of
Ephesus; see kahaf.
sahilah. [Ar.; through Hind.] Letter; epistle; written


document. Used (Bost. Sal. ii 24) of the
letter sent by Mohammed to the Sasanian
king which that monarch tore to pieces
«-even as his own kingdom shall be torn to
pieces*; and again (Bost. Sal. ii 43) of the
document drawn up and signed by foes of
Mohammed and deposited by them in
the Kaaba where it was eaten by white
ants.
sahih. See sahelr (proved).
Sahilan. Ceylon: Sailan and Selan. Gunong S.:
a well-known township in Central Sumatra.
sahing. I (W. Sum.) Difference; Dl.
11. = saeng (in company).
sahir. Ar. Seer; wizard; person versed in the
Black Art (ilmu seller); Bost. Sal. ii 13.
Sahit. A proper name; = Said, q.v.
sahit. I. (W. Sum.) Beard; DL, =• janggut.
11. See shahid (martyr).
111. See sayat (to slice).
sahkatl. If only; provided only; Mai. Pant. 430,
=usahkan, q.v.
Sahtnurah. A name for Cyrus the Persian, Bost.
Sal. i 106.
sahun. A tree, Durio malaccensis; W.
sahup. A variant (Must. Adat 7) of sahap (cover).
sahur. I. Ar. The meal taken just before dawn
in the month of Ramazan.
11. A fruit, sp. unid.
sahut. Replying; answering. Esp. of a reply to a
shout or call or salute. Imbau nan tidak
bersahutan: a call without an answer; Must.
Adat 19. BertSriak di - kiri di - kanan
mftnyahut: to the left and being
answered from the right*; fig,, of a person
with many servants; Ht. A bd. 5.
Abang di-sana, adek di -sini;
Bagai-lali burong bersahut - sahutan:
I am here and my loved one is there like
birds that respond to each other; Mai. Pant.
360.
sahwat, = shahwat (orgasm).
sahya. See sahaya (slave;' I),
sai. I. A forked stick covered with thorns
and used for pinning a malefactor against a
wall. Also clianggali and chabang sai.
I lid. May. i. 9.
11. Ikan sai: a ray, sp. unid.
Said. [Ar.; = fortunate] A proper name. Usually
pronounced Sahit or shortened to Hit, Id,
It.
said. I. [Ar. saiyid] Master; lord; prince; a
title well known as «syed» and as given to
reputed descendants of the Prophet. S. al -
anbia (prince of the prophets) and s. al -
bashar (prince of mankind): titles given to
Mohammed. S. itu keturunan daripada
rasul Allah: the Syeds are descendants of
the Fiophet; Ht. Abd. 15.
A distinction is drawn sometimes between
a said (descendant of the Prophet through
Hasan) and a shaiif (descendant through
Husain); but this distinction is not observed
in Malaya where all alike are «Syeds» and
their sisters «sharifahs». A «syed» or
sharif is supposed to be a descendant of the
Prophet in the direct male line; a sharifah’s
son by a non - «syed» becomes a mir (Pk.) =
amir.
[ln a general way it may be said that
Syeds in Malaya are of two classes: Hadia-
maut Syeds and Indian Syeds. The former
represent the religious aristocracy of Hadra-
raaut; some of their families rank higher
than others. The latter are only Syeds in
the loose Indian sense of the term, which
does not always imply descent from the
Prophet. But all alike are regarded with
great respect.)
ll.=Bhahid (martyred), q.v.

Dah.
saldani. Ar. «The two princes*, i. e. Hasan and
Husain.

saiduna. Ar. Our Lord, i.e. Mohammed; Kit. Muj.

sajak. I. Ar. Assonance; cadence; melodious

banyak ta’ - k6na; the cadence is poor
and the rhyming is faulty; Sing. Terb.

m6ndapat istSri yang bersajak (to find a

Ak. 33. Also of affectation (s, anggun).

sajang. (Kawi) Spirituous liquor;=arak. S. tapai;

saji. I. Served up; dished up; dressed. Of food-
courses arranged on dishes for the table, but

guests; cf. tudong s. (conical dishcover; illd.

dan di-buboh - nya saji dan di-pasangkan

300. Nasi tersaji di - lutut: «food ready
dressed and on one’s knees*, prov. of
fortune without effort.

sak. [Dutch zak] Pocket; = Mai. saku.
saka. I. Maternal heritage, in contr. to paternal
(baka). Of family property, ancestral traits,
etc. S. - baka; ancestry on both sides;
complete family history,—also baka-s. and
nioyang s.-bfrbaka (Aw. Sul. 64). In Min.
and N.S. saka is all-important: nyiur nan
s. (inherited trees); ferbit pt'saka kapada s.
(inheritance comes through the mother), Mai.
Saying 24.
If. Jav. Pillar; post. In Java as. is a

IT. Aji saka: (Java) «the era of king
Saka*, i.e., computing dates from the coming

king Salivana.

sakah. See s6kali (broken but unsevered).
Sakai. Subject; dependent. Of subject peoples
in contr. to the ruling race; therefore some-
what contemptuous and usually replaced by
terms like rayat and biduanda except in
the Riau - Lingga archipelago where the
sakal rank above the rayat. Or the terms
can be differentiated as follows: sakai
(aborigines who do not speak Malay), rayat
(aborigines who speak Malay), and biduanda
(aborigines who speak Malay, have accepted
Malay culture and been received as equals
into the community); in a loose way this is
true of the Peninsula but not of Sumatra.
P§nghulu s.; aboriginal headman (Mar.
Mah.); but negrito headmen are politely
peugliina and contemptuously gembala se -
mang; while headmen of the Besisi and
Malay-speaking aborigines are batin, q.v.
Cf.: bafin dan si'gala sakai - nya (the
island headmen and their people), Hg. Tuah
299; and the distinction drawn by Abdullah
between a Chief’s own people, the Malays
(kaum keluarga - nya), and the primitive
communities under his rule (rayat s. - nya),
Pel. Abd. 18.
See also sagai, rayat, biduanda.
sakal. I. Knocking up against; butting up against;
rapping with the knuckles. Usually of a
contrary wind (angin s.) that prevents the
light - draughted Malay ships from making
any headway; cf. angin pun tSrlalu s.,
hampir-lah la m6nyusur pantai laut (the
wind was a strong headwind, it seemed to
be following the very outline of the coast);
Ht. Best. But it is used also (Ked., Pk.)
of heavy blows with the fist: kena s. (to be
knocked down); samun s. (robbery with
violence).
Also (W. Sum.) sakar.

sakar. I. [Pers. shalt a r] Sugar (Hg. Tuah

sliagar and even (poetically) sSgara. Specific-

sweetness, e.g. lautan madu bfirpantaikan
s. (a sea of honey with a beach of sugar),
Ht. Koris, and the lines Mai. Pant. 1117),
Sungai madu, laut bersakar
Haus tidak dapat di - minum:
Oh honeyed river, sugared sea,
I thirst yet cannot drink of thee.
The common word for sugar is gula
(etym. = palm sugar). In Min., s. = round
cakes of sugar.

sakhlat. [Pers. and Hind, sak all a t] Scarlet cloth;
good broadcloth of one colour; cloth of
which uniforms are made. Associated now
by Malays with scarlet; cf. burong s. (a
scarlet bird, sp. unid.); warna s. (Pant.
Mai. 1221) = scarlet. Its original meaning
is doubtful, but it seems at one time to
have been used of silk embroidered with
gold.

ruginous); buah s.(Diospyros discolor).

sakhrat. Ar. Stone. With special reference to the
stone or «rock» in the Dome of the Rock:
s. Allah yang di-bait al-mukadis (God’s
stone that is in Jerusalem), Bost. Sal. i GO.
Like the «black stone* at Mecca this
sakhrat is believed to have been sent
down from heaven. According to the Bostan
(i 108) the Dome of the Rock was destroyed
by Constantine and made into a tbmpat
orang membuang sSresah (a place where
rubbish is dumped).

sakit. Sick; diseased; being ill or in pain. Sakiti,
mSnyakiti or mfinyakitkan; to afflict.
B6rsakit: to take pains. Kesakitan; a state
of pain, trouble or illness. Persakit: a cause
of sickness or sorrow. S. hati; annoyance;
anger; ill will. S. hid up: suffering from a
wasting disease without visible cause,
ascribed to witchcraft. S. mbmbaka: here-
ditary disease; Hn. S. menular: infectious
disease. S. payah, s. terok; serious illness.
S. waba: murrain; epidemic. Apa s.: what
ails you. Bekas s.; symptom or trace of
illness. Kbna s.: to be ill. Mendapat s.: to
fall ill. Tahi penyakit: valetudinarian. Men-
jerit-lah ia sebab kesakitan; he screamed
with pain. Mengapa 6ngkau persakit akan
hamba dbngan bala ini: why do you bring
affliction on me, thy servant, with this curse
of thine; Ht Abus. 28.
D isease (sakit, penyakit) is ascribed to
evil spirits of disease (hantu penyakit); it
varies in severity according to the nature of
the patient’s encounter with the evil spirit
(see hantu); and is treated by medicine-men
with spells as well as drugs; cf. the lines
(on love-sickness), Di-katakan sakit, deniam
pun bukan, Bukan-lah pfinyakit di-übat
jampi (you say he is ill, yet no fever is
there; no drugs and no spells can avail in
his case).
Pokok s. udang: tree, Ixonanthes
reticulata; W.

sakrat. I. Ar. Sakrat al-maut: the death-agony;
e.g. s. al-maut yaani ketika anakanda m -
lepaskan nyawa (s. al-maut or in other

11. = Sa-kerat (a section, half).


saksama. Skr. Diligent enquiry. Adil s.: impartial
and diligent in looking into things; Mai.
Annals 241. M6ndirikan hak dengan s.: to
elucidate the truth by careful enquiiy; Sh.
Nas. 4.
saksi. Skr. Witness; oral evidence; personal
testimony. Hukuni berdiri dfngan s.:
«Moslem Law is built up on the testimony
of witnesses*, i.e. it relies mainly on the
oral evidence of men of good character; —in
contr. to adat which relies more on exhibits
and circumstantial evidence (tanda). Naik s.:
to give evidence. Huruf saksi; vowels (alif,
wau or ya) written in lieu of corresponding
vowel-points so as to facilitate reading.
sakti. Skr. Supernatural power, esp. in the
Hindu sense of the word. Originally the
s h a k t i of a Hindu divinity was the gener-
ative or female principle of the idea
embodied in the God; this female principle
was personified in a corresponding Goddess,
e.g. Durgaor Kali as the «wife» of Siva. It
survives, in this sense, in expressions like
Berma-sakti, Bima-sakti. In Malay romances
based on Hindu sources sakti figures as a
divine power to work miracles and plays a
great part in the combats of the Gods and
the Titans, The Gods war by miracles (meng-
adu kesaktian). But the Hindus believed
also that a certain modicum of supernatural
power could be acquired by asceticism (tapa)
and even that this asceticism could be passed
on by ascetics to other persons and to ina-
nimate objects. Thus power and the use
of talismans figure often in old romances. An
interesting passage (Ht. Pasai 26) tells the
story of a contest between the sakti of a
Hindu ascetic and the keramat of a Moslem
king; victory, of course, went to the accepted
religion. But Islam only triumphed by putting
a veneer of orthodoxy over old beliefs; even
in the Nineteenth Century there was a
Yamtuan Sakti in Minangkabau and the
Negri Sembilan; and the Mustika Adat (p. 1)
speaks of warriors who are sakti at the
present day.
saku. I. Eur. Pocket; canvas bag. Cf.: Si Jamin
38 (saku == kantong = kochek); and ia-pun
mengeluarkan satu rupiah mas daridalam
s. - nya (he took a gold rupee out of his
pocket), Ht. Abd. Also kochek, (N. 1.)
kantong, (Pen.) paket, (Min.) sakus.
11. Cut off; separated. Menyakukan: to
sever.
sakui, sakuih. See sokoi (millet).

sal. I. [Peis, and Hind, slial] Puggaree;
woollen wrapper worn either as a plaid over
the shoulder (Jur. Bud. 43) or bound turban-
wise on the head (see sfirban).
[Etym. the same word as «shawl»; but
the modern large «shawl» is a developement
of a small wrapper and owes its vogue to
the fine silky wool of which that wrapper
was made.]

salagi. As long as; = sa-lagi.
salatl. I. At fault; amiss. Of anything going
wrong or being out of place, as: (i) a strained
sinew, =s. urat: (ii) a false step or bad
start, g. langkah, s. molangkah; (iii) a
stiff neck,=s. bantal; (iv) a misunderstanding,
= s. ambilan, s. paham; (v) a thing being
ill-timed, =s. piantan; (vi) a word giving
offence that is not intended, =s. kbna, s.
teriina; (vii) an unfavourable wind, = angin
s. Of. also ealahi or inenyalahi (to make a
thing go wrong); borsalah or tersalah or
bSrsalahan (at fault); kesalahan (error,
mistake); ta’ salah (not amiss, quite the
same); inenyalahi pantang (to violate a
taboo); inenyalahi kehbndak (to upset a
person’s (dans), Mai. Annals 240: tuanhanil a
nienyalahkan hamba-kah (do you say that
I am in the wrong): bagai pinggan dfingan
mangkok, salah sadikit hendak mengantok
(like a bowl upon a platter, misplace either
and they clattei), Prov,
S. may be used (Mai.) of an offence of
any sort, e.g,: orang s. (prisoner, defendant);


but it is also specific (Min.) for illicit inter-
course not amounting to the more serious
offence of sumbang (incest). Idioms are; s.
sa-orang (one or the other person); s. suatu
(one or the other thing); s. sileh or s. silit
(errors of all sorts; faults of various kinds);
s6rba s. (in the wrong either way; at fault
whatever one does).
Ikan s. nama: (Pk.) «the fish with the
unmentionable name*; sp. unid. 8. nama is
also a polite way of referring to plants of
which the true names are not mentioned in
polite society. Akar s. laku: a climber,
Vitis quadrangular!s; W.
11. Ar. Salah - silah: genealogy; see sala-
silah.
salai. Slow roasting; heating; grilling. Of the
medicinal «roasting» (near a very slow fire)
to which a Malay woman is subjected after
her confinement; of plantains parched over a
fire; and generally of processes where
prolonged exposure to heat (not extreme
heat) are required; cf. di -s. = di-diang,
Pet. Ayam 64. In Malaya s. implies the use
of fire; cf. the proverb bersalai tidak bfirapi
as a paradox applied to unmarried women who
become pregnant. In Sumatra and Java s.
is extended to parching by solar heat; and the
word means also (Min.) <?to light®, cf. di - s.
pula damar (the torches were lit), Must.
Adat. 26.
Balaian: the rack nearest the kitchen fire;
the lower rack; illd. Yeth Ixx 1. Pbnyalai
a sort or grid or platform for sun - drying
and preserving fish; Ch. Jen. 37. 8. is
used also of exposure to the fires of Hell;
Sh. May. 10.
Salajur. (Brun., Sar.) Immediate; direct; M. Cf.
lajur.
salak. I. A stemless thorny palm, Zalacca
edul i a, producing a fruit (buah s.) much
prized by Malays, the best coming from
Jambi (s. Jambi, Pel. Akal iii 23). Also Z.
affinis; W. Tinggal k6lopak s. (Heft
with the leaf - wrapper of the salak») is fig.
for a man stripped of everything except the
clothes he is wearing.
11. Menyalal;: to bark (of dogs). Anjing
m6nyalak di-pantat gajah; «dogs barking
after an elephant*, =; impotent fury or empty
threats; Prov.
salalu. See sftlalu (always).
Salam. A proper name. Short for Abdul - salam,
see salam. •
salam. I. Ar. Peace; the salutation «Peace be
with you* (s. alaikum); a greeting, e.g.
mSmbiiri s. (to greet), bSrjabat s. (to clasp
with both hands in greeting), Ht. Angg. 96.
This greeting (s. alaikum) is reserved for
Moslems and implies a certain equality; see
Mai. Annals 124, 144 for the story of men
who ran amuck because the word salam in
a letter of theirs was read out deliberately
as sfcmbah, the salutation of an inferior. A
salam is also the blessing at the end of a
a mosque service.
Abdul -s.: a proper name; often shortened
to salam. Dar al-s.: «abode of Peace»;
the name of the Second Heaven (Host. Sal.
i 39), and the honorific title of certain
countries notably Acheen (Hg. Tuah 502),
ancient Pahang (Mai. Annals 246) and
Kedah. Madinat al-s.: the honorific name
of Bagdad.
11. [Ar. sal lama] Salla Allahu alaihi
wa salam: «may God bless and save him*;
a prayer commonly uttered after a mention
of the Prophet’s name.
111. A tree, Eugenia sp., Sid. Rama
38. Its laurel-like leaves (daun s.) are used
in cookery.
IV. Salam di - rimba: a name for the
mousedeer; = shall alam di-rimba (emperor
of the jungle). See pelandok.
V. (Min., Brun., Sar.) To dive; =; selam.
Salamah, = Solamah or Salmah (a proper name).
salamani. Rumput salamani: herb, Blainvillea
rhoinbo i d e a; W.
salamat, selainat (security).
salang. Slaying a criminal with the kris. In this
form of execution the victim had to squat
down while the executioner stood over him
and drove a long straight - bladed rapier-like
kris I keris penyalang, kbris panjang,
keris bahari) from a certain spot (tempat
pfinyalang) within his collarbone down far
into his heart. Of. 6rti salang itu di-ikat-
nya kaki tangan oraug itu lalu di-dudok-
kan-nya di-haluan perahu, maka pbr-
tanda itu ada mSmbawa sa-bilah keris


panjang daripada Bendahara, maka di-
tikam - nya akan orang itu di - tbinpat
p&nyalang - nya (salang means that a man
i§ pinioned hand and foot and placed on a
boat’s bows, and the executioner takes a
long kr i s belonging to the Bendahara
and drives it into the man at a certain spot
near his neck), Pel. Abd. 20. The kris
was driven through cotton - wool which
absorbed any bleeding that there might be,
as «the shedding of blood* was a power
vested only in a King; cf. keris penyalang
daripada undang, pedang pemanchong
daripada keadilan (the kris that executes
bloodlessly comes from the Chief, but the
sword that beheads is the King’s), a N.S.
adat - saying.
Mati di -s.: «destined to die by the
execution - kris* = gallows - bird; Sh. Peng.
9, Raj. Jer. 17.

roof (to keep food out of the reach of animals);

by a cord (tali s.) to a person standing
below, Aw. Sul. 69.

From bersama (along with, in the same
place, together) comes a Bazaar Malay use
of sama = «with, to*, e.g.: mari sama
sahaya (come along with me); bilang s.
sahaya (tell me). Cf. also the pantun-lines,
Datang tuan, datang-lah nyawa, mari
dudok bersama - sama: oh enter, my soul
and my master, and sit yourself down at
my side; Mai. Pant. 391.

sambal. Condiment eaten with curry. A gen. name
for peppers, pickles, grated coconut or
pineapple, salt fish, fish-roe, very salted eggs,
very acid sliced fruits and other condiments
eaten cold to give additional flavour to the
curry and rice. Not to be confused with the
condiments (r6mpah-rempah) cooked with
the curry to spice it. Ularn mSnchari s.:
cthe food runs after the spicing,* a reversal
of the usual arrangement; —said of a woman
wooing a man.
In one passage (Ht. Bangs. 60) sambal
is used of cattle slaughtered for food; but
this is not the proper meaning of the word.
sambaleh. See s6mbeleh (slaughter).
sambalewa. Half- hearted; indifferent. Of patch-
work or things done by fits and starts.
Jangan s. atau lalai: don’t go in for
intermittent or indifferent service; Sid. Rama
23.

sambar. I. Pouncing to seize and carry off. Also
(Min.) sembar=;to fly away with; Tn. S.
suggests the use of teeth, nails or talons and
is used of hawks, crocodiles, sharks, dragons,
long-clawed evil spirits and even (Mas Ed.,
Pant. Mai. 170) of the Hindu divinity Kala
who is sometimes regarded as long-clawed;
also of a mother pouncing and dragging away
a naughty child and of lightning pouncing
down and killing a man (di -s. halilintar),
Ht. Panj. 133. Cf.: di-s. jdroug (taken by a


shark); sepgrti naga m6nyambar(as a dragon
darts at its prey), = swift and violent onset;
seporti lang hSndak menyambar (like a hawk
about to pounce), = imminent menace, Prov.
Sambaran: (i) pouncing, e.g. yu sambaran
(man-eating shark, ground-shark); (ii) victim of
a pounce, prey;(iii) destined victim of a pounce,
e.g. the devil’s future prey, cf. Sh. Peng. 9,
Sri Ben. 82. Peuyambar: snatcher; thief;
robber. S. - menyambar: dashing at each
other with tooth and claw —of beasts of
prey or fabulous monsters. Sambaran angin:
a tree, Psychotria sp.

used for temporary screens or shelters; or
for laying as a tarpaulin over cargo (s ayer.
s. muat). S. la’- habis knjang pula: «you
are wanting your tarpaulin before the dried

Prov.

sampir. I. Upper portion or crosspiece of kris-
sheath; = (Java) warangka. Made usually of
wood (in Malaya of ktimuning or kfitenggar,
occasionally of seroyan; in Java of pelet
or of blackwood); sometimes of ivory; in some
royal krisses the wood is encased in gold,
see terapang. The sampir is met with
(Mai.) in two distinct shapes: one flattened
the usual Malay shape, and the other
boat-shaped (illd. Rafll., Leyd. XT. iii 1 2).
This latter shape, common in Java, is met
with in the Patani«king-fisher» kris (keris
lajang, keris hulu pekakak) and sometimes
in rapier-krisses.

sanding. 1. Bersanding; (Mai.) to sit side by side

leception. In Kelantan beratur is used for

sandusin, = sundusin (brocade).
sang. I. A titular prefix attached:
(i) in the expression sang-yang to the
names of major divinities, i.e. Vishnu (sang-
yang Mahabisnu); Siva the Teacher (sang-
yang Guru),—but the latter is also described
as sang-raja Guru, Ind. Meng., Hg. Tuah
49;
(ii) to the names of heroes and demigods
such as A r j u n a (Sang Ranjuna), Kelem bai
(Sang - k6l6mbai); and the founder of the
Malay dynasty (Sang - Sfipfirba);
(iii) to the title of kings in certain
honorifics, e.g. sang-nata, sang-aji, sang -
ratu, sang - sinuhun, sang - ulun;
(iv) to animal-names in fable, e.g. sang-
kanchil (mousedeer), sang-nyamok (mosquito),
sang - agas (sandfly), etc.; fish are generally
dang though sang -yu is used of the shark
in one passage (Si Misk. 58);
(v) to descriptive names of animals such
as sang - sengat (Mr Stinger the Hornet)
and sang - pahlawan (Mr. Champion the
Tiger), Ht. Pdk. 1,4, 10, 15, 26, 28;
and (vi) personifications of the inanimate,
e.g. sang - api (Mr. Fire), Ch. Jen. 83.
In History the title sang occurs in the
honorific names of many minor dignitaries
mostly of the military class, e. g.: Sang
S6tia, Sang Lela, Sang Aria, Sang Jaya,
etc. Men of this rank were known collectively
as pfirsangan and ranked after men bearing
titles begining with s6ri or tun (Mai. An-
nals 65). These sang titles are now obsolete.
11. Mengesang: (onom.) to blow the nose.
See sih and 6sang. Of the sound so made;
the act is lechit, hingus.
111. «one«, —in some numeral systems
and some games.

altifrons; W. Also sar; W.
V. Pers. Stone.

Sanggit. See sanggit 11.
sanggit. I. Bersanggit: to scrape or rub against
one another [of two hard bodies such as a
ship’s side and a wharf, or (Ht. Angg.) as
adjoining branches scrape when a wind blows
through a tree]. Menyanggit gigi: to grind
the teeth. Dempit tidak bersanggit: «in
contact yet unconnected*, e.g. as lover and
mistress. Ka - darat meranti bersanggit
dahan: landward the meranti rustled its
boughs*, a description of the scenery of
old Minangkabau: Mai. Say. 16.
S. dayong: an insect the note of which
is believed to announce the approaching
return of the house - owner.
IT. Ken Sanggit: name or description of
one of the two faithful followers of Chandra
Kirana; with her companion, Ken Bayan,
a type of loyal service.
sanggohatli. The legendary crown of Minangkabau;
see s.v. mahkota.
sanggonani, sanggonaning. See singgananai
(legendary cock).
sanggu. See sangu (a sea-weed).
sanggugu. Menyanggugu: (Sum.) to howl; to
speak with a whine; Tn.
sanggugui. Tersanggugui: (Sum.) bewildered;
confused; speechless; Tn.
Sanggu 1. Dressed hair; coiffure, when the hair is
bound up at the back of the head and not
allowed to hang down in a knot or queue.
In Sumatra s. = hair in a loose twist, illd.
Veth xi 4; siput = coils or «buns* at the
back of the head, illd. Veth xi 2; konde
hanging knot or plait, illd. Veth xi 3. In
Malaya s. is gen. for all coils on the head;
it includes s. siput; kundai is a hanging
knot. In Java s. and konde refer to the
same style of dressing; cf. (Java) tusuk
konde = (Mai.) chuchok s., or chok s. =
tutup s. (Ht. Bugis 52) = hair pins.
Varieties: s. ayam mengeram (the «sitting
fowl*, i.e. hair in a circle or «-nest» round
the top of the head with a mass of hair
rising «fowl-like» out of it); s. bulat (braided
tresses in a circle at the back of the head);
s. belong (trefoil - knot at back of head);
s. lintang (coiffure standing out on both
sides —a Min. style); s. niereng (at an angle);
s. nyonya (Chinese quinqnefoil coiffure); s.
rod a lambong («paddle-wheels»; two braided
circles, one on each side of the head); s.
serani (an elaborate «Portuguese* style).
Bersanggul lichin: with hair dressed and
oiled. Bunga s.; artificial flowers mounted on
wires to adorn a bride’s hair (illd. Veth
vii 1, xxii B),=bunga ketar or gerak geinpa.
B. Fatimah: «'Fatimah’s coiffure*; name of
a talismanic design; Raj. Muda 117, = two
squares, one inscribed diagonally in the other.
8. terlepas: dishevelled hair; dressing that
has become undone.
sanggup. Answering for; assuming responsibility


for; cf. chakap. Pa’-s.: «Daddy Plead-guilty;»
nickname for a man who marries a woman
known to be with child. Tiada s. ia mbm-
bayar wang; he cannot be got to pay the
money. S. ia berlawan dbngan perompak;
he is equal to fighting the pirates; Hg. Tuah.
27. Ta’s. menahan lagi: he could not hold
out any longer; Bur. Glat. 27.
Also (Java) sanggem; B.
sanggur. [Pers. san’gur] Basket for drinks.

santan. Soft milky pulp of the coconut, much
used in cooking and a type of richness.
Ayers.: coconut - milk. Kfipala s. or pati s.:
the «cream» of the coconut; the very best
of its pulp; (fig.) virginity, first embraces.
LSmak s., xnanis gala, tidak sedar rachun

other people «eaG> (makan). Santapan or
pSrsantapan: royal repast. S. mempelai:
bridal viands; the ceremonial repast of bride
and bridegroom, each feeding the other in
token of their common lot and mutual
affection. Cf. also;
Santap ia santap beradat,
Dua snap, ketiga sudah:
he took his repast as a royal prince should;
two mouthfuls he took, the third was his
last; Mai. Dein. 27.
santau. 1. Slow and sure poison. Not a specific
drug, but a compound of several slow
poisons, the idea being that if one fails
another will succeed, while the complexity
of the symptoms will puzzle and mislead
the doctors.

sarok. I. Putting down one’s foot into anything.
Of the way a man steps into a sarong;
also of putting the foot into a noose - snare
or pitfall. Oajah fimpat kaki lagi tersarok:
«even an elephant may put all four feet
into it»; everybody gets caught at times;
Prov. Cf. sadong, sfiradong, serandong.

sarok: fluked.

saron. JaV. A sort of harmonica or xylophone
with metal keys; illd. J.S.A.S. Ixv pi. v, fig.
4,6, 6; pi. vi, 4,5; May. i 89; Rallies XXV
6. Its keys (six or seven in number) vary in

sarong. I. Sheath; covering. S. jari: thimble. S.
kaki: sock. S. kferis: kr i s-sheath. S. perisai:
metal covering on framework of shield, e.g.
s. pbrisai mas (shield sheathed in gold as a

stock of gun. S. tangan: glove. Seluar s.
nangka: tights.
Menyarongkan senjata: to sheathe a
weapon; cf. also: hujong keris - nya akan
tfirsarong didalam dada Paduka Liku
(the point of his dagger would have been
sheathed in the breast of the second Queen),
Ht. Panj. 127. Tiada dapat dua keris di-
dalam suatu s.: «you won’t get two krisses
into one sheath*, i.e. a woman cannot have
two husbands; Prov.
11. Kain sarong; «sarong»; the typical
Malay long kilt or skirt. Usually explained
as sarong (sheath, wrapper), but the
garment is in use in Ceylon where it is
known as saran; Yule derives the word
from Singhalese. Malays rarely use the word;
a sarong is kain in Malaya and samping
or jarit in Java. In literature the word does
not occur except Pant. Mai. 202 (kain s.)
and of a sarong kesaktian in a modern
edition of the Ht. Indra Bangsawan (p. 33).
Cf. also sarok
sarpa. (Sum.) To welcome; cf. sapa.

sartan. Ar. Cancer (in the Zodiac); Bost. Sal. i
49. Bintang s.: id. For purposes of divination
Cancer is associated with well-water, the
scorpion, the crab, the almond (ketapang)
and the planet Jupiter. It is the «star» of
Enoch (Idris) and Khidzir.
Often confused ■with shartan (horns of
Aries).

Satariah. [Ar. shattariyat] Name of a school of


mysticism, founded by as-Shattari, now
obsolete except in Malaya. It was introduced
into Acheen by Abdnrauf of Singkel
(Seventeenth Century) and until recently
was the one great school of mysticism in
Malaya.
[According to the Bostan (ii 123) mysticism
was first taught in Acheen by a Gujarat
Arab, Shaikh Muhammad Jilani bin Hasan
bin Muhammat Hamid, of the tribe of the
Koreish. This man came to Acheen in the
reign of Alaedin Mansur Shah but only
began to teach mysticism under Sultan
Alaedin Riayat Shah (1589-1604 A. D.).
His school of doctrine is not given. From
the Malay Annals it would appear that
mysticism had been taught in Malacca at a
much earlier date].

satoh. A single - edged cutting - sword of the

hut with a rounded point and an edge that
is (only very slightly) concave. It is met
with in the Pulau Tujoh and is said to have
been introduced from Kedah.

s.-s. (Ht. Abd. 11) or better s. - bersatu
(one by one), Gem. Ht. 12, Pel. Akal iii.

saudara, Skr. Brother or sister; near relative of
about one’s own age. S. sa-jalan sa-jadi

sa - ibu; half - brother on mother’s side. S.

first cousin; Bost. Sal. ii 81, Ht. Bangs. 48.
S. rapat: near relative. S. mara, s. daging,
or s. rfsnggang: distant relative. Anak s.:
nephew; niece. Adek s.; younger first cousin.
Sanak s.: kindred. Menganibil akan s.: to
* accept as a brother (and not as a lover); to
break off a liaison amicably; = m6ngaku
adek - beradek.
Saudara is a name given also to the
afterbirth as it is believed to be endowed
with spiritual life and to affect a child's
fortunes very materially.
[Cf. Ada - pun s. sa-jalan sa-jadi s.


s6mak dengan tuboh, tetapi sahabat itu s.
seniak dengan nyawa: Sh. Kub.]
Sauh. I. Anchor: grapnel. Varieties: s. buji
(light four - fluked boat, - anchor); s. chemat
or s. kechil (kedge); s. jangkar (mooring
anchor or heavy anchor): s. tfirbang (flying
grapnel for scaling a wall or boarding a ship),
Ht. Hamz., Mai. Annals 126; s. tunggal
(single anchor, whether for starting at a
moment’s notice or as cne’s last hope); s.
wangkang (Chinese type of anchor). Parts:
batang s. (shaft or beam); batu s. (stone to
give the anchor weight); kuku s. (fluke);
langkang s. or rangkang s. (cross-piece).
S. larat: anchor dragging. Champak s.:
to cast antin'r. Putaran s.; cafstan. Tuding-
kan 8,: to heave short. Ukuran s.: method
of calculating angle of fluke of native anchor.
Bfirsauhkan parch: «using its beak as an
anchor*; Mai. Dewa 62, —of a bird of romance.

saujana. Extensive; = sa-yojana, a Sanskrit measure
based on the length of the furrow that an
ox can plough in a day. Used only in a
couple of expressions: padang s. (open coun-
try, wide plain) and s. inata memandang
(a far as the eye can distinguish objects).
Also sajauhana and (Ked.) so’jana.
Sauk, I. Scoop; concavity such as a saucepan -

sawa. I. Python; snake that crushes and
swallows. There are three true pythons in
the Malay area: (i( Python molurus,
the largest, common in Java but not re-
corded from the Penisula, = (Mai.) ular
sawa rgndam, large and aquatic; (ii) P.
reticulata s, the common python of Ma-
laya = ular s. chindai; and (iii) the short
and broad - bodied P. curtus, = ular s.
batu, s. katak. Other snakes known as sawa
are: s. burong (D i ps ad om orp h u s den-
drophilus); s. Ibkir (Coluber mela-
n u r u s), also s. tfikukur; and the unidentified
s. buna, s. pokok, and s. tikus.
S. mfingampai: «the swaying python*; a
name for certain gadroon patterns. Rangkek
b§lang s.: a shell, Conus capitaneus.
Tahi ular s.: python-dung, rich in ammonia
and used medicinally by Malays and Chinese.
Pachat hendak meujadi s.: «the leech wants
to be a python*; prov. for absurd pretensions.
Tidnr bfirlingkar bagai s.: <rto sleep coiled
up like a python*, said of a humpbacked
shipwright of romance; Ht. Angg. 32.
11. Buah sawa: (Pen.) sapodilla; Hn., =
buah sau, buah sauh, chiku, sau Manila.

sawab. Ar. What is right; the truth. Esp. in
the expression Allahu alam ba - sawab (God
knoweth what is true).
sawah. Land cultivated with swamp-rice, whether
the rice be planted in natural swamp (s.
ayer) or on irrigated soil (s. benchah). Rice
is planted usually in small lots separated
from one another hy low dykes (batas); a
stretch of these lots is s. sa - bendang Other
terms are s. bgrbandar langit, a (Min.)
equivalent of s. ayer; and s. padi (ricefield
with growing crop). S. ayer is also (fig.)
surf.
The word sawah is used in South Malaya
and Minangkabau, hut bendang has taken
its place in Kedah and Perak and baroh
in Kelantan and Patam; e.g. (Joh., Min.)
bersawah = (Ked., Pk.) buat bendang (to
plant rice); (Joh., Min.) mSrabajak s. =
(Ked., Pk.) menenggala bendang (to plough
rice - fields). Si - p6sawah: a rice - grower;
Pert. Tebu 32.
See also huma and ladang.
sawai. I. BSrsawai: to hold a shamanistic
seance (of aborigines), = (Mai.) b6rhantu.
Used esp. of the singing by the shaman as
he crouches in his little beehive-hut.
