sawan. Convulsive fits; strokes; e.g.: s. babi
(epilepsy); s. bangkai or s. tfirjun (apoplexy);
s. inau (convulsions with heavy breathing
in children), Hn.; s. inja, s. lenja (fits with
foaming at the mouth); batoks. (uncontrollable
fits of coughing, whooping cough); bsdak s.
(cooling powder for children’s complaints);
ibu s. (an eruption of boils on the head in
children). Terjun s.: to fall in a fit; Bur.
Nuri 7. Terkena s.: to have an attack of
convulsions; Ik. Trub. 9. S. gila luar janji;
*epilepsy and madness lie outside the
contract*, i.e. the marriage - contract is
invalidated if either party has epilepsy or
madness.

sawar. I, Barrier; obstruction. The term covers
much; e.g.: (i) a fish-weir with an opening
letting fish into a trap; (ii) fences (s. p6lan-
dok) to lead mousedeer into a trap; (iii) a
gh'dle of thorns (s. duri) fastened round a
tree - trunk to prevent thieves climbing it
and stealing the fruit; (iv) a rattan rope
(tali s.l with men at each end used to drive
cattle into a pen; and (v) a string with pendent
coconut - fronds to indicate that a path is
closed to traffic because of quarantine,
see also kawar and gawar. Cf. the pantun
(Mai. Pant. 302) on <<the fruit protected by
a girdle of thorns (buah b<srsawar dengan
duri) and the reply (Mai. Pant. 803) about
•lopping the girdle of thorns away* (mem-
buang s. duri).

sEdang. I. Intermediate; in the mean time. S. has
several meanings:
(i) the happy mean, e.g.: a flower at its
best (bunga s.); the bloom of youth (s.
reniaja); perfect ripeness (s. inasak); a girl
ripe for marriage (anak dara s.);
(ii) medium, average: e.g.: orang s. (man
of moderate rank); jauh-nya s. (at a fair
distance);
(iii) «in the midst of», i.e. «while»,
«during»; cf.: s. meminum ayer (while
drinking); s. ada di-sana (while there);
(iv) «in despite of», s. ia
perEmpuan (though a woman); sEdangkan
binatang lagi sa-kian ia berkasch-kasehan
laki-bini (though mere animals the pair so
loved each other), Ht. Abd. G 2.

sßgunja, Epiphytic climber, Anadendrum
raontanum; W.
SBguntang. Bukit SBguntang; (locally) Bukit Si-
guntang - guntang: the traditional hill at
the foot of Mahameru on which Sang S -
perba and his brothers appeared before
founding the Shailendra or
dynasty of Sri Vijaya (Palembang). The
dynasty was founded in the eighth Century
A.D. The hill of Seguntang is really a
hummock on the banks of the' Jambi River,
the site of a later palace of the Shailen-
dra Kings; cf. Hg. Tuah. Geographically
it has nothing to do with Mahameru; but
later tradition which knew of the legendary
coming of the kings from the Mahameru
foothills (shailendra) and knew them also
as Seguntang kings identified the latter
site with the foothills of the former.
In the Peninsula Seguntang is known
usually as Segantang.
sßgurai, sßguri. Variants of s6l6guri, q.v.
sßguro. [Port, seguro] To frank (a letter).
seh. I. Ch. Chinese seh, i.e. clan. Seh-
names (Lim, Tan, Khoo, Cheah, etc.)‘cor-
respond in many ways to English surnames
but the number of persons in a seh tar
exceeds the number bearing any of our
surnames however common.

believes in it.

Demam s.; cold stage in fever. Jawa s.: a
name for the «raksasa» kris-handle on Java-
nese krisses;=Jawa gigil and Jawa dingin.
It gets its name from the arms crossed (to
carry the feet of Vishnu) that suggest a man
hugging himself for warmth.

sekah, I. [Ar. sikkah] Mint-impression. Rupiah
8.: «sicca - rupee*; Ht. Abd. 75. Suratkan
nama raja pada s. derham - nya: to record
a prince’s name on the die of his coins; Isk.
Dz. [The «sicca» rupee is the standardized
rupee of the Mogul Emperor Shah Alam; it
was coined by the East India Company from
1793 to 1835 and contained 176 grains of
pure silver. In 1835 a new rupee was
introduced with only 165 grains of pure
silver; the name «sicca rupee* was then given
to the older and more valuable coin.]

SSlangur. Selangor; name of a river and Sultanate
on the West Coast of the Peninsula. The
Sultanate was founded by Raja Lumu, a
Bugis daong of the family of the Yamtuan
Muda of Riau. His descendants still hold
it.
The meaning of the name is not known.
The term sSlangur is applied descriptively
to an ant (s6mut s.) and a threadfin (ikan
kurau s.).

Chuchok s., chuchok mata s.: a form of

sgluar. [Pers. shalwar; Ar. sarwal; Hind,
sarwal and shilwar; Java sSrual; Sum.
sarwal, sarewal, sarawal, shilawar)
Trousers; (Mai.) gen. for all kinds of trousers;
but the Jav. srual is limited to one type
(baggy, and extending to just below the knee),
other types being known as chSlana and
katok.
Varieties are:
(i) short, worn as working shorts (s.
sanipak) or as drawers under a sarong (s.
pandak); = (Java) katok;
(ii) medium (to below the knee)=seluar,
(Java) sSrual, also s. lamhok, s. Acheh
(illd. Veth iii 2);
(iii) long and narrowing at the ankles; s.
panjang - panjut; (Java) chftlana, cholana
panji - panji;
(iv) long and bell-bottomed: s. bambu;
(v) long and of European style: s. Johor;
(vi) long and of the old Chinese loose
type: s. China;
(vii) long and of the tighter modern
Chinese type: s. gadok;
(viii) pants or drawers: s. dalam; s.
tapeh;
(ix) tights: s. sarong nangka;
(x) European pyjamas; s. bulat; and
(xi) trousers lined with silk: s. langgai.
[The word sbluar has a long history:
Hind, sh i 1 w a r=Pers. sha 1 w a r=Pehlevi
shar v a r = Zend sharavara, a garment
mentioned in the Septuagiut (saravara,
Daniel iii 27). The Bostan (i 97) ascribes
its invention to Abraham. The Indian
shilwar (worn by either sex) is a baggy
garment with trouser-legs extending to just
below the knee. That this was the garment
introduced into Indonesia by the Moslems is
clear from pictures of Malays in the books
of old navigators. At a later date the Acheh-
nese hegemony made a certain variety of
these trousers, the «Achehnese style* (s.
Acheh), fashionable in Malaya especially in
Perak; and the way these Achehnese trousers
are cut and sewn together is illustrated and
described b} r Jasper. But trousers were also
used to show the wearer’s rank. In general
any gold showed royal rank, whether it
took the form of gold piping or gold braid
down the side (s. pedendang), or gold -
embroidered patterns on the cloth itself (s.
berchanggal mas), or designs in gold - leaf
imprinted on the trousers (s. telepok). The
design also marked rank. The puchok rebong
pattern was the most distinguished while
the tapak itek pattern was allowed on the
bridal garments of a Said, Mir or Megat, a
bridegroom being king for the day only (raja
sa - hari). Colour was also made a mark of
rank. Suits of one colour throughout are
worn by men of the very highest rank in
Perak: all yellow for a Raja Muda, all


black for a Bendahara, and all red for a
temenggong. An army - commander ranked
after these in the matter of colour; he was
allowed to wear one trouser-leg of one colour
and the other of a second colour, a piebald
style (s. pasalewa), illd. Veth xviii 3.
Next after the army leaders came the great
feudal Chiefs with trousers banded in four
stripes (s. empat sa-karap). These Chiefs
eight in number (hulubalang yang de-
lapan) —governed districts. After them came
the feudal Chiefs of townships, the «Sixteen»,
who wore trousers banded in eight stripes
(s. lam - sayong). These are Perak customs.
Elsewhere the rules differed in detail, but
the general principles were much the same].

sSlupat. I. Membrane; thin natural wrapper over

sSIuSOII. Drug or charm used at a confinement.
Not a particular drug, but gen. for anything
—whether a simple, a process or a charm—
used by a midwife to expedite delivery (s.
beranak), or to assist the removal of the
afterbirth (s. uri), or to avoid septicaemia
(tawar s.), or to deal with a dangerous
situation such as transverse presentation (s.
anak nrelintang dalant perut). Many of
the prescriptions contain large numbers of
drugs and are <'helped/> by magic.
The word is used also as a name for
plants supplying these remedies, e. g.: s.
Fatirnah (Labisia pothoina), and s.
Sfimang (M elodo r u rn lanuginosa m;
Leptonychia glabra); Bkl.
sSlusup. Jav. Splinter; B.
sSlusur, = sfilosor (hand - rail).
sSlut. (Ked.) Slush; mud; slime; = (Job.)
lumpur. Ikan s.: mudfish. Jijak s. kaki
t6rb6nam: «tread on mud and your foot sinks
into it->; trickiness lets you down; Prov.
sSlatan. A (Sum.) variant of sultan. See also
sutan.
ssma. Soma-sema: cold in head, = s6l6s6ma.
sema. (Pk.) We; = sahaya ma or sahaya s -
inua. Cf kita.
sUrnagi. Kain somagi: pall laid over a dead body
in the house but not used in the procession
to the grave.
semah. Propitiatory offering to evil spirits. Food
offerings (penyemah) are made to the tutelary
spirits of durian-trees (menyeniah durian)
to secure good crops of the fruit; fishermen
inaugurate new fishing - stakes by certain
ritual services and by suspension of food -
offerings on the king-posts of their traps
(menyeniah belat); and offerings on a large
scale are made every three, five or seven
years by the people of a Malay State to the
jin kerajaan or spirits of the kingdom. This
last is known as menyeniah nbgeri. For
the object in view cf. jin yang kurang s.
(hungry or unpropitiated ghost; angry spirit),
Kumb. Chumb. But in the major instances
there may be some idea that the albino
buffaloes offered up are scapegoats for the
sins of the people, cf. tuboh - nya buat s.
negeri (offer his body as a sacrifice for the
sake of his country), Sfi. Kub.
[Skeat refers (Mai. Magic 198) to the
mfinyeiuah durian, and gives a description
(ib., pp. 310-314) of the menyeniah belat,
Shaw (Rice - planting, p. 9) says that the
word semah is only used loosely for such
minor offerings; and that, strictly speaking,
it should he confined to ceremonies at which
the National Wizard or his deputy is present.
In other words the term should be confined
to the great triennial, quinquennial or septen-
nial sacrifice offered up by the whole State
and presided over (in Perak at least) by the
Sorcerer - Ruler (Sultan Muda) of the
Kingdom. This is probably correct.]

Semang. Negrito. A name given bj'’ Malays to
certain aboriginal negritoes of Kedah and
Peiak, those in Pahang and Kelantan being
known as Pangan. Probably from an aboriginal
word sema’(men). Both Semang and Pangan
are mentioned in the Hikayat Koris; and
the Kedah Annals (Mar. Mah.) speak of the
bangsa S. dan Wila yaani Bila dan rayat
bukit.
[The <-.Semang» include (i) the Sakai
Jeram of the Perak valley who speak a
North Sakai dialect but are racially negritoes;
(ii) the Sakai Tanjong of the upper waters
of the Perak and its tributaries who are an
outpost of the Pangan; (iii) the Semang of
Selama and Ijok who are described as S.
Paya or S. Bukit according to their habitat;
and (iv) the extinct Bila or Wila of Province
Wellesley and Kedah Peak.]
sgmang. I. Anak semang; (N.S.) child by tribal
adoption. The Minangkabau political system,
based on uterine relationship, had to employ
adoption to absorb strangers who settled a-
mong them, the person adopted (anak s.)
being received into the tribe and family of
his or her adopted mother (indok s.), Pant,


Mai. 1129. Slaves and other dependents were
often dealt with in this way; cf. Sid. Rama
199 where the hero asks a servant-girl who
her indok s., i.e. her mistress, is.
[The Rembau waris Tebat who are said
to be descended from a Portuguese girl from
Malacca must owe their position as waris to
some such «adoption». Malays in N.S. when
electing to a title prefer claims by blood to
adoptive membership of a family; and the
claim of the waris Tebat is regarded by
many as questionable.]
11. A climber, Quisqualis d ensi f 1 ora;
W.
sgmangat. Spirit of life; vitality; «soul» (in the
old Indonesian sense); = (Min.) sumangat.
For more modern ideas see nafas (vitality)
and nyawa (soul). The Indonesian «soub> is
a bird of life, timorous and easily scared; its
flight (tbrbang s.) is synonymous with weak
vitality (hilang s., kurang s., lemah s.).
It leaves the body in sleep (cf. Mai.
Pant. 328, 329, 330, 333), and when absent
from the body may be seduced or captured
by other persons; magic is used sometimes
to attract and so via a girl’s sSmangat
(lambai s., ambil s.) or to «attach» it to
oneself (gantong s., kundang s.).
Malays believe that this spirit of life is
found in all nature, even in things that we
consider inanimate. Thus the «soul of iron*
(s. besi) is responsible for the special merits
of iron; and due homage has to be paid
to it (menyfimbah s. besi) if a kris is to
retain its virtue. This animistic belief
underlies the special reverence paid to certain
weapons (see keris and chura); and comes
out clearly in the harvest rites associated
with the «rice-soul» (s. padi). If the seed-
rice is to give a good crop the following
year it must retain its spirit of life; and
every care is taken to honour it and to see
that reaping is done so as not to lessen its
vitality (see tual). Ibu s. padi: «mother -
sheaf*, at a harvest festival.
The bird-like character of the sbmangat
leads to its being addressed as a bird (Joh.
kur s., Ked. kern s., Min. kuru s.); and
this form of address has become a term of
endearment. In Malay as in English the
word for «soul» has many tender associations;
cf. Mai. Pant. 420,
Adok jauh, rasa tbrchfirai,
S6niangat tinggttl dalam sanggul-nya:
Though absence wrings this heart of mine,
And far apart are we, —
Her braided tresses still entwine
The very soul of me.
[For the hird-like character of the sSmangat
see Mai. Magic 587, Journal F.M.S. Museums,
1922*, p. 283, and the note to my first
edition s.v. semangat. It is supposed to
res de in the stomach and to enter the body
by the mouth. But the beliefs of the aborigines
—even of the Proto-Malayan aborigines—may
mean a man-like soul; the offerings left on
graves suggest a human existence; the <'Soul -
ladders* (tangga s.) on a Jakun grave are
alien to the «bird» idea; and other ideas
i ust be linked to the belief that the soul of
a wizard becomes a were - tiger and that a
vizard’s head is projected in sleep in the
f rm of a penanggalan (see manjang).]
Sgmanggh Watercress, Hydrocotyle latiseta
(< r H. rotundifolia); also s. China and
(Ked.) semangi. Its leaves are edible and
are also used medicinally and for cleaning
kris- blades. S. gunong: the plant Desmo-
dium macrophyllum, Both s. gunong
and s. China give their names to well-known
patterns in gold-embroidered cloth: the former
(s. gunong) is illd. Jasp. ii fig. 289.

sßmantong. Thunderous weather (without rain).

sBmar. A merry - andrew of the shadow - play

element is introduced into ancient legend as
into modern Malay opera (bangsawan) to
avoid monotony and not as an integral part
of the plot.

residing. Bersbmayam: to sit in state or

yang kemasan: the king came forth and

[Used loosely of any prince and even of

of residence, e.g.. bersomayam di-Bukit
Chandan).

sßmbab, = sembap (bloated).
sßmbada. (Kawi) Right; just; = patut.
SBmbadra. Dewi Sembadra; a nymph of Heaven
(Suprabha?), cf. laksana Dewi S. meng-
hilangan akal segala yang meraandang
(like SBmbadra whose beauty gave love -


madness to all who beheld her); Tk. i 754.
SSmbah. See Samba.
sfimbah. Obeisance; gesture of worship or homage;
speech accompanied by such a gesture;
(Min.) sambah. In the sembah the hands
are closed as though in prayer with the
finger-tips touching; they are then raised,
not above the chin if the Chief is of less
than royal blood but as high as the forehead
if he is a reigning Sultan. The sembah
proper is the way the hands are held, cf. s.
di-angkat jari sa - puloh (raising all ten
fingers in obeisance); cf. also the Sri Rama
description (J.S.A.S. xvii 88): .hands closed
as the rootlets ot the bakong; fingers one on
the other like a pile of sireh - leaves*. The
body movements may vary; cl'.: menyembah
panjang (to do obeisance standing, i. e.
bowing and lifting the hands to the face);
tundok menyembah (to do obeisance squat-
ting or cowering); and sujud mfinyembah
(to do obeisance on one’s knees or bowing
to the ground as in prayer).
The meaning of the .obeisance* also
varies. Menyembah is used of divine wor-
ship, cf: sembahyang (divine service);
menyembah berhala (to worship idols);
menyembah lembu (to worship cows), Host.
Sal. i 81; menyembah patong (to worship
images), Boat. Sal. i 80; menyembah Sung-
ai Gangga (to worship the Ganges), Boat.
Sal. 81. But the divine worship of the
Hindu period was puja, a word abandoned
because of its heathen associations and
surviving only in sorcery and old literature:
cf. Sang Bima pun memuja Bayupaksa,
sudah itu maka ia m£ny6mbah matahari
(Bhima made his prayers to the God of the
Winds, after which he did obeisance to the
Sun), Tk. iii 90. Sembah is used also of
vassalage to a King or State, e.g. menygm-
bah ka-benua Siam (owing allegiance to
Siam), or of a State like Siak admitting the
overlordship of Malacca (menyfimbah ka -
Melaka), Mai. Annals 3of. So also the
word is used of allegiance to a feudal
Chief and even of respect to the aged or of
submission to the head of a family, but care
is taken when paying such homage not to
raise the hands to royal levels.
Lastly, as it is customary for a sembah
to accompany any words addressed to a
Sultan, the word is used of such speech
itself; cf.; pSrsSmbah jasa (to present one’s
humhle duty), Ht. Koris; p6rs6mbahkan
upbti (to pay tribute), Raj. Muda 186; s.
daripada buah - buahan (a respectful gift of
fruit), Sg. Samb.; demi di-dSngar oloh
baginda akan s. ahli al-mijum (when the
king heard what the astrologers had
to say). The technical term for the approval
of a subject’s application to his Sultan is
Utah lain s6mbah bfirlaku (it is the royal
command that the request be given effect
to). Cf. also lulus juga s. patek (what I
sought has been approved), Hg. Tuah 86.
For the importance attaching to these points
of etiquette see Mai. Magic 87 40, and
(in traditional history) the amok that fol-
lowed the substitution of sembah for salam
in a letter from the Sultan of Malacca to
Pasai; and the tricky explaining away of
the use of sfimbah in a Sultan’s letter to
the Emperor of China (Mai. Annals 107,
108).
sSmbahyang, «Obeisance (s6mbah) to the Gods
(yang)*; divine worship; ritual;=Ar. salat,
pi. salawat, but these Arabic terms haVe
not superseded the Malay and have indeed
acquired specialized meanings of their own.
A single prayer is doa. Sembahyangkan:
to conduct a service (e.g. the funeral service)
over a person. Ayei’s.: water for ritual
ablution before prayer. S. lama waktu: the
five (obligatory) daily prayers,=s. wajib,=
s. peilu. S.tujoh waktu; the seven daily
prayers, i.e. all the prayers obligatory or «re-
commended*, = s.sunat. The five obligatory
are: s. suboh (at dawn); s. lohor (midday);s.
asar (afternoon); s. maghrib (evening); s. isha
(nightfall) The two additional •recommen-
ded* prayers (s. sunat, Ht. Bugis 148) are
s. loha (forenoon) and s. tahajud (night).
The Friday service is s. jumaat; and the
special prayers in the Fasting Month are s.
tbrawoh. The religious exercises (ratib) of
mystics are not sembahyang.
[A sembahyang covers the following acts.
The worshipper first stands erect with his
lace in the direction of Mecca (kiblat) and
repeats a niat. He then raises his arms and
repeats the takbir. He then recites the
fatihah and goes through the series of
prayers and ritual movements known as
rakaat, q.v. This is a complete s. of .one
rakaat*, but the rakaat may be repeated


again and again if desired; and the
congregational service is the above
supplemented by the call to prayer when
the worshippers have met, by a khutbah or
address, and by a shahadat and a salam
when the worshippers disperse.]

sCmbilan. Nine;=one (sa) taken (ambilan) from
the ten fingers. Cf. (Ach.) sa-k u rang (one
less than the ten.) Nbgbri s.: the «Nine

confederacy. Ayer s.: water used for the

sSrtlbilang. Ikan sfimbilang: catfish of the genus
P 1 otos u s, notorious among Malays for the
poisoned wounds inflicted by the serrated
spines of its dorsal and pectoral fins.
Malays recognize four kinds: (i) s. b6tul
(probably the young Plotosus canius
= Paraplotosus albilabris); (ii) s.
raya (the same when very large); (iii) s.
karang (Plotosus lineatus sive
a nguillaris); and (iv) s. usat or unsat
(the same when the linear markings are very
distinct, i.e. in youth).
[Cf. the lines;
K6na s6ngat sSmbilang karang,
Siang malam dudok infingfirang,
Puas di-d6mah, habis di-ganggang,
Tujoh hari bisa ta’-hilang.]

sSmbur. I. Bespattering from the mouth; = (Min.)
sambur. Not spitting (ludah), but taking
water into the mouth and then ejecting it
as is done (with magical simples) by witch-
doctors on a diseased limb to cure it, or (fig.)
at the spirit of disease to drive it away; cf.
seperti polong kona s. (like a bespattered
lamiliar spirit, i.e. like a devil doused with
holy water), Prov. S. is used also of snakes
ejecting their venom; e.g.; di-semburkan
upas yang bisa itu deugan sa - kali s. (it
spat out its venom in a single spurt), Ind.
Jaya. More loosely a. is used of brains
bespattering the ground (bersbmbnran otak-
nya), Ht. Pdk. 42; and of fountains with
water spurting out of dragon - mouths (Mai.
Hem. 107).

sgmgaanjong. Peninsula; Al. Mai. 9. Cf. tanjong.
sgmgnda. BersemSnda: (of a man) to marry into
a woman’s family according to Minangkabau
custom; = (Min.) basumanda. Orang s.: the
man so marrying. Tempat s.: the family
into which he marries. Hutting di-bayar,
piutang di-terima oleh tempat s.: «the
wife’s family pays what a husband owes
and receives all that is due to him*.
[Among primitive people who work on
communal lines a marriage affects the whole
family as well as the persons marrying. The
labour of every man or woman counts. A
man has to work either for his wife’s tribe
or for his own; and the adat, for good
reasons, makes it the wife’s. But the marriage
—as between the parties to it —is one of
perfect equality; and the old mistranslation
<<a man shall be subject to his mother-
in-law* (orang s. ka-tempat s.) gives a false
idea of the system. Every family (perut) is
controlled by a male elder (N.S. buapak,
Min. tungganai), and «petticoat influence*
is no greater than is to be expected from a
system that (unlike every other Asiatic
system) puts women in a position of absolute
equality with men.]
sSmgndal. Mica.

sSmu. Deceiving by means of lying tales; to
humbug. Not as strong as tipu (to cheat).
Bermain s.: to take in. S. lengkong: decep-
tively round*, i.e. more or less round. Ter-
semu di - tengah tfirang: cdone» in broad
daylight; Ht. Koris. Cherdek orang Mela-
ka ini, tiada tersemu oleh kita: these
Malacca men have their wits about them,
they have seen through us; Mai. Annals 102.
The word plays a part in proverbs about
national traits: s. Jawa, pujok M6layu
(humbug comes from Java and blarney from
the Malays ; and tipu Biak, s. Melayu (Siak
men cheat you, Malays take you in).
sSmua. Skr. All; the whole; every one of. Kes6-
mua-nya: all of them; the whole lot.
sSmuang. I. A platform or house (on river- bank)
to which water is draw n from the river and
thence conveyed in bamboo conduits to its

sSmuchup, Love - grass; burr; Andropogon
aciculatus. Also sfonunchup, (Sel.) ch -
inuchup, (Ked.) terauchut, (Pk.) kemunchup,
(Sp.) chernnchnp.
Sgmudgra. [Skr. samudra] Name of a Malay
State, probably the first converted to Islam.
Being thus the first Sumatran State to be-
come well - known to the Arabs its name
was given by them to the whole Island. But
its seat of government was soon afterwards
transferred to Pasai by which name the State
is better known to the Malays: Ht. Pasai
9-15.

sSmut. Ant; gen. for Formicidae; = (Min.)
gamut; but limited sometimes to the smaller

an: formication; the «pins and needles*
feeling. S. b6riring: ants on the march.
Liangs.: ant-hole. Mat! s. dalam gula:
«ants die in sugar*; enmity is killed by
kindness; Prov. Datang ribut, keluar s.;
centering, a whirlwind; dejiarting an ant»;
= coming in like a lion and going out like

GStek s. or kbtip s.; «ant - nip*; this
gives its name to a pinching game (main
gbtek s., main k6tip - k6tip s.) played by
very young children; described in detail,
Mai. Amusements 77.
Malays recognize many species of ants
apart from the so-called «white ant» (anal-
anai; rayap; but sometimes s. puteh, from the
English). The «red ant» i.e. the tree-ant or
tailor-ant (k6r6ugga), and the big black
«bulldog» ant (kiak - kiak, kengkiak, k -
ISngkiak) are not classed as semut. Among
the s6mut are:
(i) Nobopelta distinguenda, a
long black ant that stings very badly, = s.
api, possibly the akas of Java;
(ii) Sima rufonigra, a venomous ant
found in boats and sandy places, = s. sabong,
s. sabur;
(iii) the minute sugar-ant (Solenopsis
sp.) that is a nuisance in store - rooms, = s.
gula, s. manisan, (Pat.) s. liar;
(iv) Monomorium pharaonis, a
small house - ant, yellow with a shining
posterior, = s. gatal or (Pat.) s. tiong;
(v) an ant, sp. unid., eaten as an acid
delicacy by the aborigines, = s. asam;
(vi) a small poisonous black ant found on
trees and giving a very painful bite, =s.
ipoh, (Java) s. upas;
(vii) the «peppery» ant, found on trees and
giving a bite the sting of which is sharp
but soon passes, = s. lada;
(viii) a large black ant, sp. unid., said
to be seen only at night, = s. kfttong;
(ix) a large solitary black ant often met
on jungle paths; it is about an inch long;=s.
tbmbnggong;
(x) a long-legged ant (given as Formica
sanguinea by Mayer), =s. geramarig;
and
(xi) the unidentified: (Pk.) s. bewak jatoh;
s. daging; s. genting; s. gila; s. hitam; s.
lata; s. minyak; s. muntah sawa; s. pa-
dang; s. s6langur; s. s6lembada; s. sSntada;
s. sesawi; s. tedong; s. tblok sbra; and s.
tfinggiling.

scen s ; Bkl.

sgnak. Overfull; = (Min.) sanak, (Java) senfik.
Used in Sumatra of rivers being swollen
(bandar ayer menyanak); (Mai.) of a basket
having more fruit in it than it will hold;
also of utterance being choked by too much
feeling (tbrsfinak kata): cf. also mbnaugis
dengan tbrniuat sangat tersbnak - senak
(weeping with choking sobs), Ch. Jen. 87.
This has led (Mai.) to a second and more
specialized meaning: viz.;
Pain in the region of the bowels due to
over - repletion; cf. senoh (oppression without
pain). Of pain with distension (s. kbmbong)
or with pain in breathing (s. napas) or with
colic (s. perut) or more loosely of the pangs
of hunger, cf. datang - lah s. daripada
sangat lapar-nya (he began to feel the
pains of extreme hunger), Ht. Mash. 50.
senak. A ring of rattan (also rotan senak)
between the frame and the leather of a tabor
(rSbana); to tauten the face of the tabor by


' means of a ring; Cl, Cf. sendak.

you find the Tartar; Prov.

sahaja hanya s. didalam mfimikiri, jika

sCngal. I. Cramp; shooting pains in the muscles
or joints. Of pains as the result, of move-
ments that ordinarily cause no pain; a
rheumatic person gets s. by moving a limb,
a healthy person gets nothing. So also a rap,
if on the funny-bone, causes s.; a man stiff
after exercise gets s. when he moves about.
Varieties: s. kaki (stiffness after riding); s.
tulang (rheumatism).

sßntgri. [T am. santiri] Seminarist; divinity
student. In Indonesia no man becomes an
alim in his own village; he has to travel
and study under teachers of repute. While
doing so he is regarded as a worthy object
of religious charity. In Java <pesantren»
or residential schools for these wandering
scholars are common; in Malaya the word
senteri is commoner in literature than in
real life, e.g. in the expression dagang s.
(traders and students; strangers of all sorts),
Gul Bak. 21, Jay. Lengg.

sßpui. I. Blowing softly, of the breeze, e.g.

sgrah. Making over to another; surrendering; =
(Min., Brun.) sarah. Of a place being
handed over by treaty (lit. Abd. 134, 135);

surrendering its weapons to a superior force
(Ht. Pasni 49); of the bride being given to
the bridegroom (Gul Bak. 44); of submission
to God’s will (kapada Allah bfirserah); of
self-surrender generally (serahkan diri).

hendak hati: (i) an absolute surrender at

sSraf, I. Citronella grass, Cymbopogon spp.

sgrambah. Sgrambahin: (Batav.) to be diffused
over a large area; to spread (as an inunda-
tion), From Jav. Cf. rampak, rambak.
Sgrambi. A long low closed front verandah made
by prolonging the eaves of the main building
or ibu rumah; usually supported outwardly
by an additional row of posts (tiang s.). If,
to gain headroom, the s. floor is at a lower
level than that of the main room the s. is
known as a s. jatoh. A balcony or verandah
not supported on pillars of its own is s.
gantong. Used loosely of foreign verandahs
and balconies also; e.g.: s. muka (front
verandah), s. bglakang (back verandah), s.
loteng (upper floor balcony), Sid. Rama 35,
61, 291. Also (Min.) salasar; but sglasar
in Malaya is now specifically an open unroofed
verandah, see sglasar. The word serambi
occurs: Jay. Pati, Sh. Ul. 19, Ht. Bugis 74.
A Malaya sgrambi is lit by a long low
window (tingkap s.) running along most of
its length; it communicates with the
inner room by a single curtained door. It
serves for the entertainment of guests and
may be regarded as the public part of the
dwelling in contr. to the women’s quarters.
In Sum. a rumah sgrambi is a house of a
superior type.
Possibly from Malayalam shrambi
(room on posts).
sgrampah. Rubbish; = sampah, q.v.
sgrampang. I. Trident; a three - pronged spear
used in warfare (Ht. Bugis 147), and more
commonly for spearing fish (illd. Veth cxxvi
3). The two outer spikes (wet s., uit s.) of
this fish-trident are barbed on the inside
only; the central spike is shorter and barbed
on both sides. All three meet in a common
base (mal or mai s.) attached firmly to the
wooden shaft (batang s.) by a ferrule or band
(tgmin). The torak trident is loose -
headed; the shaft comes away;—not so the
sgrampang.
Also tombak serampang and serapang.
IF. Sgrampang-sgramping: very ragged
at the edge. Cf. chompang - champing.
lIF. (Batav.) To club; to strike with a
stick; Dl.
sSrampat. See sSngkglit (climbing loop).

refuse sago left on the mat after the good
sago has been cleared away.
IF. (Ked.) A tree, sp. nnid.

Sgrani. fAr. nasrani] Nazarene; Christian; esp.
Catholic. Etym. = Christian; and, as such,
applied to the first Christians who visited
Indonesia, i.e. the Catholic Portuguese.
Protestants drew a distinction by calling
themselves masehi and by national names;
so that sgrani has come to be limited to
Catholics, esp. to Portuguese. Ayer s.: holy
water. Oereja s.: a Catholic church. Igama
s.; Catholicism. Masok s.: to become a Catho-
lic. Orang s.: a Portuguese.

cernuum.
sSranta. Advertising a fact; proclaiming; letting
everybody know. Usually of letting a Malay
village know that a buffalo is about to be
slaughtered so that buyers of meat may be
forthcoming. In literature sCrantakan is used
(Bost. Sal. ii 21) of a king’ s proclaiming
that people must be charitable; and again
(Bost. Sal. ii 91) of the Caliph Yazid sending
his father’s head round Damascus as proof
of his own accession to the throne,

11. A game played by children.
S£ri, Skr. The Hindu divinity Sri, the Indian
Ceres. Wife of Vishnu. Represented on old
monuments as four-armed; associated specially
with the lotus. She is the goddess of ferti-
lity; presides as a fortunate influence over
one of the five ominous times (kfitika Seri);
and as dewi S6ri or (in Java) nyat S. is
the good genius of the rice - crops.
sCri. I. Skr. Charm; quintessence; splendour;
glory; pick or best or embryo; an honorific
prefix to;
(i) the names or descriptions of royal
personages: s. Sultan raja Perak (H.H. the
Sultan who rules Perak); s. paduka sahabat
beta (our royal friend);
(ii) honorary non-royal titles of the highest
rank such as «Sri Maharaja*, «Sri Paduka
Raja», «Sri Adika Raja»;
pii) names of ships, = «the good ship*;
and
(iv) certain names of cakes and plants,
see below.
S. balai: place of honour in the audience
hall. S. bumi: plant, Heliotropium


indicum. S. 6nggang or 8. hutan: plant,
Hyptis brevipes. S. kaya: (i) sugar
apple, Anona squamosa; (ii) a sweetmeat,
see pulut. S. kaya Belanda: soursop, Anona
muricata. S. panggong; star-actress. S.
tanian: heart of a garden round which the
rest is laid out. For s. muka and s. n6gori
(sweetmeats) see muka and negeri. «To
take the honey out of a flower* (mengambil
s6ri, mSnyeri bunga, mimyeri madu) means
seduction, and is confused with spring (the
humming of bees round a flower), cf. Ht.
Panj. 126, Lail. Mejn.

banu.
[This lady is said to have been a Persian
princess and by her marriage with Husain
brings his descendants (the Sharif families)
into the line of Alexander and Kaiomorz.]

sgrkap. A conical trap or coop. As a trap (illd.
Veth) it is a truncated conical openwork
frame of rattan or bamboo that is thrust
down suddenly (di-s6rkup) over fish in
shallow w’ater; any fish so caught are taken
out through the opening in the truncated


top. Mbnyerkap: to catch in this way; (fig.)
to capture by a sudden attack, Sid. Rama
42. Hukum s,: «fish - trap law*, i. e. impri-
soning every one found in the vicinity of an
offence so as to ensure that the offender
shall not escape. Buang s. jarang: «to use
a wide - meshed trap*, i.e. to stop and ques-
tion all connected with a case; menebar
jala rambang.
As a coop the sbrkap is conical and
without an aperture at the top.
sSrkup. To clap down a concave trap or receptacle
over anything; e.g. as fish are caught under a
sbrkap, or as a fly is caught under an
inverted tumbler. Di-s. dengan kawah:
bottled under an inverted cauldron; Mai.
Dem. 41. Tiada dapat B. ini di-sbrknp
dbngan sbrkap jarang: «you won’t catch
this B. under any wide-meshed thrust-trap*,
i.e. this girl will always find a loop-hole of
escape from any dilemma; Gul. Bak. 98.
Of. lekap, tbrkap, tbrkup; cheknp.

sSrunai. I. [Pers. surnai] A sort of clarionet of

whistle with a slide for varying the pitch.
The mouthpiece is pipits., its reed lidah s.,
and a projection from the shaft cheper s.

sgtu. 1. [Jav.; from Skr. astu (be it so)] Spell-
change; metamorphosis; a physical change in
a person due to a spell, blessing or curse
laid upon him by a Hindu divinity or by a
Hindu ascetic endowed with supernatural
powers. For.a minor change, cf. di - sEtul
baginda sa-moga-moga Jayeng Kesonia
tiada makan oloh sEnjata (the ruler laid a
spell on J.K. rendering him invulnerable to
weapons); Mas. Ed. Often a complete
metamorphosis: maka Raden Oaloli pun di -
setu’f oleli BEtara Kala, maka bErubah -
lah rupa-nya sepErti rupa laki - laki (the
princess had a spell laid upon her by the
great god Kala and her form was changed
into that of a man); Perb. Jaya.
Derivatives of setu are often taken direct
from the Javanese; e.g.: to lay a spell (or to
metamorphose) is setu'i, mengfisStui, sEtoni
and merestoni; the being so metamorphosed
is pSngsetu (or pSngEstu) and pEngsetu -
kara.

s.: a sea snake that is found often in the
vicinity of this plant.

sewai. (Min.) By misapprehension; mistake; Tn.
sewaka. Skr. Seiwiceable; B.
sewai. Misfortune; unlucky; = sial, q.v.
sewar. (Sum.) A dagger. It has a single - edged
blade, narrow and of almost even width,
curving slightly inw'ards near the hilt and
outwards lower down, so that the cutting
edge is first concave and then convex. Hid.
Leyd. X pi. vii 7; Veth xxvii 1, ci 9.
Practically identical in type with the (Ba-
tav.) sewah; (Mai.) tumbok lada and golok
R6mbau; (Sum.) tombak lada, tumbok
lading; (Ach.) renchong. Tari s.: (Min.)
dagger-dance.
The sewar is worn as a dress - weapon
in places where the kr i s is not usually so
worn (Min., N.S.); its handle and sheath may
be adorned with silver wire, with gold or
silver mountings and even with gems.
Also sewa, sewali.
sSwSlir. (N.r.) Maiden - hair fern; = (French)
chevelure; B.
SCWU. Jav. A thousand; = (Mai.) sa-ribu.
Chandi s.; «the thousand shrines*,= chandi
sa-ribu; well-known ruins in Java.
sha. Ar. Willed. In expressions like nia-sba-
Allah (what God hath willedl and in-slia -
Allah (if God hath so willed itb
Shaaban. Ar. Name (i) of the eighth month of
the Moslem year, known formally as sha-
aban al - mukaram and popularly as bulan
mail from the arwah or All Souls festival
occurring during the month; and(ii) a proper
name sometimes given to children born
during this month.
Also Shaban, Saban and Saaban.
Shaban. See Shaaban.
shabash. [Pers. sha bash = be joyful] Capital!
Excellent! An exclamation of pleasure or
satisfaction. Sh! beribu - ribu kali sh.:
good! good! let me say so a thousand times;
lit. Pdk. 39. Cf. also Mai. Annals 111.
shabi. See sabi (shirt).
Shadiliah. See Sadiliah (sect ol mystics).
shaer. I Ar. shi ’ r] Metrical romance or address.
In contr. to a couplet (bait), quatrain
(pantun, rubai), or sonnet (talibun). Ada-
lah ia tabu bershaer; he knew how to
write poetry; Bost. Sal. ii 86.
[The shaer is a long poem made up of
verses of four lines alt rhyming together.
The best known shaer are romantic tales in
verse, eg. the Shaer Bidasari, the Shaer
Ken Tabuhan and the Shaer Panji Se-
merang. But any sort of subject fortune
telling, or embryology, or religious exhorta-
tion— may be discussed in shaer form; Tab.
Mimpi, Sh. Rej, Man. Pari, Sh. Iblis.]
shaeri. [Ar. shi’ri] Poetic. Abu sh,: father of
poetry; great poet.
shafaat. Ar. Intercession; recommendation.


shafakat. Ar. Kindness; sympathy; fellow feeling;
Mai. Annals 247. See also shafkah.
Shafel. Ar. Shafei, i.e. (i) the name by which
Muh ainniad ibni Idris ash-Shafi’i, the
founder of the «Shafeite» school of Moslem,
law is known to Malays; (ii) «Shafeite:>,
as the name of that school of law; and (iii)
a proper name often met with among Malays
and contracted popularly to Pihi. Imam Sh.:
the jurist Shafel: Eist. Sal. ii 112. Sh.
madzhab-nya: he belonged to the Shafeite
school of religious law; Bust. Sal. ii 121.
See madzhab.
Shafkah. [Hind. shafkah, Ar. shafakkat]
Kindness; sympathy. Used ot charitable
gifts, Hr. Bugis 152.
shagar. Pers. Sugar; see sakar.
Shah. Pers. King; ruler. In three senses: (i) in
chess, the «king*, e.g. shah-mat (checkmate);
shah (check) is merely the warning «mind
your king*; (ii) in literature*an occasional
prefix to the names of kings, e.g. Shah
Kubad (King Kubad); and (iii) in Malay
court - terminology an honcrifiic suffix to
the personal name of a reigning Sultan,
e.g. Sultan Mahmud Shah, Sultan
Alaodin Sulaiman Shah. [Many Indian
Moslems in Malaya are also named after
kings and it is common to meet names like
Matsah (Muhammad Shah), Maidinsah, and
Sultan Ibrahim among Jawipekans.] Shah
Alam; ruler of the world; emperor; an
expression common in literature as a form of
address to kings, e.g. daulat s. alam, duli
s. alam, tuanku s. alam; also playfully as
a description of the «forest-emperor* (shah -
alam di-rimba; coll, salam di-rimba) or
mousedeer; see pelandok. Shah - mardan:
«king of men»; as a name for the tiger (Ht.
Pdk.), and for the royal hero of an ancient
romance, the Hikayat Shah - mardan, that
is of special interest to the student of
mysticism. Shah - peri; king of the fairies
(raja jin yang bernama shah - peri), Lang.
Buana 8. See also shahanshah, shahbandar
and shahriar.
Shahabudin. [Ar. shahab al-din] Star or
(fig.) Warrior of the Faith; a proper name
met with in Malaya and shortened to Din,
Sabudin, or Budin.
shahada. [Hind, shah da] Rakish; naughty;
wicked. Applied to) a person’s look when
teasing a bride (Ht. Bugis 35); etc.
shahadan. Ar. Furthermore; the facts are. A
word in common use for beginning a para-
graph.
shahadat. Ar. Evidence; testimony; Sh. Mard.
Also of the «confession of faith* or creed
(kalimat al-sh.). Jari sh.: index - finger.
Dar al-sh.: «home of the Creed*, —as an
honorific for a Moslem State with no other
specific title, see dar. Anak ta’-bersha-
hadat: illegitimate child.
shahan. See shahanshah (king of kings).
shahanshah. [Pers. shahan (lyings) and shah
(king); = king of kings] King of kings, as
the title borne by the ruler of Persia.
shahar. See shahru (moon, city).
shahbandar. [Pers. shah (ruler) and bandar
(port), = harbour - master] Harbour - master
and comptroller of imports and exports
under the old Malay port - kings at Malacca
and Acheen. In Perak the shahbandar was
stationed near the mouth of the Perak River
and levied (on the Sultan’s behalf) duty on
all produce entering or leaving the State.
Coll.; sabandar, to’ bandar, bandar.
shahdan, = shahadan (furthermore).
Shahdu. Shahdu perdana: preeminent; see sadu.
shahid, 1. Ar. Testifier; witness; one who has
testified to his faith in Islam by dying for
it; omartyr*. Also of «martyred*, i.e.
«murdered* kings, e.g.: of the Caliph Omar
(Bost. Sal. ii 62); of Sultan Abdul -Jalil the
ex-bendahara, murdered at Kuala Pahang;
of Raja Haji killed in battle at Malacca (Ht.
Bugis 141); etc. So too: Islam banyak
inati sh, (many Moslems suffered martyrdom),
said of the heavy losses of the Achehnese
in their attack on Malacca; Bost. Sal. ii 124,.
see also sabil. Coll. said.
11. Ar. Alain shahid; the world as it
appears to us, i.e. the world of illusion. A
mystic term.
shahmat. [Pers. shah-mat] Check - mate; see
shah.
shahmura, A weapon (unid.); Ht. Hamz.


shahrial. A variant (Ht. Bangs. 1) of shahriar.
shahriar. [Pers. shahar-yar; = l<rd of the
city] Monarch; king; esp. in the name of
King Kubad (Kubad Shahriar). Also shah-
rial. Sometimes understood as a the name of
Kubad’s kingdom.
Shahribanu, See Seribanu.
shahru. I. Ar. «Moon», as a component part of a
proper name such as Shahru’l - bahriah.
11. Pers. City. Shahru’l - nuwi: an old
name for Siam; really shahar -i - nau (the
new city, i.e. Ayodhya); Mai. Annals 51.
shahwat. Ar. Orgasm; voluptuous feeling. Also
sahwat; B. Mimplkan sh.: to have a volup-
tuous dream; Ht. Bugis 9. Mcnambahkan
sh.: «to intensify sensation*—words used in
Malay prescriptions ot aphrodisiacs to explain
their object.
shai. Ar. Thing; what exists. Esp. in the
expression La shai baada -hu (after Him
there is nought); of God’s Infinity.
shaikh. Ar. Chief; sheikh. In Malay explained
as the title given to descendants of the
Prophet’s friends (shaikh itu keturunan
daripada sahabat - sahabat rasul Allah),
Pel. Abd. 15. In reality given to all Hadra-
maut Arabs who have not the higher title of
Syed. Confused sometimes with shah:
shaikh-mardan for shah - i - mardan; shaikh
alam di - riraba for shah - alam di-riniba
(Ht. Pdk. 49). Mystics use the word shaikh
to describe the instructor of a local lodge of
a mystic order.
shair, shaer (poem).
shairi, shaeri (poetic).
Shaitan. Ar. Devil; fiend; spirit of evil. The Arch-
Fiend himself is not usually shaitan but
Iblis. Etym., sh. (= «the burnt one*) is a
description of Satan; also sh. alaihi laanat
(Satan, may God’s Curse light upon him),
Mai. Annals 157. But Malays apply the
term more commonly to the Hosts of Hell
(t£nt6ra sbgala sh.), Bost. Sal. i 57, and to
the devils that plague people with madness
(di - haru oleh sh. = possessed by a devil),
Hg. Tuah 339. A distinction is drawn also
between jin (genii, good or evil), the
descendants of Jan, and shaitan (invariably
evil), the descendants of Iblis; see Best. Sal.
i 30, i 75.
Also (coll.) setan, q.v. Ct. also kejadian
s. itu konon daripadu api (Perch. Mai. 31 1
i.e. «the Devil owes his oiigin to Fire*. See
also Iblis.
shaitani. Ar. Satanic; devilish; ID. Hamz. The
adjective of shaitan, q.v.
shajarat, = shnjrat (tree).
shajrah or shajrat. |A i-. shajrat; Hind, shajrah]
Tree; genealogical tree. See sejarah.
shak. Ar. Misdoubt; suspicion. Di - sliaki:
suspected; mistrusted; Pet. Ayam 43. M -
naroh sh.: to doubt; to lack confidence.
Jangan sh. lagi: don’t be anxious (Ch. Jen.
102); also jangan sh. hati (Mai. Annals 228).
Sangka dan sh. dan waham: doubts and
suspicions of all sorts.

Sham. I. Ar. Shem (son of Noah), ancestor of

11. Ar. Syria (bcnua Sh.); Hg. Tuah
590, Boat. Sal. ii GO.

Angg. 8. Cf. also Shamsudin.
Shamsudin, Ar. A proper name; = shams al-din


(s ha m s u’d -d i n), «sun of the Faith*.
Usually pronounced Snmsudin; shortened
to Sndin, Udin and Din.
shanan. Tam. Hindu coconut - palm - climber; Hn.
shara’. Ar. Canon Law; law based on religious
revelation in contr. to law based on very
old custom (adat). Moslem law is known
also as hukum, hukum shara’, hukum
koran and (less correctlyl as adat kitab
Allah (Mai. Saying 26). Cf. also shareat.
[ln theory local custom supplements
religious law and both are in force (adat
yang kawi, shara’ yang lazim). In practice
they overlap and are often irreconcilable.
See adat].
sharab. Ar. Strong drink; wine.
sharak, shara’ (canon law).
sharat. [Ar. shart] Condition; item; stipulation.
sharatan, = shartan (horns of Aries).
sharbat, Ar. Cooling drink; = serbrtt, q.v. Sh.
arghawani; ruby red wine; see arghawani.
shareat. Ar. Ritual; liturgy; ordinance of God; cf.
shara’. Shareat is, so to speak, the religions
law (shara’) worked out in detail and put
into words or ritual. Adat dunia balas-
bSrbalas, shareat pain - inemaln: the rule
of the world is tit for tat, of religion a blow for
a blow; Sid. Rama 212. Mansukhkan segala
sh. nabi yang dahnlu - dahnlu; to abrogate
the ordinances of the earlier Prophets; Host.
Sal. ii 40.
Also (coll.) sareat; (Java coll.) sarengat,
sSrengat.
sharekat, = sharikat (association).
Sharif, Ar. A proper name; see sliarif.
Sharif. Ar. «Noble»; a title (i) limited by some
to descendants of the Prophet in the direct
male line through Husain; (ii) extended by
others to all the Prophet’s reputed issue
(s-ee said) in the title al - sa’id al - sharif
(the noble lord), Ht. Bugis; and (iii) given
specifically to the spiritual rulers of Mecca
(subsequently kings of the Hedjaz), Ht.
Pasai 9, 10, Mai. Annals 46. Cf. mir and
sharifah.
Sharif is used also as a proper name,
popularly pronounced Sarip and shortened to
Yib or Yip.
Sharifah. See sharifah.
sharifah, [Ar.; fem. of sliarif] Noble lady; title
given to ladies whose fathers are «syeds»,
see said and sliarif. Popularly saripah or
che’ pah.
Sh. is used also as a proper name, e.g.
sa-orang anak p6r6inpuan naraa-nya Sh.
(a daughter named Sharifah), Ht. Abd. 4.
sharik. Ar. Partner; associate. Cf. (of God):
wahid, la-sharika lahu (He is One, there
is none His associate), i.e. there is no God
but Allah; Ht. Pasai 11.
sharikat, Ar. Association; partnership; all who
share, e.g., in the Faith (sh. Islam).
Also (coll.) sarekat.
shartan. [Ar. shartan or shartain] The horns
of Aries; the first mansion of the moon;
Host. Sal. i 49. Often confused with sartan
(Cancer).
shatar. Ar. Ruling board for tracing lines on
paper; illd. Veth. xxxiv 2, = papan mistar.

Shiah. Ar. Followers of a particular parly or

Moslem world. Of dissenters or sectarians;
not of heretics (zindik).
shilawar. See soluar (trousers).
shiling, Eng. Twenty-cent piece; «shilling»;=Pen.
soling. Duit sh.: small silver. Also siling,


sSngkeiing.
shin. Ar. Name of an Arabic letter transliterated
as ffsh» and pronounced like the English «sh»
in «shine». Malays, not having that sound
in their language, often pronounce it as «s»
and give it the name sin bSsar. It has the
numerical value 300 in the abjud.
shipsel. (Naut.) Cross - jack (on a square - rigged
ship). From the Laskari shck-aeih
cross-jack.
shira. Tali skira: (naut.) rope-ladder; rope for
swarming up a ship’s side. From the Laskari
s i r h i (ladder).
Shith. Ar. Nabi Shith: Seth, son of Adam.
According to tradition he slew Cain, wrote
the earliest scriptures and was the first to
use a sword; Bost. Sal. i 91.
Shohor. A proper name; a coll, variant of (Ar.)
Mashhur.
shohrat. [Hind.; from Pers. and Ar.] Divulging;
publishing.
shor. See shur (recommendation).
shorga, = shurga (heaven).
Shuaib. Ar. A name met with sometimes among
Malays. Nabi Shuaib: Jethro; the father-
in-law of Moses; Bost. Sal. i 100, ii 11.
Shufaat. Ar. Intercession. Esp. of a prayer being
answered through the intercession and for
the sake (dftngan berkat sh.) of one more
deserving than oneself.
shuhud. Ar. Witnesses. Plural of shahid.
shlikur. Ar. Thanks; e.g. bdribu sh.: a thousand
thanks; many thanks.
shur. Ar. Advice of elder or teacher. Shurkan;
to advise; to recommend. Also (Trengg.)
shor.
shurah. Ar. BSrshurah: to lecture; to explain or
expound; Gem. Ht. 6.
shurga. [Skr. swarga] Heaven. In two senses;
(i) the Heaven of Siva or Betara Guru,
in contr. to that of Indra (keindfiraan);
known also as shurga-loka or shurga-loga,
Mas. Ed.; and
(ii) the Moslem Heaven or Heavens of
Bliss; known also as shurga-jannah or jan-
nat: Dost. Sal. i 3. Also (Batav.) sorga;
(Min.) soroga, suroga.
[Tradition has it that the Heavens of’
Bliss (shurga, jannat; which must not be
confused with the heavenly strata or firma-
ments (p6tala laugit) were created after
the Pen and Tafilet of Fate, the Empyrean
(arash), the Judgment Seat (kursi) and the
Heavenly Host. For an account of all the
heavens see jannat.]
si I. A demonstrative prefix; (in Malaya) a
demonstrative usually expressive of contempt.
So the rivals Samba and Boma (in the
Samba romance) speak contemptuously of
each other as «this Boma* (si-Boma) and
* this Samba* (si - Samba): so also when
Hang Jo bat or Hang Kesturi turned
traitor and ran amuck he was described as
Si-Jobat or Si-Kosturi (Hg. Tuah, Mai.
Annals); so again an enemy who speaks of
Shall Kubad as Si-Kubad is rebuked by a
follower of the latter, Jangan-lah 6ugknn
mdmanggil Shah Kubad itu si-si (you are
not to say si-si of Shah Kubad), Sh. Kub.;
and even the great divinity Siva is spoken
of angrily as si-gurn when he refuses to
revivify Samba (Bg. Samb.). But this con-
temptuous use of si is neither ancient nor
universal. Etym , si = (Kawi, Bal.) i= «the».
This i may survive in i-ni and i-tu: just
as si, in no insulting sense, appears in
sianu and siapa. In Sumatra it is not
depreciatory. It appears in the names of the
great spirit Si - kulambai, of the great dra-
gon Si - katimuna, of the famous buffalo
Si-bdnnang sakti and of the unconquered
cock Si-kunani. It is commonly used with
personal names; and in titles it is confused
with s6ri, see si If.
In Malaya its use should be avoided. It
was formerly the prefix for names of
slaves; and though it is sometimes
used veiy deprecating!y of oneself (Hg.
Tuah 72) or of one’s young son (Ht. Abd.
14) it is met with most commonly in expres-
sions like: si - penchuri (this thief), Gul
Bak. 53; si-dftrhaka (this traitor), Hg. Tuah
87; si - chandakia - mana (w hat slanderer),
Gul Bak. 80; si-engkan si-aku (a person
with whom you need stand on no cermony),
Ht. Abd. 90, 314, Mai. Annals 240.

sidrat, Ar. Sidrat al-rnuntaha: «the Lote - tree
of Finality*, i.e. the Eha mn us- tree (in
the Seventh Heaven) that shades the Waters
of Paradise and beyond which neither angel
nor prophet can pass. For an account see
Host. Sal. i. 27.
[This tree is identified with the tree whose
leaves represent the lives of men; cf. maka
apabila sarnpai ajal mereka-itu anak Adam
maka daun kayu yang hernama sidrat al-
muntaha itu-pun jatoh-lah (Hikayat Bantam
16, Tk. iii 303). It is believed that on the
night of the 14th Shaaban (malaui baraat)
this tree is shaken and the leaves that fall
represent the lives of all who are doomed to
die within a year.]

Si I ah, I. [Ar. silsi 1 a t] Silah - silali or salah-
silah: genealogy; pedigree; line of succession.
Of a table of descent showing a prince’s
hereditary claims; also of spiritual descent,
i.e. of the system of apostolic succession
by which the head of a body of mystics
traces his authority back to the original
founder of the Order. In both cases the
«chain» (Ar. si 1 s i 1 at) should be unbroken.
In N.S. s. -s. is used of genealogies
written to show descent in the direct male
line; matrilineal genealogies (usually not
recorded in writing) are teromba. A raja is
bftrsilah-silah; a tribal headman (lombaga) is
borteromba.

simpul. I. Knot; to fasten with a knot, or to hold

mat studded with gems), Mai. Annals 87.
The dais should be about 8 or 9 feet long and
5 or 6 feet wide; and may be surmounted
by a baldacchino (kubah) on four pillars.

siong. 1. Large pointed tooth; canine tooth; tusk.
Used loosely of almost any teeth, even in

jaw, such as boar’s tushes and the supposed

cf. gfimentar-lah sggala “anggota-nya me-
-1 ihat s.-nya bota dan raksasa itu bernyala-

and ogres; Sg. Samba. Gigi s.: canine teeth,
see gigi. Raja bersioug: descriptive name
of a Kedah raja who having gergasi blood
on the distaff side developed tusks and
cannibal traits. See also taring.

sir. I. Ar. Secrecy; the hidden promptings of
the mind or flesh; e.g.: s. berahi (longings
of physical passion); tiada - lah ia sir
kapada perompuan itu (he felt no wish to
possess the woman), Ind. Nata. Sir in
Kelantan means «wanting, wishing*=mahu;
ta’-sir (Kel., Ked.) is «not caring* ,=(Pen.)
ta’-bisat, (Sp.) ta’-chanda. Sir means «lust»
in prescriptions for love - philtres and aphro-
disiacs; and the lusts of the flesh in a wider
sense in the formulae of sorcerers, e.g.
penyakit datang daripada sir, penawar -
nya datang daripada nur (the evil in man
gives illness, the divine light in him gives
its cure), Mai. Magic 582. But s. is used
also by mystics of the spiritual sense and of
the silent and secret, e.g. sir wujud yang
mutlak (the Secret of Absolute Being); and
of silent religious exercises in contr. to the
noisy ratib.
11. [Hind, se r] The Indian «seer», a
measure of weight equal (in most places) to
about 80 «tola».

siram. Besprinkling. A term applied to: (i) the

IV. Jav. Small jet of any liquid; falling

sireh. I. Betel - vine, Piper be tie; betel-leaf;
betel-leaf prepared for chewing (with areca-
nut, gambier and lime); betel as associated
with special purposes or ceremonies such as
betrothal or marriage.
Varieties of vine: s. China (Piper betle,
imported and coarse); s. Molayn (id., in-
digenous and good); s. ayer (wild, Piper
mini a turn); s. kadok (leaf of P. lon gum,
sireh - substitute); s. hntan (wild, P. sty-
lo sum?— with hard rough leaves); cbambai
nr bakek (leaves of P. cha h a; sireh -
substitute). Watson gives s. hutan as P.
caninum, P. curtisii; and adds s.
chSchawi (Scindapsus p ictus).
[Hu,kill gives: s. dudoh (Piper sar-
mentosurn); s. Melayu (P. betle); s.
mural (P. ribesoides), s. pachat (P.
caninum); s. rimau (P. porphyro-
phyllum); s. nyireh, s. padang (Ardisia
spp.); and s. puyu (A. crenata).]
Varieties of leaf: s. charang (best; young
shoots and leaves near fop of vine); s. ke-
rakap, s. kakap (larger and coarser leaves
taken lower down).
Treatment of leaf: pair of leaves (s. sa -
susun); | ile of leaves (s. sa-ikat, s. sa-rakit);
shred for use in a quid (s. sa-chabek, s. sa-
charek); prepared quid (s. sa-kapur, s. sa-
piak); chewed quid (s6pah).

sir Sp. (Batav., from Jav.) At rest or asleep,

sirinak. (W. Sum.) Skittish; Dl.
siring. I. Shrimp-net. Of two kinds; (i) a sort
of rattan racquet or stick (with trailers)
drawn through the water to frighten fish
into leaping on to a screen; and (ii) a purse-
net, = sungkur or langgai. This latter is a
plough-net drawn through mud. Two passages
(Gem. Ht. 3, Gul Bak. 122) which refer to
a shrimp being inside a siring and the name
kain siring for sack - cloth (of which purse
nets are often made) refer to the latter
meaning of siring.

sirukan. (W. Sum.) A fish with red scales, sp.

sisa. [Skr. ses a] Residue; leavings; remains,
e.g. after a meal. S. bunoh: the «remnant»
of the massacre, i.e. the one survivor; Mai.
Annals 226. S. nabi: «the remains of the
prophet’s meal», a name given to certain
soles, i.e. fish that look as if they had been
half eaten (ikan sa-belah); see note. S.
pengait: «what the reaping hook spares*,
i.e. things not worth the reaping; rubbish.
Usually of the remains of a meal, esp.
as valuable evidence against poisoners (upas
rachun s. makan). See also Ht. Panj. 23.
[The story goes that when Alexander the
Great went in search of the Water of Life
the Prophet who went wdth him (Nabi
Khidzir) got separated from the army in a
fog and sat down by a pool to eat his meal
of dried fish. When the fish was half eaten
the Prophet put what was left into the
water to soften it, whereupon it came to life
and swam away. The sole (with eyes on
one side only) suggests the «half-eaten fish*
(ikan sa-belah) or the remains of the
Prophet’s meal (sisa nabi).]

in yd a s. See pbnyu.

sisil. Rolling up or turning back the end or
tip of anything, e.g. tucking up the sleeves
or drawing back the prepuce. Cf. singsing.
sisip. Slipping in between two surfaces, e.g. as
a reader inserts a paper-knife between two
uncut pages or as a Malay slips a weapon
between his waistbelt and his coat (Raj.
Muda 15). Sisipkan: so to insert. Tersisip:


so wedged in.
Sisip is used also of replacing a worn -
out strip of planking or matting by slipping
in a substitute piece. Also (Brun.) of caulking
a boat; M.
sisir. I. Comb; harrow; comb in loom; screen
in fish trap; toothed instrument; rake; comb-
like bunch of bananas. Practically sikat;
used of combing the hair, Ht. Panj. 26
(rambut- nya di sisiri oleli dayang-dayang-
nya).

siti. I. [Ar. sitti] Lady: madam; a title

e.g.: Siti Hawa (Eve), S. Sara (Sarah), S.
M6riam (the Virgin Mary); (ii) to ladies

rifah; and (v) to Malay ladies in a position

mistress (enche’ siti sahaya). Cf. hidangan
pun di - angkat s.-s. anak raja - raja dan
mbnteri: the plates were removed by ladies

solek. Fashion; mode; style. Bersolek: to dress
up; e.g. biar-pun ia tiada bersolek (even if
she had not been well dressed), Sid. Rama
88. Pesolek: fop. Pesolek hobat: dressed
up to the nines,=(Pen.) segak.
Used: (i) of being well dressed; (ii) of
being dressed in the latest fashion; (iii) of
being rather too well dressed, i. e. foppish;
(iv) of putting on airs (Sh.); and (v) of the
way the headcloth is worn. Fashions of
wearing the head-cloth are solek, and they
are many. Veth illustrates seven (Veth xvi
1-7); Winstedt mentions twelve. Mentioned
in literature are: s. ayani patah kepak (fowl
with broken wing, i.e. raised in centre, one
side drooping), Ht. Angg. 24; s. bblah
mumbang (split coconut, i.e. with a cleft or
depression in centre), Mai. Dew’a 29; s. lang
mfinyongsong angin (eagle breasting the
breeze; i.e. headdress blown-back somewhat),
Raj. Muda 117.
Solo. Surakarta in Java.

getting up a picnic to which the donor
is asked.

SOnggeng. I. [Jav. snogging] The art of
painting or illustrating as known to the
Javanese. In a sense there is no Malay
«painting». Floral and other ornament in
colour is seen occasionally on old letters or
book margins; this is tulis, not songgeng.
Islam is known to be hostile to the
portraying of living things. But there are
traditions of a famous portrait - painter of
Majapahit (Tk. iv 139); and there is even
to this day the «picture wayang* (wayang
bebor) of Java in which incidents are shown
in pictures instead of being thrown as
shadows on a screen. Bbrsonggeng ayer
mas: depicted in gold colouring; lit. Sh.

SOngSOng. I. Breasting; making little headway or
slow progress against adverse forces, such

current), Mai, Annals 234. Also (Min.) son-
song. Best known in two expressions:
(a) songsong hams: (i) pushing on against
the tide; (ii) name of a fish, trevally or

C. speciosus, see daeng bSlang; (iii) a

acuminatum; and
(b) mSnyongsong angin: (i) fighting the
wind, of a soaiing kite or eagle; (ii) sailing
very close-hauled; and (iii) showing off or
on side* in one’s walk.

sorak. Cheering: applause. Properly «cheers of
triumph*, in contr. to tbmpek (cheers of
encouragement); cf. alah sabong mbnang s.
(losing the fight but winning in crowing),—
said of a man who persuades others that his
failures are triumphs; Prov. But sorak is a
commoner word than tempek and is used
for cheers or shouts generally, e.g. of the
cries of beaters (Ht. Abd. 49) or ot the
delighted shouts of the spectators when a
football-player is knocked head over heels
(Bint. Tim. 13. 3. 35).

subang. 1. Large coin-like ear - stud; illd. Yeth
xii 3,7, 8; xx 1,6; xxi 4,6, 10; xxii i, 3.
Also (Java) Rubbng. Seldom now worn (Mai ),
except ceremonially at weddings (cf. Ht.
Bugis 50), to he discarded when the marriage
has been consummated. Among some Kuhn
Proto-Malays the removal of the subang is
the marriage - ceremony itself. Ct. also the
proverb, Sunggoh borsubang tidak bfirdara;
«wearing ear-studs yet no maiden*, of girls
who are «no better than they should be*.
Adman s.; mould for casting these
earstuds; illd. Yeth cv G. See also lontar.
[Why the subang should be associated
with marriage is not quite clear. Etym. the


s. w'ould seem to be less an ear - ornament
than an instrument (on the principle of an
uncoiling spiral spring) for the purpose of
enlarging the hole through the ear. It is
possible that (like tooth - filing) a certain
amount of enlargement of the aperture made
through the ear by ear-boring (tindek) was
expected before marriage].

sujen. Jav. Small spike; spit; splinter; B.
suji. I- Hind. A granular meal obtained by
grinding wheat between two millstones that
are not in very close contact. The fine
flour is passed through a sieve; the bran is
removed by winnowing; and the remainder
the bigger and harder pieces—is suji. In
Penang this is prepared as a meal-porridge
or sweet pudding for very young children.
11. Embroidery. Etj-m. from the porcupine
quill (Kawi suji) formerly used as a needle.
Cf. sugi (quill); sulam tekat.
sujud. Ar. Kneeling and bowing the head to the
ground; cf. sujud-lah ia sampai ka-tanah
kepala-nya (he bowed till his head touched
the very ground), Ht. Abd. 226. The last
and humblest of the attitudes of Moslem
prayer. Also (coll.) sujut, (Batav.) sejud,
(Panj. Sg.) sujutan. Senibah s.: prostration
in homage, i.e. bowing and touching the
sovereign’s hand with your forehead. Cf.
also dudok tegak tuan sembahyang, auta-
ra s. chita lah kami: standing erect repeat


your prayers; when kneeling pray for me;
Mai. Pant. 37.
sujut, See sujud (prostration).

sukat. I. Measurement. Rightly (and in literature

It. If; provided that; supposing that.
Usually of something unlikely, e.g.: sukat
ayer mfinjadi batu (if water turns to stone),
Piov.; s. patek ambil suami - nya maka
puas rasa hati patek (if I can rob her of
her husband then indeed shall I be satisfied),
Ht. Koris.
sukgr. See sukar (arduous).
suki. (Sel.) To have enough (of food); Wt. Cf.
(Min.) suki = full up; Tn.
Sukrat. [Ar. from Gk.] Socrates. Ada - lah murid
S. hakim itu Aflatun hakim: Plato the
Philosopher was the pupil of Socrates the
Philosopher; Rost. Sal. i 80.
suku. I. Quarter; section; tribe. Etym. a «limb»;
whence the common meaning of «quarter»,
cf.: s. jam (a quarter of an hour); rial dan
s. (dollars and quarter - dollars), Sh. Dag. 2.
From «limb» or section of the population it
came to mean «tribe» in three different
senses: •
(i) among the Peninsular Malays suku is
either rather indefinite or rather contemptuous.
Indefinite in expressions like (Ked.) suku-
suku depa (that lot, that crowd), and kita
sakalian s. laki-laki (we all belong to the
male paid of the population), Mar. Mali.; cf. also
sembilan s. daripada - nya shaitan dan sa -
s. lagi itu jin dan manusia (nine tenths of
them are devils and the one-tenth genii and
men), Rost. Sal, i 76. Contemptuous from
the fact that the orang pOsukuan of the
old Johor State (people with a tribal system)
are the Protomalays, esp. the primitive
orang laut. The suku is associated with
inferior culture.


(ii) among the Protomalayan Orang Laut
a suku is a sort of clan tracing descent
through the father and broken up into many
little settlements that claim kinship one with
another, e.g. the suku Golam, s. Galang,
s. Sekanak, s. Selat, etc.;
(iii) among the Minangkabau Malays a
suku is made up of a number of uterine
families (pbrut), each under its own headman
but all recognizing the higher authority of
the tribal headman (N. S. lembaga, Min.
penghulu puchok). Among these highly
civilized Malays the tribal system connotes
advanced culture and fits into the general
scheme of world - government (alum beraja,
luhak b§rp6nghulu, suku bertuha).
In Acheen the (patrilineal) tribe is known
as kauin and not as suku.
11. (Pah.) Separate; distinct; different. S.
fasal: quite another matter.
HI. Suku sakat; genealogy;Sh. A family
in all its ramifications.
sukum, = sokoin (patchy in colouring).
sukun. .1. Buah sukun; breadfruit, Artoc arp u s
laevis; Hg. Tuah 526, Kamp. Gl. 4. Of this
fruit tw 7 o varieties are recognized, one (s.

pipless. Maja - sukun; young fruit of Ter-
minal i a a r b o r e a.

Sukur, Ar. A proper name; coll, for Abdul-
sllukur, see shukur.
sukur. Ar. Thanks; = shukur, q.v.
sula. [Skr. shula] Spit; sharp stake; spitting;
impaling. PSnyula: spit; sharp stake; Jay.
Pati. Sulakan: to impale. Terisula,: trident;
three-pointed spear; Sg. Samb.
Etym., sula (like sungga) represents a
pointed stake stuck vertically in the ground,
in contr. to the suda which is stuck in at an
angle, and to the multiple ranjau. But the
word has become associated specially with
impaling and is used: (i) of that form of
punishment; and (ii) loosely, of acts that
suggest it; e.g.: of a severed head being stuck
on a post (lit. Bugis 81); or of a dead body-
being exhibited publicly (Hr. Pasai 23, B >st.
Sal. ii 90); and even of Christ’s crucifixion
(Bost. Sal. i 81) and of the crucifixion (or
impalement) of a king of Egypt by Nebu-
chadnezzar (Bost. Sal. i 105). The terrible
punishment of impaling was used by the
Dutch (for a description see Campbell’s
«Java», 1075); but it was not introduced by
them, cf. tangkap akan Si - Kfisturi dan
Si Jhbat itu sulakan di - tepi suugai ini
karna ia derhaka (arrest these men, KAstu-
li and Jebat, and impale them on the river-
bank for they are traitors), Hg. Tuah 256.
It was inflicted also on women for infidelity
(Mai. Annals 58).
[Malay impaling was primitive; it is
described by Abdullah (Pel. Abd. 20) sula
itu di-tikam - nya dengan puchok nipah
dari lobang pantat-nya sa - hingga lain
ka-dalam perut-nya (a spike of nipah was
driven into the stomach through the anus).
The Dutch drove a pointed stake or iron
spike along the line of the backbone between
the bone and the outer skin; and a cross or
seat was provided on which the body rested.
In this way the wound was not mortal and
the torture might last for many days].
Slilah. Bald; hairless; Ch. Jen. 88. Bangau
sulah: (Java) the lesser adjutant, = (Mai.)
burong botak. Lada s.: white pepper,
Pilier re t rofrac tum; Mai. Annals 181.
Sulaiman. Ar. A proper name; Solomon. Shortened
(coll.) to Leman and Man. Nabi S.: the
biblical Solomon, regarded by Malays as
king of the world of animals and genii and
as a master of magic; also as the lover of
the queen of Sheba (puteri Balkis). He is
associated with «Solomon’s whip* (clibmeti
S.), Ht. Pdk. 43; cf. Behoboam’s saying, «My
father chastised you with whips*; and with
Solomon’s seal (chap S.), and its impression,
the pentacle (tapak S., tapak leman), used
as a talisman in war (azimat pelias perang
tolo S.). Fowlers and hunters often use
Solomon’s name in their invocations.
Daun S.: a plant - name; Hedyotis
capitellata; Bkl.
sulaimani. Ar. «Appertaining to Solomon*, —in
the name «11 1 e Solomonian stone* (batu su-
laimani) for the onyx; Hg. Tuah 523.

SUling. I. A fife, flageolet, nr pipe; illd., May. i
92, Veth xli. Also sending; (Min.) salong.
A tube of bamboo closed at one end and open
at the other; it has six small holes on one
side and one rather larger on the other near
the open end. It is of finer finish than the
bangsi. Tatnbur dan s. is used (Ht. Abd.
77, 134) of a modern drum-and-fife military
band; cf. also Mai. Dewa 76. See also
serunai.

sultan. Ar. Sultan. Till recently only a
personal title taken by any ruling prince
(yamtuan or yamtuau muda) as a prefix to
his own name, shah being taken as a suffix;
(in recent years) a title descriptive of
rulership, taken with British recognition by
certain princes such as the Bendahara of
Pahang and the Maharajah of Johore; (Min.)
an honorific or title pronounced sutan or
sblutan and not implying sovereign
authority; (Java) a descriptive ruling
title taken by certain princes notably by
the Sultan of Jogja —in place of indigenous
titles such as susuluman and pfinembahan,
S. muda: junior or deputy Sultan; a title
given in the past as an equivalent of yamtuan
muda (Mai. Annals. 228): now limited (Pk.)
to the spiritual Sultan who controls the jin
kerajaan and who is a waris neg6ri by
birth though debarred by office from
succeeding to the secular Sultanate. S.al-adzam,
s. al-muadzam, s al-mukaram: titles given
to Malay reigning princes in the past. (Hg.
Tuah 472), but of late years used to
distinguish the Sultan of Turkey from local
Sultans. Wakil al-S.: «Sultan’s deputy»; a
title borne in Perak by the Raja Muda and
Raja Bendahara. Ratu 8.: (Java) «Sultana»;
a title given to a Sultan’s principal wife
(Ht. Bugis HI), e. g. the Sultana of
Jogja.
[»Sultan» did not mean an independent
ruler till A. D. 1002. In that year the
Ghaznavid governors or «sultans» made
themselves independent of the Caliph without
changing the title that they had previously
possessed.]
sultanat, Ar. Sovereignty; sultanate.
suitani. Ar. Appertaining to the Sultan, e. g.: a
royal prince (raja s., Sh. Bid. 8); imperial
Turkish troops (rayat s., Pr. Turki 10); the
royal line (nasab s., Bost Sal. ii 126); etc.
sulu. See suloh (spy, scout).
Sulllb. [Ar. sulb, sul u b, salab] Backbone;
see sulbi. The whole backbone from the
neckbones to the coccyx, but esp. the lumnar
vertebrae; the «loins», as the depositary of
a man’s seed. Thus it is said that when
Abraham called on all mankind to build the
Caaba he was answered by all «who lived*
(yang hidup), even by those who were «in
the wombs of their mothers* (datum rahum
ibu - nya) and by those still unconceived


who were On the loins of their fathers*
(didalam sulub bapa-nva), Rost. Sal. i
61,
SUluk. 1. [Hind, suluk, Ar. saluk] Way;
path, i.e. the path of the mystic, = tarekat.
Ahlial-s.; mystics. Ilmu s.: mysticism, =
tasawuf, ilmu sufi, ilmu salek.
11. sulok (story - teller’s recitation).

clielup.
11. See selup (sloop).
sulur. I. Turning or rising upward; shoots.
Etym., of the roots of certain species of
Ficus; but used in Malay: of runners for
plants (sulur - suluran); lotus-shoots (s.
bakoug); shoots on a tree-trunk (s. batang);
upturned crockets [s. bayong, selembayong,
(Ked.) selambayong]; upward extensions of a
boat’s ribs (s. gading); topmasts (s. tiang);
etc. For sireh bersulur, see sireh.
S. bunga: stamen of a flower; Sh. S.
gadong: a climber, Dioscorea triphylla,
S. karang: id.; Embelia garciniaefolia;

sumarak. (Sum.) Lustre; splendour; (fig.) best of

Sumatra. Pulau Sumatra: Sumatra; Ht. Bugis
18. The earliest mention of the name Su-
matra occurs in Marco Polo (A.D. 1298).
He seems to have taken it from kanipong
Samudra (= kanipong laut), the earliest
seat of government of the kings of Pasai.
But Malays connect the word with a large
ant (sennit raya or sennit semfiudera).
Sumba. Pulau Sumba: Sandalwood Island, best
known for its excellent breed of ponies; Pant.
Mai. 1036. A large island of the Sunda
group known also as Pulau Chendana.
SUftibak, (Min.) Cut; gash; open wound; Tn.
sumbang. 1. Revolting; incestuous; an abomination.
Esp. of incest; cf.: anak s. (child of incest);
s. ia dtingan saudara-nya (he had incestuous
relations with his sister), Bost. Sal. ii 16.
But «iucest» (Min.) covers more than illicit
relations between near relatives (s. kadim);
it includes intercourse between unrelated
persons who may not marry under the adat
(s. balai melinlang). In a looser sense also
all serious sexual offences are sumbang (s.
kapada tabiat), e.g. adultery and illicit
pregnancy. Cf. also the expressions pokok
sumbangan applied to a tree that bears two
different flowers or fruit, e.g, alter grafting.
« Abominations* of another sort are referred
to in mSnghilirkan s. = sending the devils
of a country down - river to perish in the
sea; see lancliang. S. melangsi (a high note
in the wrong place—abominable to a
musical ear) is a rarer expression.

and cursing in turn; Panj. Sg.

SUtnin. Sumin jantan: shrub, Alchornea
vi 11 os a; W.
Sumirang, = SSmerang; see Panjt.
sumpah. Oath; ordeal; imprecation. A sum pall
was formerly an oath backed up by a test
or by the imprecation of a curse should one
swear falsely. Among the tests were true
ordeals such as: plunging the hand into boiling
oil or molten tin (s. chelur, Bost. Sal. ii
127); ordeal by lire (s. uji api); licking
redhot iron (s. jilat b6si); and ordeal by
water (s. menyelam—the litigant who stayed
under water longest winning his case). Islam
was hostile to ordeals. Imprecatory oaths
included: s. niinum aver keris (drinking
water in which a talismanic k r i s had been
plunged); s. b6si kawi (drinking water in
which a piece of iron had been placed); s.
potong ayiuu or s. sembeleh ayam (killing
a cock and imprecating its fate on oneself),
etc. To bieak such an oath or swear falsely
(melanggar s., makan s , Sid. Rama 43)
was thought to mean death by the kris or
by the besi kawi (mat! di-sula besi kawi)
or by whatever fate is invoked in the wording
of the oath. One formula (containing the
words «may the earth not receive me», or
<-may the earth spit me out») turned a perjurer
into the ghost known as bantu bungkus or
kaniolo’, q. v. The s. potong ayam is
practiced to this day even with the approval
of the Courts, as are also oaths on the Koran
(s. kuran) and oaths at shrines (s. keramat).
To take an oath "in Court is angkat s.
(because the hand is raised); to administer
the oath is mbmberi s. Then there is the
Chinese Secret Society oath with blood-drink-
iig (s. dan memakan darah); also private
assurances backed with oaths, cf. ia - pun
sudah bersumpah dengan aku (he had
sworn solemnly to me), Ht. Pdk. 91.
Sumpah also means «curse»; both;
(i) in the modern sense of mere bad
language (s. soranah, s. - serapah cursing
and swearing); cf. «the swearers* (s.-s.,
balek s.), a name given to certain lizards,
Calotes spp., because of their habit of
opening and shutting their mouths very often;
and
(ii) in the ol 1 sense of spell-change by
a curse (kena s.); cl. Mai. Pant. 223, and the
passage Beta di-s. oleh Betara Guru maka
beta jadi raksasa (I was cursed by Siva the
Teacher and turned into an ogre), Tk. iv


507. Finally there is the ultra-modern view;
Mati tidak karna suuipah, hidup tidak
karna kaul (curses don’t kill and vows don’t
save), Prov.
[The full wording of the kamolo’ oath is:
D6mi Allah, dSnii Rasul Allah, balau
sahaya berbuat kejahatan itu tidak - lah
sahaya akan be Cuban kapada Allah dan
bernabi kapada nabi Muhammad; kalau
sahaya mati biar jangau di - terima bnmi
(or di-sSmbiukau bnmi); Perch. Mai. 68].

SUilipit. I. Shooting with a blowpipe (sumpitan);

64). Sangkur s : spear-point for lashing to

nynmpit.
[The blowpipe or sarbacane is in common
use among the aborigines. It consists of an
inner and outer tube, the former being of a
special variety of bamboo (buloh temiang =
Bambusa wrayi). Temiang is used also
with the meaning The darts
(damak) inflict a trivial wound but they are
coated with dart-poison (ipoh) so as to be
deadly; cf. orang Melaka banyak mati oleh
sumpitan karna masa itu orang Melaka
belum tabu akan tawar ipoh (many men
of Malacca were slain by blowpipes for at
that time they did not yet know of the
antidote to dart - poison), Mai. Annals 126.
It would be interesting to learn what that
antidote was.]

Siinat. [Ar. sunn at] Traditional rule or custom,
proper conduct. In two special senses:
(i) commendable, in contr. to obligatory
(perlu); thus sSmbahyang s. are the two
extra daily prayers that Moslems should
repeat if possible but that it is not an actual
sin to omit; and
(ii) circumcision; cf. sunatkan (to circura-
cize); s. rasul (confirmation with circum-
cision); tidak bersunat (uncircumcized; lit.
Bugis 137); takang s. (circumcizer, = modin).
Circumcision is not obligatory though it is
invariable.
Ahli s.: traditionists, i. e. Sunnite
Moslems,
Sltllbllk. See snmbok (shallop).
sunbulat, [Ar.;=ear of corn], Virgo; the Sheaves;
the sixth sign of the Zodiac (Bost.


Sal. i 49); specifically the star Spica
Virgin! s=bintang mayang. For purposes
of divination Virgo is associated with the
earth the colour green, the civet-cat, the
stag, and the c ha m p a k flower. She is the
«star» of Elijah, is related to Venus and
dwells in the house of Mercury.

sundang. Sword-kris; Sulu kris. A heavy cutting
sword with a marked resemblance to a kris:
it is two edged; sharp-pointed; may be either
straight or sinuous; and has the ganja,
aring, lambai gajah and some other features
of the kris. It differs from the kris in
its size and massiveness and in its large
and serviceable cockatoo-headed handle.

sundang.

sungkai. Rooting up or turning up as a

sungkit. I. Kain sungkit: (Ked.) cloth embroidered
with gold or silver thread by a «digging
out* process (see chnngkil=Jav. m e n y u k i t),
i.e. by using a sharp point to pull out short
lengths of the silk of the fabric and then
substituting pieces of gold or silver thread.
Cf. also sulam. The aim of this process is
to avoid the rough surface of raised em-
broidery. Cloth woven with gold thread is
kain benang mas; cloth embroidered in the
usual way with gold is b6rtekat mas; this
drawn thread work is kain sungkit or (Joh.)
kain songket. Often met with; referred to in
literature; Ht. Koris, Ind. Meng., Kamp.
Boy. 10, Pant. Mai. 137.

suugkit: (Brun.) vaccinated; M.

xc 1. Menyungkur; to lower the head to
earth as a man bowing very low (Abd. Mk.
13) or as a bull presenting his horns to the
foe (Kal. Dam. 117). S.-sangkar: sprawling
about. S.-sembam: grovelling; Ht. Koris,
Ind. Meng. Jatoh tersungkur: to fall on
one’s face (Sg. Samb.) Nyiur sungkuran:
a coconut while still young and soft enough
to be scraped to pieces, i.e. before its shell
has hardened.

Sunni. Ar. Sunnite; traditionist; orthodox. Also
ahli sunat. Name given to the major portion
of the Moslem world; it accepted the autho-
rity of the recognized rulers of Islam after
Mohammed’s death while the <?Shiahs»
favoured the views of the house of Ali which
was usually in opposition to the established
authorities.

Of a mosquito injecting the malaria germ; of

serum, Sul. Ment. 48. Etym., of being
pierced by a thorn or needle or other fine
point.

sura. I [Ar. a shura] Bulan sura: a popular
name for the month Muharram because of
the «Ashura* fast on the 10th of that month.
This fast is really a survival of the Jewish
Day of Atonement. Bubur s.: a broth made
on this day; it contains egg, onion, maize,
etc., and is presented to the religious.

Also surat. Surat al-doa: «prayer-sura»;
first chapter of the Koran repeated as a
prayer.

surah I. Dressing the hair; (whence) dressed

Also: the mane of a horse.
