Surat. I. Thing written; letter; epistle. Suratan:
script; writing. Suratkan: to cause to be
written, e, g. to imprint on coins (Mai.
Annals 5). Of writings of all sorts, e. g.:
written charms (s. azhnat); Malay official
documents (s. chap); promissory notes (s.
hutang); writs of summons (s. saman, s.
sita); telegrams (s. kawat); letters of intro-
duction (s. kenalan); newspapers (s. khabar);
epistles (s. kiriman); orders to auction (s.
lelong,; patents (s. raenegah); written horo-
scopes (s. nujum); passes or permits (s. pas);
placards or posters (s. pblekat); powers of
attorney (s. wakil); and wills (s. wasiat).
For the technicalities of Malay letter-writing
see the Appendix to Winstedt’s Grammar.
The principal terms are: address (alamat s.);
contents (isi. s.); heading (kepala s.); com-
plimentary preamble (puji - pujian s.); to
reply (raSrabalas s.); written page (muka s.);
margin (rusok s.); a letter or epistle (sa -
puchok s.)
11. Surat belukar: a grass, Thoraco-
stachyum bancanum; W.
111. See surah (Koran chapter).
Surati, Appertaining to Surat in India. Surat rose
rapidly to importance at the end of the
Fifteenth Century and was a great trading -
port in the Sixteenth. It was a mart for
cheap Indian piece-goods. Itek S.: the Mus-
covy duck.
Surau. Name of the traditional maker of the
keris pichit.
surau. (Mai., Min.) A building that is not a
mosque of general assembly but is otherwise


devoted to religious or quasi-religious (e.g.
charitable) purposes; = (Ked., Pen., Pk.)
bnndarsah, (Java) langgar. It may be used
as a chapel; but if so used it lacks a lectern -
pulpit (millibar). It serves also as a rest-
house and Koran-school; in some places it
is a dormitory for unmarried men (cf. Maass
422, 539) or for men with no home of their
own.

SUSub. See susup (creep under).
susuhunan. [From Old - Javanese suhun - Mai.
junjong] A title borne by the so - called
Emperor of Java; = (Mai.) junjongan (he
whom we obey). Shortened to susunan and
sunan; used sometimes in pantuns of a
<dord» or «mistress».
[Historically the title was borne by the
powerful rulers of Mataram from whom the
present Susuhunan is descended. In 1749
A. D. came the partition into Surakarta
(under the Susuhunan) and Jogjakarta
(under the Sultan); this deprived the Susu-
hunan of about half his authority. His
lessened power was further curtailed by the
establishment of an independent Yamtuan
Muda at Surakarta (the Prince Mangku
N6gara)].

in quest of; Ht. Panj. 72, 80. Dapat di-s.
oleli musoh: might be overtaken (and
captured) by the enemy; Sid. Rama 73.
Kalau taliu sahaya susuli: had I known I
should have followed; Pant. Mai. 253.

suyok, (Min.) Projecting part of roof at the

T
ta. I. Name of two letters of the Malayo -
Arabic alphabet, viz.:
(i) a hard superdental pronounced by
Malays like the English T and having the
numerical value 400 in the abjad; and
(ii) an Arabic palatal T having the value
9 in the abjad.
Malays do not usually draw a distinction
between the two letters but they sometimes
pronounce the second gutturally and give a
throaty sound to whatever vowel follows it.
Alif - ba - ta; alphabet.
If. (Onom.) The «bang» of a gun. Pro-
nounced nasally.
111. See ta’ (not).
ta’. I. Not. A negative prefix. Exx.: fa’ -
baik (not good; bad); ta’ - usah (no need, —
a polite «don’t»): malm ta’ - malm (willy-
nilly). Sometimes written ta esp, in ta-
dapatiada (needs must), q.v. See also tan,
ta’ada and tidak.
11. = tak (whack).
taabir, = tabir (interpretation of dreams).
taada. See ta’ada (is not).
ta’ada. There is not; = ta’- ada. Also (coll.)
taada, tada; (Kel.) taadak; (Batav.) teradu;
(literary) tiada; = (Min.) indak. Taadak-
faadek: (Kel.) a strong negative; there
certainly is not.
taadak, taadek. See ta’ada.
taadzim. Ar. Great respect: honour. Taadzhnkan:
to revere. Member! t.; to pay all respect to.
Sembah t.: respectful homage. Dar al-t.:
see dar. Also taazim and (Lang. Buana
15) taalim.
taajub. [Ar.;=to wonder] Astonishment. Dengan
t.-nya: with surprise; Sid, Rama 139.
taala, Ar. «May He be exalted*. A prayer with
which it is usual to follow any mention of
the name of Allah, i.e. Allah taala (often
translated God Most High). T. is omitted
only in compounds (like wallah, bismillah)
which are regarded as single words. See
also subhan.
taalek or taalik. I. [Ar.; = suspension] Suspended
divorce, i.e. the pronouncing of a divorce
that only comes into effect when certain
conditions are fulfilled and is suspended ad
interim. Such «suspended divorces® are
customary if the husband is going on a long
journey and may never be heard of again:
<'six months by land, a year by sea, no
message or tidings, divorce then comes of
itself* (ka-darat 6nam bulan, ka-laut sa-
tahun, berita tidak, talak gugur sondiri-
nya). Nikah t.: a marriage accompanied by a
conditional divorce in this or similar terms,
e.g. to protect the bride against the worst
consequences of desertion. See «Rerabau», 85;
«Achehnese», i 349—366.
11. [Ar.; = suspension] «Attachment» (in
various figurative senses), e.g.: (i) having a
liking for; being taken with a person or a
story; (ii) having attached to you, as a man
keeps domestic animals (Arab. Nights 42);
(iii) being appended, as notes or explanatory
comments are appended to a text.
taalim. See taadzim (honour).
taalok. [Ar.;— to hang or cling to] Menaalokkan:
to bring into subjection or vassalage; to
conquer. Yang t.: subject; in dependence
upon (a suzerain),
taang, =tahang (tub).
taarif. Ar. Taarifkan: to announce; to make
known; to declare.
taat. Ar. Devotion to God (in the sense of
leading a God-fearing life); faith, as contrasted
with good works (atnal) and the carrying
out of formal religious obligations (ibadat).
taawil. Ar, Interpretation of ambiguous passages;
elucidation. Taawilkan mini pi: to interpret
a dream by expounding its real significance,
e.g. of Daniel interpreting the dream of
Nebuchadnezzar. Of. tafsir, tabir.


taayuil. [Ar.; inf. of ain, to eye] Determining;
specifying.
taazim. See taadzim (honour).
taba. See tabali (boldness).
tabah. I. (Min., N.S.) Laying the flat of the
hand heavily on anything, = (Mai.) tobali;
hand’s-breadth, as a linear measure, = (Mai.)
polempap, telempap. T. empatjari: breadth
of the hand measured across the fingers
(without the thumb). Daging petabah dua
jari: two-fingers’-breadth of buffalo-meat.
11. (Batav., from Bal.) Daring; boldness.
Also taba; Z.

tabong. Cylindrical vessel made of a single joint

T. kinchir: bamboo water-carriers on a
waterwheel (kinchir). Applied also to
cylindrical boxes of cardboard (t. kertas
tebal), Pet. Ayam 109. Essentially a one-
internode receptacle with no special features.
A bamboo vessel of one or more nodes is
(Pk.) bachok, (Ked.) pachok, (N.S.) p6rian,
(Java) bongbong. Varieties of the tabong
are the tukil (a Kedah type), sambang
(with a hole to simplify porterage), and
g6rigek (with a spout). See also tagek,
bongbong, berombong.

tabut. Ar. Ark-emblem; box-like framework of
lath with sides of coloured paper, carried in
procession on the 10th Muharam to com-
memorate the tragic defeat and death of the
Prophet’s grandson Husain; (loosely) any
processional emblem whether Moslem or not,
and so applied to images (kudu;=Pen., t.
KSling) carried in procession by Hindoos.
Etym., t. is the Ark of the Covenant; but
the processional emblem known as t. in
Malaya represents the tomb or shrine of
Husain at Kerbela and is known also as
durga (Pers. d a rga h = Kerbela shrine). It
is illd. by Herklots; and gives its name
(Sum. biilau tabut) to the Muharram month
bulan Hasan - Husain and (from the
illuminations) bulan api.
[Cf. the verse:

tahiat, =tahyat (greeting),
tahil. A measure of weight known widely. Best
known as the Chinese «tael» (i.e. 579. 84
grains of silver or nearly the weight of a
dollar and a half), But the word is not
Chinese; see mas, saga. In Malaya there are
two «taels»:
(i) the Chinese tael for weighing opium
=lO chi or 100 hun; and
(ii) the gold tahil (known also as bongkal),
=l6 mayam and representing the weight of
two Spanish dollars. In Java= 16 mas.

Banyak - lah t. daripada ta’-t.: «he knew
more than he did not know*, = his know-
ledge was above the average.
Tahu is used also of people ‘getting to
know*. Cf. (of secret messages):
Panggil abang didalam

a call from your flute will inform me; a

IT. (Batav.) A square yellow cake eaten
by Chinese; Z. From Ch.
talma. [Ch, than-a] Informer. Also anipama,

tahun. Year. «Years» are of various kinds: solar
(t. shamsiah); lunar (t. kamariah',; year
A.H. (t. hijrat); year A. D. (t. masehi);
seasonal from rice-crop to rice crop (t. padi);
or from maize-crop to maize-crop = three or
four months (t. jagong); or arranged in cycles
and named after letters or animals, see
daur, kop and windu. Sa-t. tutup: a full


year.
Menahun, bfirtahun - tabuu: chronic;
annual; year - long; e. g. demam menahun
(chronic malaria). T. baharu: New Year. T.
daliulu: last year. T. hadap: next year. T.
kabisat: leap-year;=(Biba) t. Inn. Belalang
t.; locust. Buah t.: windfall; thing that
rarely happens. Kepala t., sulong t.; early
days of year or undertaking. Bulan pen-
cheraian t : first month of a new year. Bu-
rong mati sa-tahun: (Pk.) plaited - casqued
horn hill, Cranorrhin us corrugatus.

tajak. I. Grass-cutter (like a short-handled golf-
club); illd. Veth xc 9, ci 4. Used for clearing
a field of weeds before planting rice. Varieties:
t. babur (broad - bladed), t. panjang (long-
handled). Mata t.: blade of a grass-cutter.
T. is applied also to the use of this
cutter, i.e., to weeding: t. giling (weeding,
and leaving the weeds to be forced into the
soil by the use of a penggiling or roller);
t. kaut (weeding, and casting the weeds on
the batas or partition - dykes); t. kfichar
(weeding, and stacking the weeds in mounds
to rot).

tajau. «3hanghai jar»; large jar of glazed earthen-
ware showing a pattern under the glaze. It
is practically identical with the tbmpayan;
but purists would say that the tajau has a
narrower mouth. The word is old; cf. mas
sa -1. (jar of gold), Ism. Yat. The Min.
tajau is a relatively small jar as there is a
proverb about using it. as a cooking - pot
laute d e mie u x.
taj6m. See tajam (sharp).
taji. Artificial spur for fighting-cock; illd. Veth
xlii 6. Also (Ind. Jaya) spur of a harpy
(walimana). The fighting - cock’s spur is of
two main types:
(ii) t. beutok: flat haft; blade slightly
curved; fastened on the side of the leg flush
with the natural spur; and, except for its
cutting edge, resembling the round spur with
the needle point used in Europe;
(ii) t. golok: rounded haft; blade of fancy


design, sometimes sinuous like a kris;
fastened across and under the claw.
Mfimbulang t.: to fasten the artificial
spur to a cock’s leg (only one spur is used)
by winding a thread about 6 feet long round
and round the spur and claw or leg. BSrom-
bong t.: case for holding artificial spurs; illd.
Veth xlii 1,2, 5. Ponggabus t.: a sort of
soft-wood cushion in which spurs are stuck;
illd. Veth xlii 3. Tuntong t.: point of spur.
The curve of a spur (t. di - bbntok) is a
common simile for a lovely eyebrow; Sg.
Samh., Gul Bak. 122.
tajin. (Min., Java, Pen., Baba) Starch, made
usually of riceflour; Kit. Muj. 47. Tajinkan:
to starch (linen); to make cloth waterproof
(Al. Mai. 28). Di - pSrbnnt untok t.. made
for conversion into starch; Üb. Kayu 3.
tajok, I. Short upward projection such as an
aigrette or a tholepin; tuft; ornament on
head; pegs fixed in a boat’s gunwale to
serve as supports for side - screens, awnings,
and quants; (Brun.) frames seeming the upper
planking to the dugout, M.
The ornamental t. (aigrette) is a tuft of
artificial flowers stuck into a bridal or festal
headdress, illd. Mai. Magic 378. ft has little
pendent chain - ornaments (t. mulai, t. goda-
bnh). The royal t. (t. mahkota) were fixed
in the traditional Malay crown (the crown
depicted on the Perak official buttons shows
three t.); but the word is now simply a term
of endearment; Kumb. Churab 13, Bur. Nuri
20.
The boat t. (t. pSraliu) looks like an
elongated tholepin. Two or more are attached
to each gunwale and are connected by a
crossbar (tufup t.). On this bar the kajang
awning may rest. The t. may be used as a
tholepin (Pen. t. dayong, Sp. fill), the bar
being attached to it by a thole-strap (tali
t.); it may cany the oars when not in use;
and it serves to give additional free - board
when waterproof matting is attached to it.

takoh. Takoh - takah; (Ked.) notched; jagged;

takok. I. Notch. OF angular cuts on coconut -
palms to help climbers; of the notch in a
swallow - tailed flag; of simple grooves for
joining planks in carpentry; of felling trees
by means of a notch cut into the side on
which the tree is intended to fall. Slight
cuts for tapping latex are takek; narrow deep
incisions are tokek; the more elaborate processes
in joinery, such as dovetailing, have names ot
their own. In tree-felling the takok weakens
the tree on one side; the actual felling is
done at a higher level and on the opposite
side.

taiak. I. Ar. Divorce - formula; divorce (of the
wife by the husband). T. tiga: tiiple (and
complete) divorce. Gfugur t.: the «fall» (i.e.
the pronouncing) of a divorce by the husband.
Menjatohkan t.; to «drop», i.e. to pronounce,
a divorce; Ht. Panj. 123. Tfibus t.: the
obtaining of a divorce by the wife through
(tebus), i.e. by the of
her settlements (niahar). Glila t.: «divorce-
inad»; a description of a man who divorces a
wife in a fit of temper and annuls the divorce
immediately afterwards. Berchcrai sulah,
t. tidak: «apart but undivorced*, —said of
lovers in separation (cf. Mai. Dem. 59); and
also of grass-widows and grass-widowers.
[Under Moslem law a husband may
divorce his wife by the utterance of a talak-
formula, «I divorce thee». He is then given
a certain time in which to recall her or not,
see idah: at the end of that time if she is
unrecalled the divorce is complete and she
may marry again. But a triple divorce (t.
tiga) whether the three taiak are uttered
together nr have been uttered on different
occasions and cancelled—is final; and the
man may only remarry his wife by a fresh
marriage - ceremony after she has been
married to some - one in the interval, see
muhallil. A woman cannot divorce her
husband; but (for good reasons) she may get
a Judge to order her husband to divorce her
in which case she forfeits her settlements;
or again she may get the Judge to declare
the marriage no longer in force (pasah
nikah), in which case she maj' retain her
settlements].

another, e.g. for holding gambier. Cf. telap.
talam. [Tam.; Tk.] Platter; tray (without pedestal);
illd. Mayer i 80. T. dua muka: «tray with
two surfaces*, i.e. double-faced. Saga di-
atas t.: epea on a platter*; vacillating;
wobbling. The word is common in literature
(Hg. Tuah, Mai. Annals, etc.). For pedestal-
trays see pahar, semberip and dalong.
Other flat trays are dulang (with upright
rim), kerikal (large size), and bandea, tabak,
nanampan, tMampan, penampan (trays
for gifts).

Talang, Orang Talang: name given to a number
of Proto-Malayan communities on the East
Coast of Sumatra, e.g.: Talang Gasip, T.
Kutip, T. Dayun and T. Pandan. They
have become Moslems and follow the Adat
Minangkabau but retain many of their
primitive customs and beliefs.

benangh throat-latch (t. rahang); bellyband

(iv) ropes in a ship’s rigging (see below);
(v) miscellaneous cords and ropes: t. agas,
t. anggas, t. kala, t. keleleh, t. sgnam, t.
singkil (rope-support for woman in labour);
t. alit, t. gasing, t. soring (string for spin-
ning top); t. anibin (strap round a load); t.
anak (small auxiliary rope); t. andoh (gun-
lashings); t. api (slowmatch for giving a light
at any time); t. bahu, t. kepala (straps
attaching a knapsack to a man’s shoulders
and head); t. bindn (cord working a lathe);
t. ccndang (su) ports of swinging cot); t.
jontera, benaugt. kinchin, kelindan (thread
in process of being spun); t. kail, t. pepas
(fishing - line); t. kalicitut (see kanchnt); t.
pupoh (see pupoh); t. relap (rope with

for driving buffaloes); t. semberttng, t. sidai,
t. ponyidai kain (clothes - line); t. suchi
(Brahminical thread); t. taudur (cords for
blinds); t. tSmali (cordage generally); t. tb-
rendak, t. tudong (laces for sun-hat); bakal

driftwood where two currents meet); t.

strips of banana); t. pusat (umbilicus, navel-


cord); t. puteri (plant, Cassytha filifor-
mis, the basis of a Malay hairwash); t. sipat
(carpenter’s line); akar t. (climbers, Gnetum

rhynchus?); awan t. ayer (linear pattern);
bunga t. -1. (flowering | lant, Quamoclit
pinnata); batu t. sipat (plumb-bob).
The word tali may be prefixed to any of
the many names of ropes in use on a boat
but is often omitted in the case of ship’s
ropes (the «lascar» word being used by itself);
see anja (halliard), batli (buntline), daman
(sheet), gai (guy-rope), labSrang (shrouds),
perdi (stays), ' sekat (ratlines), sbtinggi
(brails), sidul (leech-line), utara (downhaul).
A few lascar terms and most names of ropes
on a Malay prau have tali prefixed, viz.:
t. bawat (brace); t. bosa, t. kap (stopper for
cable); t. bubutan (downhaul): t. Chungking
(peak halliard); t. chemat, t. pcnchfimat
(warp, towrope); t. dahi layar (short cords
at the boom-ends serving as brails); t. dogang
(rope-support; ropes for use of men hanging
out to windward as live - ballast); t. duga,
t. pelnga (sounding - line); t. kblat (boat’s
sheet); t. lenggang (preventer - stay); t. pen-
chachi (loop for reefing - lever); t. pendarat
(hawser); t. pendondang (truss - tackle); t.

Bertali: attached (by a cord); having a
tie or connection of any sort. Bertali ka -
Siak; «having ties with Siaks; a description
of the political position of the old State of
Negri Sembilan. Bfirgantong tidak bertali;
♦dependent, yet by no legal tie/>, = the

11. A measure of value, always represent ing
three wang or from 6 to 25 guilder - cents.

111. See taligrap, taligram.
IV. Awi tali: (Java) bamboo; gen, for

(Min.) talang.
V. A name for the third variety of card
in a short chicky - suit. Also tinu. See
cheki.
Talib. A proper name; short for Abdul-mutalib,
see Abdul and mutalib. Commonly pronounced
Talip.
talib. Ar. A seeker after truth; an earnest
student of religion.
talibun. Ode. (The talibun is rare in Malaya and
no examples from the Peninsula have yet
been published. For Sumatran examples see
Van Hasselt 140—142. Unpublished examples
collected by me in Singapore differ from the
pantim and shaer in that all the lines of
the ode—usually about 10 or 20 rhyme
together. These odes may be written in jest
(talibun kelakar), or in praise of some
object (t. jcnang), e. g.: sahaya talibnnkan
ambar dan jebat (I sing the praise of
amhergis and musk), or
Ahi! Bataug turi,
Urat-nya panjang, pohon-nya tinggi,
Daun-nya kechil, tidak persegi;
and so on. The ode often ends with a verse
or pantuu appealing to the generosity ot the
patron or audience, e. g.:
Ya Allah Tuhan yang bahari,
Serf,a cuche’ inuda bbstari,
Harap-lah dagang sa - hari - hari
Akan tempat bengantongkan dlrl].
talifun, Eng. Telephone. Also telefuu, (N. I.)
talipon. Pukul t.: to use the telephone.
taligram. (Pen.; from Eng.) Telegram; also surat
kawat; cf. taligrap.
taligrap. Eur. Telegram. Kawat t.: telegraph line.
Also tali gelap, and (Pen.) taligram.
talimpong, See tolimpong (five gongs on stand).
talin. Burong siti talin: (Pk.) a bird, sp. unid.

Talip. See Talib.
taiipok. See tolipok (water- lily).
talipon. (N. 1.) Telephone; Waj. Hak, 24, = ta-
lifun.


talkin. [Ar.; = instruction] Exhortation to the
dead. A short address in Arabic repeated by
the presiding elder at the close of a funeral
service. It is addressed to the dead man
(who is believed to sit up and listen to it),
and consists of good advice on the replies he
should give to the questions of Munkar and
Nakir, the Interrogators of the Bead. Water
(ayer t.) is then sprinkled over the grave;
and the mourners leave the cemetery. Cf.
Mai. Pant. 248 (on love till death), Sudah
herd bran ayer t. baharu - lah puas kelien-
dak hati: when the burial-drops plash (on
the grave dug for me) my heart shall have
rest from its longing.
Popularly: telekin.

097. Cf. talap.
11. See tblok (bay).
talon. Tree-name; Ryparosa spp., W.

head; puggaree. Also terpah.
talu. I. Bertalu: continuous; one after the
other; in unbroken succession. Bertalu-talu:
id. Of such things as a continuous flow of
bad language (mbngata bertalu - talu), Sg.
Ranch. 29; of prolonged weeping (ayer mata-
nya jatoh bertalu-talu), Bur. Nuri 34; and
of gongs being beaten without any break
(lit. Bugis 42, 152). Cf. also: Ch. Jen. 90,
Ht. Pdk. 19, 21.

tampang. I. (Pah.) A tin token used as a medium


of exchange on the East Coast. It had the
shape of the modern slab or cist ingot of
smelted tin (jongkong timah); but it was
usually hollow. In Abdullah’s time sixteen
Pahang tampang represented the value of a
dollar (Pel. Abd. 14). If solid the tampang
was known as t. roman (small) or t. jong-
kong (large).
11. Cutting and fastening up. Of plant-
cuttings, such as mango-cuttings (t. mangga,
Tan. Mangga 2) for grafting, or tapioca
cuttings for planting - out (Üb. Kayu 4); of
bunches of young rice-stalks (t. padi) prepared
for manuring; of a midwife cutting and tying
up the navel-cord; of a doctor fastening up
an artery.

tanah. I. Land, i.e.:

(land quite ready for cultivation); t. tenggala

Kalau yn kaaehkan kami

And so if j’ou love, you can show me devotion
With a spadeful of earth by just damming
the Ocean.

T. boti, t. chenia; incriminating circum-
stantial evidence; = (Ked.) mdngk6rcnali.
Often simply tanda. Minangkabau adat or
common law relied more on real than on oral
evidence; e.g. «for arson the butt of a torch,
for poison the remains of the meal*, etc. Cf.
link mu terdiri dftngan saksi, adat tfirdiri
dengan t. (canon law trusts to witnesses,
common law to the evidence of facts).

T. is used (Mai.) to describe (i) Javanese

tandan. Peduncle or stem of fruit that grows in
combs or bunches. a cluster cf such fruit
being sa - tandan or sa-kaki, a single fruit
sa-tangkai. T. is used also (Peng. Kuda
43) of the solid part of a horse’s tail out
of which the hairs (bulu eknr) grow. Ekur
puteh sa-t.-nya: tail of pure white (in a
horse).
tandang. Travel; visiting; going to see people or
countries. In the form t. desa (wandering
in foreign lands) the word is common in
literature (Sg. Samb., Ind. Jaj'a, Sri Ben.


34, etc.), but has bad associations as the
ancient Malays did not travel for pleasure
and looked with suspicion on gentlemen of
the road (orang t. desa). Today t. is rather
«visiting»; e.g., it is used of a football team
visiting an out-station to play a match. Cf.
also the proverb orang baharu nikah jangan
di-t. (don’t go visiting a newly-married man);
and the passage tiada-lali pgrnali orang
kdinderaan porgi kadalam dunia bertau-
clang-tandang dengan orang dunia (never
yet have fairies of Heaven gone down to the
world on visits to the children of men), Pg.
Ttg. Rumah bertandang dudok: a house to
stay at; Ch. Jen. 11. See also adar.

hurling a spear at a fleeing man and so
degrading him to the position ol a hunted
animal. But cf. tondong.

Made by fastening to a pole the ends of a

111. See tangada (to be there).
tangada. (N. 1., coll.) To be there; = datang-ada.
tangah, See tengah (mid).
tangan. Hand. Anatomically, t. is the lower arm
and hand —in contr. to the arm above the
elbow (Rngan); it is used also specifically
of the body of the hand in contr. to the
fingers (jari). In most cases, however, it is
translatable by <'hand», both literally and
metaphorically. T. bertangkup: malformation
suggesting crossed hands. T. terbuka, (Baba)
t. lebar: open-handed; generous. T. tfirko-
kot: hands clawlike through disease. BSr-
tangan kosong, bbrhainpa t.: empty-handed.
Berpegang t.: hand in hand. Bek as t.:
sign-manual; handiwork. Bclakang t.: back
of hand. B6rasap t.: see asap. Bibir t., tem-
biring t.: side of hand. £uah t.: little gift
taken along with him by a giver. Gergaji
t.: handsaw. Hati t.: hollow of palm. Ibn t.,
biting t.: thumb. Kaku t.; callosities on
hand. Lapek t.: scrubbing-glove. Main
t.: gesticulation. Panjang t.: thievish. Pan-
las t.; deft. Retak t.: lines on hand Sarong
t.: glove. Sapu t.. kerchief; wiper; headcloth;
cf. setangan. Tanda t.; signature; sign -
manual. Tapak t.: palm. Tari t.: sword dance
without weapons, = silat. Tumitt.: centre
at base of palm. Kedua bolali t.: both hands.
Didalatn t.: in the hands (i.e., in the power)
of others.
The meaning «arm» comes out in the
expressions: jantong t. (triceps muscle);
p6nggelang t. or pergelang t. (wrist); and
kaki t. (limbs, also <'helpei»). T. also means
«sleeve» (t. baju, lengan baju) and «handle*
when the handle is bar-shaped, e.g. t. ko-
mudi (tiller - bar). For t. = possession, cf,
Mai. Pant. 254, 255, 256, ending Sial t.,
malting t., didalatn t. orang punya: «that
cursed hand, ill-omened hand, that hand that
owneth her* I
Also of ghostly «hands», i.e. an evil
spirit of which the hands only are visible;
Tk. ii 820, see below.
[The full passage is: Ilantu alas ada
yang kopala stiliaja dan ada yang tangan
sahaja dan ada yang tuboli sahaja dan
ada yang kaki sahaja dan ada yang
kblepir sahaja. When the Perak New
Territory was being taken over by Sir E.
Birch a Mala}' had a vision of this sort:
elephants’ trunks and tusks lighting without
having any elephants attached to them. It
proved to be the prelude to an attack of
homicidal mania. The Resident had a narrow
escape from assassination and the man died
within a few hours of his arrest.]

tangar. (Batav.; from Bal.) Prudent; careful:

tangasa, (Java) Tocsin; alarm; B. Cf. sfiniboyan.

tangek. I, (N.S) Nasal twang; = chengi.


11. (Min.) Block; to shut tightly; to
close an orifice.
tangga. I. House - ladder; stair-case; a numeral
coefficient for any aid to climbing of the
-ladder* type, e.g : t. pAigait (flexible and
portable for tree - climbing), t. sigai (peg-
-I,' dder, portable) and t. sulur batang (pegs
in trunk of tree to be climbed). Usually a
t. is a broad ladder of two or three rungs
(anak t., mata t.), the lowest being t. hongsu
and highest t. sulong; it leads to the door
of the homestead verandah. The usual Min.
word is janjang, tangga being little used
there; but a distinction is sometimes made
(Min.) between the two words tangga (stair-
way to house) and janjang (ladder to loft).
Rumah t.: home; (fig.) wife; wife and
family. Bertangga - fangga: at lifth or sixth
hand. Susur t.: balustrade of staircase.
Kotak t. mas: lines running across the
fingers at the joints. Tolak t. berayun
kaki: «push away the ladder by which you
climb and your feet will be left dangling in
the air*; said of people who forget their old
supporters, and of others who «fall between
two stools*.
If. Tangga - fangga: (Batav.) hospital -
assistants; telangga.
tanggaga. (Min.) Importunate; troublesome; Tn.
tanggah. See peuanggah (cook-house).
tanggak. A variant of tagak (postpone).
tanggal. I. Dropping; falling off; (naut.) being
unbent, of sails. Of things that seem to fall
spontaneously, e.g. of leaves in autumn, of
teeth lost with advancing years, of skin cast
by a snake (kulit nlar yang sudah t., Ht.
Haiw.), etc. Tanggalkan pakaian, or men-
nnggalkaii pakaian: <Bo shed one’s garments*;
to strip; to disrobe; Sg. Samb., Hg. Tuah
35, lit. Angg. 22, Gul Bak. 40. Gee also
penanggalan (evil spirit; a severed head and
dropping entrails).
11. (Batav.) New moon; first day of lunar
month; Tk.
tanggala, = tbnggala (plough).
tanggam. Rectangular groove cut into a plank to
allow of its being joined on firmly to another
plank; scarf-joint. Takok t.: id. Bertang-
gain: interlocked (as fingers); spliced (of rope).

tangkul. I. Lifting-net. A large square net held
open b} 7 diagonal cross-pieces; it is laid at
the bottom of a stream and attached to a
lever working on a post. The t. is baited and
is lifted out as fish collect over it.
Pukat t.: ground-net laid on the bottom
of the sea in shallow water to cover a fairly
large area. When fish collect over it the
sides are lifted to prevent the fish escaping,
the fish so enclosed being caught easily.
Also used in deep water with floats.
11. Tree, Calophyllum canum; W.
tangkup. Capture under a hollow. Also (Java)

ka-bantal, ib. 211).

Dato’ Maharaja Lela who stood by the

tap. Tap-tup: (onom.) the patter of feet;
Perch. Mai. 25.
tapa. I. Skr. Ascetic devotion; mortification of
the body to develope the mind and soul.
Specifically the name given to the austeri-


ties practised by Hindu recluses in ancient
Java (see ajar - ajar and übun-übun);
eleven forms of these penances are known
(E.N.1., s.v. tapa), one (t. slinger.ngj is
referred to in the Hr. gang gamba. T. is used
also loosely of Moslem devotion; strictly
speaking it is riadzat (self - mortification),
but is generally identified with khalwat
(solitary seclusion) which involves no real
training of the flesh. Malay romances regard
tapa less as a religious exercise than as a
way of securing magical power; cf. porla-
paan - nya - pun tiada satnpai, jadi terban-
tut-lah (his austerities came to nothing;
they were countered by others), Hg. Tuab
175.
Bertapa: to retire from the world and
devote oneself to a life of austerities. Pbrta-
paau: asceticism. T. sungsang: the «bat -
penance*, i.e. living with one’s feet tied to
a tree-bough and one’s bead and shoulders
resting on the ground. Ranjuua T.: see
Ilanjuna. Bongkar dari dalam t.: to break
off a penance; to get a respite; Ind. Meng.
Bagiuda pun menjadi fakir sangat pertapa
kapada Allah: the Sultan became an ascetic
and was severe in self-discipline to do the
will of God; Raj. Sul. 13.
If. Tapa-tapa: pieces of fish sliced very
thin, spiced, salted and dried in the sun.
Daging t. -t.: meat treated in the same way.
Also dendong and (Pk.) buari; tetapa is
used of thin slices of pineapple sprinkled
with sugar (Hn.).
111. (Min.) To strike; to hammer (in the

IV. See tapah.
tapah. Ikan tapah: large catfish; gen. for
Walla go spp. W. leerii is (Pk.) t.
bbrnban. W. mio stoma is (Pah.) t. danau,
(Pk.) t. rawang. Unid.: (Pah.) t. daun and
(Pah.) t. kdra. Also (Batav.) ikan cltaba.
[Sometimes called ikan tapa and explained
as «the hermit*. But the form tapah occurs
in other Indonesian languages and the name
is probably older than Hinduism],
tapai. I. Yeast; leavened cake; fermented drink.
Also (Java) tape. Specifically tapai is a
fermenting mixture made of boiled rice and
ragi. In modern Malaya it is used most
commonly as yeast for making leavened
cakes (tapai, kueh t., t. bungkus, t. lamhak,
etc.), unleavened but otherwise similar cakes [
being tepong. In literature it occurs rather j
in the sense of fermented drink. The ferment- j
ing mixture was put into a large jar (tapal-
un—tepayan or tempayan) along with rice,
maize, molasses, or other material and was ;
allowed to ferment. If fermentation was j
incomplete a light alcoholic drink (tapai,
sajung t., or «rice - beer*) was brewed; cf. j
ia mbmbnat t. dan di - buboh - nya rachun
(she brewed some beer and mixed poison
with it), Ht. Panj. 18. With complete
fermentation a strong spirit was made, either
unflavoured (t. arak) or flavoured (t. beram),
see arak and bfiram.

one near it in Cancer.

tarah. I. Planing with an adze; shaping; rough-

into the outline of what it is intended to be,
finer carving (ukir) being done with a knife
(pisau wall). T. kasau: a pattern in tooth -

Penarek or panarekan: portage; place
where a canoe can be hauled from one river
to another. [The best known pgnarekan
was near the modern Bahau where boats


could he hauled quite easily from the Muar
waterbasin to that of the Pahang and so
cross from sea to sea. This was the old trade -
route across the Peninsula.]

tari. 1. Dancing. Gen. (Mah, Min.) for all
dance-movements; = (Java) fandak, (Sund.)
igal. Cf. posta menari, pesta dangsa (ball
= dance); penari dan penyanyi (dancers
and singers), Ht. Pan). 43; menari chara
Melayn (to dance in the Malay style), Hg.
Tuah 54. But since the Malay style differed
from the Javanese and Sundanese the word
tari (like tandak and igal) has come to be
associated with a special style of dancing.
Tari attaches beauty and meaning to the
graceful swaying of the arms. Tari is asso-
ciated also with country or folk - dances and
not with the town professional dancers who
have special names (ronggeng, talodek, jo-
get, tuyul, pelandok, garaboh, topeng). Cf. t.
jangkar (see jangkar); (Min.) t. keris, t.
sewar, t. sikin (sword or dagger - dance),
illd. Veth ix 1, = (Mai.) main penchak; t.
piring (platter-dance), illd. Yeth ix 2, =
(Mai.) t. inai; t. kipas (fan-dance), illd. Yeth
xxxvi3; t. sfilendang (scarf-dance), illd. Veth
ix 3; t. tangan (sword-dance without any
weapons), = Mai. silat; etc.

taring. Large projecting canine tooth; tusk. Of
the visible tusk of a boar or mousedeer (Sh.
Kub., Ht. Pdk. G, 64, Sg. Ranch. 22); of
the canine teeth of a horse (Sul. Ment 4).
Practically synonymous with sioug; purists
distinguish between siong (long canine tooth)
and taring (its projecting portion). Actually
siong is used of the visible tusks of ogres
and wild men like the g6rgasi of Kedah;
taring of the tusks of animals; and canine
teeth in man are described in Baba Malay
as gigi t. = (Mai.) gigi siong and gigi
asu. The tusk of an elephant (gading) is
not an enlarged canine.

buaya; tree, Dolichandrone rheedii;
W. Misai bertaring: turned up moustache
(affected by Malay warriors). Jadi -la It sa -
ekur babi tunggal terlalu besar panjang -
lab maka ia bSrtaring dua bersiongan: he
became a lone boar of great height and
length, tusked with two huge canine teeth;
Mar. Mah.

tarum. Indigo-plant (indigo-dye is nila). Usually
Indigofera tinctoria, the Indian indigo-
plant, known specifically as t. daun lebar.
The Natal and Guatemala varieties are t.
daun halus. T. Siam: plant, Strobilan-
thes f 1 acid ifo 1 i us; Bid. T. hutan: Di-
dissandra frutescens; Bkl. Akar t.
(from which a native indigo is also obtained):
Marsdenia tinctoria. Native nila is
made by cutting up tarum - leaves, steeping
them in water, and finally boiling them with
lime or chalk.
Adjectivally t. = «dark - coloured*; e.g.
Imrimau t., pari t., rusa t., talang t., etc.

Buah t.: (i) icsaiy - bead made from the
hard seed of the shot-plant (Ganna indica
= bungat.); (ii) prayer-bead of any material.
Rosary - beads are made of: carnelian
(akek); mother-of-pearl (sadaf); olive-stone
jbnah zetun): ebony (abnus); akar bahar;
onyx (hafu snlaimani); coral (inerjan); and
buah jelai (seeds of Coix lacryma-jobi
from which toy rosaries are made).

tasek. Lake. Etym., the sea: cf. asin, niasin,
temasek, pasir, and the expressions arnan
t., pusat t. and t. pauh janggi, see arnan,
pusat and pauh. Used of lakes in the
Peninsula and in parts of Sumatra; lake =
da nan in other parts. Cf. ada sa - buah t.
torlalu luas sepSrti hint rupa - nya (there
was a lake of vcy great size, looking like
a sea), Mai. Annals 17. In some expressions,
e. g. inenabnr bijan ka - tasek (to sow
sesamum on the waters) it is not clear
whether Hake* or «sea» is meant. Pari t.:
(Pat.) a ray, sp. unid.

tatalu I. Jav. Chisel; punch; = Mai. pahat and
illd. Raffl. Common in Malay literature in
the secondary sense of studding or sticking
objects into an alien surface. Cf. t. mutia
(inlaid with mother-of-pearl). Usually of
jewellery being studded with precious stones
(bertatahkan ratna nmtu inanikam), Hr.
Koris, Cr. Gr. 42, Gnl Bak. 40, Pant. Shi.
13, Hg. Tuah 300; of a headdress adorned
with jewellery (destar btSrtafah); also in one
passage of the, stars being embedded (mena-
tiilt) in the sky, Sid. Rama 100. In coll,
speech it is used occasionally of almonds
stuck into a cake or raisins into a dish of
rice; pahat is confined to punches and
chisels and their use.

tatang, I. Carrying on the upturned palm of the

the expression sep£rti monatang in inyak yang
pbnoh (as one carries a bowl full of oil),
usually a simile for assiduous attention by a

A I'd. Mk. 22) or by a mother to her child

suri siang dan malani (day and night he
waited on his queen); Ht. Best. T. di-anak
lidah (carrying on the uvula) is another
proverbial expression; —an impossible
situation.

Meinohonkau t.; to ask aid of God; Kal.

tauge. Ch. Bean-sprouts prepared as a condiment
for Chinese dishes eaten with rice. The
bean used is Phaseolus radiatus
(kachang hijau, kachang chindai) which
gives its Chinese name also to a bean-shaped
ear-drop (anting-anting tauge) worn by
Chinese and urban Malay women. The name
k. tauge is given also to a black-seeded
variety of V i gn a sinensis.
Also taugek, Sh.
taugek. See tauge.
tauhid. Ar. Unity; the Unity of God; doctrine
of God’s Unity; Mil. Annals 222, Ch.
Jen. 6, Bost. Sal. i 64. The term includes


nearly all Moslem doctrinal religion. To the
mystic it means not so much that God is
One as that he is All-embracing. Historically
it may not have been so much insistence on
the unity of God as an insistence on the
divinity ot Allah as the only'- God the
others worshipped at Mecca being put aside
as of no account; see s.v. Allah. It was this
rejection of the other Meccan deities that
explains the bitter hostility aroused by the
Prophet’s teaching.
Makam T.; an old Johor capital.
tauhu. Ch. Bean curd (shaped but not pressed);
iln.
tank. I. (Ked.) To throw; to hurl. T. snub: to

tauke. Ch. «Towkay»; Chinese employer of labour
or financier behind an enterprise; descriptive

labur; capitalist supplying funds to group of
■workers. T. panglong: resident agent, of such
a capitalist.

taul. Fastening (an oar to the gunwale to

tauladan. See teladan (model, example).
taulan. Tam. Friend; comrade; associate: Ht.
Abd. 15. Also (Min.) tolan. The word con-
notes companionship more than affection.
ITaiidai t.: friends and companions; one’s
circle. In one passage taulan is used to
translate the Arabic rafik and precludes
the idea of intimacy; yang taulan itu t.Maha-
tinggi juga (the companionship that I desire
is that of the Most High), Bost. Sal. ii 51.
These Malay words translate the (Arabic)
traditional last words of the Prophet.
taulat. See tulah (misfortune) and claulat (divine

lauliah. (Trengg., from Ar.) Commission; letter of

taun, I. Ar. Pestilence; epidemic, esp. cholera.

taurat or taurit. [Ar.; from Hebrew.] The «Thora*
or Law ol Moses (etyin.); the Hebrew
Scriptures; the Old Testament. Kitab t.: id.
Ahli t.: the people of the Old Testament;
the Jews. Kertas yang sudah tersurat da-
ripada t.: a piece of paper on which was
written a text from the Hebrew scripture;
Isk. Dz.
[Malays regard the Christian Bible as made
up of the taurit, the zabur (Psalms), and
the injil (New Testament). T. has three
meanings: (i) the Hexateuch (ii)the whole of the
Old Testament;and(iii|t he ( Id Testament minus
the Psalms. The first meaning rests on
etymology; the third on popular belief. The
second comes out clearly in the Malay story
of the preparation ot the Septnagint: pada
inasa itu-lah taurit di-pindahkan segala
nlama Yunan duripada bahasa Ibrani ka-
pada bahasa Yunan, itu-lah taurit yang
sah, Best, Sal. i 10b.]
taut. I. Kayu taut, baur t., or joran t.: night-
line with rod-attachment; = (Hed.) chiding,
(Kel.) hiding.
11. = tanp (to lit together).
tauyu. Ch. Bean-sauce; Chinese ketchup.
tawa or tawa’, I. Tbrtawa: laughter. Torfawa -
tawa: continuous laughter. Tertawa gelak -
gelak: loud laughter. Tunipang tertawa: to
join iu a laugh. The form tawa’ or tawa
is common in Northern Malaya; cf. the proverb
man tawa’ baik bftrgigi: «it you want to
laugh, it is as well not to be toothless*.

kukuk - kikik: to snigger; Sh. Terlawa bbr-

laughter.

tawacLu. Ar. Performing ablutions before prayer-;
arriving at an age at which such ablutions
have to be performed, i. e. at the age of
puberty.
tawar. [Ar.; = encompassing] Making the circuit
of a Holy Place, esp. c-t the Caaba on the
Mecca pilgrimage; cf. apa yang di-uchap
tuan-hamba tatkala tawaf itu (what, Sirs,
were you repeating to yourselves when you
were making the circuit of the Caaba), Host.
Sal. i 69. Cf. taafali, tawa'if. Also (coll.)
tawap.

tawa'if. Ar. Mulnk al - tawa’if: tribal or divisional
rulers; see taefah. This name is given by
Moslem Historians (cf. Host. Sal. ii 14) to
the Diadochi or Successors of Alexander.
tawajoh. [Ar. and Hind.) Hati tawajoh: a heart
that is turning Godward. A mystic term.
tawak. I. Tawak - tawak, tetawak, or gong
tawak - tawak: name given (Sum., Borneo)
to gongs used for calling people together- or
for signals of any sort (cf. Ht. Bugis 34,
42, 121), and not forming part of an
orchestra for musical purposes. They are
true 'gongs in type (with deep rims and
hemispherical bosses); hut are smaller in size
than the instrument specifically named gong
in the gamSlan.

111. See taw a’ (to laugh).
tawakal or tawakkul. Ar. Submissive acceptance
of God’s Will. Interpreted by mystics as
representing man’s obligation to accept what
God gives him and not to trouble about the
things of the world. But popularly it means
accepting the inevitable or trusting to luck.
Untong t.: hoping for the best and prepared
to accept the worst. la - pun bertawakal -
lah; he put his trust in God (and took the
risk); Ht. Bangs. G. Habis nkal bertawa-
kal: what can’t be cured must be endured;
Prov. Tawakal - lah aku kapada Allah: 1
resigned myself to God’s Will; Ht. Abd.
222. Cf. also Sri Ben. 7, Gem. Ht. 32.
Bertawakal is transformed sometimes in
colloquial speech to batu akal.

For (i) cb: ayer t. (fresh water, in contr.

used by midwives to counter trouble in

s pec ios us); but see also Mai. Magic 78-80
for others.

t?buan. (Mai.) Hornet; (Min.) a bee, Trigona
mi nut a. Also tabohan, esp. in literature.
Explained sometimes as a derivative from

tSbus. To redeem or ransom, esp. of getting

cf.: mfinebus kaus (to redeem a pawned pair

(gift usually made by a br;degio< m to secure

(storehouses so heavily mortgaged as to be
past redemption and so having to bn sold),
Bint. Timor. Also of a wife buying her
freedom (t. talak) by paying back or
forfeiting her settlements; see khuln’.
To tebus a debt-slave meant to buy out
Lis indebtedness to his former master. This
d;d not extinguish the debt but transferred
it to a new owner. Hence the expressions
hnmba (Hg. Tuah 379) and sahaya
tbbusan (Bost. Bal. ii 40) do not mean
«freedmen» but debt-slaves acquired by
payment from other masters, i.e. bought
slaves.

Teh. Short for Putoh (as a proper name).
teh. 1. (Sp.; from Ch., = Pen. cha) Tea; the
product of Camellia theifera. Also te.
Known to Malays through the prepared tea-
leaf (daun tbli) and the beverage (avert.);
«tea-plant» (pokok t.) is the name given to
an ornamental shrub, Panax fructicosus.
T. niakau; a weed, Scoparia dulcis.
Minnm t.: to lake tea. See teko, tekoan, tesi.
The name te is given also to a plant,
Acalypha siamensis from the leaves of
which a tea is made.
|The Chinese word te is the Amoy name.
In the Changchow dialect spoken by the
Straits Chinese the word is ehha; and the
use of (eh in Malay suggests that tea was
known through ships from Amoy before
being used by settlers from Changchow.]

teja. I. Skr. Lurid sunset • clouds. Etym., a
vertical shaft of yellow light at sunset that
was believed to portend the death of a royal
personage, cf.: lit. Amrg. 16 (where it is a
portent of a queen’s death); Sg. Samb. (at
the death ofßanjunaand Samba); Sh. Kub.;
etc. Its vertical character (see Tk. ii 734)
is supported by a Sh. Kub. passage (teja
mEmbangun ka - tongah langit). Modern
Malays use the word of golden sunset-clouds
generally; and they are often horizontal
rather than vertical. T. kbluang: glow in
the sky after a rainstorm.

Sg., Sh. Ul. 6.

(i) Usually of the eggs of poultry. T.
aain: «salted eggs#, i.e. duck’s eggs preserved

tSmpayan. Water-jar; = (Ked.) tepayan, (Min.)
tampayan, (Ach.) layan, Etym., a fermenting
jar (tapaian); now used loosely of any large
jar such as a «Rangoon jar», «Shanghai
jar», «Martaban», or Dyak burial jar. Used
(Mai.) for preparing and storing fish pickled
in brine (t. budu, t. peda); cf. for storing
lard (ininyak babi sa-t., Mai. Annals IDG);
and, most of all, for storing water, cf. the
proverb pcchali bnyong t. ada (if the jug
be broken the storing-jar is always there
to supply fresh water), = there are lots of
good fish in the sea. Varieties are: the old
and true <'Martaban» or Rangoon jar (t.
taban); and the modern narrow • mouthed
Shanghai jar (t. telur buaya). Wide-mouthed
tubs are: tong, tahang (wooden); pedena
(earthenware); bajau (basin - like); t. gum-
bang, t. tapak gajah (rounded). See also
tajau.
The t. is too heavy to move when full of
water. Empty it can be moved by means of
two ring-like handles or «ears» (t6linga t),
prov. for «ears that hear not», see also
rawah. Ikan tudong t.: see tudong.

used of the cries of elephants and horses in

harimau bcrtempok ta’-makan orang (a
tiger that growls at you is never a man-

also pekis, pengkis (defiant or insulting

tengkok, Menengkok: to notch a tree for felling.
[When felling a tree a notch is first cut


towards the heart of the tree. A second
notch is then cut on the opposite side at a
higher elevation; and the felling proceeds
from the second notch towards the first. The
weight of the tree impels it to fall on the
side where the lower notch is; the men who
fell it work in safety on the other side.]
Rfngkolok. Head - wrapper; kerchief; headcloth.
[The Java kolok is a tall stiff cap of the
shape of a truncated cone, = (Mai.) kopiah,
but taller. The Borneo tikulu is a long
wrapper (not a square kerchief) bound round
the head as the Dyak head - dress. The
Minangkabau tingkulnk is worn by women;
it is of the nature of a wrapper and provides
the long pendent ends that are seen hanging
behind the large composite Payakombo
headdress worn on gala occasions. In Malaya
tengkolok, tanjak, destar, bulang hulu,
sapu-tangan and setangan are all used to
describe the square kerchief commonly worn
as a head - dress for men, = (Min.) detar,
(Java) ikat. The use of the word tengkolok
is most frequent in Perak, where the name
t. bbrsering is applied to the artificial head-
dress worn Ity a bridegroom when sitting
in state (bfirsanding).]
tßngkorak. Skull; cranium: = (Min.) tangkurak;

coconut - shell used as a primitive scoop or
water - vessel, = (Mai.) tßmpurong. T.
manusia: human skull. Ringgit t : name

med in m; W. T. lang; trees, Hyd no-
carpus castanea, Taraktogenos sp.
tßngku, Prince ; princess. T. pnan; queen. A title
or form of address that does not figure in
the Malay Annals, Malacca and Johor princes
being there styled raja as is the case in
Perak to this day. It came into prominence
about 1700 A.D. when it was taken by
princes of the new Johor dynasty (previously
non-royal and styled tun), possibly to avoid
offending the daulat of their predecessors. In
any case the assumption ot this title by
princes of the premier Sultanate gave it
great prestige in S. Malaya and even further
afield; members (male and female) of the
family of the Yamtuan Besar were styled
tengku; those of the family of the Yamtuan
Muda of Riau were called raja and bngku.
The title is now borne by princes of Kedah,
Trengganu and Negri Sembilan, as well as
hy those of the more modern Johore and
Pahang Sultanates. In Perak, however, raja
has remained the higher title, and rajahs
are addressed as 6ngku; tbngku is the
address for a non-royal Chief of the highest
rank (tbmenggong, orang kaya b£sar,
montori) and tor a non-royal principal wife
of a Sultan (tfingkn puan), a royal wife
being raja perempuan or engku pnan.
T. nxahkota: (Joh.) Crown Prince. T.
sulong: eldest son of a Prince. T. besar:
«principal prince*; crown - prince; title of
the ruler of Tampin.
[The etymology of the title is uncertain;
there are difficulties in accepting tun-ku or
tuan -ku as the original form. Tengku is
a humble distinction in Acheen; and the
early Minangkabau princes (such as Raja
Melewar, Raja Kechil and Raja Adi!) were
raja I.

tepak. Sireh - box of the Palembang type; lit.
Angg. 34, Mai. Annals 88. T. Pblombang:
id. Pbmbawa 1; the bearer of the tepak in

carrying the royal sireh - boxes (tepak and

something like a biscuit-tin, but its base is
larger than its top, the sides sloping
outwards. Inside it has a tray to carry the
little caskets (chbmbul, pbbuah, pbkapnr),
the leaf being carried in the box under the
tray.

tSpok. I. (Onom.) Light blow' with flat of hand;

tCpong. Flour; meal; = (Min.) tapong, (Kel.) dbbn;
also gen. for cakes made from flour. Tepong
is usually rice-flour (specifically known as t.
bbras); w heat - flour is t. gandoni; other

(from jawi rice), t. pulut (from glutinous

t. tawar (ordinary rice - flour watered and
mixed with leaves of the sbtawar ■ plant,
then smeared on any person or thing for the
purpose of driving away ill-luck). Gatnbar
t.: a human figure of rice - meal used in
sympathetic magic; Mai. Magic 452. Sagu
t.: tapioca - flour.
Asa cake - name t. may be used very
loosely, e.g., in Kelantan (where «flour» is
dobu) any <cake» is tepong; or it may be
confined to unleavened cakes made of meal,
leavened cakes being tapai. Varieties are:
t. bokor (or t. talam), t. bunga, t. bungkus,
t. gomak, t. manis, t. pblita, t. pbrada, t.
sbrunai, t. simpan, t. tbmelong t. torak;
but many tepong - cakes have fancy - names
of their own.

tawar.

Kshatria and Vaisya. The Sudras, the fourth
division of the population, were non - Aryan
and therefore outside the castes.

tErjali. [Ar. taj alii] Manifestation: revelation.

tSrnang. (Pk., Ked.) Water-jug for table use;
(Min.) charcnang, tarenang. A squat vessel
with a flat-rimmed mouth and bulging sides
of the type known also as buyong and in
some places by the looser term gblok. In
good houses the ternang may be of silver,
resting on a silver platter (bokor); while its
flat-rimmed mouth may support a silver
saucer (cheper) on w'hich is placed an
inverted drinking cup (ba)il). The whole is
covered ceremoniously with an embroidered
cloth (saputangan ternang). In poorer
houses it is of earthenware resting on an
earthenware platter (alas t.). Ayer dalam t.:
«water in a table-jug»; i.e. at rest, settled
down; Prov.

tJrompa, ttfrompah, or Igrompak. Indonesian
sandal; patten. Also (Batav.) telumpah;
(Min.) tarumpa. Specihcally a sandal of
untanned leather, roughly made and worn
by the peasantry in Sumatra and Java; did.
Veth ii 1. But the word is used loosely to
cover wooden pattens or clogs (Mai. t, kayu,
Jav. gamparan; did. Mayer ii 471) whicli
have a knob (kepala t.) to be held between
the big toe and its neighbour. The true t.
is held on the foot by a leather baud across
the instep and a second band passing
between the two first toes. In design it
resembles the cherpu (Jav. cheripu), did.
Mayer ii 471; but the cherpu is of finer
finish and of tanned leather. Of. also chapal,
chenela, kasut, sepatu.

tewas. I. Being worsted. Cf. alah (being
conquered or subjected); tewas refers to

reka - itu dan lari: (they got the worst of
it and so fled), Gul Bak. 94. Also of a
weapon missing its mark, e.g. anak panah-
nya t. (the arrow missed), Ind. Jaya.

teyan, teyen. [Baba, from Ch.; Batav.] Subscribing
to a common fund; clubbing together. Also
bcrlanggam; (N.S.) bfirantam; (Pen.) ber-
charum.
tezi. [Pers. and Hind.; = swift] Kuda tezi:
steed of swiftness; racehorse; thoroughbred
(of romance); Hg. Tuah 120, 262. Also
techi and teji.
tha. Name of an Arabic letter represented
in sound by our th in «t.hin, thought*,
but alien to Malay phonology. It is met
with in foreign words only and is pronounced
by the uneducated as S, e.g. hari sclasa for
hari thalatha. It has the value 500 in the
abjad.
thabit. Ar. Fixed; constant. The fem. form tha-
bitah is used of a «fixed» star, in contr. to
a «wandering» star or planet (bintang bor-
idar, bintang sayarat).
thalatha. See sclasa (Tuesday).
thalji or thalju. Ar. Snow.
thamrat. Ar. Blossom. Ya th. al - fuad: «0
Blossom of my Heart*, a heading to a
letter to a beloved daughter or young wife.
thani. Ar. Second; cf. Iskandar thani: Alexander
If; a name taken by Mahkota Alain’s
successor as Sultan of Acheen.
thari. See then (wet soil).
thaur. Ar. The sign Taurus (in the Zodiac);
Bost. Sal. i 49. For purposes of divination
it is associated with the earth, the ox, the
rhinoceros, and the plant lablab (pigeon -
peal. It is the «star» of Noah.
thawab. Ar. Recompense; requital; return.
thawabit. See thuabit (fixed stars).
thgri. Ar. Moist land; the soil after rain (but
not land naturally swampy); cf. theri itu
tanah yang basah bfiluin jadi lumpin’
(th6ri is wet land that has not yet become
sodden or trodden into mire), Bost. Sal. ii
55.
thuabit. Ar. The fixed stars; Best. Sal. i 49. In
contr. to the planets. Falak al-th: region
of fixed stars, the Ar.: al-thawabit.
thuluttl. Ar. Third; third part or portion. A term
used in dividing up intestate estates.
thunima. Ar. Afterwards; moreover; then. A word
used at the beginning of a paragraph or
sentence.
tliuraya. [Ar. al-thuraiya] Pleiades; third
Mansion of the Moon; Bost. Sal. i 49. Also
bintang seraya.
tia. Ch. Front hall (of Chinese house).
Pronounced nasally. Also tiah.
tiada. Is not. A literary form of ta’ada. Coll.:
taada or tada. Cf. tidak; (Batav.) tfirada;
(Min. coll.) indak. For stronger negation
see bukan.
tiaga, tiagan. (Min.) Trade; Tn. See beniaga.
tiah. I. Ar, Wilderness; B, See till.
11. See lia (hall).
tiak. (Min.) Crippled; Tn. Cf. topok, tonipang,
tint.
tian. I. (Min.) Uterus. Dalam tian: pregnant.
11. (Trengg.) Footbridge; = titian, Mu,
tiang. I. Mast; pillar; post. «Mast», in the names
of masts of European ships, is del, q.v.; but
Malays speak of a full - rigged ship (with
three masts) as kapal tiga tiang; of a
barque as kapal ten gall tiga t.; of a mast
with topmast housed as t. guntong; while
mabok empai t. (four-masted intoxication) is
to be gloriously drunk. In native p rah ns
t. agong is the mainmast and t. topang the
foremast. The vertical posts or pillars in
house-building are all tiang, e.g.: t seri or
t. ibu runiali (main pillars); t. sorambi (outer
or verandah pillars); t. gantong (posts
projecting downwards but not reaching the
ground); etc. These last are only allowed on
loyal palaces; Mai. Magic 33.
Other expressions are: t. bajak (shank of
plough); t. balai ppillars of the Court*; the
major N.S. Chiefs); t. bendora (flagstaff; t.
chandi (memorial pillar); t. daka (props for
a coffin-plank); t. goyang (post for securing
a paddle-rudder); t. kok (uprights of a Malay
loom); t. khemah (tent- pole); t. kinchir


(post in which the axle of a spinning-wheel
is embedded); t. konipas (tripod - stand for
theodolite); t. pagar (paling); t. pendarat
(mooring post); t. pesaka (extreme outer post
of a kelong fishtrap); t. sayung (shears for
derrick); t. sudut (corner-pillais of building);
t. tanam (housepillars imbedded in earth, in
contr. to t. bbralas or those imbedded in
brick-work); t. ganja iras (polemast); pu-
chok t. (acorn on mast); sulur t. (topmast);
tbngah t. (halfwitted); tumit t. (heel of mast);
tutup t. (wall - plate); layar tirapa t. (the
sail knocking down the mast), = betrayal by
those we trusted, Prov.
11. Pa’ - tiang: name of a game played
with marbles.
tiap, I. Sa - tiap, tiap - (iap, or tiap - miap;

11. Ch. «Dose» of medicine, i.e. drugs
measured out, compounded and wrapped up
together for taking in one dose.
tiaram. Pbniaram: cooling compress. Better pen-
jaram, see jaram.

11. See tit.
tib. Ar. Medical or magical prescription or

tiba. I. To arrive suddenly; to put in (to a

11. Tiba layar: (in a house - wall) the
projection of the upper part beyond the

tidak. No; not. Also (coll.) dak; (Min.) indak;
(Batav.) kaga. Tidakkan or inenidakkan;
to deny (the existence of anything); Kal.

tideh. Mbnideh: (Ked.) to effervesce; = mbndi-

tidur. To sleep (of commoners). The sleep of
princes is beradu, q.v. Tidurkan: to put
to sleep. Sa-tiduran: sleeping together; Sh.
Kub. T. lelap, t. lenyap, t. nybnyak, t. sb-
nyap: sound sleep; deep sleep. T. mem-
bongkok: to sleep huddled up. T. menyiding:
to sleep on one’s side. T. tbrbongkang: to
sleep stretched at full length. T. terkedah:
to sleep on one’s back with knees apart.
Lapek t.: sleeping - mat. Tempat t., tempat
tiduran, (Java) kamar t.: bedroom; sleeping
place. Übat pbnidur: sleeping-draught; Ht.
Al. 44. Malaikat yang mbmbgang t.: the
Angel of Sleep. Si-tidur di-makau si-jaga;
the sleeper is the prey of the wideawake;
Prov.
Bubu t.: long horizontal basket-trap for


fish. Burong ta’-t.: nightjar; = tfiptibau,
chapchibar. Onom., from its note.
Malays explain sleep as the temporary
departure of the bird - like semangat or
spirit of life. See sSmangat; and cf. Mai.
Pant. 328, 329.
tiga. I. Three. Bertiga: in a party of three; with
two others. Kbtiga; all three. Hari t.:
(Baba) Wednesday. Yang ketiga: the third;
third. Sa - pertigaan: a third part. Pada
mSniga hari-nya; on the third day (after
a death), cf. kenduri meniga harl (the
funeral feast held on that day).
T. pffrsegi; triangular. Akar t. chabang:
a wild pumpkin, Trichosanthes cele-
liica. Bintang t. bbradek; Orion as a group
of three stars. Kayu t. sa-kamhu: a sort of
three-card-trick played with three sticks one
of which is shorter or longer than the other
two; they are held in the closed fist and the
victim has to guess which is the shortest or
longest. Main t. lai: a card - game played
with European cards and better - known as
pakan, q.v. Rumput t. sagi: grass, Cype-
rus com press ns, W.

11. Jav. Snapping in two; making two
pieces ot one: B. Also tikbl.
tikalah. A (Sum.) variant of tbngkalak, q.v.
tikam. I. Wounding by puncture (in contr. to
wounding by cuts); to stab; to spear; (less
correctly) to prick (of a thorn). Esp. of
wounds with a pointed weapon; cf. chuchok.
Menikam: to be using a pointed weapon.
Penikam: a pointed weapon; Man. Pari 13.
T. kodok: angular rent; = kobak k6tam. T.
kundai: bridal fringe of short hair round
forehead. T. menikam: to fight with stabbing
weapons; Cr. Gr. 67, also bbrtikam -
tikaman, Sg. Samh. T, tandang: see tan-
dang. T. ta’ - bertanya: see tanya. T. ta’ -
berbalas; (fig.) to take only one helping at
a meal; Hn. Main t. sMalang: «bull-baiting»,
the part of the bull being taken by a boy.
Meronta h&ndak bertikam: struggling to
get free to stab; Hg. Tuah 149. Di -t.
tiada lut: stabbing hut failing to wound; cf.
Mai. Dewa 113. T. laksamana itu t. nibni-
bunoh, karna laksamana menikam tiada
pernah dua kali: a stab by the laksamana
was always mortal; the laksamana never
struck a second blow; Hg. Tuah 374.
11. Staking or playing (in a lottery or
game of chance). In pitch-and-toss it means
laying a coin face - upwards to indicate the
side staked on. T. po: to stake in the game
ot po. T. kaki hong: to have a ticket in a
wahweh lottery. T. belah bakul: to stake
on the section of the table nearest the
croupier.
11. Tikam surat: (Kel.) to write a letter.
tikar. Mat. Specifically a mat of fine material;
rough floor-mats are usually kblasak, (Ked.)
gelasak, (Java) kolasa. Of sleeping-mats (t.,
t. tidur); mats for sitting on (t. sila, t. lapek
dudok, t. lapek punggong); and prayer-mats
(t. sajadah, t. sembahyang). Varieties; t.
bangkar (roughly made of coarse material);
t. bbrlangkat (of several thicknesses); t.
kasah (of split rattan); t. ladang (of coarse
matwork); t. mbngkuang (of coarse
pand a n u s-work); t. puchok (of the finest
panda n u s - leaf). Associated mainly with
sleeping: t. bautal (bedding, see also
bantal); bSrtikarkan api (to sleep on fire, —


of the souls in Hell), Kal, Dam. 77; bbr-
tikarkan bumi. (to sleep on bare earth, —of
the destitute), Ht. Sh.; gnnti t. (to
sleeping-mats*, i.e. to replace a deceased wife
by her sistei). Anggal t.: hanging shelf
for mats. Anyam t.; matwork in contr. to
wickerwork (anyam sasak). Bbnfang t.: to
spread a mat. The num. coeff. of tikar is lai
or hblai or (Si Jamin 7) lembar.
T. burok: «worn-out mat*; name given
(Pk.) to the pill-millipede; see tenggulong.
tikas. Sea-weed and driftwood showing high -
water mark on a beach.
tike or tikeh. Ch.? Pipeful (of opium); chandu -
pellet; Dar. Chandu 16.
tik&l. See tikal (breaking in two).
tikiding, (Brun.) A long knapsack - basket. Cf.
ketiding.
tikil. (Ba tav.) Buffalo-skin boiled soft and cut
into small pieces to be edible. Cf kbropok.
Also kekel.
tikok. A children’s game like knuckle-bones; Tn.
Van Hasselt gives it as guessing the number
of coins in a closed hand; cf. tekok 111.
tikong. Jav. Bend (in road or river); B.
tikulu. See tengkolok (headcloth).
tikus. I. Rat; mouse; gen. for Muridae and
Sorecidae, and specific for the common
black rat, Mus rattus. The mouse (M.
muscu 1 u s) is t rumah; the Norway rat
(M. decumanus) is t. mondok, t. mundut;
field mice are collectively t. tanah; musk -
shrews (Sorecidae) are genetically t. bu-
sok, t. turi, t. kbsturi, t. pbnchuri, (Pat.)
I. bbmban, (Java) chbnchorot, cherurut.
' Other animals described sometimes as tikus
are: (i) the bandicoot-rat, Nesociasp., =
t. buloh or t. besar; but better dbkan; (ii)
the gymnura, = t. ambang bulan, (Jelebu)
kutang, or ji bulan; (iii) Hylomys
suilla = t. biji nangka; (iv) the marmot,
Cavia spp., known through books as t. gu-
nong, Sul. Ment. 17; (v) the rabbit (t. Bb-
landa; Sul. Ment. 27, but better kuching
Bblanda); (vi) the imported guinea - pig (t.
Bblanda).

11. A disease in very young children;

tilar. (Jav.) To die; = (Mal.) mbninggal, hilang.

tilawat. Ar. The chanting of the Koran.
tilek. Looking hard and fixedly at anything.
Usually in the sense of casting a spell or of
second right, = (Kel.) lek. For the latter cf.:
menilek ketika (to predict by the use of
tables of lucky and unlucky times). Jay.
Lengg.; t. abjad (see abjad); menilek nu-
jum (to take a horoscope), Jay. Lengg.;
(Sp.) tukang t. (fortune-teller); ilmu t.-me-
nilek (vaticination), = ilmu tSnong, Kep.
Mai. 6. In the sense of «casting a spell* cf.;
jahat t.-nya (be has the evil eye), DI.;
mangkat di-t. Raja S. (slain by a look from
Raja. S.), Mai. Dewa 141; and the
interesting passage (Mai. Annals 56) about
Tun Jana Khatib who was looking at a palm
when it split in two (di-t. oleh Tun Jana
Khatib belah dua potion pinang itu), a
coincidence that led to his being put to
death for black magic. A similar incident is
related of the Almighty, Di-tilek kapada -
nya dengan t. yang hebat, makahanchur-
lah manikam itu (He looked upon the gem
with the Eye of His Terrors and the
gem melted into water), Bost. Sal. i 32.
But tilek may be used also of a lover gazing
at his beloved, e.g. tilek-ku tidak kapada
yang lain (I have eyes for none but thee),
Bur. Nuri 27; or of a man thinking hard
(Min. tilek jo hati, Must. Adat 6). Cf.
also the pantun,
Khairudin nama - nya raja,
Tabal di-Telok Indftragiri;
Sedap manis di-pandang durja,
Tempat menilek sa-hari-harii
Our Ruler’s name is Khairudeen;
He reigns at Indragiri Bay;
His kindly look and gracious mien
Hold us entranced from day to day.
tilisim, [Ar. tilism, from Gk.] Talisman;
enchantment. The Copts are asserted (Host.
Sal. i 80) to be expert in these witcheries.
tilu. A winged insect, sp. unid.
tim. Ch. Cooking by stewing in a double -
saucepan (pbtiman) or bain-marie. Also
lengat. Nasi t.: rice so steamed.
Timall, A proper name; short for Fatimah, q. v.
tim ah. Tin. Also a generic term covering; zinc or
spelter (t. sari); lead (t. hitam); and tinned
iron (t. puteh). In some localities t. = tin
coin pitis t., the coin being worth about a
tenth of a copper cent. Bijeh t.: alluvial tin.
Chelur t.: ordeal by dipping the hand in
molten tin. Memasak t,, or menuang t.: to
smelt. Jongkong t.: slab of smelted tin.
Chap t.: metallic type. Lombong t.: open -
cast tin mine.
Timah - timah: a small tree, Ilex cym o-
sa. T. -t. betina: Micromelon pu-
bescens; W. T.-t. bulan, or t. -1. gading:

climber, Strepto c a u! o n wallichii.

savala. Also (Sp.) ikan montimah, (Pen.)
ikan puchok, (Sel.) ikan selayur.
timang, 1. Balancing: cf. timbang. T. is used of
a warrior balancing a spear before hurling
it or balancing a club before striking with it
(Panj. Sg.): but its commonest use is in the
kindlier sense of rocking a child in the arms
or in a cradle, —whence it is associated with
endearments and pet names. Ratap dan t :
lamenting over a child and lulling it to sleep;
Sri Ben. 21, Sh. Bid. 27. Di -1. s6rta di-
dukong: rocking it tenderly and taking it
away; Ik. Trub. 3. Anak -ku dan bunk
hati-ku timang - timangan - ku: my child,
core of my heart, nurseling of mine; Ind.
Nata. Anakanda baginda pun di - namai
oleh baginda Patera Java Pati timang -
timangan Putera Jaya Indera: the king
gave his son the name Putra Jaya Pati but
he was known more tenderly as Putra Jaya
India; Jay. Pati.
11, (Min.) A shellfish or snail, sp. unid.

tirnbakau See tembakau (tobacco).
timbal. Bertimbalnn: balancing: in equipoise.
BSrtimbal rengka: balancing one another
on the packsaddle, —of two men riding an
elephant, one on each side (Sb. Kub.); less
correctly bSrtimbang rengka (Raj. Muda
85). Also of persons corresponding in rank,
age or position with one another, e.g.: of an
officer having the same precedence as the
temfinggong (bSrtimbalan dengan temeng-
gong), Hg. Tuah 47; and of a husband not
being his wife’s equal (suami yang tiada
bbrtimbalan dengan dia), Kal. Dam. 280.
It is applied even to cheers and countercheers
being of equal loudness (Panj. Sg.) and to
fanning being done fairly (lit. Bugis 40).
Timbalan: (Trengg.) «supporter», at an
investiture; «assessor*, at a trial; Mu. Sfiligi
tajam bfirtimbal: dart sharpened at both
ends; = double - edged; Prov.
timbang. I. Weighing out. Timbangkan: to
measure the weight of anything. Menimbang:
to be engaged in weighing; to weigh (Gul
Bak. 105); to balance properly when walking
i.e. to walk evenly and gracefully (Ht. Sh.).
T. chukai: to pay customs - dues, i.e. by
weighing out a certain percentage in kind.
T. hangat: (o give good measure; also t.
panas. T. 16mah: to give short weight. T.
rasa: earning gratitude. Tirabangan badan:
«measure of myself*, «all that I have*, —as
a term of endearment (Ht. Koris); also
timbangan nyawa and penimbang nyawa
(Bail. Mejn. 20). Batu timbangan; weights
used with a balance. Ikan t, kati: a fish,
sp. unid.

face*, i. e. rusning to the point where a
weapon penetrates the skin. Mercury is
rubbed into the body through the pores in
the hope of obtaining this result.

timbun. Heap; heaping up;=(Ked.) tanibun. Tim-

timpa. Dropping down upon. Menimpa: to strike
by falling on. T. rasa or t, perasan: to bear
the brunt. Di -1. batu: struck down by
falling stones. Ahad bertimpa dengan isnen:
Monday on top of Sunday; Mai. Dera. 105.
Lagi jatoh di-t. tangga: «not only did he
fall, the ladder fell on him*, = misfortune on
misfortune, Prov.
Di -1. daulat: see daulat.
timpal. I. Sa-timpal; (Batav., from Bal.) making

11. B6rketimpal: all of a heap. Rumah
bSrkStimpal: houses all crowded together;
Hn.
timpang. See tempang (to limp).
timpas. Dead low water. The word implies that
the tide has run out and not that it is
merely ebbing (surut). T. p&rbani: low
tide with very little fall. T. pernama: very
low tide; neap tide.
timpoh. Bertimpoh: to sit as a Malay woman
sits (Ht. Koris), i.e. with the legs together
and bent at the knees, knees outward, feet
near the body, and usually a hand on the
ground. If the feet are drawn up very close
to the body the term used is bertimpoh
rapat (Ind. Meng., Sh. 111. 8, Ik. Trub. 10,
Ht. Angg. 55, Mai. Dewa 42). If one knee
is raised the term is bertimpoh lutut ter-
diri (Panj. Sg.). Cf. also Mai. Dewa CO
where a bird standing on one leg and stret-
ching out the other is described as tSrtimpoh,
timpok. (Batav., from Sund.) To fling (a stone)
with violence at anything; rolling down
(boulders); pelting heavily.
timpus. Disproportionately narrow. Of a boat
lacking in beam; a man with a broad chest
and narrow hips; etc.
timu. I. Timu - timu; correct (of action); the
proper thing to do. Bichara yang baik jadi
t. -1.: to take counsel together is what we
should do; Ht. Bugis 83. Kita beri surat
dahulu t.-t.: we must warn him in writing
if we wish «to play the game*; Ht. Bugis
144.
11. (Batav,, from Bal.) Arboriculture.
timun. Cucumber, Cue u mis sativus; also
Sntimun, m6ntimun, mfirtimun, bfirtimun;
(Min.) hantiniun; (Java) k6timun, bonteng.
Generic for cucumbers; also for watermelons
(in certain localities only); and for passion -
fruit. Varieties: t. Bblanda (grenadilla); t.
betek (Ked., squash melon); t. China (Chinese
cucumbers); t. d6ndang (Tri chosanthes
wa 11 ich i a n a), = p6d6ndang and
dang gagak; t. deudang lonjong (Pk.)
Trichosanthes celebica); t. Eropah
(European cucumbers); t. padang (passion -
flower, Passiflora edu 1 i s); t. paya
(Adenia singaporean a); t. tftinbikai
(Pat. watermelon); and (unid.) t. batang, t.
kokora, t. 16pang, t. ringan. T. hutan:
Passiflora quadrangular! s? W. T.
tikus: Gymnopetalum cochinchi-
nense or Melothria marginal a; W.
Of these the scarlet t. d6ndang is a simile
for eyes of an angry red and for things that
are fair outwardly and bitter inside. Achar
t; cucumber - pickle.
Cucumber-pips (biji t.) give their name to
the lozenge as a motif in art and to lozenge-
shaped or diamond - shaped markings, e.g.
retak biji t. (lines in palmistry giving this
pattern). Cucumber - pips are used by Malays
in the treatment of tapeworm. The cucumber
itself is used in salads, in curry as a condi-
ment, and in the Malay pharmacopoeia as a
remedy for sprue.

ra t. laut. Angin hulu t.; wind from due

tingkat, Raised floor; staging; storey. Also (Sp.)

pavilions or ceremonial bath - houses built in


platforms (tingkat), the number of the steps

liri. «Step»— in expressions like «stepfather»;
= (Java) kualon. Anak t.: stepchild. Bapa’
t. or pa’ t.: stepfather. Ma’t.: stepmother.
can be used in an offensive
sense (cf. Ht. Ansg. 70) as suggesting illicit
relations with a man’s mother. In Malaya,
where divorce is easy, references to step-
children are common; cf. sbgan sahaya bbr-
anak t., pukul sadikit mak-nya marah (I
don’t want a stepchild,—to strike him means
an angry mother); Mai. Pant. 1087.

bill). Nyamok t.: name for the Culex

titall. I, A ruling prince’s word (which has the
force of a command); royal utterance. Applied
to anything that a Sultan says and not

utterances of a raja bSrgelar, and in compli-

Adat 8. Bertitah: to speak (of a prince).
Mbmberi t.: to give instructions; also (Gul
Bak. 48) bSrtitah mbnyuroh. T. lain,
sSmbah b6rlaku: *the Sultan hath spoken,
your suit is approved*,—the official formula
when an application to the Sultan is granted.

patek apa bichara: I shall obey my love’s

Chumb. 9.

titek. I. Drop; liquid particle; dot or spot left

Menitok: to fall in drops. Titok is used

Prov. Cf. also the pantun (translation after
R. 0. Winstedt),
Darah-nya titek di-Singapura,
Badan-nya terhantar di - Langkawi:
[A rolling stone, afar he wandered,
Was slain for the offence he gave,]
In Singapore his blood was squandered,
Remote Langkawi holds his grave.

to’. I. A colloquial variant of dato’, q.v. Leas
formal than dato’ it should only be used to
a dato’ when acknowledging what he says,=
«yes», or «Sir». But for brevity’s sake it is
used almost invariably when speaking of a
dato’ to others, e.g. to’ puan (tor dato’ pe-
reinpuan), to’ muda (for dato’ muda), to’
nara (tor dato’ SSri Nara di-raja), to’sa-
dika (for dato’ S6ri Adika Raja), to’ sagor
(dato’ S6ri Akar diraja), etc. Also to (or
of) a grandfather (to’ \va, to’ nek; Pk. to’
aid; Ked. to’ wan; N.S. to’ dang of a
raja); and as a description of people of a
certain age and position, e g.; to’ nioh (Ked.,
the bomor or wizard); to’ git (mosque -
caretaker); to’ pfinghulu (the headman); to’
bidan (the midwife); to’ inang (a duenna);
cf. also orang tua to’ (the sort of old man
we call to’).

tongkab. Lengthening at the top; superimposing.

tongkang, I. Large shallow-draft barge - like sea-
going cargo-boat. Not used of river - boats.
The term is applied:
(i) to beamy boats used in the construction
of large marine fish-traps (t. bolat);
(ii) to harbour-lighters (with round-bladed
oars and dipping lugs);
(iii) to ketch - rigged beamy transom -
sterued coasting - barges of some 50 to 100
tons burden.

topeng. I. Mask; masked mummer. Usually (Mai.)

ran; illd. Mai. Magic BOS, 513]; and even of

special class of masked dancers and dances
(topeng) referred to often in literature (Sg.,

43); ct. mfmopeng or main t. (to dance in
this way), Ht. Bugis 80, 118. In these
dances the dancer may either play seriously
the part of some hero of romance, often
taking one part after another by simply
changing the mask; or he may parody and
ridicule the old plays so as to amuse his
audience.

topi. Hind. Hat. Originally (in India) any
specially made hat or cap, in contr. to a
mere kerchief or roll of cloth; cf. the
difference between tailored and untailored
garments. This old generic meaning is met
with occasionally in expressions like topi
torbua (tarboosh); t. kMayap (skull - cap).
More usually topi=hat (in contr. to cap): cf.
orang bertopi (hat-wearers, Europeans). Of
late years applied specifically by Europeans
to sun-hats or «solah topees*.

tua. I. Age; matured; old; senior; deep (of
colouring); free from alloy (of metals), in
terms of relationship like pa’ tua it signifies
that the person so described has a father’s
position (i.e. he is an uncle), and more so in
point of age: in other words he is a father’s
elder brother (pa’t., pa’ ua, pa’ wa). Ma’ t.:
eldest maternal aunt.
K6tua: elder or headman, e.g. kfitua
kanipong (village elder). P6ng6tua: senior;

leaders of a prayer or chorus, of the seniors
in a body of princes (Ht. Bangs 21), of
spokesmen, chairmen, etc. Raja yang di-

take the newness oft anything#; Hn.
Mas t.: gold that has very little alloy.

a deep black colour; Sh. Kub.

orang t. bangkut (old but feeling young);
t. chatok (dotardl; t. dato’, t. to’ (of age and
dignity): t. ganyut (trying to look young);
t. kutok (old scoundrel'); t. lara (old wretch);
t. lontok, t. renta (worn out); t. nyanyok
(doting); t. suntok (got up, made up). Bantal

of a dam. Bfdukar t.: land quite overgrown
with secondary jungle. Tongkat t.: see tuah.

tuah. Luck. Bertuah: luck - bringing, as a
mascot or talisman. Mengadu t.: to take a
chance, e.g. in a gamble; lit. Bugis ft. Tuah
melambong tinggi: fortune that raises a
man on high. Untong ada t. tidak: he does


well but luck does not help him, of a
person who works hard and is moderafel}'
prosperous.
T. is used also (Min.) of the divine
blessing resting on the authority of a

afuah (for saints), and andeka (for major
Chiefs).
