11. Burong kau tua: a small bulbul - like
bird,' sp. unid.; see kau.
tuai. A way of reaping rice; the reaping - knife
used,=penuai, pengfdam, (Ked., Pk.) reng-
g a in, (Kel.) tamin, (Java) ani-ani, (S. W.
Borneo) ranggaman, cf. Sund. etem).
This knife consists of a framework of wmod,
often crescentic and having a name of its
own [kolong, gbronggang, (Pat., Kel.lgeleng-
gangj, —in the outer centre of which a
small blade is fixed. The wooden framework
is held in the hand so as to hide the blade;
the stalks are drawn against the blade
between the fingers. The underlying idea is
that the rice-grains shall not see the knife
and that their vitality (seinangat) shall not
suffer through fright. Seed-grain is harvested
in this slow w'ay; sickles may be used for
rice if intended for consumption or sale. The
tuni-knife is illd. Veth xc 12, 13, 14; Raffl.
pi. viii; May. ii 452. Mfmuai; to reap with
this knife; Pert. Tebu 32. Bulan mata t.:
early crescent moon.
Tuai is the term used of the way the
rice was reaped at the time of the coming of
the first Malay king; Mai. Annals 21. L6pas
menuai (after the harvest) is the season for
marriages and festivities generally.
Tuai-lah padi antara inasak,
Esok jangan layu - layuan;
Intai - lah kanii anfara tampnk,
Esok jangan rindu - rinduan:
Gather the ripening rice today;
Let it not wither tomorrow;
Gaze on me now while gaze you may,
Let not delays bring sorrow.
tuak. I. Toddy; palm-wine. The best toddy (t.
kabong) is obtained from the sugar-palm;
ordinary toddy is coconut - palm toddy (t.
kblapa). When a coconut - palm is just old
enough to be tapped its age is defined as
talmn t. Toddy is obtained by cutting off
the palm - blossouf (mayang) and letting the
fresh sap (nira) flow into a bamboo mug
(tabong, 1 achok). The sap when collected
is allowed to ferment and produces ultimately
a liquor with about 6 per cent of alcohol.
Fresh and only slightly alcoholic it is known
os t. manis or tuak. If the percentage of
alcohol is increased aitificially it is known as
t. kftras.
In Kelantan tuak = <'palm - sap», not
«fermented palm - sap».
If. Tree, Sideroxylon littorale; W.
T. -1.: S. fe rr ug ine um; W.
tuakang, = toakang (arrogant).
tual. Stump; severed bit of wood (in carpentry):
Gem. Ht. 30. Also (Min.) standard; cf.
tunggul.
tuala. [Port, tool ha] Serviette; napkin; towel;
Ht. Panj. 4. T. ni.indi: towel. Also: kain
tekap tuboh, lain tfitap tnboh; (Pen.,Ked.)
tola.
tualang. See toalang (nesting-tree for bees).
tuam. Hot dry compress; Ht. Abd. 13. Usually
hot ashes wrapped in cloth; sometimes a hot
stone. Fig., of giving it to a person «hot
and strong#; e.g. dia - pun t. - bill (he let
fly); Hn.
tuan. Master; lord; (Mai.) a title assigned by
modern Malay custom to male Europeans
and to Syeds, Sharifahs and Hajis. In
literature and poetry = liege lord,
sovereign lady»; so used between lovers in
pan tuns, etc. Etym., the word is ancient
and very honourable; the title assumed by
the first Malay sovereign was yang-dip§r-
tuau (Mai. Annals 22); that rank and the
address (nan - kit are the highest of all to
this day in Malaya. T. putfiri is common
for princesses in literature; and the use by
Raffles and Crauford of the expression turn
Sultan (as recorded by Abdullah, cf. Ht.
Abd. 165, 185, 239) was due to Java custom
and not to ignorance of Malay; cf. tuan (of
a ruler), Ht. Panj. GB, and tuan pfirmaisnri
(of his consort), Ht. Panj. 23. Tuan Sultan
is still correct in Java; also (Sum.) t. gbdaug
yamtuan bbsar at Batipoh.


In Malaya tuan-tuan is applied as a name
for all Europeans as such: t. b6sar to the
head of an office or estate; t. k6chil to his
assistants; cf. also t. enjfinir (P. W. D.
engineer); t. hakim (Judge); t. polls (magis-
trate); t. kfibun (estate manager); t. toko
(merchant, in Java), Ht. Bugis 115. It need
not even be respectful; cf. t. pokah (European
beachcomber).
For the literary meaning cf. bfirtuankan
Maharaja Boma (to accept M.B. as one’s
king or overlord), Sg. Samb.; Si Tuah tiada
bfirtuan dua tiga (this Tuah does not serve
two or three masters, i.e. he does not owe
allegiance to more than one sovereign), Hg.
Tuah 193.
See also tuanku and yangdipihtuan.
tuang. I. Pouring out liquid. Of pouring liquor
into glasses, or molten metal into moulds; not
of emptying out or throwing away (cliurah,
buang). T. lilin: pouring wax into a mould.
B6si tuangan: cast iron. MSnuang b6dil:
to cast cannon; Bost. Sal. ii 121. Mtinuang
tiniah; to smelt tin into blocks. Mbnuang-
kan pula uiinuman: to pour out drinks once
more; Jay. Pati. Tuangan bongkal jala:
mould for casting the weights on a casting -
net. Menuangkan ayer tawar kadalam
laut (<pouring fresh water into the sea»)
implies a purpose to freshen the sea and
therefore symbolizes wasted effort; churahkan
ayer tawar kadalam laut («emptying out
fresh water into the sea*) vould carry no
such implication.
11. Tuang-tuang: a sort of bamboo-
horn used by Chinese pork-hawkers; also by
sailors for sigi ailing at sea; sometimes for
rousing a newly - born child that shows no
sign of life. It consists of a short thick
bamboo-joint closed at one end near which
is an orifice for blowing into.
tuanku. «Your Highness*; = tuan - ku. Used
(Mai.) only when addressing a Yauituan or
Yamtuan Muda nr (Pk.) a Raja Muda or
Raja BSndahara as the Sultan’s deputies
For this last use see Mus. Berj. 159 (edited
by a Perak Malay). In Acheen tuan-ku is
used of and to all scions of the former
reigning house. In Negri Sembilau (in recent
years only) to the Yamtuan. In Minangka-
bau tuanku is a title (= ruling prince) and
not a form of address.
tuantu. That gentleman; = tuan itu.
tuap. A splint of rattans; cf. bidai.
tuar. I. A freshwater fish - trap of thorns, =
ffingkalak onak. See tdngkalak. Tahan t.:
(i) to set this trap; (ii| to expose one’s lower
limbs.
11. Signal light; torch-signal.
ll[. See tuau I.
tuas. I. Levering up; using a lever for pressing
or lifting. See also tail. Term applied to
the raising of ground - nets (tangkul) by
means of a long wooden arm pivoted on a
post, so that a pull at the shore end raises
the other end and the net with it; also to
raising the ground - net (daun) in fishtraps
by wooden arms instead of winches. T. was
also the name given to certain diabolical
tortures, leverage being applied to break a
man’s limbs or to crush his body at the
perineum or, in the case of women guilty of
infidelity, to destroy the offending parts.
Levers or pivoted arms were used (tuas) for
raising weights in house-building. In Kedah
t. is also slang for Ho clear out, to abscond*.
11. (Ked.) Bamboos moored in deep water
with long trailing branches attached to them
to attract fish; —(Pah.) unjam.
tuasah. Creeping herb, Gymnopetalum cochin-
ch i n e n se; Bkl,
tuat. I. (Ked.) Mark indicating a good fishing-
ground. Cf. tuas.

tuboh Body (in the anatomical sense); body (as
seat of sensation). In contr. to badan (body,
not soul) and mayat (dead body). Of bodily
appearance, e.g., t.-nya sbderhana (he was
of average build); ot physical peculiarities,
e.g. t.-nya uiakin sa-hari makin - lah tani-
bun: (he became latter and fatter every day),
Ht. Abd. 238; of physical sensations, e. g.
panas rasa t.-ku (I feel warm); of physical
bonds, cf. sa -1. (sexual intercourse), bblan-
ju t. (gift to bride after consummation); of
some one coming in person (tuan t. datang
= come yourself); and of one’s personal
entity, cf.; kcmit t., bfikas t. (garment
actually worn), nama batang t. (one’s
personal name, in contr. to nickname or titles).
Batang t. means also the trunk of the body,
or the bod} r itself. The physical interpretation
of t. is illustrated in the lines: kaseh
say ting kila yang boleh, batang t.-nya
orang yang punya: (he owns the beauty of
her Hesh, her loving soul is mine), Mai.
Pant. 201.

tudoh. Accusation, esp. slanderous accusation;
pointing out a person guilty of some heinous I
act. Etym., «pcinting the finger of scorn*; I
associated with tuju, tunjok: cf. the Sund.
panudoh (index-finger, accuser). Not always I
of false charges; cf. tiada bersalahan t.- I
nya: the charges against him were fully j
proved; Ht. Best. But the word implies I
serious injury by accusation, e.g. di-t. akan- 1
dia kafir (he was accused of being an |
infidel), Bost. Sal. ii 91; and this is worse
when the accusation is false. Menudoh: to j
inform against; to accuse; Ht. Gh., cf. Abd. I
Mk. 145, Ht. Abd. 263, Mai. Annals 215. ]
See also tugas.

tugal. Dibble. Also (Min.) tugar; (Ked.) tukul;
(Brun.) togal. Properly a sharp-pointed stick

means the cultivation of «dry rice* (Oryza
mon tana) or planting on dry soil gene-
rally; cf. padi t. = (Brun.) dry rice, si -1.
kaoliang («the bean-dibbler») as a nickname

planted in soft soil. Asal Sngkau t. ada-lah
bfmeh: <df you punch holes you will always
find seed to put into them*; if you go about
giving digs you will always find some one
to quarrel with; Prov.
Also used to descibe the impression made
on the skin by a point pressing on it for
some time.

Tulian. God. PSrtuhankan: to accept as God; to

T. rabbana: the Lord our God. T. yang
6sa: the one God; God Who is One. T.
segala yang dza'if; the God of the humble;

nya Tulian, nabi Muhammad p6nghnln


kami: «Allah Most High is verily God; the
Prophet Mohammed is Chief of us all*;
a free translation of the Creed.
Many Malays attach importance to a
medial II and distinguish between Tuhan
(the divine Lord) and tuan (our sovereign on
earth); pftnghulu (our head in divine things)
and pftngulu (a chief in secular matters).
It may be that Tuhan is an artificial variant
of tuan as some say.

often used, See biugkis, burhan,

tujoh. Seven. Etym., associated with the index
tinker; cf. tuju, tMuujok, tudoh; Sund.
tu joh seven, pan u doh■■= forefinger. After
counting all the fingers of the hand (lima)
we come back to the thumb (six) and the
index-finger (seven); see also Tk. ii 374 on
corroboration from Molucca languages.
Bertujoh: making a seventh; with six
others. Ketnjoh: all seven. Menujoh:
seventh, with special reference to the funeral
feast held on the seventh day after a death;
Mai. Dem. 59, lit. Bugis 128. T. bftlas:
seventeen. T. lekur: twenty - seven. Yang
kfstujoh: seventh. Bintang t.: the «Seven
stars*, i.e. (i) the Pleiades, or (ii) the major
heavenly bodies (sun, moon, Mercury, Venus,
Mars, Jupiter and Saturn). Ketika t.: see
ketika.
Cf, pitn.
tujru’. Lembing tnjru’: (Bugis) a spear of a
Bugis type.
tuju. Pointing at; making straight for; aiming
at; = (Ked.) perSmbang. Also the name for
a kind of witchcraft (described below).
Tuju’l and monuju: to aim at; to make for;
to assail by sorcery. Penuju: rows of stakes
(supporting screens) for guiding fish into
large traps (belat Betavvi, bSlal kembang).
Sa-lujn: in unison; in harmony; with the
same aims. Meuuju tuding: to aim so as
to hit the side. Tiap - tiap pSrkataan itu
inenuju ia kapada tujuan-nya: every word
he used went straight to its mark.
The form of sorcery described as tuju is
one of those most feared by Malays. In
essence it means «poiuting out* your victim
to a spirit of evil or setting the spirit of evil
at. him. It is regarded as potentially deadly;
cf.; mfinuju orang sampai mati (aim spells
at a man till he dies), Ht. Abd. 283; and
adinda suclah kona (di-tuju) nyaris tiada
mati (I was struck by a spell and nearly
died), Mai. Dewa 115. In another passage
(Mai. Dewa 116) the procedure is described;
the wizard - king called up the evil spirit
known as jin panuli Ranjuna (Arjuna’s
arrow) by means of a magic formula (man-
tSra), and then directed it at his victim,
whom it struck and slew. But protective
magic could be used against this tuju, cf.


Mai. Dewa 115 and the pantun-lines biutang
di-langit kena tuju, uialahari turun minta
pSnawar (you have set a spell at the starry
host, and the sun has come down for the
cure), Mai. Pant. 91. T. pennaya: the fatal
variety of tujn; Kep. Mai. 41.
Tuju k6pala, t. lobang: games played
with nuts, coins or marbles; the first to hit
the target (a nut, marble or coin) winning
all the stakes.

tok.

tukang. Handicraftsman; = (Java) utas. A tukang
is, strictly speaking, a man trained in the
use of certain tools, e.g.: a blacksmith (t.
b6sil; a wheelwright (t. gerobak, t. kereta,
t. pSdati; Sul. Hid. 26); a tailor (t. jahit,
d6rji); a cobbler (t. kasut, t. sf'patu); a
carpenter (t. kayu); a mason (t. kota, t.
riimah); a gold-and-silver - smith (t. mas); a
coppersmith (t. tembaga); a farrier (t. t6r-
ompak kuda, Peng. Kuda 48). An artist-
craftsman is pandai. Skilled workers who
do not depend on training in the use of
tools are jnru; and the line of distinction
between juru and tukang is not alw'ays easy
to draw. A cook, for instance, may be
tukang masak, t. kukus nasi, juru masak,
jnru tanak. juru dapnr. Tukang also as
the better known of these two words has a
very loose use; e.g.; t. agong (petty officer
on ship); t. aycr (water - carrier in house); t.
chap (printer); t. chap batu (lithographer);
t. chbkek (strangler, thug), Sid. Rama 231;
t. chukur (barber); t. gelap innta, t. silap
mata (conjuror), = t. sunglap, Kep. Mai.
14; t. gigi (dental mechanic); t. jahit (tailor);
t. kaleng (N. 1., tinker); t. kidong (minstrel
who sings praises of tbe bride’s family at a
Borneo wedding); t. kundai (coiffeuse): t-
lampu (lamp - cleaner); t. loa (dealer in old
clothes), Si Jamin 66; t. main piano (piano-

Thirty craftsmen slain, they summoned
Him they call d the Crookback Craftsman,
Craftsman banished to Macassar,
Not, like most, for work imperfect,
But for perilous perfection.

tul. I. Main tul: a game like «puss *in - the
corner*. One child plays «puss» (orang tul);
and the others leave their homes or places
of safety to taunt him. He has to hue them
on till he has a chance of catching a child
before that child can get back to his «home».

tula. See tura (wandering speech).
tuiadan. Exemplar; model; copy to be followed.
Also (Ked.) tfdadan; tauladan.
tulah. I. Ar. Misfortune; calamity. In two
senses; (i) any misfortune, e.g. t. papah: the
curse of poverty (Sri Ben. 57); and (ii)
specifically a misfortune due to a curse for
presumption, esp. for marrying far above
one’s own rank. T. is apt to be confused or
associated with daulat; cf. fakut akan t. (to
be afraid to presume on an prince’s
graciousness lest a curse overtake one), Ht.
Bangs. 20, Ht. Fanj. 68. Thus the
• presumption* of the Chinese Emperor in
treating the king of Malacca as an inferior
was punished by a disease (Mai. Annals
109), a purulent ulcer only curable by
humiliation; and the «presumption» of girls
of humble rank who marry a prince is
supposed to be visited with kedal, q. v., cf.
Mai. Annals 22. But t. is used loosely of
other curses as well, e. g. of being turned
into stone; Sri Ben. 56.

# 1 o
each other’s hair; cf.
Di - manakan tuma hidup - nya pula
Jika la’ - makan di - atas kbpala:
A louse must get its daily bread
By grazing on the human head;
and Javanese are reputed to crack them
with their teeth, whence the saying: «Java-
nese are like fly-catcher birds, they live on
lice* (orang Jawa sbpbrti bfiberek makan
t.). But the term is not applied to parasitic
bitgrs; thus karna pijat mati t. (the louse
gets killed for what bugs do) is a warning
against bad company, and «to strip for fear
of lice* (takutkan tuma' di - buang kain
dari badan) is proverbial for overdoing
precautions.

Attacks ot smallpox are classified according
to the size and look of the pustules; kbtuni-
bohan jintan, k. kbtumbar and k. jagong
(mild forms); k. lakum, k, tapak kuching,
k. okur musang, k. kacha puteh, k. kacha
morah, k. kacha kilat, k. buah berembang
and k. duri nangka (severe forms). The
last-named is regarded as invariably fatal
and as working internally. Vaccination is


known as tanam kfitumbohau or tanam
chachar.

, and associated with under-

tun. I. A hereditary title, once common in
Malaya, now obsolete, It appears in the
Fourteenth Century as the personal title of
members of the royal house in Pasai (lit.
Pasai) and as the title of Pasai ministers
and nobles (Mai. Annals 54, 56). In the
Fifteenth Century it was the personal title
of members of the bfbidahara family at, Ma-
licca and of many other nobles. In the
Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuries it was
the personal title of the members of the
bendahar.t families in both Perak and Johor,
the families having a common origin. In
Perak this tun family lost the bfidahara-
ship but kept up their hereditary tun - title
with the feudal dignity of Sri Adika Ra ja
in the Eighteenth and early Nineteenth
Centuries. In Johor the tun family usurped
the Sultanate (A.D. 1700). From that time
the princes of the reigning house itself were
known as tengku ( = tun-ku, Dl.j, while
their collaterals, the families of the beudu-
hara and tumftnggong were known as tun.
Early in the Nineteenth Century the dignity
of temonggong of Johor passed by marriage
to a Chief (a Bngis?) with the title daeng;
and while the bendaharas were still referred
to as tun both they and the temenggongs
were becoming more generally known as


cite’ wan and addressed as engku. In
Pahang and Johore the title tun has now
been superseded completely by ffingku,
engku and che’ wan; in Perak it was
abandoned when the Sri Adika family
acquired the title mir by intermarriage with
Syed families. Pertunan: the tun family
collectively, esp. with ref. to their privilege
of carrying the royal insignia at the Daik
court; this is now also a thing of the past.
IF. (Min.) Yonder; cf. nun, nu, tu, nan-
tun.
tuna. I. Name of a mud-snake or eel with a
yellowish body. Described sometimes as ikan
t. and sometimes as ular t.

tunam. Slow-match for firing a gun; Gem. Ht.
45, Ht. Angg. 70. Membakar t : to light
the match (for firing the gun), Ht. Best ,
Abd. Mk. 23. A tunam was made usually

pa), was lit after the cannon was loaded
( Mk. 23), and then waved about in the
air to keep alight till needed for the gun.
Cf. mu rang.

VIII. Main tnnggnl: a guessing game.
[The players divide into two teams and
line up on different sides of the tunggul or
umpire. A boy from team A. goes up to the
umpire and whispers in his ear ihe name of
one of team B. A boy from team B. then
goes up and makes cue guess at the name.
If the guess is correct team A. has to give
team B. a ride on their backs. If not, ahoy
from team B. whispers a name to the umpire
for a boy from team A. to guess. So the
game goes onJ.

turis. Skin-deep slash; long but shallow cut. Of
the cut made before an animal is skinned
(pulling the skin off is soyak); of the wound
made in tree-bark by a good tapper (toreli
is to tap); also of a man writing his name
on sand or cutting his initials on a tree,
Mere surface scratches are chalar or garis.

of a fowl (Kit. Muj, 62) is t. paha.

Turki. Turkish; e. g. negeri Turki (Turkey);
orang T. (Turk); songkok T. (fez); shaor
p6rang T. (name of a Malay poem on the
Russo - Turkish war); pormadani buatan T.
(Turkey tug). Bunga T.; a name for the
pink. But while modern Malay associates
Turki with the Ottoman Turks the older
literature uses it of the Turcoman. Thus
the Turki are said (Bost. Sal. i 80) to live
by the Caspian Sea and their religion is given
as Magian, The meaning of the name itself
is given as «those left behind* (turki erti-
nya ketinggalan), the explanation given
being that they are the descendants of men
who found themselves on the wrong side of
the w’all that Alexander built to shut out
the tribes of Gog and Magog; Bost. Sal. i
70.

turun. I. Descent. Not used of a fall (jatoh) nor
of a drop by the mere force of gravity (terjun,;
but covering a traveller’s descent of a hill,
or his journey from the interior to the coast,
or (more figuratively) from «windward* to
«leeward» ports, or (more figuratively still)
descent, from generation to generation. The
word also covers the fall of rain (which is
not regarded as due simply to gravity): and
(he «descent» of the spirit in spirit-posses non.
Turunkan: to ctuse to descend; to lower;

flaw), menu run kan raja - raja dari - atas
kerajaan-nya (to depose kings from their
thrones). T. ayain; «when fowls come down
(to roost)»; 5.80 to 6 p.m. T. monogan; see
togan. T. temurun; continuous descent,
whether of rain (Raj. Muda 3) or of an
ancient family. T. ka - ayer: a haby’s first
introduction to the waters, - a ritual event,
see P.M.S.. «lucidents of Malay Life*, pp.
8, 4. Keturunan orang Bugis: Bugis by
descent. Bawa t.: to take down. Matahari
t.; setting sun. Tengaht : mid - afternoon.

Unid. are; (Mai.) u. abang, u. gantong,
u. u. kaseh, u. kembong, u. kSrtas,
u. ketak laut, u. kipas, u. lipan, u, rimau,
u. tanah, u. tiinah.
These decapods are the staple of various
dainties: shrimp - paste (see belachan); sun-
dried prawns (u. kering):prawn-pickle (achar
u.); prawn - preserves (kfirubok u., petis and
dendeng u., q.v.); Ifipar u. (balls of pulut-
rice and prawn); and pulut u. (pulut and
coconut mixed with prawn, red - pepper and
turmeric and served up in a leaf-wrapper).
Linked with the prawns that they prey
on are; (i) the «prawn - king® (raja u.) or
large kingfisher; (ii) the «prawn - nippers®
(sepit u.) or sin ill kingfishers, Ceyx spp.;
and (iii) the prawn birds (burong u. or per-
udang), i.e, To tan us spp.
Other «prawn» expressions are: bongkok
u. (slouching); gap - gap u. (a tickling game,
see gap); mala u. («prawn-eye», i.e. a small
aroid, Aglaonema minus); and x-ofan u.
(a useful rattan, Calamus didymopbyl-
lus).

circle round the player who has to cast, at
them. Cf. ukas.

uki. See ukek.

ukir. Graving; wood - carving; incising fine
des'gns on the surface of wood or metal.
Mengukir: to work as a carver (pandai u.).
See also (Kel.) sopok.
[U. is the term applied to fine Minangka-
bau wood-carving done with the pisau wall
in contr. to the rougher carpentry done
with adzes, saws, planes, chisels, etc. In
metal-work it is used of the finishing touches
with the graver in contr. to the hammer-work
done from the reverse side with the punch.

Nuri 41. Brush work is tulis; etching is
lukis, q.v.]

n., minyak u., or (Panj. Sg.) minyak uku-
pan (scents, perfumes); cf. also di-ukupi
dengan uknpan yang banyak harnm;
(perfumed with veiy fragrant scents), Ht.
Pr.nj. 50. Pinang u.: areca. - nut dried in
incense-smoke. Ayeru. is used also of scent
used for perfuming a lady’s garment and
then given as a charm to her lover to drink.

untong. I. Fate; destiny; common lot; one’s portion,

uielambong, mailing nioninipa; «it it is in

Tarek napas, tfirkiMiangkan untong:
Untong tidak sa-rupa orang:
Well may you sigh as you think of your
[lot;
Destiny’s ways are not those of a man.
• Lots* are classified aS follows,
(i) Unfong batu: the lot of a stone that
is bound to sink in water whatever else
happens; the lot of a man doomed to come
to grief; Ht. Angg. 30.
(ii) U. sabut: •husk-fortune*, that always
floats or comes to the top; the lot of those
who are bound to lise.
(iii) U. tagu: tsago-luck*, sago being
only liked when you can find nothing better
to eat; the lot of a man who comes out
always second best.
(iv) U. tawakal: the life of a man who
takes whatever comes while always hoping
for the best; the lot of a philosopher.

urian. I. [Ar. uryan (naked)(Gymnosophist; Isk.
Dz. Name given in the Alexander Legend to

themselves had mastered.
(This story is of unusual interest because
it is possible to compare its Malay text
written about 1030 A.D. with the original


Greek of about 1800 years eailier. In spite
of the change in time and place and in the
tongues through which the tale has passed the
story has hardly altered at all.J

111. Urus-urus: (Batav.) a purgative.
urut. I. Massage; clasping a sinew or limb
lightly in the hand and then drawing
the hand along it, pressi ig and
feeling the hollows all the time. This form
of massage is practised for various objects:
(i) medicinally (Kit. Muj. 87); (ii) to expedite
delivery or procure aboition; (iii) to give
suppleness to a man’s stiff limbs (Hg. Tuah
356); and, most commonly, (iv) for the sake
of the pleasure it gives (Ht. Koris, Ind.
Meng., Mas. Ed., Lai I. Mejn 20). The same
term is applied to the removal of grain from
a stalk by passing the stalk tightly through
the closed hand. Mengurut or mengurut -
ngurut: to massage. Janggut di-u.: a beard
drawn through the hand so as to form long
plaits; a forked or pointed beard.
Also hurut; cf. lurut.

11. (Brim.) To carry on the head; —(Mai.)

about for anything; Dl.
usul. [Ar., pi. of asl: see asal] Origins;
beginnings; early causes; innate character;
way r s; instincts; airs.
The word has several meanings:
(i) a man’s hereditary instincts as shown
in his bearing and behaviour (u. jijak, susok
jijak, u. sifat): cf. pakaian - nya sepbrti
derwis akan-tetapi usul - nya itu hauiba
lihat seperti orang bbsar - besar; his dress
is the dress of a beggar but his manners
seem to me like these of a man of the
highest rank (Gul Bak.);
(ii) usul-asal or asal u.: national origins;
traditional history to which Min. Malays
attach the highest importance; cf. also Kitab
Usul as a name for the Book of Genesis;
(iii) doctrinal theology (ilmu u.), as the
original base upon which Moslem law rests;
e.g. u. fakeh (theology and law); kitab u.
bbri menyatakan dzat Allah dan sifat
Allah dan kekayaan - nya (a treatise on
theology explaining the true nature of God
and the form in which He is revealed to
man, and the Almighty Power of God), Ht.
Abd, 36; and
(iv) mere thoroughness, i.e. going to the
very root or origin of things; cf. fiada dbng-
an u. pereksa (without thorough enquiry),
Ht. Bugis 129.
Though usul is (etym.) the plural of asal
the two have different associations. Usul
mbnunjokkanasal: betrays descent*,
i.e. hereditary traits (usul) show a man’s
ancestry (asal); Prov.

narrower parts ot the alimentary canal (u.
halus) and lower intestine (u, besar); Sul.
Ment. 7. Cf. pbrkakas peohernaan makanan
umpama - nya usus: the digestive organs
such as the intestine; Pet, Ayara 51.
Also (Batav.) usus; (Mai.) pbrut rauda.

utas. I. (Java; from Jav, and Sund.) Craftsman;

perigi (well - digger). Cf. pandai dan u.
(artists and craftsmen), Ism. Yat., Mai.
Annals 14, Ch. Jen. 98; and tukang dan
u. (skilled labour of all sorts), Hg. Tuah 14.


So also the Bostan (i 78) speaks of China
being famous for its workers in wood and
metal (orang u.); and the Isk. Dz. refers to
u. -u. as employed in ship - building and
carpentry.

wafak Ar. Exact time (of an occurrence), —with

wafat. Ar. To be no more; to pass away. A

to the deaths of non - royal Chiefs; and
sometimes to royal deaths (Sid. Rama 162,
Mai. Annals 238, Panj. Sg.). Cf. mangkat,
hilang.

wakil, Ar. Agent; attorney; deputy. Of a
solicitor with a local qualification in India;
any lawyer in Trengganu; a bridegroom’s
deputy (w. nikah) if the biidegroom himself
is too illiterate to repeat the Arabic responses
in the marriage-ceremony; an attorney with full
powers (w. mutlak): a documentary power of
attorney (surat w.). Wakil is met with
occasionally as a title of high rank: in Perak
the Raja Muda and Raja Bfindahara are
Avakil al - sultan; in Selangor the «Viceroy»,
Tengku Dzia-udin, was the Sultan’s wakil
rnutlak; and the Pulau Tnjoh were governed
by a wakil of the Sultan of Riau. In
Pontianak the District Officers are w. raja;
but the highest officials are wazir. Cf, also
W. darya: (lord of the waters,=tidal wave),
Kal. Dam. 109.
waktu. Ar. Appointed time; time,=(Min.) ukatu.
Berwaktu: at its proper time. Pada w. itu:
at that time. Pada tiap - tiap w.: at all
times. W. pasting daniar: lighting-up time.
Sbmbahyang lima w. tujoh w.: the five
daily prayers and the seven daily prayers,
i.e. the five that are obligatory (pbrlu) and
the two extra that are recommended or
«commendable* (sunat); cf. Bost. Sal. i 79,
ii 122. By them the time cf day is often
measured, e.g. w. asar (about the time of
afternoon prayer), cf. jam pukul tiga w.
asar (about 3 p.m.).
wakusa. A bird, sp. unid.; Sri Ben. 85.
wakwak, I. Gibbon; «wahwah»; onom. from
its cry; = ungka, q.v. Also the cry itself
wak - wak.

walad. Ar. Son; child of; a courtly variant of

w. al-inalik al - niukarapi: they named

Supreme; Mai. Annals 8.
walah, = wallah (Oh God! By God!).

wall, I. Ar. Guardian; governor. Of God as

wan. 1. A title of common occurrence in the
Northern States of the Peninsula; cf. tuan
and nan. It is said to imply that the holder
is descended from some one who held hiirh
rank, and is taken sometimes by the descendants
of great Perak Chiefs. In the form die’ wan
it is met with in Perak Johore and Pahang
where it ranks very high and is taken only
by direct descendants of Chiefs of the very


first rank (orang di-balai). In Kelantan a
wan ranks after princes (raja) aid men
holding the title of nek.
11. (Pk.) Mother-in-law; (N. S.) grand-
father.
111. A variant of arnan or man.
wana. (Java) Bnrong chabak wana; frogmouth,
Batrachostomus spp.
wang. I. An obsolete coin or measure of value;
(coll.) a nams for money generally.
i. As a measure of value the wang was
a third of a tali; the tali was an eighth of
a Spanish dollar. But the introduction of
new basic coins like the rupee and the rix-
dollar caused local differences in the value
of the tali; in places it was a quarter if a
rupee or guilder while in other places it was
more. The wang at first was eight Dutch
doits, afterwards (as w. baharu) it became
ten. But, whatever its value, the wang was
always a third of the corresponding tali;
whence the proverb, Sa-tali tiga w. juga
(a tali is always three wang whatever
its value in other currencies may be).
ii. For the modern meaning (money), cf.:
w. belanja (salary): w. bSrlambak - lainbak
(money in little piles on a gaming table);
W. bnta (wasted money; also a retainer paid
to a lawyer, not for his services but to prevent
his being retained by the other side); w.
hadiali (gifts in cash); w. jajah (Ilatav.,
pocket - money); w. jasa (pension or gratuity
for good service); w. kortas (paper - money);
w. panchang (N. 1., bribes to market-peons);
av. pura (Sum , Straits money, = AA r ang
Singapura); aa t . tunai, inata av. (ready
money); bnnga w. (interest); kokurangan
w. (poverty); tukang w. (shroff, purser,
cashier); liada ia nibmandang w. (he had
no regard for money), Ht. Abd. (13.

warid. I. Ar. Illumination of the heart by mystic
exercises. The ratib or persistent repetition
of some religious saying such as «God is
Great* has a double effect. It, distracts one’s
thoughts from this world of illusion, thus
creating religious ecstasy (dzauk), and it
enlightens that ecstasy with the thoughts
suggested by the idea that God is great.
This latter effect is warid.

warip. Alive; = urip.
warirang, = walirang (sulphur).
waris. I. Ar. Heir; inheritor or potential
inheritor. Used in a wider sense than the
English •heir-at-law*, waris means any
one eligible to inherit under any circumstan-
ces. Thus the term waris uegeri (Pk.)
includes all the males of the royal house as
being potential heirs of the Sultanate. So
also w. boneh, w. daerah and w. tanah are
terms applicable to the males of a feudal
house; while w. laki-laki and w. p6rem-
puan are the terms used of the families of
the bridegroom and bride at any Malay
wedding.
In N. S. where property belongs usually
to the family rather than to the individual
the «heirs* to a State, though they cannot
all share the rulership, have certain claims
collectively on the State revenues; thus
waste lands are regarded as the property of
the waris as a whole; and they received
certain fees when waste land was taken up
for cultivation. In Sungei Ujong where there
was a dual rulership we get two waris
families, the Klana’s (w. di-darat) and the
Randat’s (w. di - ayer). W. sa - kadim:
cognates generally.
See also warith.

warith. Ar. Heir-at-law', i.e. under Moslem law;

warna. Skr. Colour; hue. Warnakan; to colour;
Ht. Bugis 71. W.-nya hitam: black. Ber-
bagai bagai w. - nya: of all sorts of colours.
Hues or tints or shades of colour are

colour, e. g.: w. biji rAnbunia (rembunia-
pip - colour, i.e. mouse - colour). Others are:
av. ch6mpaka (champak - yellow); w. dSlima
(ruby-red); av. hijau ungu (sea-purple); w.
ISmbayong (carmine); w. merah jambu
(rose); w. mfirjau (coral-red); av. sakhlat
(scarlet).

urna. Cf. pancharona (multicoloured) and

11. Ar. Executor of a will; guardian of
minors under Moslem law. Ct. wasiat, wali.
wasiat Ar. Last injunction; testamentary disposi-
tion. Under Moslem Law property is
divided among the next of kin according to
definite rules that are not to be overridden
by testamentary dispositions. But since a
dying man may wish to leave money to
charities or mementoes to friends he is
allowed to dispose of parts of his property
(not exceeding one third in all) in legacies
to persons other than his heirs - at-law. A
wasiat therefore is not so much a will in
our sense of the word as an expression of
the testator’s wishes on issues such as the
disposal of his body, etc. Thus the Bostan
records (i 99) that Jacob expressed a dying
wish (di - wasiatkan) to be buried by the
side of his forefathers; and the Hang Tuah
tells us (p. 178) that one Sang Winara gave
instructions (wasiat) that if slain in battle
he was to be buried on Mount Imagiri and
dug up again after seven years. In another
passage (Ht. Angg. 100) a certain Nakhoda
Bahar asserts that a dead man had enjoined
solemnly upon him (bSrwasiat amanat) the
duty of taking the place of that dead man
as a raja and as a bridegroom. Nowadays
the written wasiat is of two sorts. One
(surat w.) is of the nature of a will but
deals only with payments to charities in lieu of
such duties as fasting, the daily prayers and
the pilgrimage to Mecca. The other is of the
nature of a homily. It is thought that more
weight will he attached to a religions lecture
if it is invested with the solemnity of a
saint’s or Prophet’s dying injunctions; and
religious treatises often purport to be such.
wasi!. Ar. Coming together. Usually of the safe
arrival ol a letter.
wasilah, Ar. Woman who «brings together* her
own hair and that of others; = wearer of a
switch. Specially cursed by Mohammed.
wasir. Ar. Haemorroids; = bawasir, qv.


wasit. Ar. Middleman; broker.
wasitah. Ar. Female go-between; procuress; Kal.
Ham. 357. Also a medium. Hum aa 7 .:
spiritualism; Perch. Mai. 10.
waslah. Ar. An Arabic symbol of elision ot the
alif, e.g. Abdu’llah for Abdu - Allah.
waslat. Ar. Union; connection.
waswas. Ar. Suggestion (in the special sense of

wedadari. (Java, from Skr.) Fairy; = bidadari.
wedam. [Tara., from Skr.; = Vedic books] The

wedana. Jav. Native officer in charge of a sub -
district in Central or Eastern Java. In
Bantam the term is in use. A
wedana or wedono is subordinate to a
regent (adipati, ngabehi or temSnggong);
but headmen of villages (kSbayan, pembakal)
are subordinate to him. The term is not in
use in the Peninsula, but a Perak penghulu
corresponds in many ways to a «wedono».

bisai. W. niulia: a name for the plant,

wijen. See wijan and bijan (sesamum).

in contr. to the reserved portions. W. peseban
and w. pfindawa: id.; Perb. Jaya, Mas. El.

The Malay prose version is the hikayat
datia Nila Kuacha, Tk.
wizurai. [Port, vicerey] Viceroy. The word is

and is there wrongly written wazir-nya;
it is also the original of the Bedurai Puteh
of the Hikayat Anggun.
WO’, wok. A form of address to young children;
a sort of pet - name often kept on even in
later years.

(negro); wayang wong (see wayang).

bang.

wudztl. Ar. Minor ritual ablution, i.e. a washing
of face, hands and feet only; = ghasal.
Required before every prayer. For a full
account of the details of the wudzn see
Herklots 49, 50. Often pronounced (coll.)
wulu.
wujud. Ar. Existence; being; = (coll.) ujud. 01
individual life; cf. ujud kapada tuan sa -

Pant. Mai. 900. But wujud is used also as

Life; life centred in God and free from all
Illusion).

ya. I. Name of a Malayo - Arabic letter
transliterated as Y (when initial) or as I
(when it is the ya of prolongation). It has

yaakut, = yakut (jacinth).
yaani, Ar. That is to say; to wit; i. e. Also
yalni; (Min.) nan - tun.
yad. Ar. Hand; forepaw.
Yafit. Ar. Japhet; Host. Sal. i 93, 95; ii 3.
Japhet’s descendants are grouped together
as: «Turks, Franks and the tribes of Gog
and Magogs; Host. Sal. i 93.
Yah. A fem. proper name. Short for Asiah,
Sadiah, Safiah, q.v. Also Ah.
Yahudah. Ar, Judah (Dost. Sal. i 98); Judaea.
Yahudi. Ar. Jewish; Israelite; Sing. Terb. 29,
Rost. Sal. i 80, Orang Y.: Jew. Pendita
Y.: Jewish rabbi. Di-gugui kan-nya segala
manusia kadalam-nya siapa yang tiada
malm masok pada igania Y.: (into that
flaming pit) they dropped all who refused to
accept the Jewish Faith; Rost. Sal. ii 33.
yahum. [Lask.: yahom, j a horn] Angin yahum:
fair wind or following wind;—angin tuenuin-
bok kurong or angin sorong bnritan.
Yahya. Ar. John, as a proper name (not uncom-
mon among Malays). NabiY.: John the
Baptist. Injil Y.: gospel according to St.
John. An account of the life and death of
John the Baptist is given: Bost. Sal. i 197.
yai. A Java equivalent of adek (younger
brother or sister). Occurs as a form of address
in Malayo - Javanese romance for persons
younger than the speaker, e.g. by a husband
to a wife, a courtly variant being yat
ingsun = (Mai.) adinda, cf. ariningsun or
ningsun. Etym., ya’i = a'f -hi (Tk. iv 2G3);
see also nya'i (= ni-a'i) and kyal (= ki-af).
ya'fni. This is to say; to wit; i. e.; = ia-ini,
yaani; (Min.) nan-tun.
yaitil. That is to say; =ia - itu; (Min.) nan-tun.
Yajuj. Ar. Gog. Y. wa-Majuj: Gog and Magog.
According to Moslem belief the tribes of
Gog and Magog inhabit the world beyond
Mount Kaf and are destined one day to
break through their mountain - barrier and
overrun the world.
[Medieval belief in Europe regarded them
as shut off by a wall through which they
were always trying to force their way. The
reference is really to the Turcoman tribes
who are shut off from Persia by the great
mountain range that connects the Caucasus
and H indu Kush and also by a great wall
the building of which is ascribed by the
Persians to Alexander].
yak. Bfdachak yak or in£lachak yak; to be
plentiful. Of any commodity of which the
supply suddenly exceeds the demand, e.g.
fish after a big catch or fruit in a very good
season. Cf. (Min.) tayo’.
yakin. Ar. Certainly; assured confidence; =y.
didalain hati-nya (Sh. Kanch. 11) or per-
chaya ha rap dan y. (lit. Angg. 20). Of
anything that the speaker is quite certain
about; but (in the language of mystics) of the
• unerring eyes (ain al -y.) of the mystic
who has attained to spiritual wisdom, and
of the confident knowledge of absolute truth
(hak al-y.) that accompanies it. llak al - y.
is in use also as a letter - heading (kbpala
surat) to imply that the contents of the letter
are reliable.


Yakub. Ar. A proper name; Jacob; James. Nabi
Y.: the Biblical Jacob. Often pronounced
Akup, Yakup.
yakubiat, Ar. Christians who follow the Jacobite
heresy; Bost. Sal. i 81.
yakun. Ar. Kun fa yakun: (God said) «Be», and
it was; the mystic woids describing the
Creat’on; Bost. Sal i 67. The3’ are in common
use as «words of power* among sorcerers;
see kun.
Yakup. A coll, variant of Yakub (Jacob).
yakut. Ar. Jacinth; a name given to true jacinths
and also to the ruby, sapphire and chrysolite.

yamtuan. King; monarch; a popular variant of

yamyam Yamyam bondahari: title of the lady
in charge of the female attendants at the old
court of Johor and Lingga.
yang. I. A Malay relative prefix used in three
ways:
(i) as the English relative «who», «which»,
«that»; e.g, masa yang balk (a time that is
fortunate, a lucky period of time);
(ii) as a relative that brings the whole of
the following clause into relation with what
precedes, e.g. orang tua yang sudah tang-
gal gigi - nya, = (literally) «an old man who
his teeth had fallen out*, = «a man so old
that his teeth had fallen out», = a toothless
old man;
(iii) «His*, «the», as an initial prefix in
titular honorifics corresponding to European
distinctions such as «the Honourable* or
H.E.: yang mulia (to any gentleman); yang
amat mulia (to a chief or Raja); yang t6r-
amat mulia (to a Raja Muda or Bondahara);
yang malm- mulia (His Highness); yang
bSrhormat (the Hon.); yang terutama (H.E.);
yang inaha - niulia dan mahabf'sar (His
Majesty). Cf. also yangdipSrtuan.
Also (Min.) nan, nang; (Java) ing, ning.
IF. Divinity; Godhead. Usually in compounds
sangyang (major Hindu divinity), sdml ah-
yang (prayer) and yangyang, q.v. Occasion-
ally by itself’; anaky. (Pk., fairy, supernatural
being); dewa yang - Mahabisnu (the Great
God Vishnu). KAyangan: home of the Gods;
Heaven of Siva; (in modern Malaya) fairy-
land.
111. (Pah., Joh., Muntok) A feminine
titular prefix, = (Riau) enibeh; (Ked.,
Trengg.) nick. Etym. = dayang. Borne by
the eldest daughters of distinguished families.
yangdipSrtuan. King: he who is tian, i.e. lord
or master (of the State); the kingly title
that carries authority, in contr. to terms like
Sultan and Shah that are merely honorific.
Popularly yanituan. Sultan Idris Mershid-
al-aadzam Shah, yangdipertuan nSgfiri
Perak: Sultan Id ris Mersbid al-aadzam
Shah, King of Perak. Ada-pun Demang
Lobar Daun - lah yang pArtama punya
bahasa yangdipfirtuan dan patek: D.L.D.
was the first to use the terms yangdipertuan
and patek; Mai. Annals 22.
Yangdipertuan Muda: King - Coadjutor.
Usually a near relative chosen to relieve an
aged or indolent ruler of the more active
duties of kingship. Sometimes (as also in
Nepal and under the Shogunate in Japan)
the holder of the real power while the King
retained the higher dignity; cf. y. b6sar jadi
seporti perSinpuan sahaja; jika di-beri-nya
makan inaka baharu - lah niakan dan y.
mud a jadi sep6rti laki - laid dan jika
dafang satu-satu hal atau apa - apa juga
bichara mMainkan apa-apa kata y. muda;
«the Y. Bfisar is to be like a woman, when
food is given him he may eat; and the Y.
Muda is to be like her man, should a
question of any sort arise it is he who is to
decide it»; Ht, Bugis BG. This quotation
represents the Bugis idea of the relative
positions of the Malay Y. BcsarofDaik and
the Bugis Y. Muda ot Riau. In Negri
Sembilan there were at one time one Y.
B6sar and two Y. Muda each holding kingly
rank but with very limited an 1 local authority.
In Sumatra (Minaugkabau) there is a triple
system: a raja alani with a raja ndat and


a raja ibadat. In Java the Princes Mangku
NSgara at Solo and Paku Alam at Jogja
hold positions corresponding generally to
that of a Y. Muda in Malaya, the Javanese
title being pgngeran adipati aria.
Used of the Governor - General of N.I.
(y. bbsar), Pert. Tebu 10.
yangyang. I. God of Gods; Great God. e.g.
yangyang Betara Mahabisnu indera

Yazdajird. Name of the Persian King who tore

and of whom Mohammed predicted that even

Yazid. Ar. Name of the Urnmayad Caliph held
up to execration as the enemy and (indirectly)
the slayer of the Prophet’s grandson Husain.
Yib or Yip. A [ roper name; a coll, abbreviation

yogia or yogya. Seeming; proper; in the

= accordingly; in the regular course of
events; verily; of a truth; as a matter of
fact.
yojana, Skr. A measure of length of a somewhat
indefinite character. In ancient India it
represented anything from 4 to 9 miles; in
old Malay romance it figures in vague
expressions like berapa ratus ribu laksa
kSti y. (for many hundreds, thousands,
myriads and even tens of myriads of yoj ana),
Sh. Kub.; and is best known in the
expression saujana (r-sa-yojana) or saujana
niafa memandang (as tar as the eye can
see); see saujana. Also (less commonly)
wijana, sa - wijana.
yong. I. Chewe yong: «the thing that makes a
yowling noise*; the cat.
11. See ina’yong, pa’yong.
Yop. See Kulup (familiar name for boy).

subscription; Mn.
yu. I. Shark; dogfish; gen. for sharks (Car-
char i id a e), dogfish (Scylliidae), ham-
raeihead sharks (S phyr n i d a e), sawfish
(P rist i d a e), and beaked rays (Rhino-
b a ti d a e): = (Java) chuchut, Pal. kbluyu.
Of sharks the Malays recognize:
(i) the ground-shark; Carcharias spp.,
= (Sp.) jt'rong, (Ked., Pk.) yu sambaran;
and (when young) yu pandak;


(ii) the man-eating surface-shark, G a 1 e o-
cerdo rayneri, =yn tenggiri;
(iii) the harmless basking sharks
(R hinodo n t i d a e), = yu bodoh because
easily caught.
Of dogfish there are several kinds:
(i) the so - called tiger - shark,
Stegostoma tigrin u m, = yu riniau,
(Sp.) yu chichak, Pen. yu to’kok;
(ii Scy 11 iu m spp.=(Sp.) yu bblengkong,
(Pen.) yu laras, and possibly yu punai,
esp. Scyllium marmoratum; and
(iii) Chiloscyllium spp. =yu
bblangkas, yu gila and yu minyak.
Unid.: yu kSlabong.
Han.inerheads are known as (Sp.) yu
palang, (Sel.) yu bengkong, (Pen), yu
rimbas, (Pat.) yu loyang; also ju sanggul
and yu tandok.
Saw'fish are (Sp.) yu bfirui, (Pen.) yu
parang; also bfiroi, yu todak, yu gdrgaji
and yu gaji-gaji.
Beaked rays are yu kia-kia, yu kbkia,
yu chgmangi, yu kombjan, yu kemenyan;
they are proverbial types of the «double
faced* i.e. rays when looked at from in
front and sharks when looked at from
behind.
Sharks generally are types of the
voracious: Jong p§chah yu yang kfinyang
(when a ship is wrecked the sharks eat their
fill), =it is an ill wind that blows nobody
any good.
Mata yu: «shark - eyed*; = mata pasak.

cards; see chSki. Main yu: to play chicky,
= main ch6ki; (Java) main chuchut; (Pen.)
main chochot or main tan.

(Ch. an g-hoe) is half red and is known as

tsan) has red all over its surface and is yu
merah bSsar. The third (Ch. it-ban) =yu

(Ch. kasut. The sixth (Ch.
peh-hoe) = yu kuching.)

Z
za. Ar. Name of an Arabic letter translitera-
ted as Z and having the value 7 in the
ahjad. It is often pronounced as a J by
Malays igrorant of Arabic, e.g. jfibat for
zabad, jfiman for zanian, jCmorud forzamrud.
Tahun z.; the fourth year of the eight -
year cycle; see daur.
zabad. Ar. Civet; musk; see jfibat.
zabah. Ar. To slaughter (cattle); = dzabah.
zabani. Ar. Two stars in Libra constituting the
sixteenth mansion of the moon; Bost. Sal. i
49.
zabatliah. [Ar.; = pusher] The tormentors of the
damned; the angels (malah z.) who «push
back* into the fires of Hell any struggling
soul that tries to climb out; Bost. Sal. i 56,
69.
zabarjad or zabarjat. Ar, Chrysolite; green
diaphanous sem'-precious stone; Bost. Sal. i
64.
zabia. Ar. Tur-zabia: a scriptural mountain;
Bost. Sal. i 59.
zabib, Ar. Dried grapes; raisins. Anggur z.: id.:
Ht. Koris, Ism. Yat.
zabur. I. [Ar. = AI-zabur or kitab
z.: the Psalms of David. Forming (with the
taurat or Pentateuch and the injil or New
Testament) the Christian Scriptures according
to Moslem ideas.
11. [Ar.; = «sleady and strong*, of the
wind] Name of the wind that is to blow upon
the Sun and Moon on the Day of Judgment
and to fan them into flame; Bost. Sal. i 47.
zadah, [Pers.; = born of] Child of; begotten. In
compounds: shah -z. (prince); halal -z.
(legitimate); haram-z. (misbegotten, illegiti-
mate, —used as a term of abuse), Ht. Hamz.,
Pr. Ach. 15, Ch. Jen. 16. See also jadah.
zafaran. Ar. Siffron, i. e. hue .'■affirn, Crocus
sativus, not kum it; Bost. Sal. i 41, 49.
zafin. Ar. An Aiab dance (danced by two
persons). Etym. of dancing generally.
zahid. Ar. Anchorite; devotee. Loosely, any
dervish (Kal. Dam. 53); applied to John the
Baptist as a «great ascetic* (ainat z.) because
of the hardships he underwent in the
wilderness {Dost. Sal. i 107); specifically, a
man who has renounced the world because
he realizes its vanity and illusion; etym., an
♦abstainer*.
zahra. Ar. White; shining. Badi z.; (properly
India z. = Skr. biddiya) a magic pill or
bolus that was supposed to possess the power
of transporting its swallower to heaven;
Lang. Buana 38, 40.
Fatimah al-z,: «Fatimah the Fair*; the
Prophet’s daughter. Known also as Fatimah
al - zuhrah.
Zaid, Ar. A masc. proper name.
Zain. Ar. Adornment; grace; beauty. In proper
names: Muhammad Zain; Zain al-rashid;
Zain -al - abedin; etc. Shortened (coll.) to
Jenal, Zonal.
Zainab, Ar. A (fern.) proper name. Pronounced
Jenap.
Zainalabedin. Ar. A proper name: «ornament of
the devout*. Commonly shortened to Jenal
or Bidin; pronounced Zenalabedin and Je-
nalabedin.
zaitun. See zetnu (olive).
zakar. Ar. Male organ of generation; = dzakar,
q. v.
Zakaria. Ar. Zacharias; a proper name met with
among Malays. Nabi Zakaria: Zacharias,
father of John the Baptist. He is said (Bost.
Sal. i 107) to have suffered martyrdom on
a false charge of illicit relations with the
Virgin Mary.
zakat. Ar. Poor-rate. Etym., the «purifier»: cf.
(Koran ix 104) «Take thou from their
possessions alms (Ar. sadakat, see sbdAkah)
whereby thou shalt cleanse them and purify
them*. A tithe levied once a year after the
Fasting Month for distribution among
indigent servants of Allah. B£rzakut; to pay
this rate (Ungg. Bers. 16); also m6mb6ri z.


(Mar. Mah.).
Z. badan: alms given at the hari raya
besar, = pitrah, q.v.
zakiah. Ar. «Pure». In the epistolary expression
fuad al -z. (the «pure heart* or ball yang
jernch that is supposed to inspire letter-
writing).
Zakunt. Ar. Name of a tree growing in Hell, the
fruit of which supplies ford to the Damned.
zakut. Ar. Poor - rate, = zakat; Bost. Sal. i 40.
Zalikha. See Zulikha.
zamamdar. Hind. A fabric (mixed silk and cotton)
imported from Surat and made formerly into
coats (baju); Dl.
zaman. [Ar.: space of time, long or short] Age;
epoch; «time* in expressions like «since the
time of the Dutch* (daripada z. Holanda,
Ht. Abd. 22). Z. dahulu kala: the Past, —
also z. dahulu. Z. sekarang: the present.
Akhir z., akhir al-z. and akhir dan z.: to
the end of time; eternal; see akhir. Z.
tandun: the days of long ago. Kamar al-z.:
«Moon of the Age»; a Moslem proper name.
Memanjang akhir al-z.: to drag on for
ever; Ht. Bugis 153. Meninggalkan z.: to
die.
Coll.: zeman, jeman and jaman.
zamharir. Ar. Extreme cold; place of extreme
cold.
zamin. Pers. Soil; land; ground.
zamrud. [Ar. zumurrud; Pers. zumrudJEmerald;
Bost. Sal. i 54. Original derivation doubtful:
Skr. marakan; Zend asmareja; Gk.
opa^dyha.
Also (coll.) jemerud or jfimSrut.
Zamzam. [Ar.: water (i) copious and abundant or
(ii) brackish] Name of a celebrated well,
traditionally Hagar’s Well, in the mosque -
enclosure at Mecca. Its waters, perennial
but rather brackish, are regarded as holy
and give their name as an honorific tor
water in general (coll, jam jam = ayer).
zamzam. Ar. Water. See Zamzam.
Zanggi. [Ar. zanji, Pers. zan’gi] «Zanguebari»;
Ethiop; giant negro; Sh. Kub., Ind. Meng.
The Ar. zanj or zinj was used first of the
negro lands nearest Arabia, e.g. of Ptolemy’s
«Zingis» who inhabited the entrance to the
lied Sea; thence of the East African blacks
and even of negroes generally. See janggi.
zani. Ar. Adulterer; fornicator.
zaniat. Ar. Loose woman; adulteress.
Zanjabil, Zanjabila Ar. Name of certain Waters
or Springs of the Moslem Paradise.
Zaradushti. Ar. Zoroastrian.
zarah, =jarah 111 and ziarat.
zarrah. See jarah II (atom).
zat. I. dzad, dzat (name of letter).
ll.—dzat (nature).
zauj. Ar. Making a pair; counterpart; = jodo.
zauiat. Ar. Chapel; small mosque in which
congregational Friday services may not be
held. Cf. surau.
zSman. See znninn (time, en ).
Zenal. See Zain (rnasc. proper name).
zeng. Eur. (Baba) Zinc; galvanized iron. Cf.
(Mai.) timah sari (zinc) and ayan (galvanized
iron).
zetun. [Ar. zaitun] Oil-tree; olive-tree. Buah z.:
olive (Pant. Shi. 3); olive-stone. Associated
witfi the Arabs with Palestine and ultimately
with the Yunani or Greeks who aye supposed
to have introduced the olive into Palestine.
Minyak z.: olive oil.
ziadah. Ar. Addition; increment; affix.
Ziarah or ziarat. Ar. A visit (to a shrine);
pilgrimage or place of pilgrimage. Also jarah;
ct. jirat. Menziarah kuhur: to visit a grave;
Mar. Mah. (of visiting a royal grave). P6rgi
z. kapada dato’ kcrainat: to visit a miracle-
working shrine; Ht. Gh.
Zina. Ar. Illicit sexual intercourse; Baj. Sul. 2,
Hr. Abd. 200. Ada orang isteri-nya bftr-
zina wajib di-bunoh suami - nya: when a
man’s wife commits adultery her husband
has no option but to slay her; Ht. Dakht.
69.
Zindik. Ar. Unbeliever; heretic; Host. Sal. i GB.
Etyrn., a believer in the «Zend» or Median


religion; whence a Magian or «dualist», i. e.
a believer in the contending principles of
Light and Darkness; whence a disbeliever in
Mohammedanism, an infidel, Sh. Ul. 25.
But nowadays it is rather <'heretic* than
<dnfidel» (kafir).
zing, = zeng («zinc»; galvanized iron).
zir, Pers. Below. In the expression zir-bad =
di-bawah angin = «leeward», as a description
used by old Persian navigators to describe
the countries to which the S.W. Monsoon
blew them, i. e. India, Further India and
Indonesia. See angin.
zirafah, Ar. Giraffe; camelopard. Regarded as a
steed for heroes of romance or mythology;
Isk. Dz., Sh. Kub., Ht. Koris.
zirah- Pers. Baju zirah: coat of chain - mail; =
baju rantai. Also baju z. b6si; Ht. Hamz.,
Sh, Mard., Isk. Dz.
zirbad. Pers. Leeward. See zir.
zirnikh. Ar. Arsenic; = warangan.
ZU. See dzu (possessed of).
zuadah. Ar. Provisions; = (Mai.) perbfikalan, but
used esp. of cakes and sweetmeats. Also
juadah.
Zubaidah. Ar. A (feminine) proper name; commonly
shortened to Bedah. It was the name of the
wife of the Caliph Harnn al-rashid, Et3'in.
the name of an Arabian plant (Calendula
off ici na 1 i s); Dl.
zubrat. Ar. Two bright stars in Leo constituting
the eleventh lunar mansion; Bost. Sal. i 49.
zufa. Ar. Hyssop; Hyssopus officinalis.
zuhal. Ar. The planet Saturn; the «remote»
planet; placed by Moslems in the Seventh or
farthest region of the firmament; Bost. Sal.
i 48.
zuhara. Ar. Bintang zuhara: the planet Venus;
Bur. Pungg. 203. Also juara, kfijora, kfichu-
ra.
zuhra, zuhrah. Patiniah al - zuhra: «F. the
gloriously beautiful*, i. e. the Prophet’s
daughter. Better zahra.
zuhud. Ar. Ascetic; master of oneself. Defined as
ingat inonahankan did; Kep. Mai. 72. Of.
zaliid.
zulhijjati. See dzu.
Zulikha. Ar. A (feminine) proper name; the name
ascribed by tradition to Potiphar’s wife.
Commonly shortened to Leha when in use
as a Malay name. The loves of Yusuf and
Zulikha are among the great romances of
Islam,
Also Zalikha, JSlikah, Sdlehah.
zulkacdah. See dzu.
zulkarnain. See dzu.
zuriat. See dzuriat.

bangan, read («child whose very
birth was attended with trouble*);
inati kebebangan

«ectropion».

kir read kelikir.

chgmpfilek.

read kungkuina.

POSTSCRIPT.
I am indebted to Mr. I. H. Burkill for a very
large number of new botanical notes of great
lexicographical value and to Dr. J. D. Gimlette for
medical notes of the same character. A comparison
of the following article on the w'ord domain by Dr.
Gimlette with my own article on the same word
will show how much my work (alls short of the
ideal.
d6mam. Sakit domain: pyrexia or fever. D. berlat,
d. berselang - sblang: malarial fever that
intermits, i. e. has periods of cessation
itt activity. D. dingin; cold stage in
malaria. D. Eropah: (S. S.) dengue or
dandy fever. D. gigil: cold stage of malaria.
D. kelenjar: fever incident to inflammation
cl the glands (septic adenitis). D. kepialu: any
continued fever lasting more than three days;
often used for enteric fever (see kfipialu).
D. kbtar: cold stage of malaria. D. kuning:
icterus neonatorum or fever with
jaundice in newborn infants. D. kura: ague;
cf. kura - kura («tortoise»; —an enlarged
spleen is compared in shape to the back of a
tortoise). D. kura dengan kfinclting darah:
black water fever; haemoglobinuria complicating
subtertian malaria. D. kura ineuahun:
chronic malaria; continued quotidian malaria.
D. mengilam: intermittent tertian or quartan
malaria. D. nieroyan: puerperal septicaemia;
childbed fever. D. punas: hot stage in
malaria, also hyper-pyrexia (fever with high
temperatures). D. pialu: fever complicated
by jaundice. D. rabu kembang: fever
accompanying pulmonary disease. D. sa-hari-
hari: continued fever. D. yang b6rganti -
hari: intermittent fever. D. sampu tahun:
hectic or daily recurring fever with profound
sweating, chills and flushed countenance,
generally in children and associated with
tuberculosis or septic poisoning. D. sbsa-
s6sa, s§s6ma, seldsgina: hay fever; also
influenza. D. sejok; cold stage of malaria.
D. susu: milk-fever; mild puerperal septicae-
mia. D. tiada b6rtika: untimely or «unlucky»
fever. D. mat, d. longoh sbndi tulang:
rheumatic fever.
Kebah d., (Pk.) lindap: stage of defer-
vescence in fevers; crisis or turning - point;
in malaria, the sweating stage. Piantan d.:
hour at which a recrudescence of fever is
expected.
It was intended, at first, to deal with this
information in addenda; but owing to its extent
and to the fact that notes are still being received
by me from other friends as well I have thought
it better to deal with it in a separate supplement
to be published later and not to delay the issue
of this work.
My attention has been drawn also to two wants.
My book does not give words in the Arabic
character. This is true; but a good index giving
most Malay words in both characters has been
published by Dr. Winstedt in connection with his
English - Malay Dictionary and can be referred to.
My book is lightly sewn in paper covers only. This
is due to the fact that bindings are apt to perish
in the heat and damp of the tropics so that books
that sell slowly have to be bound when needed
and not long in advance.
In conclusion I wish to record my gratitude to
M. Yarvaressos, Hellenic Minister of Finance, for
his courtesy and kindness in exempting this book
from the export restrictions in force at present
in Greece.
R. J. W.
FINIS
